[[File:OkTediMine.jpg|thumb|Ok Tedi mine]] The '''Ok Tedi environmental disaster''' caused severe harm to the environment along {{convert|1000|km}} of the [[Ok Tedi River]] and the [[Fly River]] in the [[Western Province (Papua New Guinea)|Western Province of Papua New Guinea]] between about 1984 and 2013. The lives of 50,000 people have been disrupted. One of the worst [[Environmental disaster#List of environmental disasters caused by humans|environmental disasters caused by humans]], it is a consequence of the discharge of about two billion tons of untreated mining waste into the Ok Tedi from the [[Ok Tedi Mine]], an open pit mine in the [[Western Province (Papua New Guinea)|Western Province of Papua New Guinea]].
This mining pollution, caused by the collapse of the Ok Tedi [[tailings dam]] system in 1984 and consequent switch to riverine disposal (disposal of tailings directly into the river) for several decades, was the subject of [[class action]] [[litigation]], naming [[Ok Tedi Mining Limited]] and [[BHP Billiton]] and brought by local landowners. Villagers downstream from Ok Tedi in the Fly River system in the [[Middle Fly District, Western Province|Middle Fly District]] and the southern and central areas of the [[North Fly District, Western Province|North Fly District]], in particular, believe that the effect on their livelihood from this disaster far outweighs the benefits they have received from the mine's presence in their area.
==Environmental impact== [[File:Oktedi-landsat.png|alt=Ok Tedi River circa 2007|thumb|Ok Tedi River circa 2007]] In 1999, BHP reported that 90 million tons of mine waste was annually discharged into the river for more than ten years and destroyed downstream villages, agriculture and fisheries. Mine wastes were deposited along {{convert|1000|km}} of the Ok Tedi and the Fly River below its confluence with the Ok Tedi, and over an area of {{convert|100|sqkm}}. BHP's CEO, Paul Anderson, said that the [[Ok Tedi Mine]] was "not compatible with our environmental values and the company should never have become involved."<ref>{{cite news | last = Burton | first = Bob | title = BHP admits Ok Tedi mine is environmental disaster | publisher = [[Asia Times Online]] | date = 13 August 1999 | url = http://www.atimes.com/oceania/AH13Ah01.html | accessdate = 18 April 2016 }}</ref> {{Asof|2006}}, mine operators continued to discharge 80 million tons of [[tailings]], [[overburden]] and mine-induced erosion into the river system each year. About {{convert|1588|sqkm}} of forest has died or is under stress. As many as {{convert|3000|sqkm}} may eventually be harmed, an area equal to the U.S. state of [[Rhode Island]] or the Danish island of [[Funen]].<ref name="Key">{{cite web | title = Key Statistics | publisher = Ok Tedi Mining | url = http://www.oktedi.com/aboutus/keyStatistics.php | accessdate = 17 September 2006 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060820172746/http://www.oktedi.com/aboutus/keyStatistics.php <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 20 August 2006}}</ref>
Following heavy rainfall, mine tailings are swept into the surrounding rain forest, swamps and creeks, and have left behind 30 square kilometers of dead forest. Thick gray sludge from the mine is visible throughout the Fly River system, although its effects downriver are not as severe.<ref>{{cite web | last = Kirsch | first = Stuart | title = Cleaning up Ok Tedi: Settlement Favors Yonggom People | work = Journal of the International Institute | publisher = Scholarly Publishing Office of the [[University of Michigan Library]] | date = Fall 1996 | url = http://hdl.handle.net/2027/spo.4750978.0004.104 | accessdate = 2 March 2008 }}</ref> Chemicals from the tailings killed or contaminated fish, although they are still eaten by the people of the surrounding villages. However, fish counts decrease closer to the mine. The massive amount of mine-derived waste dumped into the river exceeded its carrying capacity. This dumping resulted in the river bed being raised 10 m, causing a relatively deep and slow river to become shallower and develop rapids, thereby disrupting indigenous transportation routes.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hettler|first=J.|author2=Irion, G. |author3=Lehmann, B. |title=Environmental impact of mining waste disposal on a tropical lowland river system: a case study on the Ok Tedi Mine, Papua New Guinea|journal=Mineralium Deposita|year=1997}}</ref> Flooding, caused by the raised riverbed, left a thick layer of contaminated mud on the flood plain among plantations of taro, bananas and sago palm that are the staples of the local diet. About 1300 square kilometers were damaged in this way. The concentration of copper in the water is about 30 times above the standard level, but it is below the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) standards.<ref name="Marychurch">{{cite web | last =Marychurch | first =Judith | authorlink = |author2=Natalie Stoianoff | title =Blurring the Lines of Environmental Responsibility: How Corporate and Public Governance was Circumvented in the Ok Tedi Mining Limited Disaster | work = Australasian Law Teachers Association – Refereed Conference Papers | publisher = | location = Victoria University, Melbourne, Victoria, Australia | date =4–7 July 2006 | url = http://ro.uow.edu.au/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1476&context=lawpapers | format =pdf | doi = | accessdate = 17 April 2016 }}</ref>
The original plans included an Environmental Impact Statement that required a tailings dam be built. This would allow heavy metals and solid particles to settle, before releasing the clean ‘high-water’ into the river system where remaining contaminants would be diluted. In 1984 an earthquake caused the half built dam to collapse. The company continued operations without the dam, initially because BHP argued that it would be too expensive to rebuild it. Subsequently, the PNG government decided a dam wasn’t necessary, in the wake of the closure of the [[Panguna]] mine.{{citation needed|date=March 2013}}
Most of Papua New Guinea's land is held under a system of [[customary land title|native title]], with ownership divided amongst many small clans, while the central government retains control over how resources that lie under the ground are used.
There are no waste retention facilities on the premises. This allowed all ore processing residues, waste rock and overburden to be discharged into the Ok Tedi River.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hettler|first=J.|author2=Irion, G. |author3=Lehmann, B. |title=Environmental impact of mining waste disposal on a tropical lowland river system: a case study on the Ok Tedi Mine, Papua New Guinea|journal=Mineralium Deposita|year=1997}}</ref>
==Aftermath== In the 1990s the communities of the lower [[Western Province, Papua New Guinea|Fly Region]], including the [[Yonggom]] people,<ref>{{cite book | last = Kirsch | first = Stuart | title = Reverse Anthropology: Indigenous Analysis of Social and Environmental Relations in New Guinea | publisher = Stanford University Press; | date = July 2006 | pages = 272 | url = http://www.sup.org/book.cgi?book_id=5342 | isbn = 0-8047-5342-3 }}</ref> sued BHP and received US$28.6 million in an out-of-court settlement, which was the culmination of an enormous public-relations campaign against the company by environmental groups. As part of the settlement a (limited) dredging operation was put in place and efforts were made to rehabilitate the site around the mine. However the mine is still in operation and waste continues to flow into the river system. BHP was granted legal indemnity from future mine related damages.
The Ok Tedi Mine was scheduled to close in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oktedi.com/operations/mine-closure-planning|title=Mine Closure Planning|publisher=OK Tedi Mining Limited|accessdate=16 February 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120207052613/http://www.oktedi.com/operations/mine-closure-planning|archivedate=7 February 2012|df=}}</ref> However, the PNG Government has taken over control of the mine and with support of local community, the mine life was extended.<ref>{{cite web|title=PNG to take over Ok Tedi|url=http://www.miningnews.net/storyview.asp?storyid=795159826|work=MiningNews.Net|publisher=Aspermont Ltd.|accessdate=22 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Ok Tedi’s interested parties|url=http://www.pngindustrynews.net/storyview.asp?storyid=801882085|work=PNG Industry News|publisher=Aspermot Ltd.|accessdate=12 February 2014}}</ref> Until that time two thirds of the profits go into a long-term fund to enable the mine to continue to contribute to the PNG economy for up to half a century after it closes. The balance is allocated to current development programs in the local area (Western Province) and PNG more generally. Experts have predicted that it will take 300 years to clean up the toxic contamination.<ref name="The Age Jan 20 2007">{{cite news | last = Australian Associated Press | title = Villagers sue BHP Billiton for $5bn | work = [[The Age]] | publisher = Fairfax | date = 20 January 2007 | url = http://www.theage.com.au/news/business/villagers-sue-bhp-billiton-for-5bn/2007/01/19/1169095978975.html | accessdate = 4 February 2007 }}</ref>
== Mine Life Extension and Community Support == In 2013, the PNG Government seized 100% ownership of Ok Tedi Mine<ref>{{cite news|title=BREAKING NEWS: PNG Govt seizes Ok Tedi|url=http://www.pngindustrynews.net/storyview.asp?storyID=801574086&section=Search&sectionsource=s2377&Highlight=breaking|accessdate=19 September 2013|newspaper=PNG Industry News}}</ref> and repealed laws that would allow people to sue mining giant BHP Billiton over environmental damage. BHP expressed confidence, stating that it had other indemnities in place that protected shareholders from future legal costs.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.pngreport.com/png/news/1108384/bhp-confident-despite-threat-of-ok-tedi-legal-action|title=PNG Report - Bhp "Confident" Despite Threat Of Ok Tedi Legal Action|work=PNG Report|access-date=2018-11-07|language=en-GB}}</ref> Ok Tedi Mining Limited launched the OT2025 project that was focused on transitioning the business to a smaller operation in preparation for Mine Life Extension.
Community consent for the mine’s life to be extended to 2025 was endorsed by the Mine Associated Communities, which is made up of 156 villages, through the signing of the respective Community Mine Continuation Extension Agreements by the Community representatives and OTML at the end of 2012 and beginning of 2013. The signing of the Agreements facilitated the Company to commence planning for the MLE project throughout 2013.<ref>{{cite web|last=Garrett|first=Jemima|title=Community control of Ok Tedi mine assets welcomed in Papua New Guinea's Western Province|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-02-10/an-png-ok-tedi-assets-handover/5250694|work=Australia Network News|accessdate=11 February 2014}}</ref>

{{Infobox Korean name |img=Saemangeum ast 2006280 lrg.jpg |imgwidth=250 |caption=Picture taken by [[NASA]] in October 2006. The city on top of the picture is Gusan City, and the below is Buan County. |hangul=새만금 방조제| |hanja=새萬金防潮堤 |rr=Saeman(-)geum bangjoje |mr=Saeman'gŭm pangjoje }} The '''Saemangeum Seawall''', located on the southwest coast of the [[Korean peninsula]], is the world's longest man-made [[Dike (construction)|dyke]], measuring {{convert|33|km|mi}}. It runs between two headlands, and separates the [[Yellow Sea]] and the former [[Saemangeum]] estuary. [[File:Saemangeum2018.jpg|thumb|left|A view of the Saemangeum Seawall.]] In 1991, the [[Government of South Korea|South Korean government]] announced that a dyke would be constructed to link three headlands just south of the [[South Korea]]n industrial port city of [[Gunsan]], {{convert|270|km|mi|0}} southwest of [[Seoul]], to create {{convert|400|km2|mi2}} of farmland and a freshwater reservoir. Since then, the government has spent nearly 2 trillion [[South Korean won|won]] ({{ToUSD|2000|KOR}} billion USD) on construction of the dyke, with another 220 billion won ({{ToUSD|220000|KOR}} million USD) budgeted on strengthening the dyke and a further 1.31 trillion won ({{ToUSD|1310|KOR}} billion USD) to transform the tidal flats into arable land and the reservoir. The average width of the sea wall/earth dam is {{convert|290|m|ft}} (it is {{convert|535|m|ft}} at its widest) and the average height is {{convert|36|m|ft}} ({{convert|54|m|ft}} at its highest).{{cite web|url= http://www.korea.net/NewsFocus/policies/view?articleId=89560|title= Saemangeum: a new global city|accessdate=17 August 2018}} The construction of the Saemangeum Seawall has caused controversy from the moment it was announced as environmental groups protested against the impact of the dyke on the local environment. [[Supreme Court of South Korea|Supreme Court]] challenges in 1999 and 2005 led to temporary production stoppages but ultimately failed to stop the project. Major construction was completed in April 2006, with the seawall {{convert|500|m|ft}} longer than the [[Afsluitdijk]] in the [[IJsselmeer]], the [[Netherlands]], previously the longest seawall-dyke in the world. With remaining minor construction and inspection finished, the seawall was officially open to the public on April 27, 2010. Then South Korean president [[Lee Myung Bak]] commented that Saemangeum would be "the kernel and the gateway of South Korea's west coast industrial belt", and is "another effort by us for low-carbon and green growth, along with the [[The Four Major Rivers Restoration Project|four-rivers project]]". {{Citation | last = Lee | first = Chidong | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = Lee says Saemangeum tidal flat to change S. Korea's history | newspaper = Yonhap News | pages = | date = 27 April 2010 | url = http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/national/2010/04/27/50/0301000000AEN20100427005000315F.HTML | archiveurl = | archivedate = | accessdate = }} A ceremony was held in Saemangeum the same day, with [[cabinet (government)|cabinet officials]], politicians, and delegates from other countries. == Composition == [[File:새만금 3호 방조제.jpg|thumb|3rd section of the seawall]] [[File:새만금 4호 방조제.jpg|thumb|4th section of the seawall on Gunsan-bound]] The road on Saemangeum Seawall with the length of 33km, connects [[Buan County]] to [[Gunsan]] is a part of [[National Route 77 (South Korea)|National Route 77]]. {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2014}} [[File:Cambodia-mountainsW5.JPG|thumb|430px|Mountains along the Cambodian–Thai Border north of the road between [[Sisophon]] and [[Aranyaprathet]]. One of the areas where Khmer Rouge insurgents hid at the time of the [[PRK/SOC]].]] The '''K5 Plan''', '''K5 Belt''' or '''K5 Project''', also known as the '''Bamboo Curtain''',<ref>[http://opus.macmillan.yale.edu/workpaper/pdfs/GS24.pdf Kelvin Rowley, ''Second Life, Second Death: The Khmer Rouge After 1978'', Swinburne University of Technology] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160216054030/http://opus.macmillan.yale.edu/workpaper/pdfs/GS24.pdf |date=16 February 2016 }}</ref> was an attempt between 1985 and 1989 by the government of the [[People's Republic of Kampuchea]] to seal [[Khmer Rouge]] guerrilla infiltration routes into [[Cambodia]] by means of trenches, wire fences, and [[minefield]]s along virtually the entire Thai–Cambodian border.<ref name="ReferenceA">Margaret Slocomb, ''The People's Republic of Kampuchea, 1979-1989: The revolution after Pol Pot'' {{ISBN|978-974-9575-34-5}}</ref>
==Background== [[File:Cambodia anti-PRK border camps.png|thumb|240px|Border camps hostile to the PRK; 1979-1984]] After the defeat of [[Democratic Kampuchea]] in 1979, the [[Khmer Rouge]] fled Cambodia quickly. Protected by the Thai state, and with powerful foreign connections, [[Pol Pot]]'s virtually intact militia of about 30,000 to 35,000 troops regrouped and reorganized in forested and mountainous zones behind the Thai-Cambodian border. During the early 1980s Khmer Rouge forces showed their strength in [[Thailand]], inside the refugee camps near the border, and were able to receive a steady and abundant supply of military equipment. The weapons came mainly from China and the US and were channeled across Thailand with the cooperation of the [[Royal Thai Armed Forces]].<ref name="yale.edu">[http://www.yale.edu/cgp/thailand_response.html Puangthong Rungswasdisab, ''Thailand's Response to the Cambodian Genocide'']</ref>
From their position of security in hidden military outposts along the Thai border, the Khmer Rouge militias launched a relentless military campaign against the newly established People's Republic of Kampuchea state. Even though the Khmer Rouge was dominant, it fought against the [[Kampuchean People's Revolutionary Armed Forces]] (KPRAF) and [[Vietnam People's Army]] along with minor non-communist armed factions which had formerly been fighting against the Khmer Rouge between 1975 and 1979.
The border war followed a [[wet season]] / [[dry season]] rhythm. Generally, the heavily armed Vietnamese forces conducted offensive operations during the dry seasons, and the Chinese-backed Khmer Rouge held the initiative during the rainy seasons. In 1982, Vietnam launched a largely unsuccessful offensive against the main Khmer Rouge base at [[Phnom Malai]] in the [[Cardamom Mountains]].
The major consequence of the border civil war was that the PRK was hampered in its efforts to rebuild the much-damaged nation and consolidate its administration. The new republic's rule was tenuous in the border areas owing to persistent sabotage by the Khmer Rouge of the provincial administrative system through constant guerrilla warfare.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
==Implementation== The architect of the K5 plan was Vietnamese general [[Lê Đức Anh]], commander of the PAVN forces in Cambodia. He formulated five key points for the defence of Cambodia against Khmer Rouge re-infiltration. Letter "K", the first letter of the [[Khmer alphabet]], came from ''kar karpier'', meaning 'defence' in the [[Khmer language]], and number "5" referred to Le Duc Anh's five points in his plan of defence, of which the sealing of the border with [[Thailand]] was the second point.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Many workers on the project, however, did not know what "K5" stood for.<ref>Esmeralda Luciolli, ''Le mur de bambou, ou le Cambodge après Pol Pot.'' {{ISBN|2-905538-33-3}}</ref>
The K5 Plan began on 19 July 1984.<ref>[http://khmercanada.site.voila.fr/cambodge82.htm Chronologie du Cambodge de 1960 à 1990 - from Raoul M. Jennar, ''Les clés du Cambodge'']</ref> It became a gigantic effort that included [[clearcutting|clearing]] long patches of [[tropical forest]] by felling a great number of trees, as well as slashing and uprooting tall vegetation. The purpose was to leave a continuous broad open space all along the Thai border that would be watched and mined.
In practice the K5 fence consisted of a roughly 700 km-long, 500 m-wide swath of land along the border with Thailand, where [[antitank mine|antitank]] and [[antipersonnel mine]]s were buried to a density of about 3,000 mines per kilometre of frontage.<ref>Landmine Monitor Report 2005</ref>
==Consequences== From the [[ecology|environmental viewpoint]] the massive felling of trees was an [[ecological disaster]], contributing to acute [[deforestation]], the endangerment of species, and leaving behind a vast [[Land degradation|degraded area]]. The more remote places, like the [[Cardamom Mountains]] had been relatively untouched by man until they became a stronghold of the Khmer Rouge in the 1980s. Presently these mountains form an endangered [[ecoregion]].
Unforeseen by the planners of the project, from the [[Military strategy|military point of view]] the K5 Plan was also disastrous for the PRK. It did not deter the Khmer Rouge fighters who found ways to cross it, for it was impossible to effectively police the long border. Besides, maintenance was difficult, as the razed jungle left a scruffy undergrowth that, in the tropical climate, would grow again yearly to about a man's height.<ref name="Soizick Crochet 1997">Soizick Crochet, ''Le Cambodge'', Karthala, Paris 1997, {{ISBN|2-86537-722-9}}</ref>
The K5 Plan was counterproductive for the image of the PRK, as a republic bent on reconstructing what the rule of Pol Pot and his [[Communist Party of Kampuchea]] had destroyed in Cambodia. Despite the magnitude of the effort, the whole project was ultimately unsuccessful and ended up playing into the hands of the enemies of the new pro-[[Hanoi]] republic. Thousands of Cambodian peasants, who despite the Vietnamese invasion had welcomed the release from the Khmer Rouge's interference in traditional farming and the absence of taxes under the PRK government,<ref name="ReferenceA"/> became irritated. They were sore at having to abandon their farms in order to dedicate time to clear the jungle, a heavy toil they perceived as useless and unfruitful.<ref name="Soizick Crochet 1997"/> Their resentment grew in time as they perceived the new forced labor to be, albeit without the killings, very similar to what they had experienced under the Khmer Rouge tyranny.<ref name="ReferenceB">Margaret Slocomb, ''The K5 Gamble: National Defence and Nation Building under the People's Republic of Kampuchea'' Journal of Southeast Asian Studies (2001), 32 : 195-210 Cambridge University Press</ref> Owing to unsanitary conditions and the abundance of [[mosquitoes]] in areas of difficult access, badly fed and badly lodged workers on the K5 project fell victims of [[malaria]] and exhaustion.<ref>Craig Etcheson, ''After the killing fields: lessons from the Cambodian genocide'', {{ISBN|978-0-275-98513-4}}</ref>
Many of the mines remain to this day, making the vast long area dangerous. The K5 zone became part of the great landmine problem in Cambodia after the end of the civil war. In 1990 alone, the number of Cambodians that had a leg or foot amputated as a result of an injury caused by a land mine reached around 6,000.<ref>[https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg13217914.300-the-killing-minefields-of-cambodia.html?full=true NewScientist - ''The killing minefields of Cambodia '']</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=April 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2016}} [[File:Borneo fires October 2006.jpg|thumb|right|350px|Satellite photograph of the haze above [[Borneo]]]] The '''2006 Southeast Asian haze''' event was caused by continued uncontrolled burning from "[[slash and burn]]" cultivation in [[Indonesia]], and affected several countries in the Southeast Asian region and beyond, such as [[Malaysia]], [[Singapore]], southern [[Thailand]], and as far as [[Saipan]];<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.saipantribune.com/newsstory.aspx?cat=1&newsID=61706 |title=Indon haze spreads to NMI |accessdate=8 October 2006 |publisher=saipantribune.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070218044848/http://www.saipantribune.com/newsstory.aspx?cat=1&newsID=61706 |archivedate=18 February 2007 |df= }}</ref> the effects of the haze may have spread to [[South Korea]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/NaturalHazards/natural_hazards_v2.php3?img_id=13927|title=Haze over Korea |author=[[NASA]]|date=13 October 2006|accessdate=30 October 2006|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070803001633/http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/NaturalHazards/natural_hazards_v2.php3?img_id=13927 |archivedate = 3 August 2007|deadurl=yes}}</ref> Local sources of pollution partly contributed to the increased [[toxicity]], particularly in high-pollution areas such as ports, [[oil refineries]], and dense urban areas. In the highly urbanised and industrialised [[Klang Valley]] of Malaysia in particular, the surrounding terrain acted as a natural retainer of polluted air, aggravating the situation when the [[haze]] set in.
There is also a link to [[El Niño]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nasa.gov/centers/goddard/news/topstory/2007/elnino_wildfire.html|title=NASA Data Links Indonesian Wildfire Flare-Up to Recent El Nino|accessdate=3 January 2007}}</ref> The haze was made worse than during previous occurrences by the [[El Niño-Southern Oscillation]] which delayed the year's monsoon season. Fires in Kalimantan produce great amounts of smoke, burn a long time and are difficult to extinguish because they are on [[peat]]land, and once lit the fires can burn for months and release gases that produce [[sulphuric acid]].<ref>Ghosh, Arijit. 31 October 2006. [http://www.theage.com.au/news/business/fires-leave-indonesias-neighbours-fuming/2006/10/30/1162056928811.html Fires leave Indonesia's neighbours fuming – Business – Business – theage.com.au], Bloomberg via The Age. Retrieved 1 November 2006.</ref>
Air quality across the region appeared to improve in late October as heavy rainfall doused fires in Indonesia.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/nm/20061027/sc_nm/environment_indonesia_haze_dc|title=Rain clears haze in SE Asia|accessdate=29 October 2006|publisher=Reuters at Yahoo!}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
==Countries affected== ===Brunei=== [[Brunei]], an independent [[sultanate]] that is surrounded by [[East Malaysia]]'s [[Sarawak]] state on [[Borneo]], had been affected by the haze from [[Kalimantan]]. Rains brought some relief, and on 8 October, the [[Pollutant Standards Index]] had dropped to 46, which is within the "good" range.<ref>''Borneo Bulletin''. 9 October 2006. [http://www.brunet.bn/news/bb/mon/oct9h1.htm "Call for joint Asean fund to combat haze menace"]{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} . Retrieved 13 October 2006. {{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> There was a brief spell of clear skies during the first week of [[Hari Raya Aidilfitri|Hari Raya]], following a spell of rainy weather. But the haze returned on 31 October,<ref>Othman, Azlan. 1 November 2006. [http://www.brudirect.com/DailyInfo/News/Archive/Nov06/011106/nite03.htm "Haze Returns To Brunei"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070303163353/http://www.brudirect.com/DailyInfo/News/Archive/Nov06/011106/nite03.htm |date=3 March 2007 }}, BruDirect.com.</ref> with the Department of Environment, Parks and Recreation recording a PSI of 49.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20061010091625/http://www.env.gov.bn/psireading.htm Department of Environment, Parks and Recreation PSI reading] . Retrieved 1 November 2006.</ref><ref>[http://www.bruneiweather.com.bn/haze.htm Brunei Meteorological Office] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050204105426/http://www.bruneiweather.com.bn/haze.htm |date=4 February 2005 }}</ref>
===Indonesia=== The fires originated mostly in [[Kalimantan]], the Indonesian part of [[Borneo]], and on [[Sumatra]], where they are set by [[swidden]] agriculturists employed by agroforestry concerns to clear land to grow pulp woods or market crops ahead of the [[Tillage|growing]] season. Satellite images taken over Borneo on 4 October showing 561 "hot spots" areas where fires had been set.
Officials in neighbouring countries accused Indonesian officials of doing nothing to stop the fires, though forestry ministry officials said they had [[firefighting|firefighters]] working to douse the [[forest fire|blazes]] on state-controlled land. However, they conceded, most of the fires were on private land.<ref>Agence France-Presse.6 October 2006. [http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/afp_asiapacific/view/234207/1/.html "Indonesia dousing fires causing haze: forestry official"] (retrieved via Channel NewsAsia 9 October 2006).</ref> Indonesia planned to deploy its military to aid fire fighting effort.<ref>Bernama. ''[http://bernama.com/bernama/v3/news.php?id=225179 Indonesia To Deploy Soldiers To Fight Forest Fires] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930192437/http://bernama.com/bernama/v3/news.php?id=225179 |date=30 September 2007 }}''. 16 October 2006</ref> To recruit more people to man the fire line, the government offered two days off for civil servants who volunteered for fire duty.<ref>Agence France-Presse. 17 October 2006. [http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/afp_asiapacific/view/235940/1/.html "Fight fires, get two days off work: Indonesia's anti-haze tactic"].</ref> But the country lacked equipment for fighting forest fires, having aeroplanes that were too small to carry enough water to douse the fires.<ref>Agence France-Presse. 17 October 2006.[http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/southeastasia/view/235850/1/.html "Rain brings reprieve to residents suffering from haze in South Sumatra"].</ref> In a bid to obtain bigger aircraft, the government leased two [[Beriev Be-200]] aircraft from [[Russia]], which are capable of skimming over water and taking on loads for sustained firefighting efforts.<ref>Novosti. 21 October 2006. [http://en.rian.ru/world/20061020/54979386.html "Indonesia to rent 2 Russian planes to fight forest fires"].</ref> The planes, which will be flown by Russians and maintained by Russian technicians, were due to begin operations on 1 November.<ref>[http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/JAK284005.htm Russian planes to help Indonesia fight haze], Reuters, 31 October 2006.</ref>
The fires forced schools to close, delayed and cancelled airline flights, disrupted shipping and forced Indonesians to don [[Mask|face masks]]. Cities affected include [[Pontianak, Indonesia|Pontianak]], [[West Kalimantan]], [[Palangkaraya]], [[Central Kalimantan]] and [[Pekanbaru]], [[Riau]].<ref>Agence France-Presse. 5 October 2006. [http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/afp_asiapacific/view/234091/1/.html Haze from Indonesia fires chokes region, spreads across Pacific] (retrieved via Channel NewsAsia on 9 October 2006).</ref><ref>[http://www.gulf-times.com/site/topics/article.asp?cu_no=2&item_no=111897&version=1&template_id=45&parent_id=25 Lack of funds an obstacle to halting cropland fires] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061010204818/http://www.gulf-times.com/site/topics/article.asp?cu_no=2&item_no=111897&version=1&template_id=45&parent_id=25 |date=10 October 2006 }}. ''[[Gulf Times]]''. 9 October 2006. (''retrieved on 9 October 2006'').</ref> The haze was blamed for a [[Mandala Airlines]] flight from [[Balikpapan]], the provincial capital of [[East Kalimantan]], skidding off the runway upon landing at [[Tarakan, East Kalimantan|Tarakan]] on 3 October, when visibility was reported at around 400 metres.<ref>Agence France-Presse. 3 October 2006. [http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/afp_asiapacific/view/233729/1/.html "Passenger plane skids off runway amid thick haze in Indonesia"] (retrieved via Channel NewsAsia on 9 October 2006).</ref> It has caused breathing problems for people in [[Riau]] and in [[Jambi|Jambi Province]].<ref>Jakarta Post. 9 October 2006. [http://www.thejakartapost.com/detailheadlines.asp?fileid=20061009.A05&irec=4 Haze increasing respiratory cases, doctors say]. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070926224733/http://www.thejakartapost.com/detailheadlines.asp?fileid=20061009.A05&irec=4 |date=26 September 2007 }}</ref> On 21 October 12 airlines cancelled domestic flights from [[Soekarno-Hatta International Airport]] due to smog at many destinations, including Jambi, [[Banjarmasin]], [[Jayapura]], [[Semarang]], [[Surabaya]], [[Bengkulu]], [[Denpasar]], [[Makassar]], Pekanbaru and [[Padang, Indonesia|Padang]].<ref>ANTARA. 21 October 2006. [http://www.antara.co.id/en/seenws/?id=22118 Airline companies cancel flights to different domestic destinations)]{{dead link|date=September 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}.</ref>
A 20 October report by Malaysian government news agency [[BERNAMA]] offered a first-hand account of the scene in Kalimantan: "The suffocating smell of smoke, sore throat and eyes got worse when this reporter and a photographer stepped foot in central Kalimantan, forcing them to put on face masks. Throughout the 200-kilometre journey from Banjarmasin to Palangkaraya, what could be seen of the forests on both sides of the road was a landscape of blackish soil with smoke still billowing from the ground in some areas and of withering trees and plants. The area was foggy and dusty as the air was filled with flying ashes and other particles."
Local villagers, the report said, appeared to be unconcerned with the smog, saying it was "normal". "If we do not burn the forest, where are we going to get our food from?" a villager said.<ref>Madian, Amrizan. 20 October 2006. [http://www.bernama.com.my/bernama/v3/printable.php?id=225856 "Haze creates regional human-environment crisis"], BERNAMA.</ref>
On the environmental front, fires destroyed 1 km² of the [[Tesso Nilo National Park]] in [[Riau|Riau Province]].<ref name="delay">{{cite news|title=Unhealthy air may last for a few weeks|author=Tan, Tania|work=Straits Times |location=Singapore |date=17 October 2006|page=1|publisher=[[Singapore Press Holdings]]}}</ref> At the [[Tanjung Puting National Park]] in [[Central Kalimantan]], the haze adversely affected the [[orangutan]]s.<ref name="delay"/>
===Malaysia===
The effects of the haze started in early July and affected the northern [[Malaysia]]n states severely.<ref>The __earthinc. [http://maddruid.com/?p=825 Of possible return of haze] 4 July 2006.</ref><!-- WP:RS - no blogs allowed. If possible, find better source. --> However, the haze had cleared substantially throughout [[Peninsular Malaysia]] from 29 August 2006 due to the arrival of the rainy season. The rain reduced the number of hotspots throughout Sumatra and the Malay Peninsula. On 30 August 2006, ''[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]]'' reported that Kuala Lumpur would be free of haze during the Independence Day. In the late evening just before midnight on 31 August 2006, the visibility in the Klang Valley was recorded to be very good.
Unfortunately, the haze returned again in late September when Muslim Malaysians were experiencing [[Ramadan]]. This was partly due to a change of wind direction towards the southwest, partially caused by [[Typhoon Xangsane]].<ref>[[Brunei Times]]. Filipino wind of change. 3 October 2006.</ref> The worst hit place was [[Kuching]]. The Sarawak state government had declared that schools would close if the API breaches the 300 mark.<ref>[[Bernama]]. [http://www.bernama.com.my/bernama/v3/news.php?id=223339 Schools In Sarawak To Close If API Breaches 300 Level]. 5 October 2006.</ref> The worst affected area in Peninsular Malaysia is [[Johor Bahru]] which recorded an API of 150 on 7 and 8 October. For now, many people are wearing [[mask]]s to prevent themselves from inhaling excessive amounts of haze. On 7 October, [[visibility]] in parts of [[East Malaysia]] fell to 300 metres. On or about 9 October, the worst of the haze in Peninsular seemed to be in the state of [[Negeri Sembilan]], where [[visibility]] in [[Sepang]] fell briefly to 500 metres and the [[Air Pollution Index|API]] in [[Nilai]] reached 198, before the rain relieved the haze partially. Shortly thereafter changing winds caused conditions to improve rapidly. [[Sarawak]] has started [[cloud seeding]] attempts to try to encourage rainfall that will help relieve the haze.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2006/10/7/nation/15661601&sec=nation |accessdate=8 October 2006 |title=Malaysians have had enough of haze woes |publisher=The Star Online |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081220034848/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2006%2F10%2F7%2Fnation%2F15661601&sec=nation |archivedate=20 December 2008 |df=dmy }}</ref> Each cloud seeding session costs at least [[Ringgit Malaysia|RM]]50,000 (roughly US$14,000).<ref>The Star. [https://web.archive.org/web/20081220034843/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2006%2F10%2F16%2Fnation%2F15733822&sec=nation Cloud-seeding proving costly for Sarawak]. 16 October 2006.</ref> On 21 October, the winds has changed direction and started to blow the hazes away from Malaysia, and the following day, heavy rain has cleared the haze. Later on 26 October, the heavy rain returned again, and there were isolated showers in [[Klang Valley]]. [[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] reported that the hazy days are soon coming to an end as the [[monsoon]] season is approaching.

The average API for that day was in between 70 and 80.]] [[File:HazeKualaLumpurParliamentHafiz.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Overlooking the [[Perdana Lake Gardens]] in Kuala Lumpur at noon of 16 October 2006. ===Singapore=== While the haze largely spared Singapore with 24-hour [[Pollutant Standards Index]] readings within the "Good" range for 15 days in September and the rest in the "Moderate" range and no higher than a reading of 66,<ref name="PSI">{{cite web|title=PSI Reading for Singapore|publisher=Singapore [[National Environment Agency]]|url=http://app.nea.gov.sg/cms/htdocs/article_frm.asp?pid=2780|accessdate=14 October 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061023131842/http://app.nea.gov.sg/cms/htdocs/article_frm.asp?pid=2780|archivedate=23 October 2006|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> its harmful effects became more prevalent in October.
On 7 October 2006, the 3-hour PSI reading breached the 100 mark at 8 a.m. and entered unhealthy levels for the first time in the year, as winds from neighbouring [[Sumatra]] blew the haze to Singapore.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://app.nea.gov.sg/cms/htdocs/article.asp?pid=2777 |accessdate=7 October 2006 |title=Haze update 7 Oct 2006 |publisher=[[National Environment Agency]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070611034917/http://app.nea.gov.sg/cms/htdocs/article.asp?pid=2777 |archivedate=11 June 2007 |df=dmy }}</ref> At 10 a.m., it hit 130, the highest in three years, before subsiding to 80 at 4 p.m. and climbing rapidly to 150 at 9 p.m.,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/234369/1/.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20061023005348/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/234369/1/.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=23 October 2006|accessdate=8 October 2006|title=Haze worsens in Singapore, PSI hits new high for the year|publisher=[[Channel NewsAsia]]}}</ref> the worst since 1997, before ending the day at 136, still in the unhealthy range.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.asiaone.com/a1news/20061007_story1_3.html|title=Singapore records worst pollution reading in 10 years|accessdate=8 October 2006|publisher=[[asiaone News]] |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061103061347/http://news.asiaone.com/a1news/20061007_story1_3.html |archivedate = 3 November 2006}}</ref>
Although the air quality was set to improve with the arrival of the [[Northeast monsoon]] rains in mid-October, southeasterly winds extended the hazy season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.todayonline.com/articles/148867.asp|accessdate=16 October 2006|title=A grey start to the week|publisher=[[TODAYOnline]]}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> A mild [[El Niño]] effect delayed the starting of the showers to late October or early November,<ref name="delay"/> or even until the end of November. The prolonged haze could be attributed to the extended dry season, which put the rains on hold and affected wind patterns which brought the haze to Singapore. Intermittent showers could occur in the pre-monsoon period, but these would do little in increasing air quality. The unpredictable winds in the pre-monsoon period could bring haze from either Sumatra or Kalimantan.<ref name="more delay">{{cite news|title=Late rains mean haze may stay till end-Nov|author1=Tan, Tania |author2=Peh, Shing Huei|work=Straits Times |location=Singapore |date=21 October 2006|page=1|publisher=[[Singapore Press Holdings]]}}</ref>
Air quality remained in the moderate range for the next week<ref name="PSI"/> until 14 October, when the 3-hour PSI readings gradually increased from 53 at 6 a.m. to peak at an unhealthy 116 at 10 p.m.<ref name="Oct14">{{cite news| title=Air quality back to unhealthy level|author1=Suhaimi, Nur Dianah |author2=Sua, Tracy|work=[[The Sunday Times (Singapore)|The Sunday Times]]|date=15 October 2006|page=1|publisher=[[Singapore Press Holdings]]}}</ref> This time, majority of the haze came from [[Kalimantan]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://app.nea.gov.sg/cms/htdocs/article.asp?pid=2785|accessdate=14 October 2006|title=Haze update 14 Oct 2006|publisher=[[National Environment Agency]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061023131322/http://app.nea.gov.sg/cms/htdocs/article.asp?pid=2785|archivedate=23 October 2006|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Similarly, on 15 October, the PSI readings increased from 69 at 6 a.m. to 98 at 3 p.m. and 4 p.m.,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601080&sid=a4a.e4nGytHY&refer=asia|title=Singapore, Clouded in Haze, May Face Deteriorating Air Quality|accessdate=15 October 2006|publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]}}</ref> 3 points short of reaching the unhealthy range. This eased to 82 by midnight.<ref name="Second hazy weekend">{{cite news|title=Second hazy weekend for S'poreans|author=Chua, Adeline|work=Straits Times |location=Singapore |date=16 October 2006|page=H4|publisher=[[Singapore Press Holdings]]}}</ref> As winds remained southeasterly, haze from Kalimantan blew across the [[South China Sea]] to Singapore.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://app.nea.gov.sg/cms/htdocs/article.asp?pid=2786|accessdate=15 October 2006|title=Haze update 15 Oct 2006|publisher=[[National Environment Agency]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061023131554/http://app.nea.gov.sg/cms/htdocs/article.asp?pid=2786|archivedate=23 October 2006|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The next day, on 16 October, the PSI stayed in the 80s in the morning, before shooting up once again into the unhealthy range, hitting a high of 130 at 4 p.m. and 5 p.m. The 3-hour PSI remained in unhealthy levels for 8 consecutive hours, between 2 p.m. and 9 p.m.<ref name="health">{{cite news|title=Even a little haze is bad for health|author=Khalik, Salma|work=Straits Times |location=Singapore |date=17 October 2006|page=6|publisher=[[Singapore Press Holdings]]}}</ref> The haze obscured the sun, and symptoms of exposure to haze resurfaced in the general population.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chinapost.com.tw/i_latestdetail.asp?id=41756 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120730122805/http://www.chinapost.com.tw/i_latestdetail.asp?id=41756 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=30 July 2012 |accessdate=16 October 2006 |title=Singapore's air quality at unhealthy level (4:07 p.m.) |work=The China Post |location=Taiwan (ROC) }}</ref> The 24-hour PSI for 16 October reached 98,<ref name="PSI"/> just 3 points short of unhealthy. Visibility dropped to as low as 1 km in some areas, compared to the usual 20 km.<ref name="health"/>
The PSI on 17 October gradually increased from the moderate range in the morning to slip into the unhealthy range at 4 p.m., reaching 106,<ref name="persist">{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/236004/1/.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20061102231228/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/236004/1/.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2 November 2006|accessdate=17 October 2006|title=Hazy conditions expected to persist on Wednesday|publisher=[[Channel NewsAsia]]}}</ref> before declining back to 100 in the moderate range at 10 p.m.<ref>{{cite news|title=7 prime-time hours of bad air in Singapore|author1=Tan, Tania |author2=Hussain, Zakir|work=Straits Times |location=Singapore |date=18 October 2006|page=5|publisher=[[Singapore Press Holdings]]}}</ref> The hazy conditions were expected to persist.<ref name="persist"/>
On 19 October, the PSI crept into the unhealthy range at 106 at 2 p.m.,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/236367/1/.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20061023161946/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/236367/1/.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=23 October 2006|accessdate=19 October 2006|title=Haze in Singapore back to unhealthy range after respite|publisher=[[Channel NewsAsia]]}}</ref> peaking at 113 at 4 p.m. The National Environment Agency reported that the situation would not improve the next day.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/236442/1/.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20061023162058/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/236442/1/.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=23 October 2006|accessdate=19 October 2006|title=Hazy conditions to continue in Singapore on Friday: NEA|publisher=[[Channel NewsAsia]]}}</ref>
Throughout the early morning on 20 October, the PSI kept in the 90s, before reaching a high of 103 at 8 a.m.<ref name="more delay"/> This dropped to 74 by 7 p.m., although the PSI remained in the 90s in the afternoon.<ref>{{cite news|title=Morning rain brings no reprieve|work=Straits Times |location=Singapore |date=21 October 2006|page=9|publisher=[[Singapore Press Holdings]]}}</ref> Even though rain fell in some areas, this was not enough to "alleviate the haze situation". The NEA forecast thunderstorms over the weekend, but the southeasterly winds would continue to prevail.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://app.nea.gov.sg/cms/htdocs/article.asp?pid=2794 |accessdate=20 October 2006 |title=Haze Update 20 Oct 2006 |publisher=[[National Environment Agency]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070611035214/http://app.nea.gov.sg/cms/htdocs/article.asp?pid=2794 |archivedate=11 June 2007 |df=dmy }}</ref> The 24-hour PSI on 20 October also reached the unhealthy range at 102.<ref name="PSI"/>
Later in October, though, the situation began to improve, with the PSI hitting a low of 11 at 2 p.m. on 26 October.
However, in early November, intermonsoonal winds brought slight haze back to Singapore, with the 3-hour PSI in the moderate range most of the time.
The highest 3-hour average PSI recorded prior to that point 226 in September 1997.<ref>{{cite news| title=Haze hits pollution index record of 226|author=Tan, Terence|work=Straits Times |location=Singapore |date=19 September 1997|page=1|publisher=[[Singapore Press Holdings]]}}</ref>
====Impact==== While some Singaporeans began donning face masks, others frequented shopping malls and public places like [[VivoCity]], with many shopping before [[Deepavali]] at [[Little India, Singapore|Little India]],<ref name="Shrouded">{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/235631/1/.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20061023161202/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/235631/1/.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=23 October 2006|accessdate=15 October 2006|title=Singapore shrouded in haze, public urged to reduce vigorous outdoor activity|publisher=[[Channel NewsAsia]]}}</ref> and going to [[Geylang Serai]]'s annual [[Hari Raya]] bazaar. Stallholders said that the haze had not affected their business.<ref>{{cite news|title=Grumbles, but it's business as usual for Singaporeans|author=Suhaimi, Nur Dianah|work=[[The Sunday Times (Singapore)|The Sunday Times]]|date=15 October 2006|page=19|publisher=[[Singapore Press Holdings]]}}</ref> However, Singaporeans generally kept indoors,<ref name="Second hazy weekend"/> with some staying away from [[East Coast Park]].<ref name="Shrouded"/>
The government announced plans for a haze action plan if the situation became "extremely dangerous", which included priority treatment for haze-related illnesses.<ref name="Action plan">{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/235784/1/.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20061023161303/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/235784/1/.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=23 October 2006|accessdate=16 October 2006|title=Haze action plan to kick in if PSI hits extremely dangerous level|publisher=[[Channel NewsAsia]]}}</ref> Health Minister [[Khaw Boon Wan]] said that there was "very little that (could) be done to stop the haze", and advised people to remain indoors, especially those with prior respiratory conditions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/236219/1/.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20061019011403/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/236219/1/.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=19 October 2006|accessdate=18 October 2006|title=Health Minister hopes preventive measures will be taken to stop haze in future|publisher=[[Channel NewsAsia]]}}</ref>
Some minor haze-related illness began to surface, but free clinics across the island did not report any increase in patients with this symptoms.<ref name="Oct14"/> However, attendance figures at [[polyclinic]]s islandwide increased by 600 cases to about 15,000 cases of haze-related conditions in the first week of October as compared to the same period last month.<ref name="Action plan"/> This is despite the [[National Healthcare Group]] reporting that the number of people "complaining of the same ailments" has decreased from the same period last year.<ref name="Worse in west">{{cite news|title=Singapore's smoke central|author1=Tan, Tania |author2=Lim, Jessica|work=Straits Times |location=Singapore |date=20 October 2006|page=6|publisher=[[Singapore Press Holdings]]}}</ref>
[[Air purifier]] sales shot up during the hazy period. [[Best Denki]], an electronic store, sold [[Singapore dollar|S$]]350,000 worth of air purifiers and related items in 4 days, a 300 percent increase. However, experts from the Institute of Environmental Science & Engineering at the [[Nanyang Technological University]] said that only some of these products, like High Efficiency Particulate [[air filter]]s, would effectively remove small particles from air. Other kinds of air purifiers like [[air ionizer|ionizing purifiers]] gave off [[ozone]] which could cause symptoms similar to those caused by the haze. The experts recommended regularly cleaning the filter media and opening windows to get some fresh air at night.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/236697/1/.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20061023162310/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/236697/1/.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=23 October 2006|accessdate=21 October 2006|title=Sales of air purifiers increase by more than two-fold as haze persists|publisher=[[Channel NewsAsia]]}}</ref>
The [[West Region, Singapore|western region]], which includes [[Boon Lay]], [[Choa Chu Kang]] and [[Jurong]], seemed to be the "[[epicentre]]" of the haze. Residents there complained of the worse conditions in their area, saying that it felt "hotter than usual", and health problems were more widespread. The air quality levels in the west may have consistently been the worst, but only by several points. Some speculated that the more polluted air was caused by the many construction sites and [[industrial park]]s in [[Jurong]], but NEA refuted this, claiming that they did not contribute to the haze. Polyclinics in Jurong and [[Bukit Batok]] had an increase of 20 percent admission for patients with respiratory problems and [[asthma]].<ref name="Worse in west"/>
Schools islandwide restricted outdoor activities and had to rethink post-examination activities and training or revert to wet-weather programmes. The [[Singapore Sports School]]'s swim team had to cut back on training when the haze reached unhealthy levels even though they were in the midst of various international competitions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/235970/1/.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20061023161426/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/235970/1/.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=23 October 2006|accessdate=17 October 2006|title=Sports School training affected by haze, outdoor activities cut back|publisher=[[Channel NewsAsia]]}}</ref> The [[Ministry of Education (Singapore)|Ministry of Education]] recommended that schools suspend all outdoor activities when the PSI reading passes 100, but some schools chose to move indoors regardless of the PSI.<ref>{{cite news|title=Jurong schools moved more activities indoors|author=Lim, Jessica|work=Straits Times |location=Singapore |date=20 October 2006|page=6|publisher=[[Singapore Press Holdings]]}}</ref>
Many Singaporean "fitness buffs" also made the move indoors. [[Fitness club]]s reported increases in turn-outs and check-ins, utilising gym facilities rather than outdoor activities. [[Rock climbing|Rock climbers]] were also affected, and began to move activities indoors instead.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/236825/1/.html|accessdate=21 October 2006|title=Fitness buffs heading indoors to exercise to beat the haze|publisher=[[Channel NewsAsia]]}}</ref>
The haze also caused increased sales and rental of entertainment [[Video CD|VCD]] and DVD titles, but cinema attendance was unchanged.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/235636/1/.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20061102232437/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/235636/1/.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2 November 2006|accessdate=16 October 2006|title=Hazy days drive up demand for entertainment DVDs and VCDs|publisher=[[Channel NewsAsia]]}}</ref>
The National Environment Agency website received about 170,000 hits on 14 October, as compared to the usual 60,000, and caused the server to temporarily go down due to the sheer volume of traffic.<ref name="delay"/>
According to economists, Singapore suffered a US$50 million economic loss due to the onset of the haze in 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/235112/1/.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20061022152817/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/235112/1/.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=22 October 2006|title=Economic loss estimated at US$50 m since the start of the haze|accessdate=14 October 2006|publisher=[[Channel NewsAsia]]}}</ref>

===Thailand=== In July, the southern [[Thailand|Thai]] provinces of [[Pattani Province|Pattani]] and [[Satun Province|Satun]] suffered an on-and-off bout of smog, with the levels of pollutants in Satun being high enough to constitute a health hazard.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/breaking_news/breakingnews.php?id=106974|accessdate=8 October 2006|title=Indonesia smog covers two provinces|publisher=bangkokpost.com}}</ref> In all, seven provinces were affected by the haze in July and August.
Haze was again reported on 6 October, with respiratory illnesses and eye irritation reported in [[Narathiwat Province|Narathiwat]].<ref>Thai News Agency. 6 October 2006. [http://etna.mcot.net/query.php?nid=25233 "Indonesian forest fire smog again blankets southern Thailand"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061009083544/http://etna.mcot.net/query.php?nid=25233 |date=9 October 2006 }}, MCOT.</ref> Visibility and air quality were also affected in [[Songkhla Province|Songkhla]], Satun and [[Yala Province|Yala]]. Health warnings were issued and [[surgical mask]]s were issued to residents. Three days later, meteorological officials reported that the haze had thinned to almost normal visibility.<ref>Thai News Agency. 9 October 2006. [http://etna.mcot.net/query.php?nid=25300 "Smog from Indonesia over southern Thailand thins out"]{{dead link|date=September 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, MCOT.</ref>
Strong winds in the region brought haze from Indonesia back into Songkhla, Satun, Pattani, Yala and Narathiwat provinces on 17 October. Visibility in Yala and Songkhla was reduced to less than a kilometre, and officials warned fishermen going out to the [[Andaman Sea]] and [[Gulf of Thailand]] to "stay vigilant". Drivers were also asked to turn on their headlights.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://etna.mcot.net/query.php?nid=25459 |accessdate=17 October 2006 |title=Indonesian smog returns to southern Thailand |publisher=TNA English News }}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==ASEAN Ministerial Meeting on Transboundary Haze Pollution==<!-- This section is linked from [[ASEAN Ministerial Meeting on Transboundary Haze Pollution]]. See [[WP:MOS#Section management]] -->
Malaysia and Singapore criticised the way Indonesia handled the issue. Both urged the latter to ratify the [[ASEAN Agreement on Transboundary Haze Pollution]]. The Malaysian Environment Minister [[Azmi Khalid]] said "Frustration is an understatement", directed toward Indonesia.<ref>[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]]. [http://www.malaysianbar.org.my/content/view/4967/2/ Malaysians have had enough of haze woes] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20121219224631/http://www.malaysianbar.org.my/content/view/4967/2/ |date=19 December 2012 }}. 7 October 2006.</ref> There was also a protest in front of the Indonesia embassy in Kuala Lumpur, organised by local political parties.<ref>Dow Jones. [http://www.lloyds.com/CmsPhoenix/DowJonesArticle.aspx?id=239108 Malaysians protest outside Indonesia embassy over haze]. 10 October 2006. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928020544/http://www.lloyds.com/CmsPhoenix/DowJonesArticle.aspx?id=239108 |date=28 September 2007 }}</ref> Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expressed disappointment toward Indonesia soon after Azmi Khalid made his view public.<ref>[[Channel News Asia]]. [http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/234808/1/.html Singapore expresses disappointment over haze to Indonesia]. 11 October 2006.</ref> In response to the letter, Indonesian President apologised for the regional haze.<ref>Bloomberg. [https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601080&sid=ahLanwV7u_Jw&refer=asia Indonesia Apologizes to Its Neighbors for Smoke Haze]. 11 October 2006</ref> Indonesia has earlier stated that it lacked the resources to combat the burning effectively.<ref>[[The Sun (Malaysia)|The Sun]]. [http://www.sun2surf.com/article.cfm?id=15745 No fund, pray for rain] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081219130435/http://www.sun2surf.com/article.cfm?id=15745 |date=19 December 2008 }}. 13 October 2006.</ref>
Singapore proposed regional talks on the haze, to be held in Singapore. Indonesia, however, requested such talks to be held in [[Pekan Baru]], [[Kalimantan]] instead.<ref>AFP at [[Yahoo!]]. [https://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20061010/sc_afp/malaysiaindonesia Southeast Asian ministers to pressure Indonesia over haze]{{dead link|date=September 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} 10 October 2006</ref> The request was agreed to and talks were held on 13 October 2006. At the meeting, Malaysia proposed the setting up of a regional fund to help combat the environmental disaster.<ref>[[Bernama]]. [http://bernama.com/bernama/v3/news_lite.php?id=224481 Malaysia proposes special fund to fight haze] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071001000237/http://bernama.com/bernama/v3/news_lite.php?id=224481 |date=1 October 2007 }}. 12 October 2006</ref>
With the arrival of the northeastern winter [[monsoons]] in December, the haze problem was effectively ended for 2006.

{{EngvarB|date=April 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2016}} {{Refimprove|date=September 2012}} [[File:TOMS indonesia smog lrg.jpg|upright=1.6|thumb|Air pollution over Southeast Asia in October 1997]] The '''1997 Southeast Asian haze''' was a large-scale air quality disaster that occurred during the second half of 1997, its after-effects causing widespread atmospheric visibility and health problems within [[Southeast Asia]]. The total costs of the Southeast Asian haze are estimated at [[United States dollar|US$]]9 billion, due mainly to health care and disruption of air travel and business activities.
The influence of the [[1997 Indonesian forest fires|1997 fires in Kalimantan and Sumatra]] on ambient air quality was evident by July and peaked in September/October before weakening by November, when the delayed [[monsoon|monsoonal rain]] extinguished the fires and improved air quality within the region. During the peak episode, satellite imagery (NASA/TOMS aerosol index maps) showed a haze layer that expanded over an area of more than {{convert|3000000|km²|sqmi|abbr=on}}, covering large parts of [[Sumatra]] and [[Kalimantan]]. Its northward extension partially reached [[Malaysia]], [[Singapore]], [[Brunei]] and [[Thailand]]. During this period, [[Atmospheric particulate matter|particulate matter]] concentrations frequently exceeded national ambient air quality standards. Monthly mean horizontal visibility at most locations in Sumatra and Kalimantan in September was below {{convert|1|km|abbr= on}} and daily maximum visibility was frequently below {{convert|100|m|abbr=out}}.
==Countries affected== * [[Indonesia]] * [[Singapore]] * [[Malaysia]] * [[Thailand]] * [[Brunei]]
==Causes==
The 1997 Southeast Asian haze was caused mainly by [[slash-and-burn]] techniques adopted by farmers in Indonesia.<ref>[http://haze.asean.org/docs/1272361130/Jambi%2BCollaboration%2BBooklet_English%2B(reduced).pdf/view&sa=U&ei=wAXjT7rbA8btrQfmh4i4Aw&ved=0CB8QFjAG&usg=AFQjCNESJ5UpfPRVFGOxrRzEFf-LTVQiyg Jambi Collaboration Booklet_English (reduced).pdf - Asean]{{dead link|date=May 2016}}</ref> Slash and burn has been extensively used for many years as the cheapest and easiest means to clear the lands for traditional agriculture.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ecologyandsociety.org/vol9/iss1/art15/ |title=The Role of Fire in Changing Land Use and Livelihoods in Riau-Sumatra |publisher= |date= |accessdate=2016-05-11}}</ref> Fire is also used during the long fallow rotation of the so-called jungle rubber in Sumatra and Kalimantan to remove most of the [[biomass]], including the woody parts before new plantations are re-established.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldagroforestry.org/sea/Publications/files/journal/JA0132-04.pdf |title=Farmers' perspectives on slash-and-burn as a land clearing method for small-scale rubber producers in Sepunggur, Jambi Province, Sumatra, Indonesia |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2016-05-11}}</ref>
Fire may also be deliberately used as a weapon to claim property on the islands and provinces where land ownership is not clear, an action taken by both smallholders and large operators alike. After burning out its previous owner, the smallholder or large operator plants their own crops there, gaining de facto control over the disputed land {{Citation needed|date=April 2010}}.
During the dry season, dry fuels readily ignite and lead to large wildfires, and due to the [[1997–98 El Niño event]], the dry season in Southeast Asia was even drier than normal. These accidental fires may have the same underlying socio-economic and institutional problems. In cases like this, fire suppression can be very difficult and costly especially when they reach the highly flammable peat-swamp areas.
==Effects== [[Atmospheric particulate matter]] was the form of air pollutant that predominantly contributed to the haze and degradation in ambient air quality standards during this crisis. In all countries affected by the smoke [[haze]], an increase of acute health outcomes was observed. Health effects; included emergency room visits due to respiratory symptoms such as [[asthma]], [[upper respiratory infection]], decreased lung function as well as eye and skin irritation, were caused mainly by this [[granular material|particulate matter]]. In Singapore, for instance, health surveillance showed a 30% increase in hospital attendance due to air quality related symptoms. Generally, children and the elderly, as well as those with pre-existing respiratory and [[cardiac disease]]s were the most susceptible to adverse health outcomes from the [[haze]] exposure. The smoke haze episode has added to the urban and industrial air pollution in [[Southeast Asia]], causing it to reach alarming levels in many metropolitan areas.
By scattering and absorbing light, the fire-related particulate also resulted in reduced [[visibility]]; impairing transportation by air, land and water and seriously affecting the economies of Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore. Among the economic sectors affected most were air, land and sea transportation, construction, tourism and agricultural industries. [[EEPSEA]]/[[World Wide Fund for Nature|WWF]] roughly estimated the economic value of the damages caused by the 1997 fires and haze. They estimated one billion US$ from haze-related damages for Indonesia only. The damages to Malaysia and Singapore are figured at 0.4 billion US$. Including the fire related damages, the total damages are estimated to amount to 4.5 billion US$. However, a variety of the damages such as decreased quality of life, loss of biodiversity and atmospheric impacts are difficult to establish.
Fire-related smoke haze episodes also reveal a social component: a large part of the population in Southeast Asia do not have the financial means to buy protective measures such as respiratory masks and air conditioning, nor are they able to refrain from outdoor work when air pollution is high.

{{EngvarB|date=April 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2016}}
[[File:TOMS indonesia smog lrg.jpg|thumb|350px|Air pollution over Southeast Asia in October 1997.]] The '''1997 group of [[forest fire]]s in [[Indonesia]]''' that lasted well into 1998 were probably among the two or three, if not ''the'' largest, forest fires group in the last two centuries of recorded history.
In the middle of 1997 forest fires burning in Indonesia began to affect neighbouring countries, spreading thick clouds of smoke and haze to [[Malaysia]] and [[Singapore]]. Then Malaysian Prime Minister [[Mahathir bin Mohamad]] searched desperately for a solution,<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1309&dat=19971108&id=cLBOAAAAIBAJ&sjid=MRUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5399,1353 New Straits Times - Nov 8, 1997]</ref> and based on a plan by the head of the Malaysian fire and rescue department sent a team of Malaysian firefighters across to Indonesia under code name [[Operation Haze]]. This is to mitigate the effect of the Haze to Malaysia economy. The value of the Haze damage to Malaysian GDP is estimated to be 0.30 per cent.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=eMBu_rXSq3QC&pg=PA44&lpg=PA44&dq=operation+haze+malaysia&source=bl&ots=IOY8RfxPyk&sig=kXuKaptYi5e1PUzEYjv_IZjfhnU&hl=en&sa=X&ei=VQp3T5_nHMHirAfioMSuDQ&ved=0CDQQ6AEwAzgU#v=onepage&q=operation%20haze%20malaysia&f=false Indonesia's Fires and Haze: The Cost of Catastrophe By David Glover, Timothy Jessup, page 46]</ref>
Seasonal rains in early December brought a brief respite but soon after the dry conditions and fires returned. By 1998 [[Brunei]] and to a lesser extent [[Thailand]], [[Vietnam]] and the [[Philippines]] had also felt the haze from the [[smoke]] of the forest fires. By the time the 1997-98 forest fires were finally over some 8 million hectares of land had burned while countless millions of people suffered from air pollution.
== Causes and effect == The 1997 Indonesian forest fires were caused by changing land use which made the tropical forest vulnerable to fire during a drought associated with that year's [[El Niño]]. Indonesian forests have historically been resistant to burning even during long dry seasons and despite the use of fire to clear land for [[Slash-and-burn|swidden]] agriculture. The land use changes that led to the fires were a combination of industrial-scale logging, draining peatlands for conversion to oil palm and fast-growing tree plantations, and a massive government program to drain swamps and convert them to rice paddies.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Why_Forests_Why_Now.html?id=WWx6rgEACAAJ|title=Why Forests? Why Now?: The Science, Economics, and Politics of Tropical Forests and Climate Change|last=Seymour|first=Frances|last2=Busch|first2=Jonah|date=2016|publisher=Center for Global Development|year=|isbn=9781933286853|location=|pages=|language=en}}</ref> A total of 240 people perished in the wildfires.<ref name="Worst Wildfires">{{cite web |title=Capter 3 It Only Takes A Spark: The Hazard of Wildfires |url=https://www.brookings.edu/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/ND-Review-Chapter-3.pdf |publisher=Brookings.edu |accessdate=24 July 2018}}</ref>
== Estimated cost == The total economic value of the damages are conservatively estimated to be US$4.47 billion, of which by far the largest share was borne by Indonesia.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=eMBu_rXSq3QC&oi=fnd&pg=PR5&dq=1997+indonesia+forest+fire+causes&ots=IQXaWoxOuq&sig=x0CIVO5azr4Wj0hSzuBBGrdBTSg#v=onepage&q=1997%20indonesia%20forest%20fire%20causes&f=false|title=Indonesia's Fires and Haze: The Cost of Catastrophe|last=Glover|first=David|date=2006|publisher=IDRC|isbn=9781552503324|language=en}}</ref> This figure excludes a number of damages that are especially difficult to measure or to value in monetary terms, such as loss of human life, long term health impacts, and some biodiversity losses.
Forest fires in Indonesia in 1997 were estimated to have released between 0.81 and 2.57 gigatonnes of carbon into the atmosphere, which is between 13-40% of the annual [[carbon dioxide]] emissions from burning [[fossil fuels]].,<ref>''[http://climate.ncas.ac.uk/people/allan/Seasonal_Forecasting_papers/harrison_09_global_impact_indonesian_forest_fires.pdf The global impact of Indonesian forest fires]'', Mark E Harrison, Susan E Page, and Suwido H Limin, [[Biologist]], Volume 56 Number 3, August 2009</ref><ref>''[http://www.monitor.net/monitor/0211a/rainfire2.html Indonesia Rainforest Fires Doubled CO2 Levels Globally]{{Dead link|date=February 2019 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}'', Cat Lazaroff, [[Albion Monitor]], 5 November 2002</ref>
As part of steps taken to avoid the recurring of the Haze, the [[Association of Southeast Asian Nations]] (ASEAN) approved the need for an early warning system in the Regional Haze Action Plan (RHAP) in 1998 to prevent forest fires and the resulting haze through improved management policies and enforcements, example via Fire Danger Rating System (FDRS)<ref>[http://www.wamis.org/agm/meetings/wofire08/S2-Zaki_Malaysia.pdf OPERATIONAL FDR IN MALAYSIA AND ASSOCIATION OF SOUTHEAST ASIA NATIONS]</ref>
==Countries affected== * {{flag|Indonesia}} * {{flag|Singapore}} * {{flag|Malaysia}} * {{flag|Thailand}} * {{flag|Brunei}} * {{flag|Vietnam}}

{{Infobox power station | name = Mishraq Sulphur Plant | name_official = مصنع الكبريت المشراق (Arabic) | image = | image_size = | image_caption = | image_alt = | location_map = | location_map_size = | location_map_caption = | location_map_alt = | coordinates = <!-- {{coord| | |region:??_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} --> | country = [[Iraq]] | location = [[Qayyarah subdistrict]], [[Nineveh Governorate]] | status = Operational | construction_began = | commissioned = | decommissioned = | cost = | owner = [[Ministry of Industry and Minerals (Iraq)|Ministry of Industry and Minerals]] | operator = Mishraq Sulphur State Company <!------------------------- GENERAL --> | ps_units_operational = | ps_units_manu_model = | ps_units_uc = | ps_units_planned = | ps_units_cancelled = | ps_units_decommissioned= | ps_thermal_capacity = | ps_electrical_capacity = | ps_electrical_cap_fac = | ps_storage_hours = | ps_annual_generation = | ps_annual_gen_year = | website = {{URL|www.mishraq.industry.gov.iq}} | extra = }} '''Al-Mishraq,''' or '''Mishraq Sulphur State Company,''' is a state run [[sulfur]] plant near [[Mosul]], [[Iraq]].
It has twice been set alight and burned for prolonged periods. In 2003, what is thought to have been a deliberately started fire, burned for about three weeks, resulting in the largest human-made release of [[sulfur dioxide]] ever recorded. In 2016 it was set alight by [[ISIL]] and burned for seven days.
==Fires== In June 2003, it was the site of the largest human-made release of [[sulfur dioxide]] ever recorded when a fire (thought to have been deliberately started) gained control and burned for about three weeks.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/3955005.stm|title=Iraq sulphur fire breaks records|date=26 October 2004|work=[[BBC Online]]|accessdate=14 February 2012}}</ref> At its height, the fire was putting 21,000 tons of sulfur dioxide a day into the atmosphere. The pollution in [[Mosul]], which is about 45 kilometres from Mishraq, reached a catastrophic level. For over 48 hours the white smoke from sulfur dioxide could be seen in the air. Many people were taken into hospitals and most vegetation was killed.
On 22 October 2016 the plant was set alight by [[ISIL]] militants as part of the [[Battle of Mosul (2016)|Battle of Mosul]]. Two civilians died and nearly 1,000 people were treated for toxic gas inhalation.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mosul battle: Hundreds treated over toxic fumes in Iraq|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-37738667|accessdate=22 October 2016|publisher=BBC News|date=22 October 2016}}</ref> Shifting winds sent the gas to [[Qayyarah Airfield West]], where U.S. and coalition forces were forced to use gas masks.<ref name="abc1022">{{cite news|title=The Latest: Abadi: Kirkuk Nearly Secured After IS Attack|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/latest-iraqi-army-launches-push-town-mosul-42982676|accessdate=22 October 2016|publisher=ABC News|date=22 October 2016}}</ref> The total mass of the released sulfur dioxide was estimated to approximately 161,000 tons distributed over seven days, equivalent to a small volcanic eruption.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Björnham |first1=0.|last2=Grahn |first2=H.|last3=von Schoenberg |first3=P.|last4=Liljedahl |first4=B.|last5=Waleij |first5=A.|last6=Brännström |first6=N. |title=The 2016 Al-Mishraq sulphur plant fire: Source and health risk area estimation|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1352231017306167 |date=September 2017|journal=Atmospheric Environment|volume=169 |page=287–296| doi=10.1016/j.atmosenv.2017.09.025 }}</ref><ref name=“veconomist” >{{cite news|author=|title=It will take years to clear up the rubble in the Middle East|url=https://www.economist.com/news/middle-east-and-africa/21730166-want-shovel-it-will-take-years-clear-up-rubble-middle-east|work=[[The Economist]]|date=12 October 2017}}</ref>
