===Indonesia=== In [[Pekanbaru]], capital of [[Riau]] province, where the majority of hotspots were located, visibility dropped and a number of Pekanbaru residents complained that the haze was affecting their health,{{cite news|title=Haze continues blanketing Pekanbaru|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2009/06/23/haze-continues-blanketing-pekanbaru.html|accessdate=22 June 2013|website=The Jakarta Post|date=21 June 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140202125926/http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2009/06/23/haze-continues-blanketing-pekanbaru.html|archive-date=2 February 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} and [[Sultan Syarif Kasim II Airport]] had to be closed for several hours, causing several flights to be diverted to nearby airports such as [[Polonia International Airport]], [[Medan]] or to [[Kuala Lumpur]], Malaysia.{{cite news|title=Pekanbaru's airport shut down due to thick haze|url=http://www.antaranews.com/en/news/89465/pekanbarus-airport-shut-down-due-to-thick-haze|accessdate=22 June 2013|website=Antara News|date=20 June 2013}} Flights to and from [[Pinang Kampai Airport]] of [[Dumai]] were also suspended by the authorities because of poor visibility. While much of the press focused on the haze's impact in Singapore and Malaysia, the local residents of Riau were also affected. Residents fled their homes in Bengkalis, with about 30% experiencing respiratory problems. The fires burned through hectares of local farmland, decimating the season's crops.{{cite news|title=Why Indonesia Can Only Wait for Rain as Riau Burns and Singapore Chokes|url=http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/news/why-indonesia-can-only-wait-for-rain-as-riau-burns-and-singapore-chokes/|accessdate=22 June 2013|website=The Jakarta Globe|date=21 June 2013}} The PSI in [[Dumai]] hit 492 on the morning of 21 June 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/breaking-news/se-asia/story/haze-update-dumai-psi-reaches-491-friday-morning-20130621|title=Haze update: In Dumai, PSI reaches 491 on Friday morning|date=21 June 2013|accessdate=22 June 2013}} However, because of the wind patterns, most parts of Indonesia were not hit by the haze. Earlier on 22 June, Indonesian government blamed eight companies, including Jakarta-based [[Sinar Mas Group|PT Sinar Mas Agro Resources and Technology]] (SMART) and [[Asia Pacific Resources International Holdings|Asia Pacific Resources International]] (APRIL), for the fires.{{cite news|title=Indonesian fires worsen, Singapore smog sets record|url=http://sg.news.yahoo.com/indonesian-fires-worsen-singapore-smog-sets-record-133942173.html|author=Kanupriya Kapoor and Michael Taylor|accessdate=22 June 2013|publisher=Reuters|website=Yahoo News Singapore|date=22 June 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130624100329/http://sg.news.yahoo.com/indonesian-fires-worsen-singapore-smog-sets-record-133942173.html|archive-date=24 June 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} Later on 22 June, Environment Minister Balthasar Kambuaya revealed that at least 20 plantation companies operating in Riau were suspected to have caused land and forest fires, of which 8 were Malaysian: PT Langgam Inti Hiberida, PT Bumi Rakksa Sejati, PT Tunggal Mitra Plantation, PT Udaya Loh Dinawi, PT Adei Plantation, PT Jatim Jaya Perkasa, PT Multi Gambut Industri and PT Mustika Agro Lestari.{{cite news|title=Malaysian firms suspected to have sent haze home|url=http://www.antaranews.com/en/news/89491/malaysian-firms-suspected-to-have-sent-haze-home|author=Andi Abdussalam|accessdate=23 June 2013|publisher=Antara|website=Antara|date=23 June 2013}} However, following a meeting in Indonesia between Balthasar and Palanivel, only four of the companies were from Malaysia and the companies had denied any involvement in the fires.{{cite news|title=Haze: Malaysia, Indonesia agree to work together to overcome haze problem|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2013/6/27/nation/20130627165730&sec=nation|accessdate=27 June 2013|publisher=The Star|date=27 June 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130627173844/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2013%2F6%2F27%2Fnation%2F20130627165730&sec=nation|archive-date=27 June 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} Other local companies detected were PT Siak Seraya, PT Kimia Tirta Utama, PT Inti Indo Sawit Subur, Village Unit Cooperatives (KUD) Dayus Mas, PT Padasa Enam Utama, PT Kartayatam Bhakti Mulia, PT Langgam Inti Hibrindo, PT Riau Sakti Trans, PT Raja Garuda Masa Sejati, PT Sabira Negeri Utama, PT Guntung Hasrat Makmur, PT Panca Surya Agrindo, PT Bumi Reksa Nusa Sejati, PT Surya Bratasena Plantation, PT Adei Crumb Rubber, PT Rokan Adi Raya, Cooperatives 13 Anak Suku Bonai, PT Karyatama Bhakti Muli and PT Agroraya Gematrans. On the morning of 24 June, the haze shrouded [[Pekanbaru]], the provincial capital of [[Riau]]. The [[Pollutant Standards Index|PSI]] in Pekanbaru had been hovering around the moderate reading of 100 the previous week, but it rose to an unhealthy reading of 140 on the night of 23 June 2013. The same morning, several commercial flights at Syarif Kasim II Airport were delayed before takeoff by poor visibility caused by the haze.{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/breaking-news/se-asia/story/haze-update-haze-covers-pekanbaru-despite-efforts-douse-fires-20130624|title=Haze update: Haze covers Pekanbaru despite efforts to douse fires|publisher=The Straits Times|date=24 June 2013|accessdate=24 June 2013}} In Dumai, one of the worst-affected regencies in Riau, visibility was reduced to less than 500m after the PSI hit a hazardous record of 900. This was the highest in any haze crisis and three times above the minimum "Hazardous" level. On 25 June, eight Indonesian farmers were arrested for creating fires that set in motion the blazes.{{cite web|url=http://investvine.com/eight-indonesians-arrested-as-singapore-haze-creeps-back-join-the-discussion/|title=Eight Indonesians arrested as Singapore haze creeps back – Join the discussion|first=Justin|last=Calderon|work=Inside Investor|date=27 June 2013|accessdate=27 June 2013}} The number increased to 23 on 1 July, after another six farmers were arrested for carrying out illegal slash-and-burn activities. Indonesia said that it would ratify the 2002 ASEAN Agreement on Transboundary Haze Pollution as soon as possible. Indonesia's Environment Minister, Balthasar Kambuaya, emphasised the importance of ratifying the agreement, saying that Indonesia should be concerned about the impact of the haze on its own people, and also the well-being of people in neighbouring countries affected by the haze. As of 6 July 2013, Indonesia had yet to ratify the pact.{{cite news | title=Jakarta moves to ratify Asean haze pact | work=The Straits Times | date=5 July 2013 | agency=Singapore Press Holdings }} On 21 July, thick haze blanketed Dumai again because of the sudden increase in the number of hotspots, with visibility at street level dropping to below 200m. On 22 July, many parts of Riau recorded hazardous PSI readings. The worst reading, 619, was recorded in [[Rumbai]], north of Pekanbaru, the provincial capital of Riau. Since then, the air quality in Riau has been worsening. Flights to and from Pekanbaru were delayed because of the deteriorating visibility. ====Measures taken==== The Indonesian government used weather-changing technology to create [[Cloud seeding|artificial rain]] and extinguish raging fires.{{cite news|title=Forestry Ministry Looks to Cloud-Seeding to Douse Forest Fires Raging in Sumatra|url=http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/news/forestry-ministry-looks-to-cloud-seeding-to-douse-forest-fires-raging-in-sumatra-2/|accessdate=22 June 2013|website=The Jakarta Globe|date=21 June 2013}} It earmarked around 200 billion rupiah (around US$20M, S$25.6M at the time) to handle the disaster and deployed seven military aircraft for water bombings and cloud-seeding to fight raging forest fires on 21 June 2013. In June alone, more than 3000 soldiers, marines and air force officers were deployed to help fight the fires.{{cite web | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-07-23/indonesia-prepares-cloud-seeding-as-haze-returns.html | title=Indonesia Prepares Cloud Seeding as Haze Returns | publisher=Bloomberg | date=24 July 2013 | accessdate=25 July 2013}} The Agriculture Minister [[Suswono]] stated that an investigation has been launched to find the firms responsible for the air pollution, and agreed to publish the names of the firms if they were proven guilty.{{cite news|title=Indonesia to punish firm burning forest|url=http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/90777/8293264.html|accessdate=22 June 2013|website=People's Daily|date=21 June 2013}} Forestry Minister Zulkifli Hasan said the government would not tolerate companies burning land and bushes that caused the haze shrouding Riau and its surroundings. Companies which are proved to have used slash-and-burn to clear land would be acted upon firmly. The government assigned the [[Indonesian National Police|National Police]] to handle the legal process and make sanctions against firms behind forest fires. At dawn on 23 June, rain fell for 30 minutes in [[Dumai]], the coastal city nearest to many of the hotspots, as a result of cloud-seeding. Rain fell on Dumai again at 5pm on the same day, after a Hercules C-130 jet commenced cloud-seeding in the Bengkalis district as well as Dumai at 2pm. However, not much rain fell.{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/malaysia-suffocated-by/722232.html|title=Malaysia suffocated by haze|publisher=Channel NewsAsia|date=24 June 2013|accessdate=24 June 2013}} First Lieutenant Fajar Gusthana, one of those who did the cloud-seeding, said that it was difficult as there were very few clouds, and the clouds were generally quite thin. He also said that there were no clouds directly above the hotspots, which made it harder for them to carry out the cloud-seeding.{{cite news|title=Rain-inducing efforts bring some relief to Riau|work=The Straits Times|date=24 June 2013|agency=Singapore Press Holdings |page=A12}} On 27 June, Indonesia said that it would start larger scale water-bombing in one week. Indonesia planned to do this with the help of rented Russian Kamov helicopters with belly tanks that could carry 8,000 litres of water, compared with Indonesian helicopters carrying 500 litres.{{cite news | title=Jakarta to step up water bombing | work=The Straits Times | date=28 June 2013 | agency=Singapore Press Holdings }} Indonesia switched into preventive mode on 1 July, after it had successfully put out most of the fires, although fires were still raging underground in the [[peatland]]. To enable itself to respond faster and extinguish the fires before they got out of control again, Indonesia increased night patrols. Water-bombing and cloud-seeding aircraft were placed on standby. Indonesia has said that the standby aircraft should be able to respond quickly to the fires and fly out immediately to [[Jambi]], [[South Sumatra]], and [[Lampung]] in [[Sumatra]], as well as four provinces in [[Kalimantan]] on [[Borneo]]. Indonesia's National Disaster Management Agency spokesman Dr Agus Wibowo said that Indonesia expects fires to affect seven other provinces as well, as the dry season was not at its peak yet and was expected to continue until October. As of 21 July, there were four helicopters and an aeroplane on standby in Riau, so that fires could be put out using cloud seeding and water bombing.{{cite web | url=http://www.thestar.com.my/News/Regional/2013/07/21/Clear-skies-in-Dumai-but-for-how-long.aspx | title=Clear skies in Dumai, but for how long? | publisher=The Star Online | date=21 July 2013 | accessdate=23 July 2013}} A statement from Indonesia's disaster management agency on 22 July said that there were a total of 6 aeroplanes on standby for cloud seeding, while soldiers were also placed on standby to help fight any fires that occurred. Indonesia began cloud-seeding and water bombing over Riau on 22 July, to reduce the number of hotspots which had risen sharply over the prior weekend and caused the haze to return to Malaysia. More than 370 firefighters were deployed to fight the fires, with 3 helicopters used for water bombing.{{cite web | url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/s-pore-expresses-concern/752494.html | title=S'pore expresses concern to Indonesia as hotspots in Sumatra rise | publisher=Channel NewsAsia | date=22 July 2013 | accessdate=23 July 2013}} In Pekanbaru, the provincial capital of Riau, there were more than 22 water-bombing operations carried out. However, there was only one cloud-seeding operation conducted, as there were insufficient clouds over Pekanbaru to make rain. Willem Rampangilei, a deputy minister at the Coordinating Ministry for People's Welfare, said that the provincial government had already tried its best to fight the fires, but the number of hotspots remained about the same. He also said that following the failure to decrease the number of hotspots significantly, Jakarta would send more troops to fight the fires. On 24 July, planes conducted cloud seeding operations, to reduce the haze which had shrouded Riau and the Straits of Malacca for the past few days. On 8 January 2014, the Meulaboh district court on Sumatra island ruled that Indonesian company Kallista Alam had illegally burnt vegetation on 1,000 hectares (2,500 acres) of peatland in Aceh province to clear it for a palm oil plantation. In the civil case brought by the Ministry of Environment, the court ordered the company to pay 114.3 billion rupiah (S$9.4 million) in losses to the state and 252 billion rupiah to rehabilitate the land it destroyed.{{cite web | url=http://news.xin.msn.com/en/regional/indonesia/indonesian-palm-oil-firm-to-pay-losses-in-historic-ruling-1 | title=Indonesian palm oil firm to pay losses in 'historic' ruling | publisher=Agence France-Presse | date=9 January 2014 | accessdate=20 January 2014}} ===Malaysia=== ====Peninsular Malaysia==== {{multiple image |direction = horizontal |width = 220 |footer = |image1 = Center of Kuala Lumpur looking south on 9 May 2013.jpg |alt1 = |caption1 = Centre of Kuala Lumpur looking south on 9 May 2013. |image2 = Center of Kuala Lumpur looking south on 23 June 2013.jpg |alt2 = |caption2 = Centre of Kuala Lumpur looking south on 23 June 2013. }} The haze that affected Malaysia was the worst since 2005, starting with the [[Air Pollution Index|Air Pollution Index (API)]] hitting 172 on 19 June.{{cite news|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/searealtime/2013/06/18/haze-shrouds-singapore-malaysia/|title=Haze Shrouds Singapore, Malaysia|accessdate=19 June 2013|newspaper=Online Wall Street Journal|date=18 June 2013}} On 17 June, there were only two areas recording unhealthy API values, a reduction from six areas on 16 June.{{cite news|url=http://www.utusan.com.my/utusan/Dalam_Negeri/20130618/dn_12/Hanya-dua-kawasan-bacaan-IPU-tidak-sihat|title=Hanya dua kawasan bacaan IPU tidak sihat|language=Malay|accessdate=19 June 2013|newspaper=Utusan Malaysia|date=18 June 2013}}{{cite news|url=http://www.utusan.com.my/utusan/Dalam_Negeri/20130617/dn_10/Enam-kawasan-catat-IPU-tidak-sihat|title=Enam kawasan catat IPU tidak sihat|language=Malay|accessdate=19 June 2013|newspaper=Utusan Malaysia|date=17 June 2013}} According to the Malaysian Department of Environment, the two areas were [[Kemaman]], [[Terengganu]] (118) and Balok Baru, [[Kuantan]], [[Pahang]] (110). On 19 June, API readings at 5 p.m. by the Malaysian Department of Environment showed that [[Johor]] and [[Malacca]] were the two states worst affected by the haze. The highest reading in Johor was 172, recorded in [[Muar District|Muar]], while that of Malacca was 161, recorded in the state capital, [[Malacca City]].{{cite web|url=http://www.doe.gov.my/apims/index.php?gmap=load&date=2013-06-19|title=API readings by Malaysian Department of Environment: 19 June 2013|publisher=Malaysian Department of Environment|accessdate=19 June 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130621100428/http://www.doe.gov.my/apims/index.php?gmap=load&date=2013-06-19|archive-date=21 June 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} On 20 June, the haze in Malaysia worsened. Johor and Malacca remained the worst-affected states. In Johor, Muar recorded a hazardous reading (383) at 11 a.m., which was one of the worst among the readings. [[Kota Tinggi]] was the second worst, hitting a ''Very unhealthy'' reading of 232. In Malacca, an [[API]] reading of 137 was recorded in Malacca City exceeding the ''Unhealthy'' API. Readings in other parts of Malaysia ranged from ''Good'' to ''Unhealthy''.{{cite web|url=http://www.doe.gov.my/apims/index.php?gmap=load&date=2013-06-20|title=API readings by Malaysian Department of Environment: 20 June 2013|date=20 June 2013|accessdate=20 June 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100728052404/http://www.doe.gov.my/apims/index.php?gmap=load|archive-date=28 July 2010|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} A day later, the Malaysian Meteorological Department predicted that the haze would not dissipate until 26 June, when tropical storm Bebinca was expected to be blown from the southwest, bringing strong winds and dry weather to carry the smog from Sumatra over to West Malaysia. The Johor State Health Department reported the number of citizens with upper respiratory tract ailments increased by at least 21%.{{cite web|title=HAZE UPDATE: Kota Tinggi, Pasir Gudang still at hazardous level|url=http://www.nst.com.my/latest/font-color-red-haze-update-font-kota-tinggi-pasir-gudang-still-at-hazardous-level-1.304686|publisher=New Straits Times|date=21 June 2013|accessdate=21 June 2013}} On 23 June, the [[Air Pollution Index|Air Pollution Index (API)]] in Muar, Johor spiked to 746 at 7 a.m. which was almost 2.5 times the lower end of the ''Hazardous'' level thus resulting in the declaration of a state of emergency in Muar and Ledang (which was afterwards lifted on 25 June in the morning), leaving the towns in virtual shutdown. It was also almost 450 more than the minimum range of the ''Hazardous'' level. On 24 June, shifting winds blew the haze northwards away from Johor and Singapore, towards [[Malacca]], [[Selangor]], [[Negeri Sembilan]], [[Perak]] and [[Penang]]. The haze also blanketed the east coast, especially the states of [[Pahang]], [[Terengganu]], and [[Kelantan]]. Air quality in central and northern Peninsula Malaysia was also worsening. [[Kuala Lumpur]] recorded an ''Unhealthy'' API of 198 at 11 a.m. indicating the first reading in KL to be on the cusp of entering the ''Very unhealthy'' range in the haze season. [[Port Dickson]] was the worst hit by the haze, with the API entering the ''Hazardous'' range with a reading of 335 at 7 a.m., although the figure decreased to a ''Very unhealthy'' reading of 292 at 11 a.m.{{cite web|url=http://www.doe.gov.my/apims/index.php?gmap=load&date=2013-06-24|title=API readings by Malaysian Department of Environment: 24 June 2013|publisher=Malaysia Department of Environment|date=24 June 2013|accessdate=24 June 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100728052404/http://www.doe.gov.my/apims/index.php?gmap=load|archive-date=28 July 2010|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} Even though the haze had cleared off a bit in the southern parts of the nation, [[Port Klang]] recorded a ''Very unhealthy'' series of API values which reached the ''Hazardous'' range with a reading of 487 in the morning of 25 June. The drifting smoke from the south also caused other places in Selangor and Kuala Lumpur to be blanketed by thick smog, resulting in the API coming very close to entering the ''Hazardous'' level. [[Seri Manjung]] in Perak which is 200 km away from Port Klang was also hit hard by the haze.[http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/now-its-haze-choking-port-klang-at-487/ "Now, the haze is choking Port Klang at 487"], ''[[The Malaysian Insider]]'', Malaysia. 25 June 2013. Visibility remained poor in Kuala Lumpur and several other states. Malaysians were able to breathe easier when the overnight rain in numerous parts of the west coast helped to clear the skies. There was a significant drop in the API values in most areas, including Port Klang since 26 June.{{cite web|url=http://www.nst.com.my/latest/font-color-red-haze-update-font-api-improving-in-selangor-1.308170|title=HAZE UPDATE: API improving in Selangor|work=[[New Straits Times]]|date=26 June 2013|accessdate=27 June 2013}} The haze crisis is believed to have claimed its first life, a diabetic woman from [[Muar District|Muar]] who was suffering from [[asthma]].{{cite web | url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/southeast-asia-haze/724966.html | title=Southeast Asia haze crisis eases as rain douses fires | date=26 June 2013 | accessdate=27 June 2013}} Another casualty was an elderly man, also from the same town. Both deaths were reported early in the week.{{cite web|url=http://www.ntv7.com.my/7edition/local-en/HAZE_WOES_HAZE_CLAIMS_TWO_VICTIMS_SAYS_CHINA_PRESS.html|title=HAZE WOES : HAZE CLAIMS TWO VICTIMS, SAYS CHINA PRESS|date=26 June 2013|accessdate=27 June 2013|work=[[NTV7]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130917083903/http://www.ntv7.com.my/7edition/local-en/HAZE_WOES_HAZE_CLAIMS_TWO_VICTIMS_SAYS_CHINA_PRESS.html|archive-date=17 September 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} On 29 June, the improvement in API readings continued, with the PSI readings hovering in the ''Good'' and ''Moderate'' ranges. At 5pm, the worst PSI readings were in the ''Moderate'' range, recorded in [[Kota Tinggi]] and [[Bukit Rambai]], at 81 and 86 respectively. On 21 July, the haze blanketed certain states of Malaysia yet again. Some parts of Selangor, Negeri Sembilan, and Malacca were hit with API readings in the higher part of the ''Moderate'' range. Bukit Rambai, in the state of Malacca, was worst hit. At 12am, a moderate API reading of 94 was recorded. The reading then continued to escalate, hitting right at the very end of the ''Moderate'' range (100) at 7am, and entered the ''Unhealthy'' range an hour later. The air quality in Bukit Rambai continued to worsen, and the highest API value of the day, 118, was recorded at 8pm and 9pm. It began to subside at 10pm.{{cite web | url=http://apims.doe.gov.my/apims/hourly1.php?date=2013-07-21 | title=API readings: 21 July 2013 from 12am to 5am | publisher=Malaysian Department of Environment | date=21 July 2013 | accessdate=21 July 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130726133637/http://apims.doe.gov.my/apims/hourly1.php?date=2013-07-21 | archive-date=26 July 2013 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }}{{cite web | url=http://apims.doe.gov.my/apims/hourly2.php?date=2013-07-21 | title=API readings: 21 July 2013 from 6am to 11am | publisher=Malaysian Department of Environment | date=21 July 2013 | accessdate=21 July 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714182103/http://apims.doe.gov.my/apims/hourly2.php?date=2013-07-21 | archive-date=14 July 2014 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }}{{cite web | url=http://apims.doe.gov.my/apims/hourly3.php?date=2013-07-21 | title=API readings: 21 July 2013 from 12pm to 5pm | publisher=Malaysian Department of Environment | date=21 July 2013 | accessdate=21 July 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714134900/http://apims.doe.gov.my/apims/hourly3.php?date=2013-07-21 | archive-date=14 July 2014 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }}{{cite web | url=http://apims.doe.gov.my/apims/hourly4.php?date=2013-07-21 | title=API readings: 21 July 2013 from 6pm to 11pm | publisher=Malaysian Department of Environment | date=21 July 2013 | accessdate=21 July 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714182851/http://apims.doe.gov.my/apims/hourly4.php?date=2013-07-21 | archive-date=14 July 2014 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }} On 22 July, the haze conditions in Selangor, Malacca and Negeri Sembilan worsened. Johor also got hit by the haze. Bukit Rambai remained the worst hit of all, with an unhealthy API of 135, the worst since the haze returned, recorded there. Muar, Malacca City, Banting, and Kuala Lumpur also recorded unhealthy readings.{{cite web | url=http://apims.doe.gov.my/apims/hourly3.php?date=2013-07-22 | title=API readings: 22 July 2013 from 12pm to 5pm | publisher=Malaysian Department of Environment | date=22 July 2013 | accessdate=22 July 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130725001921/http://apims.doe.gov.my/apims/hourly3.php?date=2013-07-22 | archive-date=25 July 2013 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }} On 23 July, the haze conditions changed again. At 8am, API readings in Port Klang was 105, 116 in Bukit Rambai and 115 in Muar. Visibility at several Malaysian airports was reduced by the haze, which travelled northwards to the northern states of [[Terengganu]], [[Kelantan]] and [[Penang]]. In Terengganu, visibility at the [[Sultan Mahmud Airport]] in [[Kuala Terengganu]] was reduced to 3 km in the evening, while visibility at [[Kerteh Airport]] was reduced to 6 km. In Penang, the [[Penang International Airport]] in [[Bayan Lepas]] also had visibility reduced to 6 km. However, in Kelantan, visibility at the [[Sultan Ismail Petra Airport]] in [[Kota Baru]] was at a safe 10 km. [[Petaling Jaya]] and [[Subang, Selangor|Subang]], both in Selangor, were also hit by poor visibility at around noon, but it gradually improved to reach 6 km and 9 km respectively.{{cite web | url=http://www.thestar.com.my/News/Nation/2013/07/24/Haze-continues-slow-spread-northwards-Several-states-experience-poor-visibility-levels.aspx | title=Haze continues slow spread northwards | publisher=The Star | date=24 July 2013 | accessdate=24 July 2013}} The haze was expected to ease over [[Johor]], [[Pahang]], [[Klang Valley]], Muar, Malacca City and [[Manjung]] on 25 July, where rain was expected. However, Kuala Lumpur, Petaling Jaya, Kuala Selangor, Putrajaya, Port Dickson would remain dry.{{cite web|url=http://www.todayonline.com/world/asia/haze-worsens-malaysia|title=Haze worsens in Malaysia|publisher=Today Online|date=23 July 2013|accessdate=23 July 2013}} On 24 July, Ipoh, Tanjung Malim, and Perai recorded unhealthy API levels in the afternoon, at 106 (4pm), 101 (5pm) and 102 (1pm and 2pm) respectively. API readings for the day were mostly moderate in Malaysia, although a few areas recorded good readings.{{cite web | url=http://apims.doe.gov.my/apims/hourly3.php?date=2013-07-25 | archive-url=https://archive.is/20130726144910/http://apims.doe.gov.my/apims/hourly3.php?date=2013-07-25 | dead-url=yes | archive-date=26 July 2013 | title=API readings: 25 July 2013 from 12pm to 5pm | publisher=Malaysian Department of Environment | date=25 July 2013 | accessdate=27 July 2013 }} On 25 July, the haze continued to be blown towards the northern parts of Malaysia. Air quality in most parts of Malaysia were in the ''Moderate'' range for the day. The worst hit areas were [[Ipoh]], the state capital of [[Perak]], and [[Seberang Jaya]], in [[Penang]], where unhealthy API levels were recorded in the afternoon. The highest API reading of the day, 106, was recorded in Ipoh at 4pm.{{cite web | url=http://apims.doe.gov.my/apims/hourly3.php?date=2013-07-25 | archive-url=https://archive.is/20130726144910/http://apims.doe.gov.my/apims/hourly3.php?date=2013-07-25 | dead-url=yes | archive-date=26 July 2013 | title=API readings: 25 July 2013 from 12pm to 5pm | publisher=Malaysian Department of Environment | date=25 July 2013 | accessdate=26 July 2013 }} On 26 July, Bukit Rambai (Malacca), Seri Manjung (Perak), Port Klang (Selangor) and Perai (Penang) were worst affected, with the highest API readings at 82 (11pm), 87 (12am), 84 (12am) and 87 (12am).{{cite web | url=http://apims.doe.gov.my/apims/hourly1.php?date=2013-07-26 | title=API readings: 26 July 2013 | publisher=Malaysian Department of Environment | date=26 July 2013 | accessdate=27 July 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130728160650/http://apims.doe.gov.my/apims/hourly1.php?date=2013-07-26 | archive-date=28 July 2013 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }} On 27 July, air quality in many parts of Malaysia returned to the ''Good'' range, although some remained in the ''Moderate'' range. From 12am to 5am, most of the API readings were in the lower part of the ''Moderate'' range. However, Bukit Rambai, Seri Manjung, Port Klang and Ipoh remained the worst affected areas, with a highest API reading of 83 (multiple times in the morning), 79 (2am and 3am) and 78 (2am and 3am) respectively. Ipoh's API almost entered the ''Unhealthy'' range, recording the worst reading of the day, 99, at 3pm. This was only one point away from the "Unhealthy" range, in which even the slightest increase could result in the entering of the "Unhealthy" range.{{cite web | url=http://apims.doe.gov.my/apims/hourly1.php?date=2013-07-27 | title=API readings: 27 July 2013 from 12am to 5am | publisher=Malaysian Department of Environment | date=27 July 2013 | accessdate=27 July 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130728160809/http://apims.doe.gov.my/apims/hourly1.php?date=2013-07-27 | archive-date=28 July 2013 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }} On 28 July, air quality remained in the ''Moderate'' range in many parts of Malaysia during the day, although most areas recorded good readings in the early morning. Bukit Rambai's air quality remained in the ''Moderate'' range for the whole day. Its worst reading was 82, recorded at 10pm and 11pm. In Negeri Sembilan, [[Seremban]] was worst-affected, recording a moderate 84 at 4pm. Ipoh's worst reading was a moderate 92, also at 4pm. Selangor, which included the capital state of [[Wilayah Persekutuan]], was worst-hit. [[Petaling Jaya]], [[Putrajaya]], and the [[Cheras, Kuala Lumpur|Cheras]] area of [[Kuala Lumpur]] all recorded unhealthy API levels. Cheras was worst affected, with air quality remaining unhealthy from 2pm to 6pm. Its highest reading, 139, was recorded at 5pm, the worst reading of the day in Malaysia. Petaling Jaya's air quality was unhealthy from 3 to 4pm, recording 105 at 3pm. Putrajaya only breached the 100 mark for an hour, recording 101 at 5pm.{{cite web | url=http://apims.doe.gov.my/apims/hourly1.php?date=2013-07-28 | title=API readings: 28 July 2013 | publisher=Malaysian Department of Environment | date=28 July 2013 | accessdate=28 July 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140413130320/http://apims.doe.gov.my/apims/hourly1.php?date=2013-07-28 | archive-date=13 April 2014 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }} On 29 July, Bukit Rambai, Seremban, Banting, Port Klang, Kuala Lumpur, Petaling Jaya and [[Shah Alam]] were worst hit. Excluding KL, their worst readings were 84 (11pm), 95 (4pm), 82 (10pm), 92 (11pm), 81 (10–11pm) and 80 (11pm). The Batu Muda area of KL recorded its worst reading of 83 from 2pm to 6pm. The Cheras area of KL recorded readings in the lower part of the ''Moderate'' range for most part of the day, but was the only place to breach the ''Unhealthy'' range, when an API reading of 102 was recorded at 1pm.{{cite web | url=http://apims.doe.gov.my/apims/hourly1.php?date=2013-07-29 | archive-url=https://archive.is/20130730105154/http://apims.doe.gov.my/apims/hourly1.php?date=2013-07-29 | dead-url=yes | archive-date=30 July 2013 | title=API readings: 29 July 2013 | publisher=Malaysian Department of Environment | date=29 July 2013 | accessdate=30 July 2013 }} On 30 July, Bukit Rambai was worst affected, with the API constantly remaining in the 80s. Its worst reading was 85, recorded at 12am. [[Tanjung Malim]] recorded 81 at 3pm, after a sudden spike from a good 48 the previous hour, although it dropped to 52 at 4pm. Port Klang recorded the worst reading of the day, 92, at 12am. However, air quality in the other badly affected areas of the previous day improved.{{cite web | url=http://apims.doe.gov.my/apims/hourly1.php?date=2013-07-30 | archive-url=https://archive.is/20130730110935/http://apims.doe.gov.my/apims/hourly1.php?date=2013-07-30 | dead-url=yes | archive-date=30 July 2013 | title=API readings: 30 July 2013 | publisher=Malaysian Department of Environment | date=30 July 2013 | accessdate=30 July 2013 }} On 31 July, Bukit Rambai remained the worst affected area. API readings there hovered in the 80s, although occasionally dropping to the upper 70s, like the past few days. The highest reading was 84, at 10am. That was also the highest reading for the day in Malaysia. Port Klang's API readings rose from the 50s in the early morning to 77 (5–9pm). For most of the day, it was in the 70s. API readings in some other areas like [[Kemaman]] in Terrenganu, Banting, Malacca City and Muar were in the 60s for most of the day. Tanjung Malim's air quality was good for most of the day, but spiked suddenly to reach 72 at 3pm, and 75 an hour later. It gradually decreased and returned to the ''Good'' range at 8pm.{{cite web | url=http://apims.doe.gov.my/apims/hourly1.php?date=2013-07-31 | archive-url=https://archive.is/20130731154704/http://apims.doe.gov.my/apims/hourly1.php?date=2013-07-31 | dead-url=yes | archive-date=31 July 2013 | title=API readings: 31 July 2013 | publisher=Malaysian Department of Environment | date=31 July 2013 | accessdate=31 July 2013 }} On 1 August, Bukit Rambai remained the worst-affected. API readings there dropped gradually during the morning, reaching 68 at 11am, the lowest recorded there for many days already. However, it then increased quickly for the rest of the day, breaching the 80 mark at 3pm. At 4pm, API was 90. As of 10pm, the API was 92. The highest API for the day in Bukit Rambai was 93, recorded at 9pm. That was also the highest reading of the day in Malaysia. [[Port Dickson]]'s air quality remained between 52 and 70 for most of the day. However, it suddenly increased to 78 at 3pm and 83 at 4pm, before dropping an hour later. In Kuala Lumpur, air quality was mainly in the 50s. But in the Cheras area of KL, API readings soared to 71 at 2pm, then to 86 at 3pm, 77 at 4pm, before returning to the 50s. In [[Seremban]], air quality hovered around 60 for most of the day, although at 3pm, a reading of 80 was recorded.{{cite web | url=http://apims.doe.gov.my/apims/hourly1.php?date=2013-08-01 | archive-url=https://archive.is/20130801151719/http://apims.doe.gov.my/apims/hourly1.php?date=2013-08-01 | dead-url=yes | archive-date=1 August 2013 | title=API readings: 1 August 2013 | publisher=Malaysian Department of Environment | date=1 August 2013 | accessdate=1 August 2013 }} On 2 August, the haze still hit Bukit Rambai the hardest. In the early morning, the API readings continued rising up the 90s, hitting 100 at 5am. That meant it was at the top of the "Moderate" range and even if it were to increase by only 1, that's it and it would enter the "Unhealthy" range. At 6am, the API reading entered the ''Unhealthy'' range, hovering between 101 and 105. The highest reading, 105, was recorded at noon. At 3pm, the air quality was back in the ''Moderate'' range, and subsided gradually. At 9pm, it was 84. However, instead of Bukit Rambai, it was Tanjung Malim which recorded the worst reading of the day, 114, at 5pm. That was also the highest in Malaysia. Like the past few days, Tanjung Malim's air quality was ''Good'' for most of the day, only spiking for a few hours each day. The air quality there entered the ''Moderate'' range at 2pm, and returned to the ''Good'' range at 8pm. Other than the above two locations, Kemaman, Port Dickson, Seremban, Nilai and Malacca City also recorded air quality in the 70s for a few hours.{{cite web | url=http://apims.doe.gov.my/apims/hourly1.php?date=2013-08-02 | title=API readings: 2 August 2013 | publisher=Malaysian Department of Environment | date=2 August 2013 | accessdate=2 August 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714202135/http://apims.doe.gov.my/apims/hourly1.php?date=2013-08-02 | archive-date=14 July 2014 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }} ====Malaysian Borneo==== On 20 June, the API index in [[Sabah]] was moderate, with [[Kota Kinabalu]] at 74, [[Keningau]], 66 and Sandakan, 42.{{cite news|title=Moderate haze in Sabah|url=http://www.nst.com.my/latest/moderate-haze-in-sabah-1.303965|publisher=New Straits Times|date=20 June 2013|accessdate=26 June 2013}} On 22 June, the hazy condition in Sabah and [[Labuan]] became worse when the index in several areas had risen.{{cite news|title=Jerebu: Muar makin 'lenyap'|url=http://www.bharian.com.my/bharian/articles/Jerebu_Muarmakin_lenyap_/Article/|publisher=Berita Harian|language=Malay|date=23 June 2013|accessdate=26 June 2013}} Keningau registered a reading of 98 at 11 a.m., while Kota Kinabalu with 91 and Labuan 97. Until 25 June, only [[Sandakan]] and [[Tawau]] enjoyed cleaner air than other areas, with API readings at 50 and 42 respectively.{{cite news|title=Haze: Only Sandakan and Tawau residents enjoy clean air|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2013/6/25/nation/20130625103039&sec=nation|publisher=The Star|date=25 June 2013|accessdate=26 June 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130625034715/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2013%2F6%2F25%2Fnation%2F20130625103039&sec=nation|archive-date=25 June 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} In [[Sarawak]], the API entered the moderate range on 20 June, with readings of 72 in [[Miri, Malaysia|Miri]] and 55 in [[Kapit]] and [[Sri Aman]]. In addition, sixteen hot spots were detected on 18 June with [[Mukah]] having the most with five and [[Sarikei]], three.{{cite news|title=Most of Sarawak register moderately healthy API|url=http://www.theborneopost.com/2013/06/20/most-of-sarawak-register-moderately-healthy-api/|publisher=The Borneo Post|date=20 June 2013|accessdate=26 June 2013}} Big plantation companies had been accused of being the major cause of haze in the state.{{cite news|title=Big plantations accused of being major cause of haze in Sarawak|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2013/6/22/sarawak/13272781&sec=sarawak|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130628042627/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2013/6/22/sarawak/13272781&sec=sarawak|dead-url=yes|archive-date=28 June 2013|publisher=The Star|date=22 June 2013|accessdate=26 June 2013}} ====Measures taken==== The organisers of the Olympic Day Run, [[McDonald's]] Malaysia and [[Olympic Council of Malaysia]] announced on 20 June the postponement of the 10th annual Run scheduled for 23 June amid health fears.{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10152906604915023&set=a.354401130022.351428.142518590022&type=1|title=McDonald's Olympic Day Run postponed|accessdate=26 June 2013|date=20 June 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://olympic.org.my/images/documents/2013_odr/postponed.htm|title=Olympic Day Run postponed|date=20 June 2013|accessdate=26 June 2013|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130628042530/http://olympic.org.my/images/documents/2013_odr/postponed.htm|archive-date=28 June 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} As of 23 June, more than 600 schools closed in areas of Johor where the [[Air Pollution Index|Air Pollution Index (API)]] readings had exceeded the hazardous point of 300. Schools in areas with the API reaching 150 were advised to avoid outdoor activities.[http://www.nst.com.my/nation/general/686-schools-close-in-johor-1.305314 "686 Schools Close in Johor"], ''[[New Straits Times]]'', Malaysia. 22 June 2013. While the 2013 Johor Rugby Carnival had to be deferred until further notice, a directive was given to cancel all outdoor activities in the [[Malaysian National Service]] (PLKN) training camps in affected areas with ''Unhealthy'' API readings.{{cite news|title=Jerebu: Aktiviti luar di kem PLKN dihentikan|url=http://www.utusan.com.my/utusan/Dalam_Negeri/20130620/dn_25/Jerebu-Aktiviti-luar-di-kem-PLKN-dihentikan|accessdate=21 June 2013|newspaper=Utusan Malaysia|language=Malay|date=20 June 2013}}{{cite news|title=Jerebu: Karnival Ragbi Johor 2013 ditangguh|url=http://www.sinarharian.com.my/jerebu-karnival-ragbi-johor-2013-ditangguh-1.173855|accessdate=21 June 2013|newspaper=Sinar Harian|language=Malay|date=20 June 2013}} The Department of Environment issued a ban against open burning in Selangor, Malacca and Johor; those convicted would face fines of not more than RM500,000 (S$199,400), a maximum imprisonment of five years, or both according to Section 29AA(2) of the Environmental Quality (Amendment) Act 2001.{{cite news|title=Indonesia to extinguish fires using cloud-seeding|url=http://www.todayonline.com/world/asia/indonesia-extinguish-fires-using-cloud-seeding|accessdate=20 June 2013|newspaper=Today Online|date=20 June 2013}} Malaysia's Prime Minister [[Najib Razak]] advised the public to reduce outdoor activities while the haze was still present.{{cite news|url=http://www.nst.com.my/nation/general/pm-urges-caution-as-haze-worsens-1.302360?cache=03%2F7.206949%2F7.209145%2F7.209565%3Fkey%3DMalaysia|title=PM urges caution as haze worsens|date=18 June 2013|accessdate=19 June 2013|newspaper=[[New Straits Times]]}} On 23 June, he declared a [[state of emergency]] in two southern districts, Muar and Ledang after the API values increased badly. The emergency status was later lifted on 25 June, Tuesday morning.[http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/malaysia-declares-state/721254.html "Malaysia's government on Sunday declared a state of emergency in Muar and Ledang as air pollution levels reached 16-year-highs."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130626025209/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/malaysia-declares-state/721254.html |date=26 June 2013 }}, ''[[Channel NewsAsia]]'', Singapore. 23 June 2013. On 23 June, Malaysia's Natural Resources and Environment Minister, Datuk Seri [[G. Palanivel]] pronounced the closure of all schools in [[Kuala Lumpur]], Selangor and Malacca on 24 June as a precautionary step. A total of 480 government-run kindergartens in Malacca were told to stop classes. Operators of private kindergartens and pre-schools were urged to follow suit by the [[Malacca State Legislative Assembly|state government of Malacca]].[http://www.bharian.com.my/bharian/articles/Jerebu_SemuatadikadiMelakadiarahtutupmulaiesok/Article/?bh "Jerebu: Semua tadika di Melaka diarah tutup mulai esok"], ''[[Berita Harian]]'', Malaysia. 23 June 2013. Schools in [[Port Dickson]] and Kuantan were shut down as ordered by the respective state governments. In Johor Bahru, a number of schools remained temporarily closed while 300 schools in other parts of [[Johor]] were allowed to operate again as usual.[http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2013/6/24/nation/13278980&sec=nation "Haze forces schools in KL, Selangor and Malacca to be shut down"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130624020811/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2013%2F6%2F24%2Fnation%2F13278980&sec=nation |date=24 June 2013 }}, ''[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]]'', Malaysia. 24 June 2013. The next day, [[Pizza Hut]] Malaysia also temporarily halted delivery services for their Muar and Port Klang branches to ensure the riders' safety because of the worsening haze. They resumed delivery services in Muar a day later.{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/permalink.php?story_fbid=10151647287729654&id=27673314653|title=Pizza Hut temporarily stopped delivery services|date=24 June 2013|accessdate=26 June 2013}}{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/permalink.php?story_fbid=10151649046864654&id=27673314653|title=Pizza Hut resumed delivery in Muar|date=25 June 2013|accessdate=26 June 2013}} On 25 June, Malaysia's Education Minister, [[Muhyiddin Yassin]] said that parents had the discretion not to send their children to school in fear of health problems as long as they informed the relevant school authorities, as schools in some states were starting to reopen.[http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2013/6/25/nation/13283259&sec=nation "Haze: Schools to close if API hits 300"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130625034749/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2013%2F6%2F25%2Fnation%2F13283259&sec=nation |date=25 June 2013 }}, ''[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]]'', Malaysia. 25 June 2013. The [[Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment (Malaysia)|Department of Environment (DOE)]] began updating the API readings on an hourly basis. They were made available for public access on both the Department's official website and portal.{{cite web|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2013/6/25/nation/20130625103947&sec=nation|title=Haze: DOE offers hourly API readings; status as at 10am|work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]]|date=25 June 2013|accessdate=27 June 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130625034445/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2013%2F6%2F25%2Fnation%2F20130625103947&sec=nation|archive-date=25 June 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} The haze forced the opening ceremony of the 13th [[Parliament of Malaysia|Parliament]] session in Kuala Lumpur to be held indoors for the first time in Malaysian history. [[Yang di-Pertuan Agong]] [[Abdul Halim of Kedah|Tuanku Abdul Halim Mu'adzam Shah]] did the customary inspection of the guard-of-honour at the banquet hall of the Parliament building.{{cite web | url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2013/6/25/nation/20130625105419&sec=nation | title=Parliament: Haze forces King to inspect guard-of-honour in banquet hall (Updated) | publisher=The Star | date=25 June 2013 | accessdate=25 June 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130629010738/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2013%2F6%2F25%2Fnation%2F20130625105419&sec=nation | archive-date=29 June 2013 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }} [[G. Palanivel]] was scheduled to meet his Indonesian counterpart to discuss the situation while Malaysian and Singaporean officials sought to move forward a meeting of the [[Association of Southeast Asian Nations|Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN)]] haze committee to the following week instead of August.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-23026450 "Haze from Indonesia continues to shroud Malaysia"], ''[[BBC Online]]''. 24 June 2013. The Premier League newcomers, [[Cardiff City F.C.]] also postponed their six-day promotional tour of Malaysia in the week because of the air pollution crisis.{{cite web|url=http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/news/football-haze-blame-cardiff-cancel-tour-malaysia-061959720.html|title=Premier League – Haze to blame as Cardiff cancel tour of Malaysia|work=Yahoo! UK & Ireland Eurosport|date=26 June 2013}} Concurrently, all orders to shut schools in the nation were withdrawn by 27 June, though outdoor activities were to remain cancelled in some parts of the country.{{cite web|url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/234088|title=All schools to reopen tomorrow|work=[[Malaysiakini]]|date=26 June 2013|accessdate=27 June 2013}} On 28 June, the [[Eco-marathon|Shell Eco-marathon]] that was planned to be held in [[Kuala Lumpur]] on 4–7 July was cancelled because of worsening air quality.{{cite web|url=http://www.thesundaily.my/news/755684|title=Shell Eco-marathon Asia in Malaysia cancelled due to haze|work=TheSunDaily|date=28 June 2013|accessdate=28 June 2013}} Upon the return of the haze in mid-July, the Penang state government prepared 200,000 face masks to be distributed to the people, especially school children, pregnant women, motorcyclists and pillion riders. ====Air Pollution Index readings==== {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto; text-align: center;" |- !24-hour API readings in some areas in June 2013{{cite web|url=http://www.doe.gov.my/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=818&Itemid=370&lang=en |title=Department of Environment Malaysia |publisher=Doe.gov.my |date= |accessdate=30 June 2013}} {| class="wikitable" |- |style="width:10%;"|Date (Time)||style="width:7.5%;"|[[George Town, Penang|George Town]]||style="width:7.5%;"|[[Seremban]]||style="width:7.5%;"|[[Kuala Lumpur]]

At 12 p.m. on 21 June 2013, the readings reached a record-breaking level of 401, in the highest possible ''Hazardous'' range.]] Mild haze began to affect Singapore on 13 June,{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/psi-reading-remains-in/712194.html|title=PSI reading remains in moderate range|publisher=Channel NewsAsia|date=16 June 2013|accessdate=21 June 2013}} before air quality worsened and remained in the ''Unhealthy'' range for a few days.{{cite news|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/specialreports/hazewatch/news/psi-reading-climbs-in-s/710384.html|title=PSI reading climbs in S'pore but remains within moderate range|newspaper=Channel NewsAsia|accessdate=19 June 2013}} [[Pollutant Standards Index|Pollutant Standards Index (PSI)]] first hit levels unseen in 16 years when a PSI of 155 was recorded at 10 p.m. on 17 June 2013. The highest in the 16 years of the haze was finally broken. At 10 p.m. on 19 June 2013, the 3-hour PSI reading of 321 breached the ''Hazardous'' zone for the first time in history, surpassing its previous record of 226 (Very unhealthy) during the [[1997 Southeast Asian haze|1997 haze]].{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/breaking-news/singapore/story/haze-singapore-hits-new-high-psi-321-10pm-20130619|title=S'pore PSI hits all-time high, PSI at 321 at 10pm|publisher=The Straits Times|date=19 June 2013|accessdate=19 June 2013}} However, the 10 p.m. reading was released 57 minutes late at 10:57 p.m. and the reading soon decreased to 282 at 11 p.m., and 218 at 12 a.m., both of which are in the ''Very unhealthy'' range. At 1 p.m. on 20 June 2013, the 3-hour PSI reading reached record levels once again with a reading of 371 in the ''Hazardous'' range, a jump from 299 an hour ago, which was only one point shy of the "Hazardous" level. The PM2.5 concentration also reached 300 for the first time in the nation's history.{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/haze-reaches-hazardous/717772.html|title=Haze reaches hazardous level; PSI hits 371|publisher=Channel NewsAsia|date=20 June 2013|accessdate=20 June 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130822084746/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/haze-reaches-hazardous/717772.html|archivedate=22 August 2013|df=dmy-all}} At 11 a.m. on 21 June 2013, another new all-time high was recorded, with a PSI of 400. The new record was broken again at 12 p.m., with the PSI remaining in the ''Hazardous'' range at 401.{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/psi-hits-new-all-time/719496.html |title=PSI hits new all-time high of 401 on Friday |publisher=Channel NewsAsia |date=21 June 2013 |accessdate=21 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130624015317/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/psi-hits-new-all-time/719496.html |archivedate=24 June 2013 }} As with prior haze events, this strained ties between Indonesia and Singapore, with Indonesia swiftly pushing the blame for the haze to Singapore and Malaysia, which invested in palm oil firms in the area of the burning.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/singapore/10127259/Singapore-and-Indonesia-clash-over-regional-haze.html|newspaper=[[Telegraph.co.uk|Telegraph]]|title=Singapore and Indonesia clash over regional haze|date=18 June 2013}} The Prime Minister of Singapore, [[Lee Hsien Loong]], as well as [[Vivian Balakrishnan]], the Singaporean Minister of Environment and Water Resources, expressed concern over the haze and called on Indonesia to do more to resolve the issue.{{cite news|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/the-big-story/the-haze-singapore/story/haze-update-pm-lee-says-singapore-urging-indonesia-take-actio|date=18 June 2013|title=Haze update: PM Lee says Singapore urging Indonesia to take action to reduce haze|author=Feng Zengkun|newspaper=[[The Straits Times]]}} However, Indonesian officials became irate at the demands, and on Thursday Indonesia's Coordinating Minister for People's Welfare Agung Laksono accused Singapore of acting "like a child."{{cite web | url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/indonesia-chides/717798.html | title=Indonesia chides Singapore over reactions on haze situation | publisher=Channel NewsAsia | date=20 June 2013 | accessdate=27 June 2013}} In response, Singapore's Emeritus Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong responded that "the Singapore Child is being suffocated", borrowing the same descriptor to highlight the nation's innocence yet vulnerability in the haze crisis.{{cite web|title="Singapore child is being suffocated," says ESM Goh|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/specialreports/hazewatch/news/singapore-child-is-being/719626.html|publisher=Channel News Asia|accessdate=22 June 2013|date=21 June 2013}} While [[cloud seeding]] was suggested to get rid of the haze, Singapore's meteorological service found it not possible because of insufficient cloud cover.{{cite news|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/the-big-story/the-haze-singapore/story/haze-update-record-321-psi-10pm-plans-place-if-haze-worsens-2|date=20 June 2013|title=Haze update: Record 321 PSI at 10pm; plans in place if haze worsens|first=Zengkun|last=Feng|newspaper=[[The Straits Times]]}} Initially, [[Respirator#Mechanical filter respirators|face masks]] were sold out in major drugstores and other retailers because of strong demand,[https://www.cnbc.com/id/100830090 Face Masks, Anyone? Singapore Struggles With Haze], CNBC, 20 June 2013 although the [[Ministry of Health (Singapore)|Ministry of Health]] subsequently reassured the public that restocks were being distributed from its armoury of close to nine million N95 masks.{{cite web|title=There is sufficient stock of N95 masks: Health Ministry|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/the-big-story/the-haze-singapore/story/there-sufficient-stock-n95-masks-health-ministry-20130620|publisher=The Straits Times|accessdate=20 June 2013|date=20 June 2013}} More than 4 million masks were distributed after that, with 1 million masks to constituencies and the remaining 3 million to retailers.[http://www.e101.gov.sg/haze/cutthruehaze.htm Cut Thru The Haze] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130624171534/http://www.e101.gov.sg/haze/cutthruehaze.htm |date=24 June 2013 }}, E101 Gov.SG, 26 June 2013 The [[Ministry of Manpower (Singapore)|Manpower Ministry]] refrained from issuing a stop-work order, saying that the [[Government of Singapore|Government]] would do so only if the haze worsened severely.{{cite web|title=Haze update: Record 321 PSI at 10pm; plans in place if haze worsens|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/the-big-story/the-haze-singapore/story/haze-update-record-321-psi-10pm-plans-place-if-haze-worsens-2|publisher=The Straits Times|accessdate=21 June 2013|date=20 June 2013}} On 22 June 2013, the haze started giving way to clear skies as the PSI dropped from 326 at 10am in the ''Hazardous'' range to 73 at 5pm in the ''Moderate'' range.{{cite web|title = Haze update: 3pm reading down to 122 as more reports of blue skies|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/the-big-story/the-haze-singapore/story/haze-update-3pm-reading-down-122-more-reports-blue-skies-2013|accessdate=22 June 2013|date=22 June 2013}} The next day, the improvement was sustained in the morning, with the PSI in the ''Moderate'' range. The improvement in the air quality was due to a change in the direction of the low level winds over Singapore, from south-westerly to southerly.{{cite web|url=http://app2.nea.gov.sg/corporate-functions/newsroom/advisories/haze-update-from-nea-(12pm-on-23-june-2013)|title=Haze Update From NEA (12PM on 23 June 2013)|publisher=National Environment Agency|date=23 June 2013|accessdate=23 June 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130626063058/http://app2.nea.gov.sg/corporate-functions/newsroom/advisories/haze-update-from-nea-(12pm-on-23-june-2013)|archive-date=26 June 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} As dry conditions and winds blowing from the southwest or west persisted, the 24-hour PSI reading for the rest of the day was expected to be in the ''Moderate'' range.{{cite web|title=Haze Update from NEA (12pm on 23 June 2013)|url=http://app2.nea.gov.sg/corporate-functions/newsroom/advisories/haze-update-from-nea-(12pm-on-23-june-2013)|publisher=National Environmental Agency|accessdate=23 June 2013|date=23 June 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130626063058/http://app2.nea.gov.sg/corporate-functions/newsroom/advisories/haze-update-from-nea-(12pm-on-23-june-2013)|archive-date=26 June 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} However, in the night the PSI reached 102, which is in the ''Unhealthy'' range, in the west. The readings increased as the night passed. In the late afternoon of 25 June 2013, thunderstorms accompanied by strong, gusty winds drenched many parts of Singapore with heavy rain and hailstones even fell in the western part of Singapore.{{cite news|title=Hail rains down on western Singapore|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/the-big-story/asia-report/singapore/story/hail-rains-down-western-singapore-20130626|accessdate=27 June 2015|agency=The Straits Times}} The storms were a welcome respite, after Singapore had endured a week of record-breaking haze and no rain. There was a huge decrease in the PSI.{{cite web | url=http://sg.news.yahoo.com/hailstorm-in-western-singapore-bring-respite-from-heavy-haze-081827958.html | title=Hailstorm in western Singapore brings respite from heavy haze | publisher=Yahoo! News (Singapore) | date=25 June 2013 | accessdate=25 June 2013}}{{cite web | url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/from-haze-to-hail/723852.html | title=From haze to hail | publisher=Channel NewsAsia | date=25 June 2013 | accessdate=25 June 2013}}{{cite web | url=http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/hail-hits-singapore | title=Hail hits Singapore | publisher=TODAYonline | date=25 June 2013 | accessdate=25 June 2013}}{{cite news | title=Rain, hail and strong winds wreak havoc | work=The Straits Times | date=26 June 2013 | agency=Singapore Press Holdings }}{{cite web | url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/thunderstorms-most/724446.html | title=Thunderstorms most intense over western S'pore: Met Service | publisher=Channel NewsAsia | date=26 June 2013 | accessdate=27 June 2013}} Singapore's Minister for the Environment and Water Resources Dr Vivian Balakrishnan assured Singaporeans that Singapore's water quality had not been affected by the haze.{{cite web | url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/water-quality-not/724848.html | title=Water quality not affected by haze: Vivian Balakrishnan | publisher=Channel NewsAsia | date=26 June 2013 | accessdate=27 June 2013}} On 30 June 2013, a morning shower caused a significant decrease in the 3-hour PSI readings. The PSI had dropped into the ''Good'' range. However, PM2.5 concentrations for the past few days had remained unhealthy, and this was predicted to continue into the coming days.{{cite web | url=http://www.straitstimes.com/the-big-story/the-haze-singapore/story/haze-update-sunday-be-unhealthy-20130629 | title=Haze Update: Sunday to be unhealthy | publisher = The Straits Times | date=29 June 2013 | accessdate = 30 June 2013}}{{cite web | url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/slightly-hazy-conditions/729414.html | title=Slightly hazy conditions expected for Monday: NEA | publisher=Channel NewsAsia | date=30 June 2013 | accessdate=30 June 2013}} On 1 July, the PSI readings remained in the ''Good'' range for most of the day. The highest PSI readings of the day were 49–53 (''Moderate''). PSI readings on 2 and 3 July were also in the ''Good'' range. On 5 July 2013, a PSI reading of 6 was recorded – the lowest reading since the haze started blowing towards Singapore. Despite Malaysia getting hit by the haze on 21 and 22 July, Singapore remained relatively unaffected, as the winds were mainly blowing from the south or southeast. On 26 July, the PSI reached the 40s for the first time in weeks, reaching a high of 46.{{cite web|title=NEA haze readings for past 24 hours (refreshed daily)|url=http://www.haze.gov.sg/haze-update/past-24-hour-psi-reading.aspx|archive-url=https://archive.today/20130727145441/http://www.haze.gov.sg/haze-update/past-24-hour-psi-reading.aspx|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2013-07-27|publisher=National Environment Agency}} On 31 July, the PSI reached a high of 44, but decreased again the next day because of thunderstorms. On 20 August, the haze briefly returned to Singapore during the afternoon with the PSI rising to 55.{{cite web | url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/haze-in-singapore-due-to/784088.html | title=Haze in Singapore due to Sumatra fires: NEA | publisher=Channel NewsAsia | date=20 August 2013 | accessdate=21 August 2013}} ====Measures taken==== Over the first four days of the haze, the government and other institutions implemented a series of safety precautions meant to reduce exposure to the haze. Most were focused on restricting outdoor activities. Schools and childcare centres began restricting outdoor activities.{{cite news|title=Schools suspend outdoor activities as PSI reaches unhealthy range|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/schools-suspend-outdoor/715144.html|accessdate=21 June 2013|website=Channel NewsAsia|date=18 June 2013}}{{cite news|title=Seletar Airport closed due to prolonged poor visibility caused by haze|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/the-big-story/the-haze-singapore/story/seletar-airport-closed-due-prolonged-poor-visibility-caused-h|accessdate=20 June 2013|website=The Straits Times|date=20 June 2013}}{{cite web| url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/specialreports/hazewatch/news/events-in-singapore/718470.html | title=Events in Singapore postponed due to haze | publisher=Channel NewsAsia | date=20 June 2013 | accessdate=21 June 2013}} It was announced that should the haze situation worsen, schools would be closed and the Ministry of Manpower Singapore might issue a stop-work order;{{cite news|title=Haze update: Haze taskforce convened as PSI soared to record level|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/the-big-story/the-haze-singapore/story/haze-update-haze-taskforce-convened-psi-soared-record-level-2|accessdate=20 June 2013|website=The Straits Times|date=20 June 2013}} the Ministry of Education declared all school activities in June cancelled on 21 June 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.todayonline.com/moe-stops-all-school-activities-june.html|title=MOE stops all school activities for June|publisher=TODAYonline|date=21 June 2013|accessdate=21 June 2013}}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In addition, talks with Indonesia were initiated.{{cite web|url=http://app2.nea.gov.sg/corporate-functions/newsroom/news-releases/singapore-government-agencies-coordinate-effort-to-mitigate-haze-impact-on-public|title=Singapore Government Agencies Coordinate Effort To Mitigate Haze Impact on Public|date=19 June 2013|publisher=National Environment Agency, Singapore|access-date=21 June 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130622073752/http://app2.nea.gov.sg/corporate-functions/newsroom/news-releases/singapore-government-agencies-coordinate-effort-to-mitigate-haze-impact-on-public|archive-date=22 June 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|title=Environment minister Vivian meets counterpart in Jakarta on haze problem|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/the-big-story/the-haze-singapore/story/environment-minister-vivian-meets-counterpart-jakarta-haze-pr|accessdate=22 June 2013|website=The Straits Times|date=21 June 2013}} The Singapore Government distributed a few hundred thousand respirators to households without the means to purchase their own,{{cite news|title=Govt to give out free N95 masks to 200,000 needy households|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/breaking-news/singapore/story/govt-give-out-free-n95-masks-200000-needy-households-20130621|accessdate=22 June 2013|website=The Straits Times|date=21 June 2013}} while the country's top Islam board gave the green light for Muslims to not attend Friday prayer at mosques should they deem fit.{{cite web |
