|- |colspan="25"| 0–50 Good 51–100 Moderate 101–200 Unhealthy 201–300 Very unhealthy >301 Hazardous |} |} ===Southern Thailand=== As of 25 June, the haze affected [[Southern Thailand]] according to the Thai News Agency.{{cite web|title=Indonesian haze blankets Thailand's south|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2013-06/25/c_132485584.htm|publisher=Xinhua.net|date=25 June 2013|accessdate=26 June 2013}} The haze affected the [[Yala Province]] first, causing irritation to the locals but not affecting visibility on the road.{{cite web|title=Yala now affected by Indonesian haze|url=http://thainews.prd.go.th/centerweb/newsen/NewsDetail?NT01_NewsID=WNDAT5606250010001|publisher=National News Bureau of Thailand|date=25 June 2013|accessdate=27 June 2013}} A day later, the haze in [[Pattani Province|Pattani]], [[Yala Province|Yala]] and [[Satun]] thickened and caused poor visibility on the road.{{cite web|title=Indonesian haze blanketing a few Southern provinces to get worse in 2–3 days|url=http://thainews.prd.go.th/centerweb/newsen/NewsDetail?NT01_NewsID=WNDAT5606260010002|publisher=National News Bureau of Thailand|date=26 June 2013|accessdate=27 June 2013}} Among the seven Southern Thailand provinces affected by the haze, [[Narathiwat Province|Narathiwat]] was hit the worst, with [[Particulates|particulate matter]] levels there reaching 129 µg/m³, a level which is considered adverse to health.{{cite web|title=Southern Thailand provinces affected by haze|url=http://news.asiaone.com/News/Haze/Story/A1Story20130626-432381.html|publisher=asiaone|date=26 June 2013|accessdate=27 June 2013}} ====Measures taken==== The provincial public health offices have advised the public to wear a face mask and avoid any outdoor activities. ==Reactions== * {{flagu|Indonesia}} – Indonesian officials stated that farmers were being educated by the government on alternatives to clearing land, instead of the traditional slash-and-burn method.{{cite web|title=Singapore tells residents to stay indoors, possibly for WEEKS, after smoke from Indonesian forest fire blankets city|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2345093/Singapore-haze-2013-Residents-told-stay-indoors-possibly-WEEKS.html?ito=feeds-newsxml|publisher=The Daily Mail UK (Online)|date=20 June 2013|accessdate=21 June 2013}} A foreign ministry official said that the government planned to use [[Cloud Seeding|cloud-seeding]] to extinguish the fires that were causing the haze. [[Agung Laksono]], the Indonesian Minister for People's Welfare, called for Singapore to cease "making all this noise" and accused the country of "behaving like a child", insisting that Singapore companies that own plantations on Sumatra must share the blame.{{cite news|newspaper=[[Channel News Asia]] |url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/indonesia-chides/717798.html |title=Indonesia chides Singapore over reactions on haze situation |date=20 June 2013 }} On 21 June 2013, Indonesia's Forestry Ministry general secretary Hadi Daryanto said that Indonesia's efforts to fight the fires might not be effective without help in the form of a heavy downpour, which Indonesia's meteorological service predicted to occur on 28 June. The fire had engulfed more than {{Convert|3000|ha}} of plantations and forests, and it was no longer possible to put out the widespread fire. Hadi also mentioned that it would take two weeks to use cloud-seeding to put out the fires, and that the haze could last for weeks, or even months, if there was no downpour. Other than deploying many firefighters to the scene, Indonesia also turned to water bombing to extinguish the fires. It was also mentioned that they would rather set a block around settlements to prevent the fire from burning homes.{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/the-big-story/the-haze-singapore/story/only-heavy-downpour-can-help-singapore-now-indonesia-20130621|title=Heavy downpour needed to deal with haze: Indonesia official|publisher=The Straits Times|date=21 June 2013|accessdate=22 June 2013}} On 24 June 2013, Indonesian President [[Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono]] apologised to Singapore and Malaysia about the haze situation and that he hoped to seek the neighbours' understanding.{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/breaking-news/se-asia/story/haze-update-indonesias-yudhoyono-apologises-haze-20130624|title=Haze update: Indonesia's Yudhoyono apologises for haze|publisher=The Straits Times|date=24 June 2013|accessdate=24 June 2013}} He promised to try his best to tackle the haze problem and emphasised that the Indonesian authorities would find out the culprits behind the fire, bringing them to justice.{{cite web | url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/gracious-of-president/723862.html | title=Gracious of President Yudhoyono to apologise for haze, says PM Lee | publisher=Channel NewsAsia | date=25 June 2013 | accessdate=25 June 2013}} Aside from that, Indonesia agreed to hasten a sub-regional meeting of five [[Association of Southeast Asian Nations|ASEAN]] countries on the transboundary haze till July after a meeting between Environment Minister, Balthasar Kambuaya and his Malaysian counterpart, [[G. Palanivel]].{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/breaking-news/se-asia/story/haze-update-indonesia-agress-bring-forward-asean-meeting-haze-mid-july-2|title=Haze update: Indonesia agrees to bring forward Asean meeting on haze to mid-July|date=27 June 2013|work=[[The Straits Times]]}} On 27 June 2013, Indonesian hacking group ''Indonesia J.A.M.5 Team'' hacked the website of [[Eu Yan Sang]], a Singapore company, in protest against the outrage in Singapore over the haze caused by Indonesia. "''Bambu was here. Don't insult our country (Indonesia) for the haze in your country (Singapore). Don't blame Indonesia just because the air in your country is polluted. Blame the wind. Who told the wind to blow towards your country?''".{{cite web | url=http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/eu-yan-sang-website-hacked-protest-over-haze-outrage-spore | title=Eu Yan Sang website hacked in protest over haze outrage in S'pore | publisher=TODAYonline | date=28 June 2013 | accessdate=28 June 2013}}{{cite news | title=3 websites defaced with 'haze message' | work=The Straits Times | date=28 June 2013 | agency=Singapore Press Holdings |page=A8}} * {{flagu|Malaysia}} – [[Prime Minister of Malaysia|Prime Minister]] Datuk Seri [[Najib Razak]] said on Twitter that four ministers from four countries ([[Brunei]], [[Indonesia]], Singapore and [[Thailand]]) would meet in Malaysia to discuss the issue on 20 August 2013.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/NajibRazak/status/346919241095716864|title=Najib statement about the haze|publisher=Twitter|accessdate=19 June 2013}}{{cite news|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2013/6/18/nation/13253039&sec=nation|title=Asean ministers to discuss haze problem|date=18 June 2013|accessdate=19 June 2013|newspaper=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130620130324/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2013%2F6%2F18%2Fnation%2F13253039&sec=nation|archive-date=20 June 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} Malaysia is also willing to send help to [[Sumatra]] and help Indonesia with [[cloud-seeding]].{{cite news|url=http://www.nst.com.my/latest/malaysia-willing-to-aid-indonesia-on-haze-1.303985|title=Malaysia willing to aid Indonesia on haze|date=20 June 2013|accessdate=21 June 2013|newspaper=New Straits Times}}{{cite news|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2013/6/22/nation/13274917&sec=nation|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130624235715/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2013/6/22/nation/13274917&sec=nation|dead-url=yes|archive-date=24 June 2013|title=Malaysia to offer cloud seeding|date=22 June 2013|accessdate=22 June 2013|newspaper=The Star}} [[Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment (Malaysia)|Malaysian Minister of Natural Resources and Environment]], Datuk Seri [[G. Palanivel]] was scheduled to meet his Indonesian counterpart to discuss ways to resolve the crisis.[http://www.straitstimes.com/the-big-story/the-haze-singapore/story/haze-update-malaysias-mca-urges-immediate-action-jakarta-2013 "Haze update: Malaysia's Palanivel to meet Jakarta next week"], ''[[The Straits Times]]'', Singapore. 21 June 2013. Retrieved 25 June 2013. Additionally, he asked Indonesia to prove the involvement of Malaysian agricultural companies in the open burning in Sumatra, in response to their allegation claiming that many Malaysian companies were involved.{{cite news|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2013/6/25/nation/13281452&sec=nation|title=Haze: Show us proof Malaysian firms are involved, Indonesia urged|date=25 June 2013|accessdate=25 June 2013|newspaper=The Star|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130625034439/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2013%2F6%2F25%2Fnation%2F13281452&sec=nation|archive-date=25 June 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} Meanwhile, [[Ministry of Health (Malaysia)|Malaysian Health Minister]], Datuk Seri [[Subramaniam Sathasivam|S. Subramaniam]] said that Malaysia would support any Indonesia's action against errant Malaysian companies involved in the slash-and-burn activities. Prime Minister [[Najib Razak]] sent an official letter to the [[Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono|Indonesian President]] seeking co-operation to punish those responsible.[http://www.straitstimes.com/breaking-news/se-asia/story/haze-update-malaysia-pm-najib-seeks-cooperation-jakarta-haze-20130625 "Haze Update: Malaysia PM Najib seeks cooperation from Jakarta on haze"], ''[[The Straits Times]]'', Singapore. 25 June 2013. * {{flagu|Singapore}} – On 21 June, Emeritus Senior Minister [[Goh Chok Tong]] stated on his Facebook page that "the Singapore Child is being suffocated, how can he not scream?". This was in response to Agung Laksono's comments on Singaporeans "behaving like a child" over the haze issue, made the day before. Using an example of Malaysian and Singaporeans being neighbours, he stressed that one should be considerate for another and co-operate with one another in fighting the haze instead of blaming one another. He then quoted an act of "burning our garden refuse openly if the smoke will enter our neighbour's house" for instance.{{cite news |url=http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/singapore-child-being-suffocated-goh-chok-tong.html |website=Channel NewsAsia |title=The 'Singapore Child is being suffocated': Goh Chok Tong |date=21 June 2013 |accessdate=21 June 2013 }}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} On 22 June 2013, [[Minister for Foreign Affairs (Singapore)|Minister for Foreign Affairs]] and [[Ministry of Law (Singapore)|Minister for Law]] [[K. Shanmugam]] urged the [[Indonesia]] government to take "decisive action" towards the haze situation. In response to provocative remarks made by several Indonesian ministers, he stressed that the attitude by those ministers will not improve the problem any further, instead the main concern should be dedicated in solving the haze situation. He has added that Indonesia has not been carrying "the same tone of cooperation" that both countries once had over the years.{{cite news|url=http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/singapore-cannot-do-nothing-and-say-nothing-about-haze-shanmugam |website=TODAYonline |title=Singapore cannot 'do nothing and say nothing' about haze: Shanmugam |date=22 June 2013 |accessdate=23 June 2013}} On 25 June, Singapore Prime Minister [[Lee Hsien Loong]] accepted Indonesia President [[Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono|Susilo Bambang]]'s apology wholeheartedly, and said that the apology was a very gracious act. He also welcomed Susilo's promise to try his best to tackle the haze problem. PM Lee also said that Singapore was ready to work closely with Indonesia, Malaysia and other ASEAN countries to find a permanent solution to prevent the haze problem from recurring annually. When the number of hotspots spiked in mid-July, Singapore also offered to assist Indonesia in putting out the fires, to prevent the haze from affecting Singapore again. An aircraft was also offered to help with cloud-seeding over the hotspots. * {{flagu|Thailand}} – Prime Minister [[Yingluck Shinawatra]] expressed her concern about the haze that has spread to Southern Thailand.{{cite web|url=http://202.47.224.92/view.php?m_newsid=255606260002&tb=N255606|title=Foreign Minister to discuss Indonesian wildfire at ASEAN meeting|publisher=National News Bureau of Thailand|date=26 June 2013|accessdate=25 December 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141225110121/http://202.47.224.92/view.php?m_newsid=255606260002&tb=N255606|archivedate=25 December 2014}} While, [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Thailand)|Thailand Minister of Foreign Affairs]] [[Surapong Tovichakchaikul]] said that he would bring up the issue at the upcoming ASEAN meeting and discuss with other bloc members how to help Indonesia to tackle the problem. He also said that Malaysia and Singapore had proposed to hold the ASEAN meeting sooner than scheduled, so the bloc members could help. ===International reactions=== * '''[[Greenpeace International]]''' – The environmental organisation thought of the situation as an "international problem", stating that "nothing could be more illustrative of forest destruction than the polluting haze that is coming from [[Sumatra]]". It urged the parties responsible for the haze to take preventive actions.{{cite news|url=http://www.eco-business.com/news/name-and-shame-companies-behind-haze-singapore/ |newspaper=Eco-Business |title=Name and shame companies behind haze: Singapore |date=19 June 2013 |last=Cheam |first=Jessica }} Greenpeace also called on big palm oil companies such as Malaysia-based [[Sime Darby]] and Singapore-based [[Wilmar International]] to check whether their suppliers were involved in the burning.{{cite web | url=http://www.greenpeace.org/international/en/press/releases/Palm-oil-companies-must-come-clean-on-Indonesian-fire-hotspots---Greenpeace/ | title=Palm oil companies must come clean on Indonesian fire hotspots (Press release) | publisher=Greenpeace. | date=22 June 2013 | accessdate=22 June 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130705221804/http://www.greenpeace.org/international/en/press/releases/Palm-oil-companies-must-come-clean-on-Indonesian-fire-hotspots---Greenpeace/ | archive-date=5 July 2013 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }} ==Comparison with previous haze events in Southeast Asia== Forest and land fires have been an annual occurrence in Sumatra in recent history. In the period from 2006 to 2013, the cumulative hotspot count in 2013 was the fifth highest. There were more hotspots in 2012, 2006, 2007 and 2009.{{cite web|title=Cumulative Hotspot Count Charts|url=http://www.weather.gov.sg/wip/c/portal/layout?p_l_id=PUB.1003.613|publisher=ASEAN Specialised Metrological Centre|accessdate=16 February 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222053810/http://www.weather.gov.sg/wip/c/portal/layout?p_l_id=PUB.1003.613|archive-date=22 February 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} The record-breaking pollution levels in Singapore and Peninsular Malaysia in June 2013 were caused by a combination of a spike in hotspots in Sumatra and wind patterns which directed the smoke towards Singapore and Malaysia during that month.{{cite web|title=Wind, not big increase in forest fires, driving haze in Singapore |url=http://news.mongabay.com/2013/0626-singapore-wind-wri.html|publisher=Mongabay|accessdate=16 February 2014|date=26 June 2013}} There were more than 8,000 fire alerts in Sumatra in June 2013. Over the past 12 years, there have only been three other months with more than 8,000 fire alerts – all of which occurred in 2006.{{cite web|title=New Data Shows Indonesian Forest Fires a Longstanding Crisis|url=http://www.wri.org/blog/new-data-shows-indonesian-forest-fires-longstanding-crisis|publisher=World Resources Institute|accessdate=16 February 2014|first=Nigel |last=Sizer|first2=Kemen |last2=Austin|first3=Ariana |last3=Alisjahbana|first4=Fred |last4=Stolle|first5=James |last5=Anderson|date=25 June 2013}} ==See also== {{Portal|Asia|Southeast Asia|Atmospheric sciences}} * [[Air quality index]] * [[Asian brown cloud]] * [[Borneo peat swamp forests]] * [[Deforestation in Borneo]] * [[People's Movement to Stop Haze]] * [[Pollutant Standards Index]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|2013 haze in Singapore}} * [https://archive.is/20130627191705/http://hazecam.netcompartner.com/kl-cam/ Kuala Lumpur HazeCam (Petronas Twin Towers View)] * [http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/before-after-haze Interactive gallery: Singapore's skyline during and after the #sghaze] * [http://aprildialog.com/2013/07/22/infographic-why-responsible-forestry-is-important-for-indonesia/ Why Responsible Forestry Is Important For Indonesia] {{Asia Pollution}} {{Heat wave}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Southeast Asian Haze, 2013}} [[Category:Southeast Asian haze]] [[Category:2013 in Southeast Asia]] [[Category:2013 natural disasters]] [[Category:2013 in Indonesia]] [[Category:2013 in Malaysia]] [[Category:2013 in Singapore]] [[Category:2013 in Thailand]] [[Category:2013 in the environment]] [[Category:Air pollution in Malaysia]] [[Category:Environment of Malaysia]] [[Category:Environment of Singapore]] [[Category:Environment of Thailand]] [[Category:Environmental disasters in Asia]] [[Category:Fires in Indonesia]] [[Category:Health disasters in Malaysia]] [[Category:Health in Singapore]] [[Category:Health in Thailand]]

revision.text: {{EngvarB|date=April 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2016}} The '''2009 Southeast Asian haze''' was an episode of large scale [[air pollution]] primarily caused by [[slash and burn]] practices used to clear land for agricultural purposes in [[Sumatra]], [[Indonesia]]. It affected the areas surrounding the [[Straits of Malacca]] which besides Indonesia include [[Malaysia]] and [[Singapore]]. The haze began in early June 2009 and progressively became worse toward July. With a prevailing dry season caused by [[El Nino]], burning and hence the haze was expected to continue until August or September when the [[monsoon]] season arrived.{{cite news | title=Indonesia forest fires flare, Malaysia hit by haze | publisher=Reuters | date=12 June 2009 | url=http://in.reuters.com/article/environmentNews/idINTRE55B1BX20090612?sp=true}} ==Malaysia== ===Air Pollution The haze affected [[Indonesia]] from at least late June,{{cite web|title=Haze envelopes parts of Riau province in Indonesia|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/haze-envelopes-parts-of-riau-province-in-indonesia|work=[[The Straits Times]]|accessdate=11 October 2015|date=30 June 2015}} to the end of October, turning into an international problem for other countries in September. It was the latest occurrence of the [[Southeast Asian haze]], a long-term issue that occurs in varying intensity during every dry season in the region.{{cite web |title = Why is South-East Asia's annual haze so hard to deal with?|url= https://www.economist.com/blogs/economist-explains/2013/07/economist-explains-3 | work = The Economist |date= 7 July 2013}} It was caused by [[forest fires]] resulting from illegal [[slash-and-burn]] practices, principally on the Indonesian islands of Sumatra and Kalimantan, which then spread quickly in the [[dry season]].{{cite web|url=
