Times]]|accessdate=7 October 2015}} According to a 2016 [[Harvard]]-[[Columbia University]] study, the haze caused more than 100,000 additional [[death]]s, most of them (> 90,000) in Indonesia.Koplitz et al.: ''Public health impacts of the severe haze in Equatorial Asia in September–October 2015: demonstration of a new framework for informing fire management strategies to reduce downwind smoke exposure''. [[Environmental Research Letters]] Vol. 11, No. 9, 2016, {{DOI|10.1088/1748-9326/11/9/094023}}.{{cite news|author=G.F.|title=Why the North American west is on fire|url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/economist-explains/2017/10/economist-explains-10|work=[[The Economist]]|date=13 October 2017}} But later, the claim was refuted by Indonesia, Singapore and Malaysian health authorities.{{cite web|url=http://m.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/malaysia-singapore-and-indonesia-refute-study-on-haze-causing-100000-deaths|title=Malaysia, Singapore and Indonesia refute study on haze causing 100,000 deaths}} The haze caused by the Indonesian forest fires has been shown to increase haze related illnesses, such as upper respiratory illnesses and acute conjunctivitis, in Singapore {{cite journal |last1=Sheldon, Sankaran |first1=Tamara, Chandini |title=The Impact of Indonesian Forest Fires on Singaporean Pollution and Health |journal=American Economic Review: Papers and Proceedings |date=2017 |volume=5 |issue=107 |pages=526–529.}} The Indonesian government estimated that the haze crisis would cost it between 300 and 475 trillion [[Indonesian rupiah|rupiah]] (up to US$35 billion or [[Singapore dollar|S$]]47 billion) to mitigate.{{cite web|last1=Chan|first1=Francis|title=$47b? Indonesia counts costs of haze|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/47b-indonesia-counts-costs-of-haze|work=[[The Straits Times]]|accessdate=11 October 2015}} School closures due to the haze were implemented in Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore; these affected nearly four million students in Malaysia alone.{{cite web|last1=Au|first1=Eunice|title=Schools closed in Malaysia as haze reaches hazardous levels|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/schools-closed-in-malaysia-as-haze-reaches-hazardous-levels|publisher=[[The Straits Times]]|accessdate=10 October 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2015/08/03/islands-focus-city-extend-school-closure-over-haze-frenzy.html|title=Islands in focus: City to extend school closure over haze frenzy|publisher=The Jakarta Post|date=3 August 2015|accessdate=17 September 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/schools-to-close-on/2147982.html|publisher=Channel News Asia|accessdate=24 September 2015|author=Chan Luo Er, Leong Wai Kit|title=Schools to close on Friday due to worsening haze situation: MOE}} Among the events disrupted or even cancelled due to the haze were the [[2015 FINA Swimming World Cup]] in Singapore and the [[Kuala Lumpur Marathon]] in [[Malaysia]]. Heavy rains in Sumatra and Kalimantan in the last days of October 2015 significantly reduced the size and number of fires, and improved the air quality in most affected areas.{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/heavy-rain-clears-haze-as-jokowi-arrives-in-s-sumatra|title=Heavy rain clears haze as Jokowi arrives in S. Sumatra|author=WAHYUDI SOERIAATMADJA|work=The Straits Times}}{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/29/world/asia/indonesia-forest-fire-toxic-haze.html|title=Rain in Indonesia Dampens Forest Fires That Spread Toxic Haze|date=29 October 2015|work=The New York Times|via=New York Times}}{{cite web|url=http://news.liputan6.com/read/2353146/hujan-3-hari-usir-kepekatan-kabut-asap-di-sumatera-dan-kalimantan|title=Hujan 3 Hari Usir Kepekatan Kabut Asap di Sumatera dan Kalimantan|work=liputan6.com}}{{cite web|url=http://nasional.tempo.co/read/news/2015/10/28/206713917/bmkg-hujan-di-kalimantan-dan-sumatera-redakan-a|title=BMKG: Hujan di Kalimantan dan Sumatera Redakan Asap|work=Tempo Nasional}} In turn, the NEA of Singapore stopped issuing haze advisories from 15 November 2015. == Background == [[File:Satellite image of 2015 Southeast Asian haze - 20150924.jpg|upright=1.2|thumbnail|left|A [[NASA]] satellite image showing the extent of the haze on 24 September 2015.]] Indonesia has struggled for years to contain forest fires, especially in the islands of [[Sumatra]] and [[Kalimantan]]. In September 2014, Indonesia ratified the [[ASEAN Agreement on Transboundary Haze Pollution]]. It is the last ASEAN country to do so.{{cite web | url = http://www.menlh.go.id/indonesia-meratifikasi-undang-undang-tentang-pengesahan-asean-agreement-on-transboundary-haze-pollution-persetujuan-asean-tentang-pencemaran-asap-lintas-batas/ |title=Indonesia Meratifikasi Undang-Undang Tentang Pengesahan Asean Agreement On Transboundary Haze Pollution (Persetujuan Asean Tentang Pencemaran Asap Lintas Batas)|language=Indonesian|publisher=Ministry of Environment, Indonesia | accessdate = 16 September 2015}} The agreement calls on Indonesia to take steps to solve the problem through its own efforts or through international co-operation, or else face legal action based on the impact of the haze on its south-east Asian neighbours.{{cite web|url=http://kxan.com/ap/image-of-asia-wildfire-haze-shrouds-indonesias-neighbors/ |title=Image of Asia: Wildfire haze shrouds Indonesia’s neighbors |work=The Associated Press |publisher=Kxan |date=11 September 2015 |accessdate=14 September 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150925013203/http://kxan.com/ap/image-of-asia-wildfire-haze-shrouds-indonesias-neighbors/ |archivedate=25 September 2015 }} In 2014, Singapore also passed laws that allow it to prosecute people and firms that contribute to the haze.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-34265922 |title= What causes South-East Asia's haze?| publisher =BBC | work = News |date=16 September 2015|accessdate=16 September 2015}} In early August 2015, although Cambodia, [[Laos]], Thailand, [[Myanmar]], and Vietnam met to discuss the haze problem, Indonesia did not join the talks.{{cite web|url=http://www.khmertimeskh.com/news/16585/indonesian-haze-may-be-choking-cambodia/|title=Indonesian Haze May be Choking Cambodia|author=Jonathan Cox|publisher=Khmer Times|date=6 October 2015|accessdate=8 October 2015}} === Causes === The fires are caused by firms and farmers engaging in illegal [[slash-and-burn]] practices as a relatively inexpensive means to clear their land of unwanted vegetation and peat. Sumatra and Kalimantan possess large areas of [[peatland]], which is highly combustible during [[dry season]]. [[Peat]], which is made up of layers of dead vegetation and other organic matter, contributed heavily to carbon emissions because of the substance's high density{{cite news| title = Peatland Fires Biggest Contributor to Carbon Emissions: Researcher |newspaper =Jakarta Globe| url =http://jakartaglobe.beritasatu.com/environment/peatland-fires-biggest-contributor-carbon-emissions-scientist/ }} and carbon content. The haze was particularly severe in 2015 due to the [[El Niño]] phenomenon, which caused drier conditions, causing the fires to spread more.{{cite web |url= http://www.dw.com/en/why-southeast-asias-haze-problem-persists/a-18715535 |title = Why South-east Asia's haze problem persists | first =Gabriel | last = Domínguez| work =Deutsche Welle|date= 15 September 2015|accessdate=16 September 2015}} Research published in the [[Environmental Research Letters]] stated that 59% of fire emissions in Sumatra and 73% in Kalimantan originated from "outside timber and palm oil concession boundaries".{{cite web | url = http://www.todayonline.com/world/getting-facts-right-indonesias-haze-problems |title=Getting the facts right on Indonesia’s haze problems | first =Erik | last = Meijaard |work= The Jakarta Globe| publisher = Today Online|date=14 September 2015 |accessdate=14 September 2015}} Environmental rights activists added that [[palm oil]] activities were still involved in the burning. Firstly, land clearing by burning is cheap and is more often chosen by companies than any other land-clearing method. Secondly, most companies want to avoid spending money on [[reforestation]]. Any company which obtains a license for forest lands must replant them from a fund provided by the government.{{cite web | url = http://en.tempo.co/read/news/2015/09/16/055701104/Former-Riau-Police-Chief-Reveals-Three-Motives-for-Forest-Burning|title=Former Riau Police Chief Reveals Three Motives for Forest Burning|author=Arkhelaus Wisnu|publisher=Tempo|date=16 September 2015|accessdate=16 September 2015}} Most companies do not replant, and to avoid detection, they burn the land. Thirdly, the companies revitalise palm plantations by cutting or burning old palm trees that are no longer productive. The regulation stipulates that such burning must be done on a bed of concrete to avoid spreading the fire, but to reduce costs, most companies do not do this. == Countries affected == At least six of the ten countries in the [[Association of Southeast Asian Nations|ASEAN]] region have been affected by the haze: southern [[Thailand]], [[Vietnam]],{{cite web|url=http://english.astroawani.com/malaysia-news/haze-netizens-four-countries-share-their-gripe-73010|title=Haze: Netizens from four countries share their gripe|author1=Kohilah Sekaran|author2=Syafique Shuib|publisher=Astro Awani|date=12 September 2015|accessdate=14 September 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/environment/679996/haze-blocks-out-hat-yai-trang|title=Haze blocks out Hat Yai, Trang|author=DPA|publisher=Bangkok Post|date=4 September 2015|accessdate=14 September 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://tuoitrenews.vn/society/30851/indonesia-forest-fires-to-blame-for-foggy-ho-chi-minh-city-expert|title=Indonesia forest fires to blame for foggy Ho Chi Minh City: expert|publisher=Tuổi Trẻ|date=7 October 2015|accessdate=7 October 2015}} and most parts of [[Brunei]], [[Indonesia]], [[Malaysia]], and [[Singapore]]. The haze affecting [[Cambodia]] and [[Cebu]] in the [[Philippines]] was also suspected to have arisen from Indonesian rather than local sources.{{cite web|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/107954-philippines-suspects-haze-indonesia-fires|title=Philippines suspects week-long haze from Indonesia fires|work=Agence France-Presse|date=3 October 2015|accessdate=3 October 2015}} On 29 September 2015, the [[International Business Times|IBTimes]] published interactive before-and-after photos that showed the dramatically reduced visibility in [[Singapore]] and Indonesia due to haze.{{cite web|title=Singapore and Indonesia haze: Interactive before-and-after photos show dramatically reduced visibility|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/singapore-indonesia-haze-interactive-before-after-photos-show-dramatically-reduced-visibility-1521643|accessdate=1 October 2015}} The [[Global Fire Emissions Database]] reported that the 2015 Indonesian fires had generated around 600 million tonnes of [[greenhouse gas]]es, an amount described as 'roughly equivalent to Germany's entire annual output'. [[NASA]] said that the 2015 haze crisis could become the worst one recorded in the region, possibly outstripping [[1997 Southeast Asian haze|the 1997 crisis]], which cost an estimated nine billion US dollars.{{cite web|title=Indonesian fires sending haze across south-east Asia could become worst on record, NASA warns|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-10-02/indonesia-forest-fires-could-become-worst-on-record-nasa-warns/6824460|publisher=[[ABC Online]]|accessdate=4 October 2015}} === Brunei === Smoke from forest fires in [[Kalimantan]], blown by prevailing south-westerly winds, brought hazy conditions to [[Brunei]].{{cite web|url=http://englishnews.thaipbs.or.th/brunei-haze-may-last-for-a-week|title=Brunei haze may last for a week|work=The Brunei Times|publisher=Thai PBS|date=26 August 2015|accessdate=14 September 2015}} A duty forecaster at the Brunei Meteorological Department, Nurulinani Haji Jahari, said heavy thunderstorms would do little to relieve the hazy conditions because westerly winds were still expected to continue bringing more smoke from [[Kalimantan]] and Sumatra. On 15 September, the [[Tutong District]] recorded an all-time-high [[Pollutant Standards Index]] (PSI) reading of 68; followed by [[Belait District|Belait]], with 67; [[Brunei-Muara District|Brunei-Muara]], with 65; and [[Temburong District|Temburong]], with 48.{{cite web|url=http://news.asiaone.com/news/asia/hazy-conditions-persist-brunei-week|title=Hazy conditions to persist in Brunei this week|author=Wail Wardi Wasil|work=The Brunei Times/Asia News Network|publisher=AsiaOne|date=15 September 2015|accessdate=15 September 2015}} The Bruneian public were advised by authorities to drink plenty of water and seek medical assistance if experiencing smoke-related symptoms. Authorities also warned against any open burning or other activities that might worsen the haze. === Cambodia === [[Phnom Penh]] suffered from haze, and its [[Ministry of Environment (Cambodia)|Cambodian Ministry of the Environment]] suspected that fires set by plantation owners in Indonesia might be to blame. Uncertainty of the source remained since Indonesia released little relevant information. === Indonesia === The 2015 haze affected Indonesia from at least late June, with the municipality of [[Dumai]] (in the province of Riau on the island of Sumatra) reporting haze beginning 28 June. The problem persisted for months.{{cite web|last1=Nazeer|first1=Zubaidah|title=Haze blankets parts of Sumatra|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/haze-blankets-parts-of-sumatra|work=[[The Straits Times]]|accessdate=11 October 2015}} As of 7 October 2015, more than 140,000 Indonesians have reported respiratory illnesses in the haze-affected areas.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/inpictures/2015/10/southeast-asia-hazardous-haze-151007061537973.html|title=Southeast Asia's hazardous haze|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=7 October 2015|accessdate=8 October 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://en.cihan.com.tr/en/over-30000-people-affected-by-haze-in-riau-indonesia-1893941.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151003142806/http://en.cihan.com.tr/en/over-30000-people-affected-by-haze-in-riau-indonesia-1893941.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=3 October 2015 |title=Over 30,000 people affected by haze in Riau, Indonesia |publisher=Cihan |date=18 September 2015 |accessdate=18 September 2015 }} By 15 September 2015, around 25,834 were suffering from [[respiratory infection]], 538 having [[pneumonia]], 2,246 suffering from [[skin irritation]], and 1,656 suffering from eye irritation. The haze blanketing the whole of [[Sumatra]] island and parts of [[Kalimantan]] hampered tourism, aviation and maritime activities as well as the Indonesian economy.{{cite web|url=http://fokus.kontan.co.id/news/asap-bikin-ekonomi-ikut-menguap|title=Asap bikin ekonomi ikut menguap|language=Indonesian|author1=Hendra Gunawan|author2=Agus Triyono|author3=Noverius Laoli|publisher=Kontan.co.id|date=14 September 2015|accessdate=15 September 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.antaranews.com/en/news/100446/more-indonesia-airports-affected-by-haze-from-land-fires|title=More Indonesia airports affected by haze from land fires|author=Juwita Trisna Rahayu|publisher=Antara|date=11 September 2015|accessdate=15 September 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://regional.kontan.co.id/news/bmkg-asap-kebakaran-menyelimuti-seluruh-sumatera/2015/09/04|title=BMKG: Asap kebakaran menyelimuti seluruh Sumatera|language=Indonesian|author=Havid Vebri|work=Antara|publisher=Kontan.co.id|date=4 September 2015|accessdate=15 September 2015}} A state of emergency has been declared in the province of [[Riau]], one of the worst-affected by the haze. In Riau's capital, [[Pekanbaru]], authorities ordered the closing of schools to prevent pupils from being exposed to the haze,{{cite web|url=http://www.riaupos.co/85486-berita--sekolah-kembali-diliburkan,-sampai-kondisi-membaik.html|title=Sekolah Kembali Diliburkan, Sampai Kondisi Membaik|language=Indonesian|author1=Dofi Iskandar|author2=Yudi Waldi|publisher=Riau Pos|date=14 September 2015|accessdate=16 September 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150925124124/http://www.riaupos.co/85486-berita--sekolah-kembali-diliburkan,-sampai-kondisi-membaik.html|archive-date=25 September 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} and thousands were forced to flee the city. Flight cancellations were reported daily in [[Pekanbaru]] as well as in [[Balikpapan]], [[East Kalimantan]], due to poor visibility.{{cite web|url=http://news.liputan6.com/read/2317321/kabut-asap-batalkan-70-penerbangan-di-bandara-ssk-ii-pekanbaru|title=Kabut asap batalkan 70 penerbangan di Bandara Sultan Syarif Kasim II|author1=M Syukur|author2=Yusron Fahmi|language=Indonesian|publisher=Liputan 6|date=14 September 2015|accessdate=16 September 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://regional.kompas.com/read/2015/09/12/20070481/Asap.Kiriman.Ganggu.Belasan.Jadwal.Penerbangan.di.Balikpapan.Setiap.Hari|title=Asap Kiriman Ganggu Belasan Jadwal Penerbangan di Balikpapan Setiap Hari|author1=Dani Julius|author2=Sandro Gatra|language=Indonesian|publisher=Kompas|date=12 September 2015|accessdate=16 September 2015}} The [[Indonesian Agency for Meteorology, Climatology and Geophysics]], which considers a pollution index over 350 "hazardous", reported on 22 September 2015 that the index in [[Palangkaraya]] in [[Central Kalimantan]] hit 1,986 and the index for [[Pontianak, Indonesia|Pontianak]] in [[West Kalimantan]] reached 706.{{cite web|last1=Rahadiana|first1=Reika|title=Haze Worsens as Smog Covers Singapore, Parts of Indonesia|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-09-22/haze-worsens-as-singapore-parts-of-indonesia-covered-in-smog|publisher=[[Bloomberg News]]|accessdate=26 September 2015}} These readings surpassed quintuple and double the official "hazardous" level, respectively. In late September, the province of Central Kalimantan measured a record high of 2,300 on Indonesia's PSI. On 2 October, Central Kalimantan was still experiencing a very high PSI of 1,801, such that firefighting helicopters were unable to water-bomb certain areas due to low visibility. By mid-late October the burning hotspots, increasing sharply in number, had even spread to Indonesia's [[Papua region]]. The ''Terra Aqua'' satellite also discovered 63 hotspots in [[Maluku (province)|Maluku]] and 17 in [[North Maluku]]. 1,545 hotspots were detected in Indonesia, although the exact number couldn't be ascertained as the haze covering the region was too thick. The [[Nusa Tenggara Islands]] also had hotspots: around 67 in [[East Nusa Tenggara]] and 25 in [[West Nusa Tenggara]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/indonesia/berita_indonesia/2015/10/151019_indonesia_asap_sulawesi|title=Kebakaran hutan mencapai Sulawesi, Maluku dan Papua|language=Indonesian|publisher=BBC News|date=19 October 2015|accessdate=21 October 2015}} Dozens of flights were cancelled in [[Timika]], [[West Papua (province)|West Papua]]. Both the Moluccas Islands and Sulawesi were covered by haze. In Sulawesi, around 800 hotspots were discovered by BPBD, a disaster mitigation agency. There were 57 hotspots in [[West Sulawesi]], 151 in [[South Sulawesi]], 361 in [[Central Sulawesi]], 126 in [[Southeast Sulawesi]], 47 in [[Gorontalo]] and 59 in [[North Sulawesi]]. The city of [[Palu]] was covered by haze from nearby Kalimantan, causing some flight delays. [[File:The haze pollution Aceh in 2015.JPG|thumb| Limited visibility due to smog in [[Aceh]], [[Sumatra]], 24 October 2015]] In Java, forest fires burned in [[West Java]] and [[Mount Merapi]], [[Central Java]]. A forest fire, which trapped hikers and killed at least seven of them on [[Mount Lawu]] in [[Magetan Regency]] in [[East Java]], was later reported to have been caused by a [[bonfire]].{{cite web|title= Seven Hikers Were Burned To Death In Mount Lawu|url=http://www.jawapos.com/read/2015/10/19/7589/7-pendaki-gunung-lawu-tewas-terpanggang|accessdate=21 October 2015|publisher=Jawa Pos|language=Indonesian}} This incident caused local areas to be evacuated. The haze in Palangkaraya was so thick that it turned the air yellow and exceeded the 'dangerous' threshold by 10 times. The annual parliamentary meeting was interrupted, as the smoke from outside entered the room, causing all of the politicians to use masks and tissues in the room.{{cite web|title=Rapat Diganggu Asap, Pj Gubernur Kalteng: Parah, Perlu Bantuan Pusat!|url=http://news.detik.com/berita/3048444/rapat-diganggu-asap-pj-gubernur-kalteng-parah-perlu-bantuan-pusat|accessdate=20 October 2015|publisher=Detik.com}}{{cite web|title=Kalimantan politicians wear facemasks inside parliament as Palangkaraya suffers in silence|url=http://news.mongabay.com/2015/10/kalimantan-politicians-wear-facemasks-inside-parliament-as-palangkaraya-suffers-in-silence/|accessdate=21 October 2015|publisher=''Mongabay.com''}} Most schools in the affected area were closed until further notice due to the haze. In Riau and [[Palembang]], students were advised to go to school only twice a week. Sometimes they did not even go to school for a whole week due to the haze, causing wide concern among parents and government officials. At least ten companies, seven of which are foreign companies, were declared as the prime suspects for fire in Sumatra and Kalimantan. Two of the companies' certificates were suspended by the government. Indonesian president [[Joko Widodo]] ordered all hospitals and ''[[puskesmas]]'' (community health clinics) to be open for 24 hours. On 20 October, there were 825 new hotspots in Sumatra, with the visibility in Riau deteriorating to 50 meters. Around 66 flights in Pekanbaru were cancelled. At noon, the haze worsened as the air became yellow.{{cite web|title= Help, Thick Smoke Surrounding Pekanbaru|url=http://news.detik.com/berita/3049389/tolong-asap-pekat-menguning-kepung-pekanbaru|accessdate=21 October 2015|publisher=Detik.com|language=Indonesian}} The Government of Riau, later made a statement that the haze crisis has killed their citizens slowly by suffocating them. On 21 October, it was reported that the number of people with respiratory problems had risen to 78,829 in Riau alone. Many reported they suffered from dizziness and sore eyes. Most of the victims killed by the haze were students and newborn babies.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/indonesia/berita_indonesia/2015/10/151002_indonesia_baby_shelter_haze|title=Apa pemerintah menunggu anak-anak kami mati karena asap?|language=Indonesian|publisher=BBC News|date=2 October 2015|accessdate=21 October 2015}} A nine-year-old third-grade student died because of the smoke and the doctors and nurses who tried to save the child reported that the child's lungs were fully filled with smoke. A 15-month-old baby also died in Jambi. The photos of the dead body, taken with the baby's mother, went viral on [[Facebook]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rappler.com/indonesia/107935-bayi-meninggal-kabut-asap-jambi|title=Satu lagi bayi meninggal karena kabut Asap|language=Indonesian|publisher=Rappler|date=3 October 2015|accessdate=21 October 2015}}{{cite web|title=Foto Bayi Meninggal Akibat Kabut Asap Ramai di Medsos|url=http://news.okezone.com/read/2015/10/02/340/1224950/foto-bayi-meninggal-akibat-kabut-asap-ramai-di-medsos|accessdate= 30 September 2015|publisher=''Okezone''}} The haze crisis also interrupted the search for a missing [[Eurocopter EC130]] with five people on board in [[Lake Toba]]. The sole survivor reported that the cause of the crash was the haze. === Malaysia === Unhealthy [[Air Pollution Index]] (API) readings were recorded in 24 areas in the states of [[Sarawak]], with [[Selangor]] and [[Langkawi]] in [[Kedah]] being the worst hit by the haze.{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/haze-twenty-four-areas-record-unhealthy-api-readings|title=Haze in Malaysia: Unhealthy air quality in Malacca, Selangor, Kuala Lumpur, Sarawak|publisher=The Straits Times|date=14 September 2015|accessdate=14 September 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/selangor-worst-hit-by-haze-in-malaysia|title=Selangor worst hit by haze in Malaysia; air quality unhealthy in several areas|publisher=The Straits Times|date=12 September 2015|accessdate=14 September 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/haze-in-malaysia-schools-in-kuching-and-samarahan-close-as-air-quality-worsens|title=Sarawak worst-hit by haze in Malaysia as schools shut|publisher=The Straits Times|date=17 September 2015|accessdate=17 September 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/langkawi-in-malaysia-worst-hit-by-haze-as-schools-remain-shut|title=Langkawi in Malaysia worst hit by haze as schools remain shut|publisher=The Straits Times|date=6 October 2015|accessdate=6 October 2015}} Residents with asthma and pulmonary problems were told to stay indoors until the air quality in their areas improved. Malaysia's aviation and maritime sectors were put on high alert following a worsening in view of the reduced visibility caused by the haze.{{cite web|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/news-ians/malaysia-s-aviation-maritime-sectors-on-high-alert-115091300499_1.html|title=Malaysia's aviation, maritime sectors on high alert|publisher=Business Standard|date=13 September 2015|accessdate=14 September 2015}} The education ministry stated all schools had to close if the API readings surpassed 200. As a result, on 15 September, schools in the four states of Sarawak, Selangor, [[Negeri Sembilan]] and [[Malacca]] together with the [[Federal Territories (Malaysia)|Federal Territories]] of [[Kuala Lumpur]] and [[Putrajaya]] were ordered to close temporarily.{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/News/Nation/2015/09/14/Haze-schools-to-close/|title=Haze: Schools must close once API exceeds 200|publisher=The Star|date=14 September 2015|accessdate=14 September 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/ministry-orders-closure-of-schools-in-three-states-ft|title=Ministry orders closure of schools in three states, FT|publisher=The Malay Mail|date=15 September 2015|accessdate=15 September 2015}} On 3 October, the officials decided to cancel the [[Kuala Lumpur Marathon|Standard Chartered KL Marathon 2015]] due to the worsening haze.{{cite web|url=http://www.nst.com.my/news/2015/10/kl-marathon-cancelled-due-haze|title=Standard Chartered KL Marathon cancelled due to haze|publisher=New Straits Times Online|date=3 October 2015|accessdate=4 October 2015}} On 4 October, as haze reached unhealthy levels in many parts of the country, the government announced that all states except for Kelantan, Sabah and Sarawak were to close schools again for two days.{{cite web|url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/schools-close-for-2-days-except-in-kelantan-east-malaysia-says-minister |title=Schools close for 2 days, except in Kelantan, East Malaysia |publisher=The Malaysian Insider |date=4 October 2015 |accessdate=4 October 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151005163146/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/schools-close-for-2-days-except-in-kelantan-east-malaysia-says-minister |archivedate=5 October 2015 }} The API in Shah Alam, Selangor even hit the hazardous level of 308.{{cite web|url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/haze-worsens-nationwide-api-in-shah-alam-hits-hazardous-level|title=Haze worsens nationwide, API in Shah Alam hits ‘hazardous’ level|publisher=The Malay Mail Online|date=4 October 2015|accessdate=4 October 2015}} Until 20 October, around 1,909,842 students from 3,029 schools in Malaysia were affected,{{cite web|url=http://www.dailyexpress.com.my/news.cfm?NewsID=103872|title=East Coast schools closed due to haze|publisher=Daily Express|date=20 October 2015|accessdate=21 October 2015}} which increased to 2,696,110 students and 4,778 schools by 22 October.{{cite web|url=http://www.theborneopost.com/2015/10/22/haze-forces-4778-schools-to-close-today-2696110-students-affected/|title=Haze forces 4,778 schools to close today; 2,696,110 students affected|author=Eve Sonary Heng|publisher=The Borneo Post|date=22 October 2015|accessdate=22 October 2015}} Flights were also delayed and cancelled in the east coast of Sabah due to continuous haze from Kalimantan.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailyexpress.com.my/news.cfm?NewsID=103845|title=Haze: Flights cancelled, delayed in Tawau|publisher=Daily Express|date=19 October 2015|accessdate=21 October 2015}} It was a concern in the week leading up to the [[2015 Malaysian motorcycle Grand Prix]] as the event could have come under threat of haze. === Philippines === As of 3 October, the [[Philippine]] island of [[Cebu]] suffered its seventh straight day of haze. Therefore, it was suspected, although not confirmed, that the haze was originating from Indonesian and not local sources, possibly as a result of monsoon winds blowing north-east from fires in Indonesia towards the direction of the central [[Philippines]].{{cite web|url=http://www.manilatimes.net/indon-haze-blankets-cebu/221983/|title=Indon haze blankets Cebu|publisher=The Manila Times|date=3 October 2015|accessdate=3 October 2015}} As a result, some [[Philippine]] aircraft had difficulties landing at the [[Mactan–Cebu International Airport]]. [[Visual Flight Rules]] in the country were suspended, so that "only airline operations using airplanes with instrument flying capabilities are allowed to take off and land".{{cite web|url=http://www.sunstar.com.ph/cebu/local-news/2015/10/02/haze-hits-cebu-433513|title=‘Haze’ hits Cebu|author1=Justin K. Vestil|author2=Elias O. Baquero|publisher=Rappler|date=3 October 2015|accessdate=3 October 2015}} The [[Philippines]] at first did not believe haze from Indonesia was reaching the country,{{cite web|url=http://www.mb.com.ph/haze-blanketing-cebu-link-to-indonesia-wildfires-dismissed/ |title=Haze blanketing Cebu; link to Indonesia wildfires dismissed |author=Mars W. Mosqueda Jr. |publisher=Manila Bulletin |date=2 October 2015 |accessdate=3 October 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151005031613/http://www.mb.com.ph/haze-blanketing-cebu-link-to-indonesia-wildfires-dismissed/ |archivedate=5 October 2015 }} but later suspected it was due to the fact that the haze did not disappear within a day as per the usual haze that is particular to the region of [[Cebu City]]. Gerry Bagtasa, an atmospheric scientist, however concluded that the haze in Cebu was both from Indonesian and local sources due to several factors including effects by [[Typhoon Koppu (2015)|Typhoon Koppu]], locally known as Typhoon Lando, and the [[amihan|north-east monsoon]]. The interaction made a pocket of air above Cebu where a visible haze accumulated. Bagtasa said that the haze had already reached the island of [[Mindanao]] and other parts of [[Visayas]] when it was reported in Cebu but was too thin to be visible.{{cite news|last1=Dimacali|first1=TJ|title=Why only in Cebu? Mysterious haze explained|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/539618/scitech/weather/why-only-in-cebu-mysterious-haze-explained|accessdate=26 October 2015|publisher=GMA News|date=5 October 2015}} By mid-October, haze from Indonesia had reached [[Mindanao]]. On 20 October, it was reported that the [[Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration]] (PAGASA) in Southern Mindanao had been monitoring the haze for days. The weather body said that haze had been visible in Davao City since 17 October. [[Typhoon Koppu (2015)|Typhoon Koppu]] and the [[amihan|north-east monsoon]] were linked to the haze affecting Mindanao. Haze was also reported in the cities of [[Cagayan de Oro]], [[General Santos]], [[Iligan]], [[Davao City|Davao]], and [[Zamboanga City|Zamboanga]].{{cite news|last1=Manlupig|first1=Karlos|title=Haze from Indonesia blankets Mindanao cities|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/732736/haze-from-indonesia-blankets-mindanao-cities|accessdate=21 October 2015|agency=Inquirer Mindanao|publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=20 October 2015|location=Davao City}}{{cite news|title=Indonesia haze reaches cities in Mindanao|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/110051-indonesia-haze-cities-mindanao-philippines|accessdate=21 October 2015|publisher=Rappler|date=20 October 2015}} Haze affected operations of airports in Mindanao and Visayas.{{cite news|title=Haze affects airport ops in Visayas, Mindanao: CAAP|url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/nation/regions/10/25/15/haze-affects-airport-ops-mindanao-caap|accessdate=26 October 2015|publisher=ABS-CBN News|date=25 October 2015}} It was also observed in [[Metro Manila]] since 23 October although as of 25 October it was not linked to sources from Indonesia but to local pollution. At 12:00 (GMT+8) on 25 October, the research monitoring station in [[University of the Philippines Diliman]] recorded a [[Particulate matter|PM]]2.5 measurement of above 150 micrograms, which is deemed as "hazardous".{{cite news|last1=Suarez|first1=KD|title=Hazy Sunday in Metro Manila|url=http://www.rappler.com/science-nature/environment/110575-haze-metro-manila-visayas-mindanao|accessdate=26 October 2015|publisher=Rappler|date=25 October 2015}} There were concerns about haze from Indonesia reaching Metro Manila and it was theorised that this could happen if another typhoon hit the country.{{cite news|last1=Iglesias|first1=Iza|title=‘Smaze could reach Manila’|url=http://www.manilatimes.net/smaze-could-reach-manila/225456/|accessdate=26 October 2015|publisher=The Manila Times|date=24 October 2015}} === Singapore === [[File:Haze on Orchard Road September 2015.jpg|thumb|Hazy conditions in [[Orchard, Singapore]] during early September 2015]] Some outdoor activities in Singapore were postponed following the haze.{{Cite web|title = Guide to the #haze in infographics|url = http://graphics.straitstimes.com/STI/STIMEDIA/Interactives/2015/09/haze-in-singapore/index.html|accessdate = 21 September 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/environment/hazy-conditions-over-singapore-expected-to-continue-on-sunday-and-monday|title=Outdoor activities affected by haze on Sunday; showers expected on Monday may bring only temporary respite|author1=Calvin Yang|author2=Lee Min Kok|publisher=The Straits Times|date=13 September 2015|accessdate=14 September 2015}} It was a concern in the week leading up to the [[2015 Singapore Grand Prix]] as the event could have come under threat of haze.{{cite web|title=Haze in Singapore back at unhealthy levels on Saturday|url=http://news.asiaone.com/news/singapore/haze-singapore-back-unhealthy-levels-saturday}}{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/motorsport/formulaone/11863885/Singapore-Grand-Prix-could-be-affected-by-dangerous-smog-levels.html|title=Singapore Grand Prix could be affected by dangerous smog levels|author=Daniel Johnson|publisher=The Telegraph|date=14 September 2015|accessdate=15 September 2015}} The haze rose into the "very unhealthy" range of the [[Pollutant Standards Index]] on 14 September, with a reading of 223 at 8 p.m.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/NEAsg/status/643395705348853760|title=Daily PSI readings of Singapore|work=National Environment Agency (Singapore)|publisher=Twitter|accessdate=15 September 2015}} It rose further to 249 at 9 p.m. before dropping back to the "unhealthy" range for the rest of the night. Thunderstorms and rain had improved the situation in the afternoons of the 15th and 16th, while a change in prevailing wind direction improved the situation from the 20th to the 22nd. The haze deteriorated again on the evening of the 23rd and the morning of the 24th as denser haze from Sumatra was blown into the country by prevailing southerly winds.{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/environment/haze-conditions-may-worsen-on-thursday-24-hour-psi-may-cross-into-very|title=Haze worsens on Thursday, 24-hour PSI edges into very unhealthy range|author=Lee Min Kok|publisher=The Straits Times|date=24 September 2015|accessdate=24 September 2015}} On 24 September, the PSI reading at 7 p.m. rose into the "hazardous" range for the first time in 2015 with a reading of 313. It rose further to 317 at 8 p.m., which prompted the [[Ministry of Education (Singapore)|Ministry of Education (MOE)]] to close all primary and secondary schools on the 25th due to the worsening haze conditions. The haze deteriorated further during the small hours, reaching a record high for the year at 5 a.m. with a reading of 341. However, the 3-hour PSI quickly fell back into the "moderate" range at 1 p.m. the next day. The PSI had been hovering at the unhealthy range from the late afternoon to the evening, and the MOE announced schools to reopen on 28 September 2015. Since that day, PSI levels have remained at the unhealthy range, even rising up to very unhealthy on a few occasions.{{cite web|title=NEA haze readings for past 24 hours (refreshed daily)|url=http://www.nea.gov.sg/anti-pollution-radiation-protection/air-pollution-control/psi/psi-readings-over-the-last-24-hours|archive-url=https://archive.is/20150925122632/http://www.nea.gov.sg/anti-pollution-radiation-protection/air-pollution-control/psi/psi-readings-over-the-last-24-hours|dead-url=yes|archive-date=25 September 2015|publisher=National Environment Agency, Singapore|accessdate=15 September 2015}} On 24 September 2015, [[Ministry of Manpower (Singapore)|Ministry of Manpower]] (MOM) lodged a police report over a [[Hoaxes in Singapore|hoax]] post on social media ([[WhatsApp]] and [[Facebook]]) that claimed it had declared a "[[2015 Voluntary non-work day|voluntary non-work day]]" on Friday, 25 September 2015 as a result of the haze.{{cite web|title=MOM lodges police report over hoax post|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/mom-lodges-police-report-over-hoax-post|accessdate=29 September 2015}}{{cite web|title=Haze & confused|url=http://news.asiaone.com/news/singapore/haze-confused|accessdate=29 September 2015}}{{cite web|title=MOM debunks fake 'voluntary non-work day' Facebook post|url=http://www.tnp.sg/news/singapore-news/mom-debunks-fake-voluntary-non-work-day-facebook-post}} On 25 September 2015, the government, for the first time, named five firms: [[Asia Pulp and Paper]], [[Rimba Hutani Mas]], [[Sebangun Bumi Andalas Wood Industries]], [[Bumi Sriwijaya Sentosa]] and [[Wachyuni Mandira]] as responsible for the haze and instructed them to take measures to extinguish fires on their land, not to start new ones, and to submit action plans on how they would prevent future fires. The Minister for the Environment and Water Resources stressed that the haze was a man-made problem that should not be tolerated. Under Singapore's Transboundary Haze Pollution Act, those guilty can be fined up to $100,000 a day, capped at $2 million, for causing unhealthy haze. Some of the [[2015 FINA Swimming World Cup]]'s events on 3 October 2015 were cancelled as the PSI was in the 'unhealthy' range.{{cite web|title=FINA Swimming World Cup finals cancelled due to haze|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/sport/fina-swimming-world-cup/2167788.html|publisher=[[Channel News Asia]]|accessdate=4 October 2015}} On 19 October 2015, the 1-hour PM2.5 concentration reached a record high of 471μg/m³ for the West region at 11 p.m., while the South region was at 301μg/m³ . This was a sharp increase as the highest 1-hour PM2.5 concentration in Singapore at 9 p.m. was 164μg/m³ . The [[National Environment Agency]] attributed this to "denser haze from the sea areas south of Singapore being blown in by the prevailing south-south=easterly winds".{{cite web|title=PM2.5 levels hit 471 as haze situation worsens|url=http://www.todayonline.com/world/asia/pm25-levels-hit-471-haze-situation-worsens|work=[[Today (Singapore newspaper)|Today]]|accessdate=20 October 2015}} Thunderstorms in the morning of 28 October 2015 brought respite from the haze when the PSI dropped from 61 to 26 at 9 a.m. The National Environment Agency (NEA) announced that they would stop issuing daily haze advisories from 15 November 2015 onwards.{{cite web|title=Haze Situation Update (15 November 2015)|url=http://www.nea.gov.sg/corporate-functions/newsroom/advisories/haze-situation-update-15-november-2015|website=National Environment Agency|publisher=Government of Singapore|accessdate=18 June 2017|date=November 15, 2015}} The 2015 haze crisis in Singapore was considered as the most serious haze episode for Singapore as it lasted for a long time. It was also the first time the Singapore Armed Forces (SAF) deployed a Republic of Singapore Air Force (RSAF) Chinook helicopter and 34 SAF personnel to help fight the ongoing forest fires in Sumatra, Indonesia.{{Cite news|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/saf-and-scdf-teams-set-off-to-help-fight-haze-fires-in-indonesia|title=SAF and SCDF teams set off to help fight haze fires in Indonesia|last=|first=|date=2015-10-10|work=The Straits Times|access-date=2018-02-25|language=en}} === Thailand === The haze from [[Sumatra]] turned most parts of southern Thailand such as [[Narathiwat Province|Narathiwat]], [[Pattani Province|Pattani]], [[Phuket Province|Phuket]], [[Satun Province|Satun]], [[Songkhla Province|Songkhla]], [[Surat Thani Province|Surat Thani]], [[Trang Province|Trang]] and [[Yala Province|Yala]] provinces unsightly, even reaching hazardous levels on 7 October{{cite web|url=http://www.thephuketnews.com/sumatra-forest-fire-haze-returns-to-blanket-phuket-53945.php|title=Sumatra forest fire haze returns to blanket Phuket|author=Saroj Kueprasertkij|publisher=The Phuket News|date=4 September 2015|accessdate=14 September 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/asean/720720/pm-calls-for-regional-haze-cooperation|title=PM calls for regional haze cooperation|publisher=Bangkok Post|date=7 October 2015|accessdate=7 October 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/general/720160/smoke-haze-hazardous-in-three-southern-provinces|title=Smoke haze hazardous in three southern provinces|publisher=Bangkok Post|date=6 October 2015|accessdate=6 October 2015}} The Phuket Provincial Health Office (PPHO) issued a health advisory to its residents in August 2015 and in October the province saw a number of flight delays in [[Phuket Airport]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thephuketnews.com/phuket-health-advisory-issued-over-forest-fire-haze-53838.php|title=Phuket health advisory issued over forest fire haze|author1=Saroj Kueprasertkij|author2=Tanyaluk Sakoot|publisher=The Phuket News|date=27 August 2015|accessdate=14 September 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://thethaiger.com/news/phuket/Haze-causes-delays-flights-Phuket-Airport|title=Haze causes more delays for flights at Phuket Airport|author=Kritsada Mueanhawong|publisher=Phuket Gazette|date=8 October 2015|accessdate=29 September 2018}} The air quality index in provinces of southern Thailand were increasing with the Regional Environmental Office Director Halem Jehmarikan saying the current air pollution levels were the result of the wind direction and a low pressure area, preventing the haze from being blown away. A number of hospitals saw an increase in child patients with respiratory system related symptoms.{{cite web|url=http://www.eco-business.com/news/thailand-southern-haze-hits-this-years-worst/|title=Thailand: Southern haze hits this year's worst|work=National News Bureau of Thailand|publisher=Eco Business|date=5 October 2015|accessdate=6 October 2015}} Halem also added the pollution was the worst in decades compared to previous smog that faded within four hours.{{cite web|url=http://www.nationmultimedia.com/national/Haze-in-South-rises-beyond-safety-mark-30270267.html|title=Haze in South rises beyond safety mark|publisher=The Nation|date=6 October 2015|accessdate=6 October 2015}} === Vietnam === [[Ho Chi Minh City]] and other provinces in Southern Vietnam were enveloped in haze as of 4 October. Vietnamese experts believe that the phenomenon was partly caused by the fire in Indonesia. According to the southern unit of the Vietnamese National Centre for Hydro-Meteorological Forecasting, many provinces and cities in the [[Mekong Delta]], such as [[Sóc Trăng]], [[Cà Mau]], [[Kiến Giang]], [[Đồng Tháp Province|Đồng Tháp]], [[Bến Tre Province|Bến Tre]], and [[Cần Thơ]] also experienced similar foggy weather since the beginning of October. Residents were told to stay indoors as southern Vietnam saw a rising number of child patients suffering irritated eyes, nosebleeds, runny noses, and sneezing. The haze was predicted to continue for three days before being gradually eased by heavy rains.{{cite web|url=http://english.vietnamnet.vn/fms/society/143553/dry-haze-sends-rising-number-of-southern-children-to-hospitals.html|title=Dry haze sends rising number of southern children to hospitals|publisher=Vietnam Net|date=9 October 2015|accessdate=9 October 2015}} == Counter-measures == === Firefighting === [[File:Rewetting canal.jpg|thumb|upright=1.35|President [[Joko Widodo]] of Indonesia, inspecting the work in building [[retention basin]] to restore peatland moisture and to stop the forest fire in Rimbo Panjang, [[Riau]].]] Both Indonesia and Malaysia started daily [[cloud seeding]] on 15 September.{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/malaysia-and-indonesia-begin-cloud-seeding-to-fight-haze-how-cloud-seeding-works|title=Malaysia and Indonesia begin cloud seeding to fight haze: How cloud seeding works|author=Chew Hui Min|publisher=The Straits Times|date=15 September 2015|accessdate=15 September 2015}}{{cite web|title=Cloud seeding done daily|url=http://news.asiaone.com/news/malaysia/cloud-seeding-done-daily|accessdate=7 October 2015}} Fourteen helicopters were deployed by Indonesian authorities to dump water on fires in Sumatra and Kalimantan, and cloud seeding aircraft were deployed to Kalimantan.{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/News/Regional/2015/09/15/Indonesia-fights-blazes-Helicopters-water-bomb-hotspots-in-Sumatra/|title=Indonesia fights blazes|work=Agence France-Presse|publisher=The Star|date=15 September 2015|accessdate=15 September 2015}} In Malaysia, the cloud seeding operation was carried out for 10 days until 25 September in areas such as [[Kuching]], [[Sri Aman]], [[Kota Samarahan]] and [[Sarikei]] in Malaysian Borneo and [[Klang Valley]] in peninsular Malaysia.{{cite web|url=http://www.theborneopost.com/2015/09/15/cloud-seeding-operations-begin-today/|title=Cloud seeding operations begin today *updated*|author=Geryl Ogilvy Ruekeith|publisher=The Borneo Post|date=15 September 2015|accessdate=15 September 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2015/09/15/malaysia-to-begin-cloud-seeding-as-schools-shut-due-to-haze|title=Haze forces school closures in Malaysia, with officials to try cloud-seeding to induce rain|work=Associated Press|publisher=US News|date=15 September 2015|accessdate=15 September 2015}} The Indonesian government also started building [[retention basin]]s to restore moisture to the peatland in Sumatra and Kalimantan. Dry peatland, due to the dry season and also drainage for oil palm cultivation, was cited as the reason that fire spread quickly. Retention basins were built by blocking water flow in drainage canals, and the re-wetted peatland would serve to check the fire.{{cite web|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2014/07/15/after-peat-fires-riau-shows-down-earth-approach-ending-haze.html|title=After the peat fires, Riau shows down-to-earth approach to ending haze|author=Warief Djajanto Basorie|publisher=The Jakarta Post|date=15 July 2014|accessdate=21 October 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/presidenID/posts/459759717546216|title=Joko Widodo recent activities in Facebook|author=Joko Widodo|publisher=Facebook|date=10 October 2015|accessdate=21 October 2015}} Firefighting efforts involved Singapore, Malaysia and Australia. Russian-made Beriev Be-200 water bombers were involved.{{Cite web|title = Haze: Indonesia needs more firefighting aircraft|url = http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/indonesia-needs-more-firefighting-aircraft|website = The Straits Times|accessdate = 21 October 2015|last = hermes}} One of them had arrived at 21 Oct 0411 hours.{{Cite web|title = A Beriev Be-200 by the Russians arrived at Palembang.|url = http://www.ichigolabbit.com/2015/10/a-beriev-be-200-by-the-russian-arrived-at-palembang-.html|website = 9V-ichigoLabbit - Aviation News|accessdate = 21 October 2015}} === Mitigation of health effects === Free face masks were distributed to residents in areas worst affected by the haze and many schools in [[Peninsular Malaysia]], [[Sarawak]], [[Singapore]] as well as [[Indonesia]] were ordered to close.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/15/malaysia-closes-schools-as-indonesian-forest-fires-cloak-region-in-smoke|title=Malaysia resorts to cloud-seeding in hope of clearing smoke over region|work=Agence France-Presse|publisher=The Guardian|date=15 September 2015|accessdate=15 September 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/environment/haze-forces-closure-of-schools-across-spore|title=Haze forces closure of schools across Singapore|publisher=The Straits Times|date=25 September 2015|accessdate=25 September 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://nasional.tempo.co/read/news/2015/10/08/079707538/kabut-asap-ganggu-sekolah-kalender-akademik-dijadwal-ulang|title=Kabut Asap Ganggu Sekolah, Kalender Akademik Dijadwal Ulang|language=Indonesian|author=Faiz Nashrillah|publisher=Tempo|date=8 October 2015|accessdate=9 October 2015}} Most Indonesian pharmacies sold [[oxygen tank|oxygen cylinders]] to the public.{{cite web|url=http://www.radarpekalongan.com/97134/disaat-asap-tak-kunjung-hilang-masyarakat-harus-membeli-oksigen/|title=Disaat Asap Tak Kunjung Hilang, Masyarakat Harus Membeli Oksigen|language=Indonesian|publisher=Radar Pekalongan|date=7 October 2015|accessdate=9 October 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151117043328/http://www.radarpekalongan.com/97134/disaat-asap-tak-kunjung-hilang-masyarakat-harus-membeli-oksigen/|archive-date=17 November 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} Singapore launched legal action that could lead to massive fines against Indonesian companies blamed for farm and plantation fires spewing unhealthy levels of air pollution over the city-state.{{cite web|url=http://www.manilatimes.net/singapore-moves-vs-indon-firms-over-haze/220785/|title=Singapore moves vs Indon firms over haze|publisher=The Manila Times|date=26 September 2015|accessdate=27 September 2015}} Singapore also launched its own supplies for its residents, mainly to those elderly households who are very vulnerable to the haze with the distribution of AIR+ smart masks to 29,000 elderly residents along with WeCare PAcks, which contain food and essential items like [[eyedrops]], [[vitamin C]] tablets, biscuits, instant noodles and canned food.{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/haze-supplies-30-000/2130702.html|title=Haze supplies: 30,000 households to get WeCare PAcks, 29,000 masks for needy elderly|author1=Xabryna Kek|author2=Hetty Musfirah Abdul Khamid|publisher=Channel News Asia|date=16 September 2015|accessdate=17 September 2015}} In Thailand, Songkhla Province governor Songpol Sawasditham set up a "war room" to provide aid to affected residents and to combat the impact of smog from Indonesian forest fires. The [[Government of Thailand|Thai government]] also launched an application called Air4ASEAN that tracked the spread of the haze from the Indonesian fires, and monitored the air quality in different countries. == Criticism of responses == Residents and non-governmental organisations in [[Riau]] and [[Central Kalimantan]] complained about the lack of aid and inaction from the [[Government of Indonesia|Indonesian government]] over the ongoing forest fires.{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/protesters-in-kalimantan/2142782.html|title=Protesters in Kalimantan decry Indonesian inaction against forest fires, haze|author=Kane Cunico|publisher=Channel News Asia|date=22 September 2015|accessdate=22 September 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/indonesians-protest-government-inaction-over-managing-forest-fires-2107827|title=Indonesians Protest Government Inaction Over Managing Forest Fires|author=Madhav Mohan|publisher=International Business Times|date=22 September 2015|accessdate=22 September 2015}} An NGO([[Non-governmental organization|non-governmental organisation]]) called the "Mandate of People's Suffering" as well as some Riau residents even wrote to the Malaysian government requesting aid.{{cite web|url=http://nasional.news.viva.co.id/news/read/670367-kecewa-dengan-ri--warga-riau-ngadu-ke-malaysia|title=Kecewa dengan RI, Warga Riau Ngadu ke Malaysia|author1=Rochimawati|author2=Ali Azumar|language=Indonesian|publisher=Viva.co.id|date=6 September 2015|accessdate=14 September 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150908162535/http://nasional.news.viva.co.id/news/read/670367-kecewa-dengan-ri--warga-riau-ngadu-ke-malaysia|archive-date=8 September 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite AV media|url=http://video.metrotvnews.com/play/2015/10/05/437786/pemuda-muhammadiyah-riau-minta-bantuan-malaysia-atasi-kabut-asap|title=Pemuda Muhammadiyah Riau Minta Bantuan Malaysia Atasi Kabut Asap|author=ARV|language=Indonesian|medium=video|time=01:28|publisher=Metro TV News|date=5 October 2015|accessdate=6 October 2015}} Some residents and leaders in Riau claimed that the central government was intentionally providing a slow and inadequate response, although the situation had been worsening over time. They explained that foreign aid had been blocked,{{cite web|url=http://vietnamnews.vn/miscellany/276819/indonesia-accepts-international-help-to-combat-fires.html|title=Indonesia accepts international help to combat fires|publisher=Việt Nam News|work=Agence France-Presse|date=8 October 2015|accessdate=10 October 2015}} even though the government had shown an inability to combat the fires itself, and that sub-standard masks were handed out to locals.{{cite web|url=http://www.jpnn.com/read/2015/09/21/328004/Tokoh-Riau-Tuding-Pemerintahan-Jokowi-Lakukan-Genosida-|title=Tokoh Riau Tuding Pemerintahan Jokowi Lakukan Genosida|language=Indonesian|publisher=Jawa Pos|date=21 September 2015|accessdate=8 October 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://nasional.republika.co.id/berita/nasional/umum/15/10/06/nvrvv9335-demi-allah-kabut-asap-ini-sudah-seperti-genosida|title='Demi Allah! Kabut Asap Ini Sudah seperti Genosida'|language=Indonesian|publisher=Republika Online|date=6 October 2015|accessdate=8 October 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.eramuslim.com/berita/nasional/warga-riau-rezim-ini-bunuh-63-juta-rakyat-riau-pelan-pelan.htm#.VhZZ-eyqqko|title=Warga Riau: Rezim Ini Bunuh 6,3 Juta Rakyat Riau Pelan-Pelan|language=Indonesian|publisher=Era Muslim|date=7 October 2015|accessdate=8 October 2015}} The Indonesian government was also criticised for promising to cut [[Carbon dioxide|{{chem|CO|2}}]] emissions by 20% but failing to provide any commitment to zero deforestation as the country has overtaken [[Deforestation in Brazil|Brazil]] in [[Deforestation in Indonesia|terms of deforestation]].{{cite web|url=http://www.greenpeace.org/international/en/news/Blogs/makingwaves/Forest-fires-indonesia-pekanbaru/blog/54046/|title=Choked in smoke – living in the thick of Indonesia’s haze|author=Zamzami|publisher=Greenpeace International|date=11 September 2015|accessdate=14 September 2015}} Indonesia has received a new record from the [[Guinness World Records]] as the country with the fastest destruction of forest due to fire. During the crisis, Indonesia surpassed the [[United States]] as the second largest producer of {{chem|CO|2}} in the world due to the haze,{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/world/asia/la-fg-great-haze-explainer-20151021-htmlstory.html|title=Fires in Southeast Asia may be emitting more greenhouse gases than the entire U.S.|author=Jonathan Kaiman|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=21 October 2015|accessdate=22 October 2015}} just behind [[China]]. The haze, which sent air pollution levels up to 'very unhealthy' levels in neighbouring Malaysia and Singapore, also affected the Pacific nations of [[Guam]], [[Palau]] and the [[Northern Marianas]]. Guam's Office of Homeland Security and Civil Defence spokesperson Jenna Gaminde warned the public to expect the haze to reduce visibility and adversely affect those with respiratory issues. Western Melanesia was currently susceptible to winds from [[Typhoon Koppu (2015)|Typhoon Koppu]] and Champi pulling smoke plumes from vast fires in Indonesia and [[Papua New Guinea]]. The [[World Resources Institute]] said in an October report that since early September, carbon emissions from the fires had exceeded average US daily output on 26 out of 44 days.{{cite web|title=South-East Asian haze strikes the Pacific as fires exceed greenhouse gas output of the US|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-10-21/se-asian-fires-producing-more-greenhouse-gas-than-us-report-says/6874598|accessdate=21 October 2015|publisher=[[American Broadcasting Company]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/indonesia/berita_indonesia/2015/10/151021_indonesia_emisi_as|title=Gara-gara kabut asap, Indonesia kalahkan AS soal emisi karbon|language=Indonesian|publisher=BBC News|date=21 October 2015|accessdate=21 October 2015}} If the haze continues until next year, the haze could be the worst [[Southeast Asian haze|haze crisis in Southeast Asia]] since the [[1997 Southeast Asia haze]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/indonesia/berita_indonesia/2015/10/151002_indonesia_asap_rekorn|title=Kebakaran hutan dan lahan Indonesia bisa samai insiden 1997|language=Indonesian|publisher=BBC News|date=2 October 2015|accessdate=21 October 2015}} Robert Field, a [[NASA]] scientist from [[Columbia University]], stated: {{quote|If the forecasts for a longer dry season hold, this suggests 2015 will rank among the most severe events on record.}} Weak enforcement of environmental laws have been criticised; in previous forest burnings, many of the perpetrators, who mostly comprised employees of Indonesian palm oil companies, had been caught with strong evidence of criminal activity but still managed to escape from getting heavier penalties. A group of [[Malaysians]] gathered in front of the Indonesian embassy in [[Kuala Lumpur]] to show their protest over Indonesia's illegal fires.{{cite AV media|url=http://english.astroawani.com/malaysia-videos/malaysians-protest-against-indonesias-illegal-fires-67056|title=Malaysians protest against Indonesia's illegal fires|medium=video|time=00:35|publisher=Astro Awani|date=18 September 2015|accessdate=8 October 2015}} In Thailand, around 50 [[Thai people|Thais]] held a peaceful protest in front of the Indonesian consulate in Songkhla to demand that the Indonesian government expedite their action in combating the fires.{{cite web|url=http://www.nationmultimedia.com/national/PM-Asean-help-needed-on-smog-30270326.html|title=PM: Asean help needed on smog|publisher=The Nation|date=7 October 2015|accessdate=7 October 2015}} Another 20 Thais representing the "Hatyai-Songkhla Residents Affected by Haze from Indonesia" group also sent a letter to the Indonesian consulate asking Indonesia to take responsibility and give its commitment to solve the issue.{{cite web|url=http://www.thesundaily.my/news/1574046|title=Thais send letter of complaint to Indonesia|work=Bernama|publisher=The Sun|date=6 October 2015|accessdate=7 October 2015}} Tensions also arose with Singapore when Singapore's largest supermarket [[NTUC FairPrice]] withdrew paper products made by an Indonesian company, [[Asia Pulp & Paper]] (APP) as APP was named as one of the companies responsible for the haze.{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-10-07/singapore-s-biggest-grocer-pulls-toilet-paper-in-haze-rebuke|title=Singapore Retailer Pulls Indonesian Toilet Rolls in Haze Row|author=Sharon Chen|publisher=Bloomberg|date=7 October 2015|accessdate=7 October 2015}} == Reactions == {{flag|Indonesia}} – President [[Joko Widodo]] has instructed government agencies to revoke the permits of any palm oil companies involved in the burning of forests and urged the arrest of those responsible.{{cite web | url = http://globalvoicesonline.org/2015/09/13/haze-returns-to-southeast-asia-as-indonesias-forest-fires-reach-critical-level/ | title = Haze Returns to Southeast Asia as Indonesia's Forest Fires Reach Critical Level|author=Carolina|publisher= GlobalVoices|date= 13 September 2015|accessdate=14 September 2015}} While Jokowi conceded in September 2015 that the recurrent haze was "not a problem that you can solve quickly", he insisted that Indonesia had "gone to great lengths" to tackle the problem, and declared: "You will see results soon and in three years we will have solved this".{{cite web|title=Indonesia 'needs time' to tackle haze - Joko Widodo|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-34387979|publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=4 October 2015}} Around 25,000 [[Indonesian National Armed Forces]] troops had been deployed to battle the fires.{{cite web|url=http://www.3news.co.nz/world/indon-accepts-international-help-on-fires-2015100820#axzz3o6L3EQED|title=Indonesia accepts international help on fires|work=Agence-France Presse|publisher=3 News NZ|date=8 October 2015|accessdate=10 October 2015}} While Indonesian Member of Parliament (MP) Hamdhani Mukhdar Said apologised to both Malaysia and Singapore over the haze,{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/indonesian-mp-apologises/2112520.html|title=Indonesian MP apologises to Singapore, Malaysia for haze|author=Melissa Goh|publisher=Channel News Asia|date=8 September 2015|accessdate=14 September 2015}} Indonesia's Vice-President [[Jusuf Kalla]] restated his position that Indonesia has no obligation to apologise to neighbouring countries for the haze caused by "forest fires" lasting "a month at the most" when these countries were not "grateful" for the "months" of "fresh air from our green environment and our forests when there are no fires".{{cite web|title=Indonesia VP Kalla reiterates that Indonesia does not need to apologise to neighbours over haze|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/kalla-reiterates-that-indonesia-does-not-need-to-apologise-to-neighbours-over-haze|work=[[The Straits Times]]|accessdate=26 September 2015|archivedate=26 September 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150926020730/http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/kalla-reiterates-that-indonesia-does-not-need-to-apologise-to-neighbours-over-haze}}{{cite web|url=http://qz.com/512956/indonesia-provides-nice-air-most-of-the-time-and-all-you-do-is-complain-about-the-pollution/|title=Indonesia provides "nice air" most of the time, and all you do is complain about the pollution|author=Steve Mollman|publisher=Quartz|date=29 September 2015|accessdate=29 September 2015}} In a separate speech, Kalla said that Indonesia is "open", and requested that "Singapore, please come if you want to help. Don't just talk".{{cite web|title=Singapore should help solve haze issue, not just talk about it: Indonesian V-P Jusuf Kalla |url=http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/singapore-should-help-solve-haze-issue-not-just-talk-about-it-indonesian-v-p-jusuf |work=[[The Straits Times]] |accessdate=29 September 2015 |archivedate=29 September 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6buCA1n5l?url=http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/singapore-should-help-solve-haze-issue-not-just-talk-about-it-indonesian-v-p-jusuf |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} However, Indonesian Environment and Forestry Minister Siti Nurbaya Bakar had earlier rejected any Singaporean offers to help Indonesia by stating that Indonesia had enough resources to deal with the crisis.{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/jakarta-declines-help-to-fight-fires|title=Jakarta declines help to fight fires|author=Wahyudi Soeriaatmadja|publisher=The Straits Times|date=13 September 2015|accessdate=14 September 2015}} October saw the [[Indonesian National Board for Disaster Management]] (BNPB) requesting help from Malaysia, Singapore or other countries to secure bigger [[aerial firefighting]] aircraft for Indonesia, around the same time as the Indonesian cabinet finally agreed to receive international help with the crisis, with President Jokowi declaring that Indonesia was now "working with a number of countries including Singapore", and other officials saying that Russia had also offered to help. Cabinet Secretary Pramono Anung explained why Indonesia had earlier rejected Singapore's help, saying that "if we are assisted, the government does not want them to claim the credit".{{cite web|title=Jakarta rejected earlier offers ‘over concerns S’pore would claim credit'|url=http://www.todayonline.com/world/asia/jakarta-rejected-earlier-offers-over-concerns-spore-would-claim-credit|publisher=[[Today (Singapore newspaper)|Today]]|accessdate=10 October 2015}} {{flag|Malaysia}} – Prime Minister [[Najib Razak]] has demanded Indonesia take action against companies responsible for illegal forest fires blanketing parts of Southeast Asia in smoke, adding "Only Indonesia alone can gather evidence and convict the companies concerned".{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-34438189|title=Malaysia's Najib Razak demands Indonesia take action over haze|publisher=BBC News|date=5 October 2015|accessdate=6 October 2015}} Meanwhile, [[Ministry of Education (Malaysia)|Malaysian Education Minister]] [[Mahdzir Khalid]] has stated "We will not compromise with anything that may bring harm to our children in schools". The [[Government of Malaysia|Malaysian government]] has called Indonesia to ratify a new [[memorandum of understanding]] to tackle transboundary haze. According to Malaysian [[Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment (Malaysia)|Minister of Natural Resources and Environment]] [[Wan Junaidi Tuanku Jaafar]] the MoU would let both countries "assisting and exchange ideas with each other in the case of jungle and peat soil fires while requiring Indonesia to comply with its side of the bargain".{{cite web|url=http://english.astroawani.com/malaysia-news/malaysia-indonesia-sign-new-mou-tackle-transboundary-haze-73066|title=Malaysia, Indonesia to sign new MoU to tackle transboundary haze|work=Bernama|publisher=Astro Awani|date=12 September 2015|accessdate=14 September 2015}} The [[Malaysian Fire and Rescue Department|Fire and Rescue Department]] of Sarawak has ready to assist in putting out peat fires in [[Pontianak, Indonesia|Pontianak]], Kalimantan, Indonesia if it is instructed to do.{{cite web|url=http://www.thesundaily.my/news/1555843|title=Sarawak Fire and Rescue Department ready to put out fires in Kalimantan|work=Bernama|publisher=The Sun|date=17 September 2015|accessdate=19 September 2015}} [[Malaysian Armed Forces|Malaysian military]] has also offered to help Indonesia to fight fires in both Sumatra and Kalimantan as been stated by [[Ministry of Defence (Malaysia)|Malaysian Defence Minister]] [[Hishammuddin Hussein]].{{cite web|url=http://en.tempo.co/read/news/2015/09/30/055705111/Malaysia-Offers-Military-Assistance-Fighting-Forest-Fire-Haze|title=Malaysia Offers Military Assistance Fighting Forest Fire, Haze|author=Putri Adityowati|work=The Malay Mail, Antara|publisher=Tempo|date=30 September 2015|accessdate=30 September 2015}} {{flag|Singapore}} – On 3 June 2015, preceding both the dry season and the 2015 haze crisis, the [[Government of Singapore|Singaporean government]] offered Indonesia an 'assistance package' to combat haze; Singapore said assistance had been "consistently" offered "since 2005". The 2015 offer included three [[Lockheed C-130 Hercules|C-130 aircraft]], one [[Boeing CH-47 Chinook|Chinook helicopter]] and a [[Singapore Civil Defence Force]] team.{{cite web|title=Singapore renews haze assistance package offer to Indonesia|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/singapore-renews-haze/1889412.html|publisher=[[Channel News Asia]]|accessdate=11 October 2015|date=3 June 2015}} The offer to deal with the crisis was again reiterated to Indonesia in September when Singapore was then affected by the haze.{{cite web|url=http://www.theborneopost.com/2015/09/11/singapore-offers-assistance-to-indonesia-to-combat-haze/|title=Singapore offers assistance to Indonesia to combat haze|work=Bernama|publisher=The Borneo Post|date=11 September 2015|accessdate=14 September 2015}} At first, Indonesia accepted the offers{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/environment/indonesia-has-accepted-singapores-offer-to-help-fight-forest-fires-in-sumatra|title=Indonesia has accepted Singapore's offer to help fight forest fires in Sumatra|publisher=The Straits Times|date=11 September 2015|accessdate=14 September 2015}} but rejected it under a recent statement by its Environment and Forestry Minister as been confirmed by its ministry's chief spokesman, Mr Eka Soegiri. Singapore has since reiterated the offer according to its former [[Minister for Environment and Water Resources]], Dr [[Vivian Balakrishnan]].{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/singapore-reiterates/2125790.html|title=Singapore reiterates offer of assistance to Indonesia to fight forest fires|publisher=Channel News Asia|date=14 September 2015|accessdate=15 September 2015}} Dr Vivian also delivered Singapore’s national statement at the United Nations (UN) Sustainable Development Summit 2015 on 27 September 2015 at the UN Headquarters in New York US. The Summit has adopted the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, a long-term global development framework that includes a set of 17 [[Sustainable Development Goals]]. In the statement, Minister Balakrishnan also called for closer regional and international co-operation on the issue of transboundary [[Southeast Asian haze|haze pollution in Southeast Asia]].{{cite web|title=Singapore's National Statement by Minister Vivian Balakrishnan at the United Nations Sustainable Development Summit 2015 |url=http://www.news.gov.sg/public/sgpc/en/media_releases/agencies/mewr/press_release/P-20150928-1.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20151006110235/http://www.news.gov.sg/public/sgpc/en/media_releases/agencies/mewr/press_release/P-20150928-1.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=6 October 2015 |accessdate=4 October 2015 }} On 7 October 2015, after the haze had affected parts of Southeast Asia for more than a month, Indonesia finally accepted Singapore's offer to help.{{cite web|title=Indonesia accepts Singapore's offer of haze assistance package|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/indonesia-accepts/2175204.html|accessdate=8 October 2015}} Singapore's [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Singapore)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] said the request was sent via the Indonesian embassy in Singapore. {{flag|Thailand}} – Prime Minister [[Prayut Chan-o-cha]] ordered its [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Thailand)|Foreign Ministry]] co-operate closely with neighbouring countries to tackle the chronic problem that has gripped parts of Southeast Asia. He also instructed officials in each affected [[Provinces of Thailand|province]] to spray water in the air to help improve visibility and to supply masks to the public. Thailand has said that they would push for Asean-level efforts to combat the haze. The Thai government has also offered them help in tackling the haze problem according to its Foreign Ministry deputy permanent secretary Vitavas Srivihok, as the Indonesian envoy had admitted his country's efforts alone were not enough to stop the fires.{{cite web|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/general/723728/government-offers-to-help-jakarta-fight-haze-hazard|title=Government offers to help Jakarta fight haze hazard|author1=Prangthong Jitcharoenkul|author2=Patsara Jikkham|author3=Amornrat Mahitthirook|publisher=Bangkok Post|date=9 October 2015|accessdate=10 October 2015}} == See page.title: Water conflicts between Malaysia and Singapore

revision.comment: /* top */ added context to article
revision.text:
{{more references|date=June 2018}} {{lead too short|date=June 2018}}
'''Singapore and Malaysia''' have a long-standing [[water conflict|conflict]] over [[water supply|water supplies]].
In ensuring sufficient water supply in the rapidly modernising colonial city of Singapore in the 1920s, in 1927, the municipal leadership of Singapore and Sultan Ibrahim of the state and territories of [[Johor]] in neighboring [[British Malaya|Malaya]] signed an agreement that allowed Singapore to rent land in Johor and use its water for free. The Municipal Water Department of Singapore, under [[David J. Murnane]], began importing raw water from Gunong Pulai in 1927 and filtered water on 31 December 1929. Since then, several water agreements had been signed between two countries.
{{TOC right}}
==History== ===20th century=== The first water agreement was signed between [[Ibrahim of Johor|Sultan Ibrahim II]] the [[Sultan of Johor]] and the Municipal Commissioners of the Town of Singapore on 5 December 1927, under the [[Legislative Council of the Straits Settlements]]. It is no longer in force.
On 1 September 1961, the [[Federation of Malaya]] signed an agreement giving Singapore the right to draw up to {{convert|86|e6impgal|m3}} of water per day collectively from the [[Tebrau River]], the [[Skudai River]], the [[Pontian District|Pontian]] Reservoir, and the [[Mount Pulai|Gunung Pulai]] Reservoir, with effect through 2011. On 29 September 1962, a further agreement was signed providing Singapore the right to draw up to {{convert|250|e6impgal|m3}} per day from the [[Johor River]], with effect until 2061. Both agreements stipulated the price of 3 Malaysian cents per {{convert|1,000|impgal|L}}.
In 1994, Linggiu Reservoir was built upstream of the Johor River and collects and releases rainwater. This pushes seawater back into the sea, ensuring that the river water is not too salty to be treated. It is operated by the [[Public Utilities Board]] (PUB) of Singapore.<ref>"Finding ways to increase water supply from Johor River", The Straits Times, 17 January 2018</ref>
===21st century=== The Malaysian government has stated{{when|date=December 2013}} that the agreements were signed in a different time and that the price should increase. It cites the example of water sold by China to Hong Kong in the past, which was approximately US$5.8 per {{convert|1,000|impgal|L}}.<ref>[http://www.wsd.gov.hk/filemanager/common/annual_report/2010_11/pdf/07.pdf Water Supplies Department of Hong Kong Annual Report 2010/11 - Optimising Water Supplies (3.11MB)]</ref> However, this price comparison is not directly applicable because while Hong Kong has borne the cost of constructing the infrastructure and China has borne the cost of maintaining to provide water to Hong Kong, Singapore paid for all the costs of the reservoirs in Johor, the dams, pipelines, plant, equipment, etc., and Singapore paid all costs of operating and maintaining the infrastructure.
On 31 August 2011, the 2011 water agreement expired, and the waterworks and facilities were handed over to the Johor state government. The handover included the Skudai and Gunung Pulai water treatment plants, which were built by the [[Public Utilities Board]] and managed by them for 50 years, as well as two pump houses in [[Pontian District|Pontian]] and [[Tebrau]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/BreakingNews/Singapore/Story/STIStory_707886.html |title=1961 water agreement with Johor expires on Wednesday |publisher=[[The Straits Times]] |accessdate=14 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110922211108/http://www.straitstimes.com/BreakingNews/Singapore/Story/STIStory_707886.html |archivedate=22 September 2011 }} </ref>
On 25 June 2018, Malaysian Prime Minister [[Mahathir Mohamed]] stated his intentions of renegotiating the agreement with Singapore as he views the low price at which water is being exported to Singapore has resulted in Malaysia losing a significant amount of revenue.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/mahathir-water-malaysia-singapore-deal-too-costly-renegotiate-10466390|title=Water supply deal with Singapore ‘too costly’, needs to be settled: Malaysia PM Mahathir|website=Channel NewsAsia}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Malaysia–Singapore relations]]
== Further reading == * {{Cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/cna/parliament/relations/pdf/vol2_a.pdf|title=1927 Water Agreement|accessdate=2010-02-24|format=PDF}} * {{Cite web|url=http://www.iseas.edu.sg/ef12003.pdf|title=The water issue between Singapore and Malaysia: no solution in sight?|accessdate=2008-01-18|publisher=Institute of Southeast Asian Studies|year=2003|author=Lee Poh Onn|work=Ecomics and Finance No.1 |format=PDF}}
