The '''2012 Guangxi cadmium spill''' (广西镉污染事件<ref>{{cite web|url=http://paper.wenweipo.com/2012/02/03/CH1202030007.htm |title=有色金屬之鄉 污染危機未除 - 香港文匯報 |publisher=Paper.wenweipo.com |date= |accessdate=2012-02-06}}</ref>) occurred in early January when toxic [[cadmium]] contaminated the [[Guangxi]] Longjiang river (龙江河) and water supply.
==Incident== [[Hechi]] authorities estimated that more than 40,000 [[kilogram]]s of fish were found dead from January 15 to February 2 within the city limits.<ref name="cdaily1">{{cite web|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/cndy/2012-02/04/content_14536059.htm |title=Officials fired over cadmium spill |publisher=chinadaily.com.cn |date= |accessdate=2012-02-06}}</ref> The spill was caused by Jinhe Mining company (沿河兩岸工廠). The spill is estimated to be 80 times the official limit, according to regional government protection official Feng Zhennian<ref name="bbc.co.uk">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-16804833|title=Seven detained over China river cadmium spill|work=BBC News|accessdate=25 May 2015}}</ref>
A toxic slick stretching more than 100[[kilometres|km]] along the Longjiang river reached the Nuomitan hydroelectric station, 57 km upstream from [[Liuzhou]], with cadmium levels five times above the national standard.<ref>South China morning post. No easy fix as huge spill threatens Liuzhou's water . 31 Jan 2012.</ref> In one month 20 [[tonnes]] of toxic cadmium metals were spilled into the river.<ref>South China morning post. Toxic metal spill may be worst in decades. 1 Feb 2012.</ref>
==Control== The government stopped supply of tap water to Liuzhou city, affecting 3.7 million residents.<ref name="scmp1">South China morning post. Media blasts officials over toxic river pollution. 1 Feb 2012.</ref> Seven company executives deemed responsible for the contamination were detained.<ref name="scmp1" /> Seven government officials were fired, including two punished for the spill.<ref name="cdaily1" /> According to local government officials from the [[Xinhua News Agency]], the pollution is under control after two weeks of cleanup. Shortly after the spill, residents of the city of Liuzhou emptied supermarkets of bottled water out of fear of contamination.<ref name="bbc.co.uk"/> Many scientists working on purification decided to return to the river, despite being hospitalized for contamination.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://news.linktv.org/videos/millions-affected-by-southern-china-cadmium-spill |title=Archived copy |access-date=2013-02-05 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120302193237/http://news.linktv.org/videos/millions-affected-by-southern-china-cadmium-spill |archive-date=2012-03-02 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
More than 60% of cadmium content in the Longjiang River in [[Hechi]], previously reported as five times higher than the restricted level, has been diluted and absorbed, according to experts. [[Guangdong]], [[Macau]] and [[Hong Kong]] are said to be unaffected.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.macaudailytimes.com.mo/macau/33290-Cadmium-spill-threat-Macau-water-safety.html |title=Cadmium spill no threat to Macau water safety |publisher=Macau Daily Times |date= |accessdate=2012-02-06}}</ref> Chinese environmentalists are calling for a cadmium pollution fund to be set up to compensate for the long-term impact of the spill, according to state-run newspaper ''[[China Daily]]''.<ref>http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/cndy/2012-02/04/content_14536059.htm</ref> "These kinds of disasters make it obvious that this is the time to change, to push for more transparency," says [[Ma Jun (environmentalist)|Ma Jun]], a well-respected Chinese green activist and director of the Institute of Public & Environmental Affairs.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970204740904577193680165583346|title=Cadmium Spill Threatens Water Supply|author=Laurie Burkitt|date=1 February 2012|work=WSJ|accessdate=25 May 2015}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Water pollution in China]] * [[Fish kill]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=June 2013}}
The '''Tianji Coal Chemical Industry Group chemical spill''' was a severe chemical spill that occurred in [[Shanxi]] Province, [[China]] during 2012–13. More than 39 tons of [[aniline]]s (toxic chemicals widely used as precursors in the manufacture of pigment,<ref>Fei Xuening, Zhang Tianyong, Zhou Chunlong, Modification study involving a Naphthol as red pigment, Dyes and Pigments, Volume 44, Issue 2, January 2000, Pages 75-80, {{ISSN|0143-7208}}, {{doi|10.1016/S0143-7208(99)00072-8}}.</ref> herbicides <ref>Lyons, C. D., Katz, S. E., and Bartha, R.: Persistence and mutagenic potential of herbicide-derived aniline residues in pond water, B Environ Contam Tox, 35, 696-703, {{doi|10.1007/bf01636575}}, 1985.</ref> and other chemicals) leaked from a loose drainage valve at a plant owned by Tianji Coal Chemical Industry Group in the [[Shanxi]] city of [[Changzhi]]. This chemical spill contaminated the Zhuozhang River which is the source of drinking water for more than one million people, and so caused a water crisis in the downstream City of [[Handan]], [[Hebei]] Province.
== Tianji Coal Chemical Industry Group == Tianji Coal Chemical Industry Group is one of the five largest state-owned coal companies in Shanxi.<ref>[http://file.lw23.com/f/f8/f80/f80370ca-a8e5-43db-ae63-fd8b1d491ba7.pdf Current conditions and development of Tianji Group Company, in Chinese]</ref> They use a water-intensive [[gasification]] process to convert [[coal]] to chemicals that are critical for a wide range of products. According to a Greenpeace report,<ref>[http://www.greenpeace.org/china/zh/news/stories/toxics/2013/01/shanxi-coal-to-chemicals/ Greenpeace Report, Tianji pollution remains (in Chinese), Jan 2013 in Shanxi Province]</ref> the factory owned by Tianji Industry Group in Changzhi dumps more than six million tons of wastewater per year. In 2010 and 2011, Tianji was judged by Shanxi’s environmental protection bureau to be polluting above normal levels in four quarters and was fined each time.
== Aniline leak == An aniline leak occurred on December 31, 2012 due to a poor-quality metal hose. About 39 tons of aniline, a potential [[carcinogen]], went into the drainage from the [[fertilizer]] factory. Thirty tons were contained by a reservoir, but nearly nine tons leaked into the Zhuozhang River. A large amount of dead fish was seen in the upper reaches of the Zhuozhang River. Leaked aniline traveled along the [[Zhang River]] and reached reservoirs in neighboring cities.
== Water crisis == The contaminated Zhuozhang River feeds into the [[Zhang River]], which is a source of drinking water for [[Shanxi]], [[Hebei]] and [[Henan]] provinces. Therefore, the spill affected at least 28 villages and a handful of cities of more than one million people, including Handan. After receiving confirmation of this chemical spill, officials in [[Handan]] shut down part of its municipal water supply system,<ref>[http://greenleapforward.com/2013/01/22/green-hops-aniline-spill-50-gw-renewables-target-nukes-resume/ China.org.cn Report, Aniline Spills, Jan 2013]</ref> which sent residents into a scramble for bottled water. In the countryside, officials also told farmers not to graze their livestock near the river. Fire engines were mobilized to bring water to the city's residents and 66,000 bottles of clean water were bought in from other cities. Underground reservoirs were also opened to support the city’s water use.
== River cleanup == Nearly 5000 workers were called in for an immediate clean-up of the river.<ref>[https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2013/01/chinas-poison-filled-river/267195/ TheAtlantic Report, China's Poison-Filled River, Jan 2013]</ref> Because of the low temperature, a large part of contaminants was stopped by ice in the river. 670 tons of contaminated ice and more than 750 tons of wastewater have been cleared away. [[Activated carbon]] was also used to absorb the chemicals remaining in the unfrozen water below.<ref>[http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/cndy/2013-01/11/content_16104394.htm Chinadaily Report, Chemical leak into river puts focus on plant, Jan 11th 2013]</ref> After several days of cleanup, concentrations of aniline in the river decreased to 2.15 mg/L from the previous level of 72 mg/L, according to data from Wangjiazhuang monitoring station on Zhuozhang river near the eastern border of Shanxi province.<ref>[http://www.china.org.cn/china/2013-01/07/content_27607047.htm China org Report, Officials sacked over chemical leaks in N. China river, Jan 7th 2013]</ref> However, based on national standards, the concentration should be less than 0.1 mg/L. Since the pollutants are not expected to decompose easily, it took weeks to solve the problems caused by this spill.
== Delayed report == After the aniline leak occurred, officials in [[Changzhi]] delayed reporting the spill for five days. The reason for delay is not clear, but it may be due to the large underestimations of the amount of leaked anilines in the first few days after spills. According to the regulation passed by the State Council in 2007, an institution responsible for an accident should report within an hour to the production safety department of a county-level government or higher. The report should reach a higher level of government within two hours. The mayor of Changzhi has apologized for the delay in reporting the spill affecting supplies of drinking water.<ref>[http://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2013/01/08/Chemical-spill-poisons-drinking-water/UPI-26131357623238/ UPI Report, Chemical spill poisons drinking water, Jan 8th 2013]</ref>
== Punishment == After investigation into this spill, 24 managers in the company who were responsible for supervision were given administrative disciplinary sanctions. The mayor of Changzhi was removed from his position. Two heads of the plant's storage workshop were fired.<ref>[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/china/2013-02/20/c_132181262.htm Xinhua Net Report, 39 punished over N China chemical leak, Feb 20th 2013]</ref>
== Challenges == The conflict over the Changzhi spill has drawn attention to the growing problems with water use and [[pollution in China]]. In 2011, inspections in 200 cities across China found that water in 55 percent of the tests was rated “fairly poor to extremely poor”.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/03/world/asia/spill-in-china-lays-bare-environmental-concerns.html?pagewanted=all&_r=1& New York Times Report, Spill in China Underlines Environmental Concerns, March 3rd 2013]</ref> During the last ten years, China has witnessed major pollution incidents due to the pursuit of economic benefit and the neglect of pollution control by local governments and enterprises. Deficiencies in emergency mechanisms to handle environmental incidents at some local governments worsen the pollution problems.<ref>[http://www.china.org.cn/china/2013-01/07/content_27607047.htm China org Report, Officials sacked over chemical leaks in N. China river, Jan 7th 2013]</ref>
== See also == *[[Environmental issues in China]]

[[File:Tree-Sparrow-2009-16-02.jpg|thumb|right|250px|The [[Eurasian tree sparrow]] was the most notable target of the campaign.]] The '''Four Pests Campaign''' ({{zh|c={{linktext|除|四|害}}}}), was one of the first actions taken in the [[Great Leap Forward]] in China from 1958 to 1962. The four pests to be eliminated were [[rat]]s, [[fly|flies]], [[mosquito]]es, and [[sparrow]]s. The extermination of sparrows is also known as '''Great Sparrow Campaign''' ({{zh|c={{linktext|打|麻|雀|运|动}}|p={{linktext|Dǎ| Má|què| Yùn|dòng}}}}) or '''Kill Sparrows Campaign''' ({{zh|c={{linktext|消灭麻雀运动}}|p={{linktext|Xiāo|miè| Máquè| Yùndòng}}}}), which resulted in severe ecological imbalance, being one of the reasons of [[Great Chinese Famine]]. In 1960, Mao ended the campaign against sparrows and redirected the fourth focus to bed bugs. ==Campaign== The "Four Pests" campaign was introduced in 1958 by [[Mao Zedong]], as a hygiene campaign aimed to eradicate the pests responsible for the transmission of pestilence and disease: the mosquitos responsible for malaria; the rodents that spread the plague; the pervasive airborne flies; and the sparrows – specifically the [[Eurasian tree sparrow]] – which ate [[grain]] seed and fruit.{{Cite news|url=http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/bodyhorrors/2014/02/26/mao-four-pests-china-disease/#.WP7DeJMrJE4|title=Paved With Good Intentions: Mao Tse-Tung’s "Four Pests" Disaster – Body Horrors|date=2014-02-26|work=Body Horrors|access-date=2017-04-25|language=en-US}} The government also declared that "birds are public animals of capitalism". As a result of this campaign, many sparrows died from exhaustion; citizens would bang pots and pans so that sparrows would not have the chance to rest on tree branches and would fall dead from the sky.{{Cite web|url=https://chineseposters.net/themes/four-pests.php|title=Eliminate the Four Pests (1958)|website=chineseposters.net|access-date=2017-04-25}} Sparrow nests were also destroyed, eggs were broken, and chicks were killed. In addition to these tactics, citizens also resorted to simply shooting the birds down from the sky.{{Cite news|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120822081443/http://io9.com/5927112/chinas-worst-self+inflicted-disaster-the-campaign-to-wipe-out-the-common-sparrow|title=China’s Worst Self-Inflicted Environmental Disaster: The Campaign to Wipe Out the Common Sparrow|last=Dvorsky|first=George|work=io9|access-date=2017-04-25|language=en-US|url=http://io9.com/5927112/chinas-worst-self+inflicted-disaster-the-campaign-to-wipe-out-the-common-sparrow|archivedate=2012-08-22}} These mass attacks depleted the sparrow population, pushing it to near extinction. Furthermore, contests were held among enterprises, government agencies, and schools in cleanliness. Non-material rewards were given to those who handed in the largest number of rat tails, dead flies and mosquitoes, or dead sparrows.{{Cite web|url=https://chineseposters.net/themes/four-pests.php|title=Eliminate the Four Pests (1958)|website=chineseposters.net|access-date=2017-04-25}}
At dawn one day last week, the slaughter of the sparrows in Peking began, continuing a campaign that has been going on in the countryside for months. The objection to the sparrows is that, like the rest of China's inhabitants, they are hungry. They are accused of pecking away at supplies in warehouses and in paddyfields at an officially estimated rate of four pounds of grain per sparrow per year. And so divisions of soldiers deployed through Peking streets, their footfalls muffled by rubber-soled sneakers. Students and civil servants in high-collared tunics, and schoolchildren carrying pots and pans, ladles and spoons, quietly took up their stations. The total force, according to Radio Peking, numbered 3,000,000.{{Cite news|url=http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,863327,00.html|title=Red China: Death to Sparrows|date=1958-05-05|work=Time|access-date=2017-04-25|issn=0040-781X}}
Some sparrows found [[refuge (ecology)|refuge]] in the [[extraterritoriality|extraterritorial]] premises of various [[diplomatic mission]]s in China. The personnel of the [[Embassy of Poland, Beijing|Polish embassy in Beijing]] denied the Chinese request of entering the premises of the embassy to scare away the sparrows who were hiding there and as a result the embassy was surrounded by people with drums. After two days of constant drumming, the Poles had to use shovels to clear the embassy of dead sparrows.{{cite web |url=http://wyborcza.pl/1,75248,140878.html |title= Chiny. Historia |last=|first=|date=2 June 1999 |access-date=3 May 2016 |language=Polish |trans-title=China. History}} By April 1960, Chinese leaders changed their opinion due to the influence of ornithologist [[Tso-hsin Cheng]]{{cite journal|journal=Der Ornithologische Beobachter| volume= 99|pages=49–70 |year=2002| title= Erinnerungen an Ornithologen, die ich kannte (4. Teil)|first=Eugeniusz |last=Nowak|url=http://m.ala-schweiz.ch/images/stories/pdf/ob/2002_99/OrnitholBeob_2002_99_49_Nowak.pdf| language=German}} who pointed out that sparrows ate a large number of insects, as well as grains.{{cite book|title=Mao's War Against Nature: Politics and the Environment in Revolutionary China|last=Shapiro|first=Judith Rae|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2001|isbn=0-521-78680-0}}{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/environment/the-secret-life-of-sparrows-410252.html|title=The secret life of sparrows|last=McCarthy|first=Michael|date=2 August 2006|newspaper=The Independent|accessdate=30 January 2009}} Rather than being increased, rice yields after the campaign were substantially decreased.{{cite book|title=In Search of Sparrows|last=Summers-Smith|first=J. Denis|publisher=Poyser|year=1992|isbn=0-85661-073-9|location=London|pages=122–124|authorlink=J. Denis Summers-Smith}} Mao ordered the end of the campaign against sparrows, replacing them with [[Bed bug (insect)|bed bug]]s, as the extermination of the former upset the ecological balance, and bugs destroyed crops as a result of the absence of natural predators. By this time, however, it was too late. With no sparrows to eat them, [[locust]] populations ballooned, swarming the country and compounding the ecological problems already caused by the [[Great Leap Forward]], including widespread deforestation and misuse of poisons and pesticides. Ecological imbalance is credited with exacerbating the [[Great Chinese Famine]], in which 20–45 million people died of starvation.{{cite journal|last=Peng|first=Xizhe|title=Demographic Consequences of the Great Leap Forward in China's Provinces|journal=Population and Development Review |volume=13|issue= 4 |year=1987|pages=639–670|doi=10.2307/1973026|jstor=1973026}}{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/books/news/maos-great-leap-forward-killed-45-million-in-four-years-2081630.html|newspaper=The Independent|title=Mao's Great Leap Forward 'killed 45 million in four years'|date=17 September 2010|last=Akbar|first=Arifa}} ==Revived campaign== On June 19, 1998, a poster was spotted at [[Southwest Agricultural University]] in [[Chongqing]], "Get rid of the Four Pests". Ninety-five percent of households were ordered to get rid of four pests. This time, sparrows were replaced with [[cockroach]]es. A similar campaign was spotted in the spring of 1998 in [[Beijing]]. Few people responded to these campaigns, as many already had the habit of killing the aforementioned pests, especially cockroaches. ==Cultural influence== In the [[TVB]] drama series ''[[Rosy Business]]'' (aired 2009 but set in mid-19th century China), a peasant came up with the idea of killing the sparrows to improve agricultural output. It was meant to be a prank used to trick the peasant owners into starvation and poverty. In Episode 20 of the children's animated television series ''[[Sagwa, the Chinese Siamese Cat]]'' (aired 2001–2002 but set in China around 1900), the mistress of the house declares that certain useless animals are banned from the compound. After the animals – the episode's eponymous birds, bees, and silkworms – are driven out, the family discovers the consequences. The mistress' fancy banquet is ruined by the lack of food and clothing, and she learns a valuable lesson. The album ''[[Every Red Heart Shines Toward the Red Sun]]'' (2006) by the American post-rock band [[Red Sparowes]] tells, by way of its song titles, the story of the Great Sparrow Campaign. The children's book ''[[Sparrow Girl]]'' (2009) by [[Sara Pennypacker]] tells the story of the Sparrow War. ==See also== * [[Emu War]] * [[List of campaigns of the Communist Party of China]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[[PBS]] series "''The Peoples' Century – 1949: The Great Leap''" *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/3371659.stm China follows Mao with mass cull (BBC)] [[Category:Birds of China]] [[Category:Campaigns of the Communist Party of China]] [[Category:Environmental disasters in China]] [[Category:Pest control campaigns]] [[Category:Maoist China]] [[Category:1958 in China]] [[Category:1962 in China]] [[Category:1958 in the environment]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox event |title=2013 Eastern China smog |image=File:Chinahaze_tmo_2013341_lrg.jpg |caption=This 7 December 2013 image from the [[NASA]]'s Terra satellite shows the severity of smog blanketing Eastern China. |date=December 2013 |time= |place=East China |coordinates = |cause=Lack of cold air flow, air masses carrying industrial emissions |deaths=0-10 }}
The '''2013 Eastern China smog''' was a severe air pollution episode that affected [[East China]], including all or parts of the municipalities of [[Shanghai]] and [[Tianjin]], and the provinces of [[Hebei]], [[Shandong]], [[Jiangsu]], [[Anhui]], [[Henan]], and [[Zhejiang]], during December 2013. A lack of cold air flow, combined with slow-moving [[air mass]]es carrying industrial emissions, collected [[air pollution|airborne pollutants]] to form a thick layer of smog over the region. Levels of [[particulates|PM<sub>2.5</sub>]] particulate matter averaged over 150 micrograms per cubic metre; in some areas, they were 300 to 500 micrograms per cubic metre.
It was one of the worst bouts of air pollution in the area, cutting visibility and causing major disruption in transportation and daily activities. Airports, highways, and schools were closed.<!--something about area-wide effects-->
==Background== In January 2013, China experienced massive fog and haze outbreak affecting about 600 million people and covering seventeen provinces, municipalities and autonomous regions, a fourth of China's territory.<ref name=nfzm201310>{{cite news|title=China Will Establish Network To Monitor Smog's Health Effects (我国将建立雾霾健康影响监测网络) |url=http://www.infzm.com/content/95493 |work=[[Southern Weekly]] |language=Chinese |date=29 October 2013 |accessdate=7 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131213073054/http://www.infzm.com/content/95493 |archivedate=13 December 2013 }}</ref> On 12 September 2013, the State Council announced the "Air Pollution Prevention Plan".<ref>{{cite news |title=(Authorized Release) Air Pollution Prevention Plan ((授权发布)大气污染防治行动计划) |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/politics/2013-09/12/c_117349304.htm |agency=[[Xinhua News Agency]] |language=Chinese |date=12 September 2013|accessdate=7 December 2013}}</ref> China limited the fine particulate matter level, and the Chinese government officials' assessment index included improving the environment for the first time.<ref name=nfzm201309>{{cite news|title=Strictest in History: "Air Pollution Prevention Plan" Introduced (史上最严：《大气污染防治行动计划》出台) |url=http://www.infzm.com/content/94377 |work=[[Southern Weekly]] |language=Chinese |date=13 September 2013 |accessdate=7 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131213070810/http://www.infzm.com/content/94377 |archivedate=13 December 2013 }}</ref>
On 4 November 2013, the [[Chinese Academy of Social Sciences]] and the [[China Meteorological Administration]] jointly released the "Green Paper on Climate Change: Addressing Climate Change (2013)". It stated that the fog and smog in China had increased in the past 50 years with the number of fog-free days significantly reduced, while that of the smog days were significantly increasing with the phenomenon of persisting smog days. The fastest growing fog and smog days occurred in the [[Pearl River Delta|Pearl]] and [[Yangtze River Delta Economic Zone|Yangtze River Delta]] regions, which are the most industrialized areas. The report also indicated that the main reason of increased fog and smog days is the yearly increase in [[fossil fuel]] consumption in China. The report calls for urgent implementation of regional joint prevention and control measures to effectively solve the air pollution crisis.<ref name=nfzm201311>{{cite news|title=Green Paper on Climate Change States Causes and Effects of Smog Days (气候变化绿皮书指出雾霾天原因及危害) |url=http://www.infzm.com/content/95690 |work=[[Southern Weekly]] |language=Chinese |date=5 November 2013 |accessdate=7 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131213072253/http://www.infzm.com/content/95690 |archivedate=13 December 2013 }}</ref>
===Weather=== The mixture of natural fog and unnatural smog started accumulating over the first weekend of December 2013. In Shanghai, the [[Air Quality Index]] (AQI) crossed the threshold of 300 on 2 December.<ref>{{cite news|last=Zhang |first=Yiqian |url=http://www.globaltimes.cn/content/829983.shtml |title=Severe winter smog shrouds eastern China |work=Global Times |date=5 December 2013|accessdate=24 March 2014}}</ref> The lingering smog also left the air qualities in neighboring cities, such as [[Nanjing]], [[Jiaxing]], at seriously polluted levels. [[National Meteorological Center of CMA|The National Meteorological Center]] (NMC) issued yellow alert for smog and fog, the third most serious alert in China's four-tiered system.<ref>{{cite news|title=Smog and fog hit east, north China|url=http://www.china.org.cn/environment/2013-12/06/content_30814209.htm|accessdate=29 March 2014|agency=Xinhua News Agency|date=6 December 2013}}</ref> PM<sub>2.5</sub> particulate levels reached their highest point on 6 December 2013, with Shanghai reaching a high of 507.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/CGShanghaiAir/status/408811882850426880 |title=12-06-2013 12:00; PM2.5; 507.0; 504; Beyond Index (at 24-hour exposure at this level) |publisher=Con Gen ShanghaiAir |date=6 December 2013|accessdate=24 March 2014}}</ref> The U.S. Embassy categorizes air quality readings over 300 as hazardous to all humans, not just those with heart or lung ailments.
According to a NASA Terra Satellite image, the thick haze stretches over Eastern China, across a distance of around {{convert|1200|km}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/IOTD/view.php?id=82535 |title=Smog Shrouds Eastern China |publisher=Earth Observatory |date=10 December 2013|accessdate=24 March 2014}}</ref> The polluted air appears gray on the image and most of the pollution is trapped in the lower boundary layer of a few hundred meters.
===Causes=== Coal burning is a primary source of fine particle air pollution. It increased as the weather worsened during winter months and residents burned more coal to keep warm. This increased the amount of [[sulphate]] and [[nitrate]] (results of coal combusting), which led to higher PM<sub>2.5</sub>. Research suggests that 41% of the [[carbon]] that made up these high PM<sub>2.5</sub> levels in Shanghai were also from coal burning.<ref>Cao, J.-J., Zhu, C.-S., Tie, X.-X., Geng, F.-H., Xu, H.-M., Ho, S.S.H., Wang, G.H., Han, Y.-M., Ho, K.-F. (2013). Characteristics and sources of carbonaceous aerosols from Shanghai, China. Atmos. Chem. Phys., 13, 803–817, 2013</ref>
Additionally, there were pollution from industrial sources. [[Jiangsu]], Anhui, [[Shandong]], Henan and many eastern provinces are heavy coal-burning regions. Research shows that prevailing winds blew low-hanging air masses of factory emissions (mostly [[sulfur dioxide|SO<sub>2</sub>]]) towards the east coast of China.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.greenpeace.org.uk/newsdesk/energy/data/map-shanghais-charts-air-pollution |title=Map: Shanghai's off the charts air pollution |publisher=Greenpeace |date=6 December 2013 |accessdate=24 March 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140307155938/http://www.greenpeace.org.uk/newsdesk/energy/data/map-shanghais-charts-air-pollution |archive-date=7 March 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Regional transportation also had a significant impact on air quality.
The State Environmental Protection Administration investigates tens of thousands of polluters every year, shutting down thousands of the worse offenders, but has failed to reach its target of reducing emissions by 2 percent.<ref>"[http://www.360doc.com/content/07/0508/23/21275_489581.shtml China shuts down thousands of firms for pollution offences]". ''People Online''. 8 May 2007. Retrieved 22 Oct 2014.</ref> In 2011, a factory manufacturing solar panels in Zhejiang province had been shut down because of toxic emissions of [[fluorine]] polluting air and water, sickening nearby residents.<ref>"[http://www.360doc.com/content/11/0919/11/363711_149446231.shtml Solar panel plant shut down as residents protest]". ''People Online''. 19 Sept 2011. Retrieved 22 Oct 2014.</ref>
==Effects on major cities and provinces==
===Shanghai=== [[File:Shanghai haze in Huangpu Distract 20131206.jpg|thumb|Smog in Huangpu District, Shanghai, 6 December 2013]] Air in Shanghai was reported to have strange taste – astringent and smoky, with an aftertaste of earthy bitterness.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/12/07/shanghai-smog_n_4402477.html |title=Shanghai Smog Hits Extremely Hazardous Levels |work=Huffington Post |date=7 December 2013|accessdate=24 March 2014}}</ref> It was possible to feel the dust-like particulate matter on tongues.
With such a high concentration of air pollutants, government authorities warned residents of health symptoms, such as coughing and headaches. Citizens were advised to wear protective masks and use air purifiers. Many sanitation workers were required to wear dust masks during work early in the morning. Schools were closed as the government ordered children to stay indoors, and reduce outdoor activities as much as possible.
Construction work was halted and authorities pulled nearly one-third of government vehicles from the roads. A majority of inbound flights were cancelled and more than 50 flights were diverted at Shanghai Pudong International Airport.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/china/article/1374386/children-and-elderly-told-stay-home-severe-smog-continues-envelop?_ga=1.70899472.1277584320.1394050026 |title=Shanghai grinds to a halt as smog nears top of air pollution scale |work=South China Morning Post |date=7 December 2013|accessdate=24 March 2014}}</ref>
===Nanjing=== The heavy smog greatly polluted central and southern Jiangsu Province, especially around [[Nanjing]], capital of East China's Jiangsu province.<ref name=wylww/> AQI remained at "severely polluted" for five straight days, "heavily polluted" for nine, and hit a record-breaking value of 331. [[particulates|PM<sub>10</sub>]] also went over 500 at times.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.chinadialogue.net/article/show/single/en/6632-Environmental-officials-deny-blame-for-eastern-China-smog |title=Environmental officials deny blame for eastern China smog |publisher=China Dialogue |date=6 January 2014|accessdate=24 March 2014}}</ref> On 3 December 2013, levels of PM<sub>2.5</sub> particulate matter averaged over 943 micrograms per cubic metre,<ref name=xinhua131213XJB>{{cite web|title=长三角遭遇重度霾 专家称石油化工和尾气是主因 |url=http://finance.people.com.cn/n/2013/1213/c66323-23828723.html |publisher=人民网（转载自《新京报》） |date=2013-12-13 |accessdate=2013-12-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131216062505/http://finance.people.com.cn/n/2013/1213/c66323-23828723.html |archivedate=16 December 2013 }}</ref> decreasing to over 338 micrograms per cubic metre on 4 December.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.chinanews.com/tp/hd2011/2013/12-04/272975.shtml|title = 中国出现入冬以来最大范围雾霾 局地严重污染 (Smog levels in China reach record levels since the end of 2013; surrounding areas severely polluted) | publisher = China news agency | author = Liu Chen-yao |language=Chinese}}</ref> Between 3:00 pm, 3 December and 2:00pm, 4 December local time, several expressways from Nanjing to other Jiangsu cities were closed, stranding dozens of passenger buses in Zhongyangmen bus station.<ref name=wylww>{{cite web|url=http://news.qq.com/a/20131205/001551.htm|title=我国25个省现雾霾 江苏成污染重灾区全国最严重|publisher=腾讯转现代快报|author=吴怡、刘伟伟}}</ref> From 5 to 6 December, Nanjing's air pollution stayed at red alert, suspending classes in all middle and primary schools and kindergartens. Experts say these figures indicate high levels of dust on construction sites. Children's Hospital outpatient services increased by 33 percent; the general incidence of bronchitis, pneumonia, upper respiratory tract infection increased significantly.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/yzyd/legal/20131206/c_118457444.htm|title=雾霾天南京学校停课 儿童医院门诊量上升三分之一|publisher=新华网|author=孙莹}}</ref> The smog dissipated 12 December.<ref name=ShanghaiGOV131210>{{cite web|url=http://www.shanghai.gov.cn/shanghai/node2314/node2315/node4411/u21ai820642.html|title=12日后受冷空气和降雨影响 南方大范围雾霾将告一段落|publisher=上海政府网|author=}}</ref> Officials blamed the dense pollution on lack of wind, automobile exhaust emissions under low air pressure and [[coal]]-powered [[district heating]] system in [[North China]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/local/2013-12/07/c_118458506.htm|title=三问今冬十面"霾"伏|publisher=人民日报海外版|author=综合本报和新华社电}}</ref>
===Jiangxi=== [[Visibility]] was reduced to less than 50 meters. Many highways in East China's Jiangxi province were closed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://usa.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2013-12/05/content_17154391.htm |title=Smog and fog hit east, north China |work=China Daily |date=5 December 2014|accessdate=24 March 2014}}</ref>
[[File:Air Contamination in Ningbo, 2013-12-07 02.jpg|thumb|Air contamination in Ningbo, Zhejiang, 7 December 2013]]
==Environmental impacts== The severe smog is raising awareness in re-assessing China's air pollution. On 12 February 2014, China's cabinet announced that government will implement a series of measures aimed at shifting the primary energy source from coal to natural gas and [[renewable energy|renewables]]. Pricing mechanisms will be used to favor cleaner alternatives to coal. Financial incentives will be offered to encourage [[sustainable energy|green energy]] companies. The government will place tougher controls over emissions and better support for developing clean technologies. It will also set up a 10 billion renminbi (US$1.7 billion) fund to help companies to meet new environmental standards.<ref>Qiu, Jane. ''Fight against smog ramps up'' ([http://www.nature.com/news/fight-against-smog-ramps-up-1.14730 Nature], 18 February 2014).</ref>
== Pollutants == [[File:上海中心 20131206 114511.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Heavy smog obscures the top of [[Shanghai Tower]]]] PM<sub>2.5</sub>, a particulate matter with a diameter of 2.5 micrometers or less, is one of the major components of the air pollution in Eastern China, contributing to the growing smog problem in large areas across cities.<ref name="science 1">{{cite journal | title=The socioeconomic drivers of China's primary PM2.5 emissions | journal=Environmental Research Letters | volume=9 | issue=2 | pages=024010 | doi=10.1088/1748-9326/9/2/024010 |year = 2014|last1 = Guan|first1 = Dabo| last2=Su | first2=Xin | last3=Zhang | first3=Qiang | last4=Peters | first4=Glen P. | last5=Liu | first5=Zhu | last6=Lei | first6=Yu | last7=He | first7=Kebin }}</ref>
The composition of PM<sub>2.5</sub> particles varies, and they are often made of heavy metals and various toxic compounds, such as lead and sulfate. Small particles can be suspended in the air for long periods of time due to their low masses. While some particles such as large-size carbon may be seen as soot and smoke, most of them can only be detected with a [[microscope]]. The Chinese Academy of Sciences indicated that smog in Beijing is a combination of both artificial factors and natural factors. While various causes such as [[coal]] burning and car emissions come from human activity, natural causes such as the humid weather and a lack of [[wind]] also contributed to the smog.<ref name="science 2">{{cite web | url=http://www.china.org.cn/video/2013-02/19/content_27995340.htm | title=Toxic compound found in Beijing smog | publisher=China.org.cn | accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref>
A study in 2005 in Beijing showed that PM<sub>2.5</sub> is mostly composed of carbon, SO{{su|b=4|p=2−}} salts, NO{{su|b=3|p=−}} salts, and NH{{su|b=4|p=+}} salts. PM<sub>2.5</sub> is a byproduct of the process of coal burning from power stations and produces significant amounts of sulfate, black carbon, ammonium, and nitrate. In 1989, 32.7% of PM<sub>2.5</sub> particulates in Beijing came from burning of coal, which decreased to 16.4% in 2000, as people started to use cleaner energy such as [[natural gas]]. Automobile exhaust also significantly contributed to the smog problem.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/282414458 | title=Chemical characteristics of PM2.5 species in Beijing ambient air | publisher=Beijing GM Research and Development Center | accessdate=6 May 2016 | author=Chan Chak | pages=48090–9055}}</ref> More importantly, such chemicals, along with [[organic carbon]] released from coal burning, may react with each other in the air, creating more toxic, harmful particles made of SO{{su|b=4|p=2−}} and NO{{su|b=3|p=−}}.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.atmos-chem-phys.net/13/4631/2013/acp-13-4631-2013.pdf | title=Characteristics of concentrations and chemical compositions for PM2.5 in the region of Beijing, Tianjin, and Hebei, China | publisher=Atmospheric Chemistry and Physics | accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref>
PM<sub>2.5</sub> particles are small enough to pass through the human [[respiratory system]] and reach the [[lung]], causing problems like [[heart attacks]] and [[asthma]] attacks.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www3.epa.gov/pmdesignations/basicinfo.htm | title=Fine Particle (PM2.5) Designations | publisher=US Environmental Protection Agency | accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref> In northern China, people live, on average, 5.5 years fewer than those in southern China, because of the over-reliance on burning coal for heating systems, which produces huge amounts of PM<sub>2.5</sub> pollutants in winter.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://money.cnn.com/2013/07/09/news/china-air-pollution/ | title=Air pollution cuts life expectancy by 5.5 years in China - study | publisher=CNN | accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref>
Pollution from China has already affected other countries, and some ozone-forming particles have travelled across the [[Pacific Ocean]] to the [[United States]], contributing to a relatively high level of ozone on the American West Coast. While these particles, along with other ozone-related chemicals, can be carried up to 30,000 feet above the ground, researchers in the United States predict that these pollutants may play a bigger role in the near future.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.cnbc.com/2015/08/13/chinese-pollution-is-coming-to-america.html | title=Chinese pollution is coming to America | publisher=CNBC | accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref>
=== Bacteria in PM<sub>2.5</sub> === Scientists are still trying to understand the microorganisms within PM<sub>2.5</sub> particles and how they are spread through pollutants. Research indicated that many kinds of pathogens and bacteria can be spread through PM<sub>2.5</sub> smog and cause diseases. For example, Chinese researchers have found that smog in Beijing contains significant amounts of inhalable microbial allergens and pathogenic species, which increase the risk of respiratory diseases.<ref name = micro>{{cite journal | title=Inhalable Microorganisms in Beijing's PM2.5 and PM10 Pollutants during a Severe Smog Event | journal=Environmental Science & Technology | volume=48 | issue=3 | pages=1499–1507 | doi=10.1021/es4048472 |year = 2014|last1 = Cao|first1 = Chen| last2=Jiang | first2=Wenjun | last3=Wang | first3=Buying | last4=Fang | first4=Jianhuo | last5=Lang | first5=Jidong | last6=Tian | first6=Geng | last7=Jiang | first7=Jingkun | last8=Zhu | first8=Ting F. }}</ref> The same study also reported that among all the microorganisms within PM<sub>2.5</sub> particles, 86.1% are [[bacteria]], 13% [[eukaryota]], 0.8% [[archaea]], and 0.1% viruses.<ref name = "micro" /> The smog contains a variety of microorganisms such as ''[[Actinobacteria]], [[Proteobacteria]], [[Chloroflexi (phylum)|Chloroflexi]], [[Firmicutes]], [[Bacteroidetes]],'' and ''[[Euryarchaeota]].'' Many of these are not harmful to humans, but some pathogenic microorganisms are carried through smog, and their numbers increase as the pollutant level increases.<ref name = "micro" />
More than 1,300 kinds of microorganisms have been detected on PM<sub>2.5</sub> particles. Because PM<sub>2.5</sub> particles have relatively large surface area, many microorganisms from the soil easily attach to them, spreading them quickly through wind. For example, scientists detected that ''[[Aspergillus fumigatus]]'' var. ''fumigatus'', a fungus which triggers allergic reactions in the respiratory system, are 1% to 8% of microorganisms found on PM<sub>2.5</sub> particles.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://news.sina.com.cn/c/2014-02-24/192129551860.shtml | title=清华大学在北京雾霾中检测出1300种微生物 | publisher=新闻中心 | accessdate=13 May 2016 |language=Chinese}}</ref>
=== Index === The [[United States Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) has developed an Air Quality Index that is used to report air quality. This AQI is divided into six categories indicating increasing levels of health concern. A PM<sub>2.5</sub> concentration lower than 12 µg/m<sup>3</sup> indicates good air quality and between 12 and 35 µg/m<sup>3</sup> the airquality is moderate. An AQI value over 300 represents hazardous air quality and below 50 the air quality is good.<ref name="aqi_basic">{{cite web|url=http://www.airnow.gov/index.cfm?action=aqibasics.aqi | title = Air Quality Index (AQI) - A Guide to Air Quality and Your Health|date= 9 December 2011 | accessdate = 8 August 2012| publisher = US EPA}}</ref> In December 2013, huge areas of Eastern China reached "hazardous" level for multiple days.

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox event |title=2013 Northeastern China smog |image=File:Northeast China smog 2013-10-21 2013294.0350.jpg |caption=Smog (grey) and fog (white) cloak northeast China on 21 October 2013. |date=21–25 October 2013 |time= |place=[[Heilongjiang]], [[Jilin]], and [[Liaoning]] [[Provinces of China]] |coordinates = |cause= |casualties1=None reported |casualties2= }}
A dense wave of [[smog]] began in Northeast China, especially in major cities including [[Harbin]], [[Changchun]] and [[Shenyang]], as well as the surrounding [[Heilongjiang]], [[Jilin]], and [[Liaoning]] [[Provinces of China|provinces]] on 20 October 2013. Unseasonably warm temperatures{{citation needed|date=October 2013}} with very little wind across northeastern China coincided with the initiation of Northeast China's coal-powered municipal heating system. Record densities of fine [[particulates]] were measured in the city.
In Harbin, the levels of PM<sub>2.5</sub> particulate matter rose to 1,000 micrograms per cubic metre, worse than Beijing's historic highs. Visibility dropped to {{convert|50|m|ft}} and authorities grounded flights and closed more than 2,000 schools.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/oct/24/dutch-artist-roosegaarde-vacuum-cleaner-china-smog Suck it and see: Dutch artist's vacuum cleaner could clear China smog] The Guardian 24.10.2013</ref>
In Changchun, air pollution recorded at an all-time high and the levels of PM<sub>2.5</sub> particulate matter rose to 845 micrograms per cubic metre on 22 October 2013.<ref name=ccrecord>{{cite news|title=长春雾霾天气强度破63年历史纪录|url=http://www.chinanews.com/gn/2013/10-23/5416856.shtml|accessdate=21 July 2014|agency=中国新闻网|language=Chinese}}</ref>
The smog eased on 25 October 2013 and had completely dissipated by the 28th due to a cold front that had moved in from [[Russia]].
==Background==
[[File:Northeast China smog 2013-10-21 detail 2013294.0350.jpg|thumb|Detail showing position of Harbin in the haze (NASA)|alt=Ddetail showing position of Harbin in the haze (NASA)]]
Officials blamed the dense pollution on lack of wind, burning of crop waste in farmers' fields, and 20 October<ref name=qq>{{cite web|url=http://news.qq.com/a/20131021/006914.htm |title=哈尔滨重度雾霾第二日：全市停课 交通瘫痪_新闻_腾讯网 [Second Day of severe Haze in Harbin] |publisher=News.qq.com |date=21 October 2013 |accessdate=23 October 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6KajCdx3B?url=http://news.qq.com/a/20131021/006914.htm |archivedate=23 October 2013 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> start-up of Harbin's coal-powered [[district heating]] system.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-24579101|title=Northern China smog closes schools and airport in Harbin|publisher=[[BBC]]|date=21 October 2013}}</ref> Harbin lies in the north of China where winter temperatures can drop to {{convert|-40|°C|F}}, necessitating a six-month heating season.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/destinations/asia/china/8884997/Harbin-China-Kingdom-of-ice.html|title=Harbin, China: Kingdom of Ice|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=13 November 2011|accessdate=24 October 2013}}</ref>
[[Air pollution in China|Air pollution in Chinese cities]] is of increasing concern to China's leadership.<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/10/21/us-china-smog-idUSBRE99K02Z20131021 China smog emergency shuts city of 11 million people] Reuters 21 October 2013</ref> [[Particulates]] in the air can adversely affect human health and also have impacts on climate and precipitation. Pollution from the burning of coal has reduced life expectancies by 5.5 years in the north of China, as a result of heart and lung diseases.<ref>{{cite web|work=National Geographic|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/energy/2013/10/131022-harbin-ice-city-smog-crisis-china-coal/|title=Harbin Smog Crisis Highlights China's Coal Problem|date=22 October 2013|accessdate=23 October 2013}}</ref> According to the National Environmental Analysis released by [[Tsinghua University]] and The Asian Development Bank in January 2013, 7 of 10 most air polluted cities in the world are located in China, including [[Taiyuan]], [[Beijing]], [[Urumqi]], [[Lanzhou]], [[Chongqing]], [[Jinan]] and [[Shijiazhuang]].<ref>{{cite news|title=WEATHER & EXTREME EVENTS 7 of 10 Most Air-Polluted Cities Are in China|url=http://news.discovery.com/earth/weather-extreme-events/7-of-10-most-air-polluted-cities-china-130116.htm|accessdate=1 September 2014|work=JAN 16, 2013|agency=http://news.discovery.com|publisher=Imaginechina/Corbis}}</ref> As air pollution in China is at an all-time high, several northern cities are among one of the most polluted cities and has one of the worst air quality in China. Reporting on China's [[airpocalypse]] has been accompanied by what seems like a monochromatic slideshow of the country's several cities smothered in thick smog. According to a survey made by "Global voices China" in February 2013, China's 10 most polluted cities on the blacklist includes major Chinese cities like [[Beijing]], [[Jinan]], [[Shijiazhuang]], [[Zhengzhou]], and 6 other prefectural cities all in [[Hebei]] Province.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bildner |first1=Eli |title=Interactive Maps of China’s Most–and Least–Polluted Places |url=http://newsmotion.org/feed-story/interactive-maps-china%E2%80%99s-most%E2%80%93and-least%E2%80%93polluted-places |accessdate=1 September 2014 |work=Global Voices China |agency=http://newsmotion.org |date=27 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140903071400/http://newsmotion.org/feed-story/interactive-maps-china%E2%80%99s-most%E2%80%93and-least%E2%80%93polluted-places |archivedate=3 September 2014 }}</ref> These cities are all situated in traditional geographic subdivision of [[North China]].
==Effects== [[File:HarbinChinaSmog 121226.jpg|thumb|Smog in Harbin, China in December 2012]] All highways in the surrounding [[Heilongjiang]] province were closed.<ref>{{cite web|last=Branigan |first=Tania |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/oct/21/chinese-city-paralysed-by-smog |title=Chinese city paralysed by smog |work=The Guardian}}</ref> In Harbin, all primary and middle schools and the [[Harbin Airport|airport]] were closed for three days.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://usa.chinadaily.com.cn/epaper/2013-10/22/content_17050715.htm |title=Smog wraps northeast, schools forced to close|last1=Huiying |first1=Zhou |last2=Yin |first2=Cao |work=China Daily |date=22 October 2013}}</ref><ref name=scmp-reopen>{{cite news|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/china/article/1337901/flights-resume-and-schools-reopen-smog-eases-harbin|title=Flights resume and schools reopen as smog eases in Harbin|agency=AFP|work=South China Morning Post|date=2013-10-23|accessdate=2013-10-25}}</ref>
Hospitals reported a 23 percent increase in admissions for [[respiratory]] problems.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://hlj.xinhuanet.com/news/2013-10/21/c_132815675.htm|title=雾霾天致呼吸道疾病患者骤增 专家：多吃梨__新华网黑龙江频道 [Respiratory Diseases Caused by Fog and Hazy Days Surge]|agency=Xinhua News Agency|date=21 October 2013|access-date=23 October 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029192526/http://hlj.xinhuanet.com/news/2013-10/21/c_132815675.htm|archive-date=29 October 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Visibility was reduced to below {{convert|50|m|ft|abbr=on}} in parts of [[Harbin]], and below {{convert|500|m|ft|abbr=on}} in most of the neighboring [[Jilin]] province.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/china/2013-10/21/c_132816417.htm |title=Smog closes schools, highways in NE China |agency=Xinhua News Agency |date=21 October 2013 |accessdate=23 October 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6KZmMLUFz?url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/china/2013-10/21/c_132816417.htm |archivedate=23 October 2013 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> On Fa Yuen Street in Harbin, visibility of less than {{convert|5|m|ft|abbr=on}} was reported.<ref name=qq/>
In Changchun, the capital of Jilin province, PM2.5 level rose to 845 on 22:00 p.m., 22 October 2013.<ref name=ccrecord/> Visibility of less than {{convert|50|m|ft|abbr=on}} was also reported, but Changchun education bureau refused to close the school and was criticized by parents of the students and public.<ref name=cccri>{{cite web|title=长春教育局回应"雾霾天气未及时通知停课"质疑|url=http://www.chinanews.com/edu/2013/10-23/5416847.shtml}}</ref> Other cities in the surrounding Jilin province, including Jilin, Songyuan and Fuyu, ordered to close the schools on 22 October.<ref name=cccri/>
Daily [[particulate]] levels of more than 40 times the [[World Health Organization]] recommended maximum level were reported in parts of Harbin municipality.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.euronews.com/2013/10/21/china-record-smog-levels-shut-down-city-of-harbin/ |title=China: record smog levels shut down city of Harbin | euronews, world news |publisher=[[Euronews]]}}</ref> The smog remained as of 23 October, when "almost all monitoring stations in Heilongjiang, Jilin, and Liaoning provinces reported readings above 200 [µg/m³] for PM2.5".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/90882/8433264.html |title=Northeast remains shrouded in smog for third straight day – People's Daily Online |work=People's Daily |date=2013-10-23 |accessdate=23 October 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6KZoMVk7n?url=http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/90882/8433264.html |archivedate=23 October 2013 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> [[PM2.5|PM<sub>2.5</sub>]] is the amount of particulate matter less than 2.5 micrometres in diameter in the air, with the World Health Organization recommending a maximum 24-hour mean of 25 micrograms per cubic meter (µg/m³).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs313/en/ |title=Air quality and health, Fact sheet N°313 |publisher=WHO |work=WHO Media Centre |date=September 2011 |accessdate=24 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160104165807/http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs313/en/ |archivedate=4 January 2016 }}</ref> On the morning of 23 October, PM<sub>2.5</sub> measurements in Harbin had fallen to an average of 123 µg/m³.<ref name=scmp-reopen/>

The '''2009 Chinese lead poisoning scandal''' occurred in the [[Shaanxi]] province of [[China]] when pollution from a [[lead]] plant [[lead poisoning|poisoned]] children in the surrounding area.<ref name=Times>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/asia/article6832217.ece ''China uses fear to hush up poisoned children'']</ref> Over 850 were affected. Villagers have accused the local and central governments of covering up the scandal.
==History== In 2003 the Dongling Lead and Zinc Smelting Company set up a factory in the Changqing [[Township (People's Republic of China)|township]]<ref name=Tel>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/6061009/More-than-1300-children-fall-ill-near-Chinese-smelting-plants.html ''More than 1,300 children fall ill near Chinese smelting plants'']</ref> near the city of [[Baoji]], describing it in brochures as "a garden-like factory".<ref name=Times/> Soon "100,000 [[ton]]s of lead and [[zinc]] a year and 700,000 tons of [[Coke (fuel)|coke]]" were being produced. In 2008 it paid more than [[£]]10m in taxes to the local government,<ref name=Times/> 17% of the administration's total income, and provided jobs for 2,000 households.<ref name=Tel/> Local parents however noticed that children were showing signs of illness - such as nose bleeds and memory problems.<ref name=Tel/> 851 children from seven villages surrounding the plant displayed up to 10 times the level of lead in their blood deemed safe by Chinese authorities.<ref name=Times/> Over 170 of the children had to be hospitalised.<ref name=Times/><ref name=Reu>[https://www.reuters.com/article/latestCrisis/idUSPEK183380 ''More parents protest against lead poisoning in China'']</ref>
Local villagers protested to authorities but claim they were ignored. On 17 August 2009 they attacked the plant causing the managers to flee. The plant has now been closed down, but according to Western reports all coverage in the Chinese media of events has now been banned.<ref name=Times/>
Chinese lead supplies the country's [[Battery (electricity)|battery]] industry, the world's largest.<ref name=mnn/> Lead poisoning can lead to [[anaemia]], [[muscle]] weakness and [[brain damage]]<ref name=Reu/> and damages the [[nervous system|nervous]] and [[reproductive system]]s.<ref name=Times/>
==Similar events== ''[[The Times]]'' reported in September 2009 that "similar protests broke out in three other provinces, where horrified parents living near smelters of lead, [[copper]] and [[aluminium]] also learnt that their children had been poisoned—1,300 of them in one city alone".<ref name=Times/> Villages that suffer from such pollution are often dubbed '[[cancer village]]s".<ref name=mnn>{{cite web|title='Lead poisoning haunts Chinese smelter communities' |url=http://www.mnn.com/lifestyle/health/stories/lead-poisoning-haunts-chinese-smelter-communities |work= |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jrTonuYe?url=http://www.mnn.com/lifestyle/health/stories/lead-poisoning-haunts-chinese-smelter-communities |archivedate=17 September 2009 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-09-14 |df=dmy }}</ref> Child health is an important issue in China, where many families are restricted to just one child.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.mnn.com/lifestyle/health/stories/2nd-lead-poisoning-case-hits-china-1300-sick |title=''2nd lead poisoning case hits China, 1,300 sick'' |access-date=14 September 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090825214352/http://www.mnn.com/lifestyle/health/stories/2nd-lead-poisoning-case-hits-china-1300-sick |archive-date=25 August 2009 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Nearly 2,000 children were poisoned in the Shaanxi and Hunan provinces.<ref name="Watts09-Lancet">{{Cite journal | pmid = 19757511 | year = 2009 | last1 = Watts | first1 = J. | title = Lead poisoning cases spark riots in China | volume = 374 | issue = 9693 | page = 868 | journal = Lancet | doi = 10.1016/S0140-6736(09)61612-3 }}</ref> Parents and villagers rioted in the Hunan province after the mass poisonings became known.<ref name="Watts09-Lancet"/> The government promised to move villagers to a new, safer living location, but plans for the move were postponed when the new location was found also to be contaminated.<ref name="Parry09-BMJ">{{Cite journal | last1 = Parry | first1 = J. | title = Metal smelting plants poison hundreds of Chinese children | journal = BMJ (Clinical research ed.) | volume = 339 | issue = aug24 2| pages = b3433 | year = 2009 | pmid = 19703927 | doi = 10.1136/bmj.b3433 }}</ref>

{{Infobox News event |image= |caption= |date= {{start date|2007|08|17}} |time=1:50GMT |place=[[Xintai]], [[Shandong]], [[China]] |casualties1=172 ~ 181 dead<ref name="ea" /><ref name="LA1" /> |casualties2= }} The '''2007 Shandong coal mine flood''' was an incident that occurred on August 17, 2007 in [[Xintai]], [[Shandong]], [[People's Republic of China]], when heavy rain caused a river to burst a [[levee]] creating a flood into two mine shafts. By 8:50 am (1:50GMT), the mine was inundated underwater.<ref name="ea">English Aljazeera. "[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/asia-pacific/2007/08/2008525135547815568.html English Aljazeera]." ''Chinese miners trapped by floods.'' Retrieved on 2008-09-08.</ref>
==Damages and casualties== More than 200mm of rain had fallen in Xintai, causing a 50-metre breach of a levee of the [[Wen river]]. Water poured into the 860-metre deep pit at the Huayuan mine, quickly overwhelming the mine's pumps.<ref name="ea" /> The 172 miners were trapped in a 3,000-foot-deep mine shaft when a mine operated by the Huayuan Mining Co.<ref name="LA1">LA times. "[http://articles.latimes.com/2007/aug/19/world/fg-chinamine19 LA times]." ''Hope dim for Chinese miners.'' Retrieved on 2008-09-15.</ref> Nine others were also missing, in a nearby mine run by a different company. None of the 181 miners, living or dead, were recovered from the two mines after the accident.<ref>Chinadaily.com.cn. "[http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2007-09/03/content_6077282.htm Chinadaily.com.cn]." ''Work safety situation still dime.'' Retrieved on 2008-09-15.</ref>
The Huayuan mine was flooded with an estimated 12 million cubic metres of water. If all six available pumps were used around the clock they could pump out about 120,000 cubic metres of water a day. But only four were operational. Unofficially, experts say that it would take almost 100 days to drain the water inside the mine.<ref name="Asianews1">Asianews.it. "[http://www.asianews.it/index.php?l=en&art=10110&size=A Asianews.it]." ''Beijing admits Xintai mining accidents were completely avoidable.'' Retrieved on 2008-09-14.</ref>
==Aftermath== An official at China.com.cn discussed the fact that signs of flooding had appeared in advance prior to the incident, and that the "disaster was completely avoidable."<ref name="Asianews1" /> On September 6, the Shangdong provincial government issued a statement citing scientists who said that none of the miners would be able to make it out alive after that amount of time underground.<ref>Xinhuanet.com. "[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2007-09/06/content_6676117.htm Xinhuanet.com]." ''Beijing admits Xintai mining accidents were completely avoidable.'' Retrieved on 2008-09-15.</ref>

{{Infobox oil spill | spill_name = Xingang Port oil spill | image = | image_size = | image_caption = | location = [[Yellow Sea]], [[Xingang Harbour]]
[[Dalian]], [[Liaoning Province]], [[China]] | coordinates = {{coord|38.92|121.63|region:CN-21_type:landmark|display=title,inline}} | spill_date = 16–26 July 2010{{cite news | title = Dalian oil spill contained, stopped from reaching open waters: vice mayor | url = http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/china/2010-07/26/c_13416064.htm | agency = [[Xinhua News Agency]] | date = 26 July 2010 | accessdate = 31 July 2010}}{{cite news | last = Kuo | first = Lily | title = China says ocean cleared of oil 10 days after spill | url = http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-china-oil-spill-20100727,0,3917306.story | work = [[Los Angeles Times]] | date = 27 July 2010 | accessdate = 31 July 2010}} | cause = Ruptured pipeline | operator = [[China National Petroleum Corporation]] | volume = {{convert|1500|to|105000|m3|gal|abbr=on}} | area = >{{convert|946|km2|abbr=on}} | coast = }} The '''Xingang Port oil spill''' is a spill that occurred in July 2010 caused by a rupture and subsequent explosion of two [[Petroleum#Crude oil|crude oil]] [[pipeline transport|pipeline]]s that run to an oil storage depot of the [[China National Petroleum Corporation]] in [[Xingang Harbour]], [[Dalian]], [[Liaoning Province]], [[China]]. The 1,500 tonnes of oil spilled from the pipes created an {{convert|180|km2|abbr=on}} slick in the Yellow Sea that grew to {{convert|430|km2|abbr=on}} within a week.{{cite news|author=Agence France-Presse |title=China rushes to clean up oil spill |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20100719/wl_asia_afp/chinaenvironmentoilpollution |work=Yahoo! News |date=19 July 2010 |accessdate=20 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100721132512/http://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20100719/wl_asia_afp/chinaenvironmentoilpollution |archivedate=July 21, 2010 }}{{cite news | author= | title=China Port Reopens After Oil Spill, Cleanup Continues | url=http://www1.voanews.com/english/news/asia/China-Port-Reopens-After-Oil-Spill-Cleanup-Continues-98853794.html | work=Voice of America News | date=20 July 2010 | accessdate=19 July 2010}}{{cite news | author=The Associated Press | title=China Oil Spill Grows, Official Warns Of 'Severe Threat' | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/07/21/china-oil-spill-grows-off_n_653852.html | work=The Huffington Post | date=21 July 2010 | accessdate=21 July 2010}} By July 21, the spill had spread to {{convert|946|km2|abbr=on}}, and stretched as far as {{convert|90|km|abbr=on}} along the coast.{{cite news|author=Agence France-Presse |title=Clean-up crews use bare hands against China oil spill |url=http://ca.news.yahoo.com/s/afp/100722/world/china_environment_oil_pollution |work=Yahoo! News |date=22 July 2010 |accessdate=22 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100724121815/http://ca.news.yahoo.com/s/afp/100722/world/china_environment_oil_pollution |archivedate=July 24, 2010 }} ==Incident== {{Location map |China Liaoning |lat=38.92 |long=121.63 |type = landmark |width=250 |float=left |caption=''Location in Liaoning''}} The spill occurred after a process to [[Hydrodesulfurization|desulfurize]] oil in a pipeline at the port began, triggering a fire which subsequently burned for 15 hours. The fire burned from oil that was released from a filled storage tank with a 90,000 ton capacity that collapsed as a result of the fire. Oil from other nearby tanks was, according to a [[Greenpeace]] report released several weeks after the incident, intentionally released to prevent the fire from expanding towards a tank containing [[dimethylbenzene]], a flammable chemical.{{cite web|title=Dalian Oil Spill: Preliminary Findings and Recommendations |url=http://www.greenpeace.org/china/en/press/release/dalian-oil-recommendations-steiner |publisher=Greenpeace |accessdate=10 August 2010 |date=2 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100805232029/http://www.greenpeace.org/china/en/press/release/dalian-oil-recommendations-steiner |archivedate=August 5, 2010 }} == Containment and cover-up == Although Chinese government officials reported that as little as 1,500 tonnes of oil spilled, a former University of Alaska marine conservation specialist, Rick Steiner, estimates the spill to have a much higher total, with somewhere in the range of 60,000 to 90,000 tons (18.47 to 27.70 million gallons) of oil spilled into the [[Yellow Sea]]. He said that "[i]t's enormous. That's at least as large as the official estimate of the Exxon Valdez disaster."{{cite news|author=Associated Press |title=US expert: China oil spill far bigger than stated |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20100730/ap_on_bi_ge/as_china_pipeline_explosion |work=Yahoo! News |date=30 July 2010 |accessdate=30 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100801062503/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20100730/ap_on_bi_ge/as_china_pipeline_explosion |archivedate=August 1, 2010 }}{{cite news | author=The Associated Press | title=China Oil Spill Far Bigger Than Stated, U.S. Expert Says | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/07/30/china-oil-spill-far-bigge_n_665038.html | work=The Huffington Post | date=30 July 2010 | accessdate=31 July 2010}} However, a government spokesperson for Dalian refuted this estimate, and referred to a panel of experts assessing the spill's size and environmental effect saying that "[w]e will know w[h]ether it's smaller or bigger than 60,000 tons based on the conclusion made by the panel".{{cite news|last=Huang |first=Jingjing |title=Dalian official refutes Greenpeace allegations about impact of spill |url=http://china.globaltimes.cn/society/2010-08/558843.html |accessdate=3 August 2010 |newspaper=Global Times China Society |date=August 3, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100806215512/http://china.globaltimes.cn/society/2010-08/558843.html |archivedate=August 6, 2010 }} According to leaks on Weibo, the accident may have begun as early as June, 10. However, because the government never formally acknowledged the accident took place, as well as threatened informed citizens to delete their posts, the true nature of the accident was not clear to the public. No assessment on the effect on wildlife was ever carried out. The ensuing fire burned for 15 hours and one firefighter drowned after being swept overboard into the water. There was extensive damage to local wildlife areas, aquaculture, and beaches were closed following the spill and conflagration which appeared to have been caused by the injection of a highly oxidizing sulfur reducing agent into a pipeline. On 26 July 2010, the Chinese local government announced the spill had been contained and that the spill had failed to reach open waters. Cleanup efforts continued two weeks after the original explosion began, with operations to remove the oil performed at night when the oil is most viscous.{{cite news | last = Hogg | first = Chris | title = China struggles to recover from 'worst ever' oil spill | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-10819987 | publisher = [[BBC News]] | date = 30 July 2010 | accessdate = 31 July 2010}} The cleanup effort largely used low-tech methods, including containment booms and straw mats to absorb the oil, as well as a fleet of fishermen manually scooping oil out of the water and transferring it to barrels for storage and eventual disposal. Additionally, limited amounts of chemical dispersants were used, as well as a material to increase biodegradation of oil. == Reaction == After the incident the Chinese government announced that safety standards would be tightened up at ports.{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/china/2010-07/23/c_13411979.htm|title=China orders ports to enhance safety after Dalian pipeline accident|publisher=[[Xinhua]]|date=23 July 2010|accessdate=31 July 2010}} ==Impact== The oil spill affected several aspects of the area's economy. [[Tourism]] was affected after oil began washing ashore on beaches, some of which were closed after the spill; according to Greenpeace, additional oil washing ashore was a possibility that remained for the rest of the summer. The oil severely affected fishing industry near Dalian, especially offshore [[shellfish]] farms, many of which were contaminated by the oil, either killing the fish or rendering them unfit for consumption. The economic loss was estimated to be as high as tens of million [[US dollar]]s. Environmental damage was also serious as a result of the spill; the majority of wildlife inhabiting the area was exposed to oil, which led to the deaths of some, while others were expected to display longer-term effects. [[Lu Guang (photographer)|Lu Guang's]] pictures of the oil spill and the subsequent funeral of firefighter Zhang Liang were awarded a third prize in the category "Spot News" in the 2011 World Press Photo contest.Jess Miller: "[http://www.greenpeace.org/international/en/news/Blogs/makingwaves/dalian-oil-spill-photographer-receives-award-/blog/34625/ Dalian oil spill photographer receives award at World Press Photo]," Greenpeace News, 8 May 2011.World Press Photo: [http://www.worldpressphoto.org/collection/photo/2011 2011 Photo Contest].World Press Photo: [http://www.worldpressphoto.org/collection/photo/2011/spot-news/lu-guang Lu Guang - 2011 Photo Contest]. == See also == * [[List of oil spills]] == References == {{Reflist|2}} == External links == {{wikinews|China launches major cleanup operation after oil spill}} * [http://www.boston.com/bigpicture/2010/07/oil_spill_in_dalian_china.html Oil spill in Dalian, China], The Big Picture * [http://link.brightcove.com/services/player/bcpid868989705001?bckey=AQ~~,AAAAybGjzqk~,6NfTc6c241GVQxOh-GBHNHu5Cuhlf-y9&bctid=912606312001 The Value of Ethical Oil] The Source with Ezra Levant - April 20, 2011 {{China National Petroleum Corporation}} [[Category:Explosions in 2010]] [[Category:2010 disasters in China]] [[Category:2010 industrial disasters]] [[Category:Oil spills]] [[Category:2010 in the environment]] [[Category:Environmental disasters in China]] [[Category:July 2010 events]]

A series of [[explosion]]s caused by an [[industrial accident]] occurred on August 26, 2008 in [[Yizhou District, Hechi|Yizhou city]] in [[Guangxi province]] in [[southwest China]].
The disaster occurred at a factory owned by Guangxi Guangwei Chemical Co. in the development zone of Yizhou city<ref name="APReport">Associated Press, [http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/world/2008-08-26-china-blast_N.htm 16 killed in chemical plant blasts in China] (August 26, 2008).</ref><ref name="NYT">[https://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/27/world/asia/27iht-explode.3.15684819.html Death toll reaches 20 after explosion at chemical plant in China], ''New York Times'' (August 27, 2008).</ref>
According to the state-run [[Xinhua News Agency]], "the plant mainly produces [[polyvinyl acetate]] (PVA), which is used in adhesives, calcium carbide, and [[vinyl acetate monomer]] (VAM), which is used in paints, adhesives and coatings."<ref name="Xinhua">[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2008-08/27/content_9724017.htm 20 confirmed dead in S China chemical plant blast], Xinhua News Agency (August 27, 2007).</ref>
The first explosion occurred at about 6 a.m. on August 26 at an [[organic compound]] workshop inside the plant; the cause is unknown.<ref name="Xinhua"/> Other explosions continued until 1 p.m. [[Conflagration|Fire]] spread over an area of nearly 108,000 square feet (10,000m²). The explosions caused the leak of toxic substances, including [[ammonia]], [[formaldehyde]], [[acetylene]], [[sulfurated hydrogen]] and [[carbon monoxide]].<ref name="APReport"/>
At least 20 people were killed and at least 60 were injured; six people remained missing following the explosions. Fearing further explosions and leaks, the government [[emergency evacuation|evacuated]] 11,500 residents.<ref name="APReport"/><ref name="NYT"/>
Xinhua quoted the provincial toxic substances emergency center director as saying that the explosions causes no serious air or water pollution. The director also said that dams had been erected to prevent discharge of pollutants into the nearby [[Long River (Guangxi)|Long River]] (Longjiang).<ref name="NYT"/>
==See also== * [[2005 Jilin chemical plant explosions]] * [[1994 Kenpeng mine disaster]]
