page.title: Accident rating of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox news event | image_name = Fukushima I by Digital Globe.jpg | image_size = 260px | caption = Satellite image on 16 March 2011 of the four damaged reactor buildings | date={{start date|2011|03|11|df=y}} | place = [[Ōkuma, Fukushima|Ōkuma]], [[Fukushima Prefecture|Fukushima]], Japan | outcome = [[International Nuclear Event Scale|INES]] Level 7 (ratings by Japanese authorities as of 11 April){{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/04/12/japan-severity-idUSTKE00635720110412 |title=Japan raises nuclear crisis severity to highest level |work=Reuters |first=Mayumi |last=Negishi |date=12 April 2011}}{{cite web|title=Fukushima accident upgraded to severity level 7|url=http://spectrum.ieee.org/tech-talk/energy/nuclear/fukushima-accident-upgraded-to-severity-level-7/ |work=[[IEEE Spectrum]]|date=12 April 2011}} | coordinates = {{coord|37|25|17|N|141|1|57|E|region:JP-07_type:landmark_dim:500|display=inline}} |reported injuries =37 with physical injuries,
2 workers taken to hospital with possible [[Ionizing radiation|radiation burns]]{{cite news |url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/UPDATE2%3A+Radiation-exposed+workers+to+be+treated+at+Chiba+hospital.-a0252558693 |title=Radiation-exposed workers to be treated at Chiba hospital|accessdate=12 February 2016 |agency=Kyodo News |date=25 March 2011}} |notes = {{location map|Japan | width = 260|border=infobox|align=center|caption=Location in Japan | coordinates = {{coord|37|25|17|N|141|1|57|E}} | mark = Locator Dot2.gif }}}}{{external media | align=right | width = 272px | video1 = [https://www.youtube.com/user/fuku1live 24 hours live camera for Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster] on [[YouTube]], certified by Tokyo Electric Power Co. Inc. }} The {{nihongo|'''Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster'''|福島第一原子力発電所事故|[[Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant|Fukushima Dai-ichi]] ''({{Audio|Fukushima daiichi.ogg|pronunciation|lang=ja|help=no}})'' genshiryoku hatsudensho jiko}} was a series of [[Nuclear and radiation accidents#Equipment failure|equipment failures]], [[nuclear meltdown]]s, and [[Nuclear and radiation accidents#Radiation accidents|releases of radioactive materials]] at the [[Fukushima I Nuclear Power Plant]], following the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami|Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]] on 11 March 2011.{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/news/article.cfm?c_id=2&objectid=10716671|title=Japan's unfolding disaster 'bigger than Chernobyl'|work=[[New Zealand Herald]]|date=2 April 2011}}{{cite web|title=Explainer: What went wrong in Japan's nuclear reactors|url=http://spectrum.ieee.org/tech-talk/energy/nuclear/explainer-what-went-wrong-in-japans-nuclear-reactors|work=IEEE Spectrum|date=4 April 2011}} It is the largest nuclear disaster since the [[Chernobyl disaster]] of 1986.[http://in.ibtimes.com/articles/132391/20110409/japan-nuclear-crisis-radiation.htm "Analysis: A month on, Japan nuclear crisis still scarring"] {{webarchive |url=https://www.webcitation.org/5y2agYEQZ?url=http://in.ibtimes.com/articles/132391/20110409/japan-nuclear-crisis-radiation.htm |date=18 April 2011 }} ''International Business Times'' (Australia). 9 April 2011, retrieved 12 April 2011; excerpt, According to [[James M. Acton|James Acton]], Associate of the Nuclear Policy Program at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, "Fukushima is not the worst nuclear accident ever but it is the most complicated and the most dramatic...This was a crisis that played out in real time on TV. Chernobyl did not." ==Overview== The plant comprises seven separate [[boiling water reactor]]s originally designed by [[General Electric]] (GE), and maintained by the [[Tokyo Electric Power Company]] (TEPCO). At the time of the quake, Reactor 4 had been de-fueled while 5 and 6 were in cold [[shutdown (nuclear reactor)|shutdown]] for planned maintenance.{{Cite news|author =Black, Richard |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-12745186 |title= Reactor breach worsens prospects |work=BBC Online |date=15 March 2011 |accessdate=23 March 2011}} Immediately after the earthquake, the remaining reactors 1-3 shut down automatically, and emergency generators came online to control electronics and coolant systems. However the tsunami following the earthquake quickly flooded the low-lying rooms in which the emergency generators were housed. The flooded generators failed, cutting power to the critical pumps that must continuously circulate [[Nuclear_reactor_coolant#Water|coolant water]] through a [[generation II reactor|Generation II nuclear reactor]] for several days in order to keep it from melting down after being shut down. As the pumps stopped, the [[Decay heat#Power reactors in shutdown|reactors overheated]] due to the normal high radioactive [[decay heat]] produced in the first few days after nuclear reactor shutdown (smaller amounts of this heat normally continue to be released for years, but are not enough to cause fuel melting). At this point, only prompt flooding of the reactors with seawater could have cooled the reactors quickly enough to prevent meltdown. Salt water flooding was delayed because it would ruin the costly reactors permanently. Flooding with seawater was finally commenced only after the government ordered that seawater be used, and at this point it was too late to prevent meltdown.F. Tanabe, Journal of Nuclear Science and Technology, 2011, volume 48, issue 8, pages 1135 to 1139 As the water boiled away in the reactors and the water levels in the [[Spent nuclear fuel|fuel]] rod pools dropped, the reactor fuel rods began to overheat severely, and to melt down. In the hours and days that followed, Reactors 1, 2 and 3 experienced full [[Nuclear meltdown|meltdown]].{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/asiapcf/06/06/japan.nuclear.meltdown/index.html?iref=NS1 |title=3 nuclear reactors melted down after quake, Japan confirms |work=CNN|date= 7 June 2011|accessdate=13 July 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/national/T110607005367.htm |title='Melt-through' at Fukushima? / Govt report to IAEA suggests situation worse than meltdown |work=Yomiuri |date=8 June 2011 |accessdate=8 June 2011}} In the intense heat and pressure of the melting reactors, a reaction between the nuclear fuel metal cladding and the remaining water surrounding them produced explosive hydrogen gas. As workers struggled to cool and shut down the reactors, several [[Hydrogen safety|hydrogen-air]] chemical explosions occurred.[http://www.hyer.eu/news/regional-news/hydrogen-in-nuclear-accidents-what-is-the-role-of-the-gas-in-fukushima Hydrogen explosions Fukushima nuclear plant: what happened?] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202235552/http://www.hyer.eu/news/regional-news/hydrogen-in-nuclear-accidents-what-is-the-role-of-the-gas-in-fukushima |date=2 December 2013 }} Concerns about the repeated small explosions, the atmospheric venting of radioactive gasses, and the possibility of larger explosions led to a {{convert|20|km|mi|abbr=on}}-radius evacuation around the plant. During the early days of the accident workers were temporarily evacuated at various times for [[radiation]] safety reasons. At the same time, sea water that had been exposed to the melting rods was returned to the sea heated and radioactive in large volumes for several months until recirculating units could be put in place to repeatedly cool and re-use a limited quantity of water for cooling. The earthquake damage and flooding in the wake of the tsunami hindered external assistance. Electrical power was slowly restored for some of the reactors, allowing for automated cooling.[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704021504576210251376606080 Stricken reactors may get power Sunday], ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', 19 March 2011 ==Assessment== Japanese officials initially assessed the accident as Level 4 on the [[International Nuclear Event Scale]] (INES) despite the views of other international agencies that it should be higher. The level was later raised to 5 and eventually to 7, the maximum scale value.Justin McCurry. [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/apr/12/japan-nuclear-alert-level-seven Japan raises nuclear alert level to seven]. The Guardian. 12 April 2011[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1375981/Now-radiation-Japan-bad-Chernobyl-crisis-level-raised-seven-second-time-history.html 'Now radiation in Japan is as bad as radiation level is raised to 7 for only the second time in history'] ''Daily Mail'' 12 April 2011. The Japanese government and TEPCO have been criticized in the foreign press for poor communication with the public and improvised cleanup efforts.{{Cite news |author =Wagner, Wieland |title=Problematic public relations: Japanese leaders leave people in the dark |work=Der Spiegel |date=15 March 2011 |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0,1518,751109,00.html |accessdate=19 March 2011}}{{Cite news |title=China urges Japan's openness amid panic buying of salt |work=Channel NewsAsia |date=17 March 2011 |url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/afp_asiapacific/view/1117111/1/.html |accessdate=17 March 2011|agency = Agence France-Presse}} On 20 March, the [[Chief Cabinet Secretary]] [[Yukio Edano]] announced that the plant would be decommissioned once the crisis was over. ==Radioactivity released== The Japanese government estimates the total amount of radioactivity released into the atmosphere was approximately one-tenth as much as was released during the Chernobyl disaster. Significant amounts of radioactive material have also been released into ground and ocean waters. Measurements taken by the Japanese government 30–50 km from the plant showed [[caesium-137]] levels high enough to cause concern, leading the government to ban the sale of food grown in the area. Tokyo officials temporarily recommended that tap water should not be used to prepare food for infants.[https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/19/us-japan-nuclear-food-idUSTRE72I1X120110319 Japan mulls Fukushima food ban: IAEA], Reuters, 19 March 2011{{Cite news|author =Justin McCurry in Osaka |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/mar/23/tokyo-water-unsafe-infants |title=Tokyo water unsafe for infants after high radiation levels detected |date=23 March 2010 |work=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=23 March 2011 |place=London}} In May 2012, TEPCO reported that at least 900 [[Petabecquerel|PBq]] had been released "into the atmosphere in March last year [2011] alone".{{cite web|url=http://english.kyodonews.jp/news/2012/05/159960.html |title=TEPCO puts radiation release early in Fukushima crisis at 900 PBq |work=[[Kyodo News]] |date=24 May 2012 |accessdate=24 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120524191342/http://english.kyodonews.jp/news/2012/05/159960.html |archivedate=24 May 2012 }}{{cite news|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2012/05/24/nuclear-japan-radiation-fukushima-idINDEE84N0CR20120524|title=Fukushima radiation higher, about double, than that first estimated|work=[[Reuters]]|author =Kevin Krolicki|date=24 May 2012|accessdate=24 May 2012}} ==Injuries== Several of the plant's workers were severely injured or killed by the disaster conditions resulting from the earthquake. There were no immediate deaths due to direct radiation exposures, but at least six workers have exceeded lifetime legal limits for radiation and more than 300 have received significant radiation doses. Predicted future cancer deaths due to accumulated radiation exposures in the population living near Fukushima have ranged from none{{cite news|agency=NPR|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/transcript/transcript.php?storyId=148227596|date=2012-03-09|accessdate=2012-04-15|title=Trauma, Not Radiation, Is Key Concern In Japan}} to 100{{Citation |last= Caracappa |first= Peter F. |date= 28 June 2011 |title= Fukushima Accident: Radioactive Releases and Potential Dose Consequences |work= ANS Annual Meeting | url= http://www.ans.org/misc/FukushimaSpecialSession-Caracappa.pdf | accessdate=13 September 2011}} to a non-peer-reviewed "guesstimate"{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/ombudsman/2012/03/15/148703963/the-cost-of-fear-the-framing-of-a-fukushima-report|date=2012-03-15|accessdate=2012-04-15|title=The Cost of Fear: The Framing of a Fukushima Report}} of 1,000. On 16 December 2011, Japanese authorities declared the plant to be stable, although it would take decades to decontaminate the surrounding areas and to decommission the plant altogether.{{cite news|title=Japan PM says Fukushima nuclear site finally stabilised|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-16212057|work=BBC Online|accessdate=7 January 2012|date=16 December 2011}} On 5 July 2012, the parliament appointed [[#Fukushima_Nuclear_Accident_Independent_Investigation_Commission|The Fukushima Nuclear Accident Independent Investigation Commission]] (NAIIC) submitted its inquiry report to the Japanese parliament,{{cite web|title=国会事故調 {{!}} 東京電力福島原子力発電所事故調査委員会のホームページ |url=http://naiic.go.jp/en/ |publisher=National Diet of Japan Fukushima Nuclear Accident Independent Investigation Commission |accessdate=9 July 2012 |author=National Diet of Japan Fukushima Nuclear Accident Independent Investigation Commission |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130119181123/http://naiic.go.jp/en/ |archivedate=19 January 2013 }} while the government appointed [[#Investigation_Committee_on_the_Accident_at_the_Fukushima_Nuclear_Power_Stations_of_Tokyo_Electric_Power_Company|Investigation Committee on the Accident at the Fukushima Nuclear Power Stations of Tokyo Electric Power Company]] submitted its final report to the Japanese government on 23 July 2012.{{cite news|title=UPDATE: Government panel blasts lack of 'safety culture' in nuclear accident |url=http://ajw.asahi.com/article/0311disaster/fukushima/AJ201207230081 |accessdate=29 July 2012 |newspaper=The [[Asahi Shimbun]] |date=23 July 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140413220232/http://ajw.asahi.com/article/0311disaster/fukushima/AJ201207230081 |archivedate=13 April 2014 }} [[Timeline of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster#Friday.2C_12_October_2012|Tepco admitted for the first time on 12 October 2012]] that it had failed to take stronger measures to prevent disasters for fear of causing lawsuits or protests against its nuclear plants.{{cite news|last=Fackler|first=Martin|title=Japan Power Company Admits Failings on Plant Precautions|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/10/13/world/asia/tepco-admits-failure-in-acknowledging-risks-at-nuclear-plant.html?_r=0|accessdate=13 October 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=12 October 2012}}{{cite news|last=Sheldrick|first=Aaron|title=Fukushima operator must learn from mistakes, new adviser says|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2012/10/13/japan-nuclear-adviser-fukushima-idINDEE89C03220121013?feedType=RSS&feedName=worldNews|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=13 October 2012|date=12 October 2012}}{{cite news|last=Yamaguchi|first=Mari|title=Japan utility agrees nuclear crisis was avoidable|url=http://www.boston.com/news/world/asia/2012/10/12/japan-utility-admits-nuke-crisis-avoidable-says-feared-consequences-new-safety-measures/NK3yENYHgVPQZ76POvbBLL/story.html|work=Associated Press|publisher=Boston.com|accessdate=13 October 2012|date=12 October 2012}}{{cite news|title=Japanese nuclear plant operator admits playing down risk|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/10/12/world/asia/japan-tepco-report/index.html?hpt=ias_c2|work=CNN Wire Staff|publisher=CNN|accessdate=13 October 2012|date=12 October 2012}} ==Accident rating== [[File:Fukushima7.png|thumb|Comparison of radiation levels for different nuclear events.]] The severity of the nuclear accident is provisionally{{cite web|url=http://www.nisa.meti.go.jp/english/files/en20110412-4.pdf |title=NISA News Release April 12, 2011 |format=PDF |accessdate=24 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xsyUr2Wx?url=http://www.nisa.meti.go.jp/english/files/en20110412-4.pdf |archivedate=12 April 2011 |df=dmy }} rated 7 on the [[International Nuclear Event Scale]] (INES). This scale runs from 0, indicating an abnormal situation with no safety consequences, to 7, indicating an accident causing widespread contamination with serious health and environmental effects. Prior to Fukushima, the [[Chernobyl disaster]] was the only level 7 accident on record, while the [[Three Mile Island accident]] was a level 5 accident. [[Arnold Gundersen]], an engineer frequently commissioned by anti-nuclear groups, said that "Fukushima is the biggest industrial catastrophe in the history of mankind".{{cite news | url = http://www.alternet.org/story/151440/fukushima%3A_world%27s_worst_industrial_disaster_reveals_how_nation_states_are_powerless_to_protect_us_from_advanced_technology | title = Fukushima: World's worst industrial disaster reveals how nation states are powerless to protect us from advanced technology | last = Kotsev | first=Victor | publisher =[[AlterNet]] | date = 27 June 2011}}{{cite news | url =http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/features/2011/06/201161664828302638.html | title=Fukushima: It's much worse than you think | publisher=[[Aljazeera]] | date=16 June 2011}} However, current estimates of the total amount of radioactivity released from the 3 Fukushima Daiichi reactors is only 10-20% that from Chernobyl. The [[Japan Atomic Energy Agency]] initially rated the Unit 1 situation as below both of these previous accidents; on 13 March it announced it was classifying the event as Level 4, an "accident with local consequences".{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/12/us-japan-quake-rating-idUSTRE72B2FR20110312|title=Japan rates quake less serious than Three Mile Island, Chernobyl|author =Maeda, Risa|date=12 March 2011|work=Reuters |accessdate=12 March 2011}} On 18 March it raised its rating on Units 1, 2 and 3 to Level 5, an "accident with wider consequences". It classified the situation at Unit 4 as a Level 3 "serious incident".{{Cite news|author =Richard Black |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-12783832 |title= Japan earthquake: Fukushima nuclear alert level raised |work=BBC Online |date=19 March 2011|accessdate=18 March 2011}} Several parties disputed the Japanese classifications, arguing that the situation was more severe than they were admitting at the time. On 14 March, three Russian experts stated that the nuclear accident should be classified at Level 5, perhaps even Level 6.{{Cite news|author =Shuster, Simon|title=Fire at Fourth Reactor: Is Worse Yet to Come in the Fukushima Nuclear Disaster?|url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2059232,00.html|work=Time Magazine|date=15 March 2011}} One day later, the [[Autorité de sûreté nucléaire|French nuclear safety authority]] and the [[Säteilyturvakeskus|Finnish nuclear safety authority]] said that the Fukushima plant could be classified as a Level 6.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/15/japan-quake-nuclear-france-idUSLDE72E2M920110315 |title=UPDATE 1-French nuclear agency now rates Japan accident at 6 |work=Reuters |date=15 March 2011|accessdate=18 March 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.hs.fi/ulkomaat/artikkeli/STUK+Fukushiman+turman+vakavuus+jo+kuutosluokkaa/1135264592277 |title=STUK: Fukushiman turman vakavuus jo kuutosluokkaa |work=Helsingin Sanomat|date=15 March 2011|language=Finnish}} On 24 March, a scientific consultant for anti-nuclear environmental group [[Greenpeace]], working with data from the Austrian [[Central Institute for Meteorology and Geodynamics|ZAMG]]{{cite web|url=http://www.zamg.ac.at/docs/aktuell/Japan2011-03-22_1500_E.pdf |title=...Spread of Radioactivity/first source estimates from CTBTO data... |work=ZAMG|date=22 March 2011}} and French [[Institut de radioprotection et de sûreté nucléaire|IRSN]], prepared an analysis in which he rated the total Fukushima accident at INES level 7.{{cite web | url =http://www.greenpeace.de/fileadmin/gpd/user_upload/themen/atomkraft/INES_7march_25th.pdf | title= Fukushima Already Level 7 Chernobyl Accident: Greenpeace analysis concludes| publisher=Greenpeace | date=24 March 2011}} [[File:Fukushima Dosis qtl1 en.svg|thumb|left|Radiation dose rates during the initial hydrogen explosions.]] The ''[[Asahi Shimbun]]'' newspaper reported on 26 March that the accident might warrant Level 6, based on its calculations.{{Cite news |url= http://www.asahi.com/english/TKY201103250204.html |title=Radiation from Fukushima exceeds Three Mile Island |work=Asahi Shimbun |place=Japan |accessdate=26 March 2011}} ''The Wall Street Journal'' stated that Japan's NISA would make any decision on raising the level.{{Cite news |url=https://blogs.wsj.com/japanrealtime/2011/03/25/at-a-glance-crisis-rating-white-smoke-at-plant-death-toll-tops-10000/ |title=At a Glance: Crisis Rating, Worker Injuries, Death Toll Tops 10,000 |date=25 March 2011 |accessdate=25 March 2011 |work=The Wall Street Journal}} INES Level 6, or "serious accident", had only been applied to the [[Kyshtym disaster]] (Soviet Union, 1957), while the only level 7 was [[Chernobyl]] (Soviet Union, 1986). Previous Level 5 accidents included the [[Windscale fire]] (United Kingdom, 1957), the [[Lucens reactor]] (Switzerland, 1969), [[Three Mile Island accident]] (United States, 1979), and the [[Goiânia accident]] (Brazil, 1987). Assessing "seriousness" as partial or full meltdown at a civilian plant, ''The New York Times'' reported on 3 April that based on remote sensing, computer "simulations suggest that the number of serious accidents has suddenly doubled, with three of the reactors at the Fukushima Daiichi complex in some stage of meltdown." The ''Times'' counted three previous civilian meltdowns, from [[World Nuclear Association]] information: Three Mile Island, [[Saint-Laurent Nuclear Power Plant]] (France, 1980, INES level 4), and Chernobyl.{{cite news|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/03/science/03meltdown.html|title = From Afar, a Vivid Picture of Japan Crisis|author = William J. Broad|date=2 April 2011|work = The New York Times}} On 11 April, the Japanese Nuclear and Industrial Safety Agency (NISA) temporarily raised the disaster at Fukushima Daiichi to Level 7 on the INES scale, by considering the whole event and not considering each reactor as an individual event (each rated between 3 and 5). This would make Fukushima the second Level 7 "major accident" in the history of the nuclear industry; however, radioactivity released as a result of the events at Fukushima was, as of 12 April, only approximately 10% of that released as a result of the accident at [[Chernobyl]] (1986), also rated as INES Level 7.{{cite web|author =Austria |url=http://www.iaea.org/newscenter/news/2011/fukushima120411.html |title=IAEA Fukushima Nuclear Accident Update Log – Updates of 12 April 2011 |work=Iaea.org |date=12 April 2011 |accessdate=24 April 2011}} As of 21 October 2011, the largest study on Fukushima fallout concludes that Fukushima was "the largest radioactive noble gas release in history not related to nuclear bomb testing. The release is a factor of 2.5 higher than the Chernobyl 133Xe source term", although the "Xenon-133 [main noble gas] does not pose serious health risks because it is not absorbed by the body or the environment."{{cite web|author =Brumfiel, G. |url=http://www.nature.com/news/2011/111025/full/478435a.html |title=Fallout forensics hike radiation toll |work=Nature News |date=25 Oct 2011 |accessdate=26 Oct 2011}}{{cite web|author1=A. Stohl |author2=P. Seibert |author3=G. Wotawa |author4=D. Arnold |author5=J. F. Burkhart |author6=S. Eckhardt |author7=C. Tapia |author8=A. Vargas |author9=T. J. Yasunari |url=http://www.atmos-chem-phys-discuss.net/11/28319/2011/acpd-11-28319-2011.html |title=Xenon-133 and caesium-137 releases into the atmosphere from the Fukushima Dai-ichi nuclear power plant: determination of the source term, atmospheric dispersion, and deposition |work=Atmos. Chem. Phys. Discuss |date=21 Oct 2011 |accessdate=26 Oct 2011}} Xenon does not remain in the atmosphere. As occurred in releases at Three Mile Island, radioactive noble gases rapidly vanish upward, and dissipate into space. http://scitechdaily.com/xenon-gas-has-almost-vanished-from-the-atmosphere/{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/10/11/xenon-noble-gas-missing-atmosphere-minerals_n_1959207.html | work=Huffington Post | first=Travis | last=Korte | title=Scientists Square Off Over Mystery Of 'Missing' Gas | date=11 October 2012}}[[Arnold Gundersen]] said Fukushima has 20 times the potential to be released than Chernobyl. Hot spots are being found 60 to 70 kilometres away from the reactor (further away than they were found from Chernobyl), and the amount of radiation in many of them is the amount that caused areas to be declared no-man's-land for Chernobyl.{{cite news|work=[[Aljazeera]]|title=Fukushima: It's much worse than you think|author = Dahr Jamail |date=16 June 2011| url = http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/features/2011/06/201161664828302638.html}}{{POV-statement|Gunderson|date=August 2011}} In off-the-record-interviews with Japanese newspapers like the ''Tokyo Shimbun'', former Japanese prime minister [[Naoto Kan]] said that there were moments he believed the disaster could have surpassed Chernobyl, many times. At first TEPCO denied that fuel-cores were melted, after all cooling functions were lost. Trade minister Banri Kaieda mentioned that TEPCO seriously considered pulling away all staff members from the plant and leaving it abandoned. Kan could not accept this: "Withdrawing from the plant is out of the question."{{cite news | title = In Nuclear Crisis, Crippling Mistrust | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/13/world/asia/13japan.html?pagewanted=all | date = 12 June 2011 | accessdate = 20 September 2012 | first=Norimitsu | last = Onishi | first2= Martin | last2= Fackler | publisher = [[The New York Times]]}} He claimed that "If that had happened, Tokyo would be deserted by now. It was a critical moment for Japan's survival. It could have been a led to leaks of dozens of times more radiation than Chernobyl."{{cite news | title = Fukushima nuclear disaster: PM at the time feared Japan would collapse | first=Justin | last=McCurry | publisher = [[The Guardian]]| date=8 September 2011}} He said that might have "compromised the very existence of the Japanese nation".{{cite news |url=http://globalspin.blogs.time.com/2012/02/29/panel-government-told-people-to-keep-calm-while-mulling-tokyo-evacuation/ |title=Fukushima Report: Japan Urged Calm While It Mulled Tokyo Evacuation |author =Krista Mahr |date=29 February 2012 |work=Time }} TEPCO's president at that time, Masataka Shimizu, was never clear in his answers, and TEPCO failed to obey the orders to vent one of the overheating reactors. In an interview to the ''Asahi Shimbun'' newspaper, Kan revealed that he went to the plant itself and visually inspected it from above in a helicopter because: "I felt I had to go there in person and speak to the people in charge or I would never have known what was going on." Kan said that the American government was seriously concerned about the Japanese response to the accident: "We were not told straight out, but it was obvious that they questioned whether we were really taking this seriously." Kan defended his changed attitude to a non-nuclear energy policy, "If there is a risk of accidents that could make half the land mass of our country uninhabitable, then we cannot afford to take that risk."{{cite news | publisher =[[The Guardian]] | date =8 September 2011 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/sep/08/fukushima-nuclear-disaster-pm-japan | title= Tepco had considered abandoning the plant after it was hit by the 11 March tsunami | location=London | first=Justin | last=McCurry}} ==See also== * [[List of civilian nuclear accidents]] * [[Lists of nuclear disasters and radioactive incidents]] * [[Timeline of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster]] * [[Comparison of Fukushima and Chernobyl nuclear accidents]] ==References== {{reflist|30em|refs= {{cite web |url=http://www.iaea.org/newscenter/news/2011/fukushima150311.html |title=Fukushima nuclear accident update log, updates of 15 March 2011 |work=IAEA |date=15 March 2011 |accessdate=8 May 2011}} {{cite web|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn20305-caesium-fallout-from-fukushima-rivals-chernobyl.html |title=Caesium fallout from Fukushima rivals Chernobyl |work=New Scientist |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xZGE47q4?url=http://www.newscientist.com/article/dn20305-caesium-fallout-from-fukushima-rivals-chernobyl.html |archivedate=30 March 2011 |accessdate=30 March 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} {{cite web |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0,1518,754868,00.html |title=A hapless Fukushima clean-up effort |author1=Veronika Hackenbroch |author2=Cordula Meyer |author3=Thilo Thielke |date=5 April 2011 |work=Der Spiegel}} {{cite web|url=http://www.iaea.org/newscenter/news/tsunamiupdate01.html|title=IAEA Update on Japan Earthquake|quote=As reported earlier, a 400 millisieverts (mSv) per hour radiation dose observed at Fukushima Daiichi occurred between 1s 3 and 4. This is a high dose-level value, but it is a local value at a single location and at a certain point in time. The IAEA continues to confirm the evolution and value of this dose rate. It should be noted that because of this detected value, non-indispensable staff was evacuated from the plant, in line with the Emergency Response Plan, and that the population around the plant is already evacuated.|accessdate=16 March 2011}} {{cite journal|url=http://bos.sagepub.com/content/67/5/27.full |title=The radiological and psychological consequences of the Fukushima Daiichi accident 210 tons (spent fuel pools not involved in incident){{cite web|title=Chernobyl Accident And Its Consequences - Nuclear Energy Institute|url=https://www.nei.org/Master-Document-Folder/Backgrounders/Fact-Sheets/Chernobyl-Accident-And-Its-Consequences|website=www.nei.org|publisher=Nuclear Energy Institute|accessdate=9 April 2017}} - note that figures were converted into US tons |- | '''Cause of the accident''' || The plants were not designed with consideration of such a large [[tsunami]]. A major [[2011 Tohoku earthquake|earthquake and tsunami]] caused the destruction of power lines and backup generators. Once the plants were without external power and the generators were flooded, a catastrophic [[decay heat]] casualty ensued, leading to major reactor plant damage including [[nuclear meltdown|meltdown]]s and explosive loss of [[reactor containment]].{{citation needed|date=May 2017}} || Proximate cause was human error and violation of procedures. The unsafe reactor design caused instability at low power due to a positive [[void coefficient]] and steam formation. When an improper test was conducted at 1:00 am at low power, the reactor became [[prompt critical]]. This was followed by a [[steam explosion]] that exposed the fuel, a raging fire, and a [[core meltdown]]. The fire lasted for days to weeks, and there is controversy over whether it was the fuel burning, nuclear decay heating or whether the [[graphite]] moderator that made up most of the core was involved. See [[Chernobyl Disaster]], Note 1, for more discussion. |- | '''Maximum level of [[radiation]] detected''' || 210 [[sievert|Sv]]/h inside Unit 2 containment vessel six years after meltdown.{{cite web|last1=Beser|first1=Ari|title=After Alarmingly High Radiation Levels Detected, What Are the Facts in Fukushima?|url=http://voices.nationalgeographic.com/2017/02/22/after-alarmingly-high-radiation-levels-detected-what-are-the-facts-in-fukushima/|website=National Geographic Society (blogs)|publisher=National Geographic Society|accessdate=9 April 2017|date=22 February 2017}} || 300 [[sievert|Sv]]/h shortly after the explosion in vicinity of the reactor core.{{cite web|url = http://handle.dtic.mil/100.2/ADA335076|title = JPRS Report: Soviet Union Economic Affairs Chernobyl Notebook|author = B. Medvedev|date =June 1989|publisher = Novy Mir|accessdate =27 March 2011|edition = Republished by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service}} |- | '''Radioactivity released''' || As of 2014, a peer reviewed estimate of the total was 340–780 P[[Becquerel|Bq]], with 80% falling into the Pacific Ocean.{{cite journal |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S004896971301173X?np=y#f0010 |title=Comparison of the Chernobyl and Fukushima nuclear accidents: A review of the environmental impacts | doi=10.1016/j.scitotenv.2013.10.029 | volume=470-471 |journal=Science of the Total Environment |pages=800–817|year=2014 |last1=Steinhauser |first1=Georg |last2=Brandl |first2=Alexander |last3=Johnson |first3=Thomas E. }} Radiation continues to be released into the Pacific via groundwater. || {{convert|5.2|EBq|PBq|abbr=on}}{{cite web|url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/stamp/stamp.jsp?arnumber=06056644|title=Three Mile Island, Chernobyl, and Fukushima, A comparison of three nuclear reactor calamities reveals some key differences|work=[[IEEE]]|date=Nov 1, 2011|accessdate=Nov 4, 2013}}{{cite 2013|accessdate=Nov 4, 2013}} |- | '''Area affected''' || Radiation levels exceeding annual limits seen over {{convert|60|km|mi}} to northwest and {{convert|40|km|mi}} to south-southwest, according to officials.{{citation needed|date=February 2017}} || An area up to {{convert|500|km|mi}} away contaminated, according to the United Nations.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}} |- | '''[[Exclusion Zone]] Area''' || 20 km (30 km voluntary) extending north-west to 45 km in the downwind direction to [[Iitate, Fukushima]]{{cite web |url=http://www.world-nuclear.org/information-library/safety-and-security/safety-of-plants/appendices/fukushima-radiation-exposure.aspx |title=Fukushima: Radiation Exposure |publisher=World Nuclear Association |date=February 2016 |accessdate=4 February 2017}} || 30 km |- | '''Population relocated''' || 154,000{{Cite web|url=http://www.reconstruction.go.jp/english/topics/GEJE/index.html|title=Reconstruction Agency|website=www.reconstruction.go.jp|access-date=2016-05-25}} || 335,000 (About 115,000 from areas surrounding the reactor in 1986; about 220,000 people from [[Belarus]], the [[Russian Federation]] and [[Ukraine]] after 1986) |- | '''Direct fatalities from the accident''' || None || Two immediate trauma deaths; 28 deaths from Acute Radiation Syndrome out of 134 showing symptoms; four from an industrial accident (helicopter crash); 15 deaths from radiation-genic thyroid cancers (as of 2005){{cite techreport| url=http://www.unscear.org/docs/reports/2008/11-80076_Report_2008_Annex_D.pdf| title=Health effects due to radiation from the Chernobyl accident (Annex D of the 2008 UNSCEAR Report)| date=2011| publisher=UNSCEAR}} |- | '''Current status''' || [[Cold shutdown]] declared on 16 December 2011, but decommissioning is likely to take 30 to 40 years.{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/04/07/toshiba-idUSL3E7F73E720110407 |title=UPDATE 1-Toshiba proposes to scrap Fukushima nuclear plant-Nikkei |accessdate=27 July 2013 |work=Reuters |first=Kavyanjali |last=Kaushik |date=7 April 2011}}{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2014/mar/10/fukushima-operator-dump-contaminated-water-pacific |title=Fukushima operator may have to dump contaminated water into Pacific |author=Justin Mccurry |newspaper=The Guardian |date=10 March 2014 |accessdate=10 March 2014}} All fuel rods in reactor 4 pool removed. [[Fukushima disaster cleanup]] is ongoing. || All reactors were shut down by 2000. The damaged reactor was covered by a hastily built steel and concrete structure called the ''[[Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant sarcophagus|sarcophagus]]''. A [[New Safe Confinement]] structure was installed in November 2016, from which the plant will be cleaned up and decommissioned. |} ==Radioactive contamination discharge== {| class="wikitable" |- !rowspan=2| Report date !rowspan=2| Place !rowspan=2| Period !colspan=2| [[Iodine-131]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2011}} [[File:Fukushima I NPP 1975 medium crop rotated labeled.jpg|thumb|Satellite image of the [[Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant]] where the "Fukushima 50" were assigned to stabilize the six reactors at the plant]]
'''Fukushima 50''' is the [[pseudonym]] given by the media to a group of employees at the crippled [[Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant]]. Following the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami|Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]] on 11 March 2011, a related [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster|series of nuclear accidents]] resulted in melting of the cores of three reactors. These 50 employees remained on-site after 750 other workers were evacuated.<ref name=Asahi /><ref name="telegraph.co.uk">https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/japan/8408863/Japan-tsunami-Fukushima-Fifty-the-first-interview.html Japan tsunami: Fukushima Fifty, the first interview</ref>
After [[Tokyo Electric Power Company|TEPCO]] management proposed withdrawing all its employees from the plant on 14 March,<ref>http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20110318p2a00m0na009000c.html {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110321030932/http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20110318p2a00m0na009000c.html# |date=21 March 2011 }} TEPCO wanted to withdraw all nuclear plant workers 3 days after quake</ref> additional manpower was deployed from around Japan.<ref name="nytimes.com">https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/31/world/asia/31workers.html?src=mv Workers Give Glimpse of Japan’s Nuclear Crisis</ref> Some workers traveled on clear roads by convoy from Tokyo.<ref name="nytimes.com"/> When they arrived, hundreds of firemen, SDF personnel and employees of TEPCO, convened {{convert|20|km|abbr=on}} from the plant and debated how to best stabilize the plant.<ref name="nytimes.com"/> On the night of 15 March, these workers joined the original Fukushima 50. Despite the incorrect figure of workers, the Fukushima 50 has remained the pseudonym used by media to refer to the group of workers at Fukushima reflecting the solitary nature of the role.<ref>{{Cite web |title=In praise of … the Fukushima 50 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/jan/02/fukushima-50 |newspaper=The Guardian |date=2 January 2013 |accessdate=2013-03-10}}</ref>
The number of the workers involved rose to 580 on the morning of 18 March<ref name=Asahi /> as staff from the [[Kashiwazaki-Kariwa Nuclear Power Plant]] and workers installing the new power line joined in. More than 1,000 workers, firefighters, and soldiers toiled at the site on 23 March.<ref name=thesun110325>{{cite news|title=Tokyo tap water 'radioactive'|url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/news/3485227/1000-workers-take-major-step-towards-ending-Japans-nuclear-crisis-by-fixing-power-lines.html|accessdate=25 March 2011|newspaper=The Sun|date=24 March 2011|location=UK}}</ref><ref name=Australian>{{cite news|last=Alford|first=Peter|title=Nameless samurai are `heroes of our modern world'|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/nameless-samurai-are-heroes-of-our-modern-world/story-fn84naht-1226027025461|accessdate=25 March 2011|newspaper=The Australian|date=24 March 2011|location=AUS}}</ref> The Fukushima 50 were drawn from [[Toshiba]], [[Hitachi]], [[Kajima]], firefighters from [[Tokyo Fire Department|Tokyo]], [[:ja:大阪市消防局|Osaka]],<ref name=SankeiOsaka>{{Cite news|script-title=ja:「特攻隊…」ヨウ素飲ませ覚悟の命令 放水支援の大阪市消防局|trans-title=Osaka Fire Department firefighter|url=http://sankei.jp.msn.com/science/news/110325/scn11032514450001-n1.htm|language=Japanese|work=[[Sankei Shimbun]]|location=JP|date=25 March 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110923032601/http://sankei.jp.msn.com/science/news/110325/scn11032514450001-n1.htm|archivedate=23 September 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> [[:ja:横浜市消防局|Yokohama]],<ref name=SankeiYokohama>{{Cite news|script-title=ja:６７人１０台を派遣 福島第１原発に横浜市消防局|trans-title=Dispatched 67 people 10 Fire apparatus to Fukushima I N-plant: Yokohama Fire Department|url=http://sankei.jp.msn.com/region/news/110321/kng11032119500006-n1.htm|language=Japanese|work=[[Sankei Shimbun]]|location=JP|date=21 March 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324145741/http://sankei.jp.msn.com/region/news/110321/kng11032119500006-n1.htm|archivedate=24 March 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> [[:ja:川崎市消防局|Kawasaki]], [[:ja:名古屋市消防局|Nagoya]] and [[:ja:京都市消防局|Kyoto]], [[TEPCO]] and its [[subsidiary|subsidiaries]] such as [[:ja:関電工|Kandenko]],<ref name=mainichiKandenko /> [[:ja:東電工業|TEP Industry]] and [[:ja:東電環境エンジニアリング|TEP Environmental Engineering]], and many small-to-mid-size companies that have contracts with these big companies.<ref name=Asahi>{{Cite news|script-title=ja:「英雄フクシマ５０」欧米メディア、原発の作業員ら称賛|trans-title="Fukushima 50" western press praise workers at nuclear plant|url=http://www.asahi.com/special/10005/TKY201103180477.html|language=Japanese|work=[[Asahi Shimbun]] |location=JP|date=18 March 2011}}</ref><ref name=Mainichi>{{Cite news|script-title=ja:福島第１原発：英雄でも何でもない…交代で懸命の復旧作業|trans-title=Fukushima I Nuclear Plant: "Not a hero...." rotating desperate work for recovering the plant|url=http://mainichi.jp/select/jiken/news/20110321k0000e040033000c.html|language=Japanese|work=[[Mainichi Shimbun]]|location=JP|date=21 March 2011|title=Archived copy|access-date=25 March 2011|archive-url=https://archive.today/20130111205536/http://mainichi.jp/select/shakai/#|archive-date=11 January 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Over 20 workers had been injured by 18 March, including one who was exposed to a large amount of [[ionizing radiation]] when the worker tried to vent vapour from a valve of the [[containment building]].<ref name=Asahi /> Three more workers were exposed to radiation over 100 [[sievert|mSv]], and two of them were sent to a hospital due to [[Radiation burn#Beta burns|beta burns]] on 24 March.<ref name=Belfasttelegraph /> Two other workers, Kazuhiko Kokubo, 24, and Yoshiki Terashima, 21, were killed by the tsunami while conducting emergency repairs immediately after the quake. Their bodies were found on 30 March.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2011/04/04/national/two-missing-tepco-workers-found-dead/|title=Two missing Tepco workers found dead|last=Takahara|first=Kanako|date=2011-04-04|work=The Japan Times Online|access-date=2018-11-12|language=en-US|issn=0447-5763}}</ref>
The workers and volunteers were assigned the mission of stabilizing the reactors. Their activities included assessing the damage and radiation levels caused by the explosions, cooling stricken reactors with seawater, and preventing any risk of fire. These workers remained on-site despite serious risks of radiation poisoning.<ref>{{cite news|title=Fukushima 50 battle radiation risks as Japan nuclear crisis deepens|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/mar/15/fukushima-50-workers-nuclear-plant|work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=15 March 2011 |first1=Tania|last1=Branigan |first2=Justin|last2=McCurry}}</ref> Levels of radiation on site are far higher than in the {{convert|20|km|abbr=on}} [[exclusion zone]] and media outlets reported that the severity of the situation could have grave implications on their future health, with possibly fatal consequences for the workers.<ref>{{Cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-12779510 |title=BBC News - Japan hails the heroic 'Fukushima 50' |first= |last=|publisher=BBC News |accessdate=17 March 2011 |date=17 March 2011}}</ref> On 18 March, according to Prime Minister [[Naoto Kan]] the workers were "prepared for death".<ref>[http://www.hindustantimes.com/More-volunteers-prepared-for-death-at-Fukushima/Article1-675822.aspx More volunteers 'prepared for death' at Fukushima]</ref>
On 14 March, a complete withdrawal proposed by [[TEPCO]] was rejected by the prime minister,<ref name="Mainichi Daily News Japan">{{Cite news|title=TEPCO wanted to withdraw all nuclear plant workers 3 days after quake|url=http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20110318p2a00m0na009000c.html|work=Mainichi Daily News|location=Japan|date=18 March 2011|access-date=19 March 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110321030932/http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20110318p2a00m0na009000c.html#|archive-date=21 March 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="The Daily Yomiuri Japan">{{Cite news|title=Kan berates TEPCO for tardy response|url=http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/national/T110315004235.htm|work=The Daily Yomiuri |location=Japan |date=16 March 2011}}</ref><ref name="Xinhua News Agency China">{{Cite news|title=Japanese PM slams nuke plant operator's handling of growing crisis, SDF switch to relief from rescue|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2011-03/15/c_13780133.htm|work=Xinhua News Agency |location=China|date=15 March 2011}}</ref> to continue attempts at bringing the reactors under control during the [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster]].
==Conditions==
===Working environment=== The workers ate and slept in shifts in a two-story earthquake-resistant building at the center of the complex constructed in July 2010,<ref name="telegraph.co.uk"/> about "the size of an average living room."<ref>{{Cite news |title=Outpouring of Tears and Prayers for Japan's Heroes: The Fukushima 50 |url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/relatives-break-silence-japans-heroes-fukushima-50/story?id=13155666 |publisher=ABC News |date=17 March 2011 |accessdate=17 March 2011}}</ref>
;A daily schedule at Fukushima I nuclear plant<ref name=mainichi110328workers>{{cite news|script-title=ja:福島第１原発：作業員、厳しい環境 食事２回、夜は雑魚寝|trans-title=Fukushima I N-plant: Workers at hard environment eat twice a day, sleep all crowded on the floor at night|url=http://mainichi.jp/select/jiken/news/20110329k0000m040150000c.html|accessdate=29 March 2011|newspaper=[[Mainichi Shimbun]]|date=28 March 2011|location=JP|language=Japanese|title=Archived copy|archive-url=https://archive.today/20130218172417/http://mainichi.jp/select/shakai/#|archive-date=18 February 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> according to the article on 28 March.
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Time !! Event |- | 6am || Wake up |- | 7-8am || Meeting at the antiseismic building (免震重要棟, menshin-jūyō-tō, lit. avoiding quakes-important-building) |- | 8-10am || Breakfast (biscuits about 30 pieces and one bottle of vegetable juice) |- | About 10am || Commence tasks at the reactor building and boiler building |- | About 5pm || Finish work |- | 5-8pm || Supper (retort-packed rice and one canned food) |- | 8-10pm || Meeting at the antiseismic building |- | About 10pm || Sleep, with blanket on the floor, except people who work at night. |}
During some work, in high radiation areas, the workers were limited to 15-minute sessions inside the damaged buildings.<ref>http://www.foxnews.com/world/2011/03/31/japans-nuclear-rescuers-inevitable-die-weeks/ Japan's Nuclear Rescuers: 'Inevitable Some of Them May Die Within Weeks'</ref>
===Radiation=== The international limit for radiation exposure for nuclear workers is 20 [[Sievert|millisievert]] (20 mSv, or 2 rem) per year, averaged over five years, with a limit of 50 mSv in any one year, however for workers performing emergency services [[United States Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) guidance on dose limits is 100 mSv when "protecting valuable property" and 250 mSv when the activity is "life saving or protection of large populations."<ref>[http://www.epa.gov/rpdweb00/docs/er/400-r-92-001.pdf Table 2-2] [[United States Environmental Protection Agency]]</ref>
Prior to the accident, the maximum permissible dose for Japanese nuclear workers was 100 mSv in any one year, but on 15 March 2011, the Japanese Health and Labor Ministry enforced the permitted 250 mSv limit, in light of the situation at the Fukushima Nuclear Power Plant.<ref>{{citation |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/16/world/asia/16workers.html |department=Asia |date=16 March 2011 |title=Last Defense at Troubled Reactors: 50 Japanese Workers |first1=Keith |last1=Bradsher |first2=Hiroko |last2=Tabuchi}}</ref><ref>{{citation | publisher = NHK | place = JP | url = http://www3.nhk.or.jp/daily/english/16_19.html | title = Gov't ups permissible radiation level | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110317010034/http://www3.nhk.or.jp/daily/english/16_19.html | archivedate = 17 March 2011 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> However, the workers at Fukushima plant declined the elevated 250 mSv limit and kept adopting the previous 100 mSv.<ref name=mainichi250Declined>{{cite news|title=TEPCO tries to enclose high radiation in sea in nuke crisis|url=http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20110410p2g00m0dm011000c.html|accessdate=10 April 2011|newspaper=[[Mainichi Shimbun]]|date=10 April 2011|location=JP|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110410215931/http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20110410p2g00m0dm011000c.html#|archive-date=10 April 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Tokyo Enesys, a TEPCO's subsidiary, adopts 80 mSv to manage the radiation level monitoring with some buffer. Kandenko, [[Kajima]] and [[Taisei Corporation]] adopted 100 mSv. [[Hitachi]] rewrote internal rule as 200 mSv.<ref name=nikkan250Declined>{{cite news|script-title=ja:政府被ばく基準増 原発作業員が拒否|trans-title=Nuclear workers had rejected the elevated formula by the government|url=http://www.nikkansports.com/general/news/p-gn-tp0-20110410-759169.html|accessdate=10 April 2011|newspaper=[[Nikkan Sports]]|date=10 April 2011|location=JP|language=Japanese|title=Archived copy|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110412142702/http://www.nikkansports.com/general/news/p-gn-tp0-20110410-759169.html#|archive-date=12 April 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> TEPCO decided to move workers around 200mSv to low-radiated site while its subsidiaries, Tokyo Enesys and Kandenko, adopted limits around 100mSv. Over 30 workers were radiated beyond 100 mSv by 23 April 2011.<ref name=sankeiOver30WorkersRadiated>{{cite news|script-title=ja:被曝１００ミリシーベルト超３０人に 熟練作業者の累積量が増大 収束へ課題|url=http://sankei.jp.msn.com/affairs/news/110423/dst11042320230042-n1.htm|accessdate=23 April 2011|newspaper=[[Sankei Shimbun]]|date=23 April 2011|location=JP|language=Japanese|title=Archived copy|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110426115251/http://sankei.jp.msn.com/affairs/news/110423/dst11042320230042-n1.htm#|archive-date=26 April 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
According to the Guardian, the Fukushima workers had to be wary of radiation spiking—a sudden and unforeseen rise in radiation.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Radiation spike forces evacuations at Fukushima nuclear power station |last=McCurry |first=Justin |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/mar/16/fukushima-workers-evacuate-radiation-spikes |publisher=Guardian |date=16 March 2011 |accessdate=18 March 2011 |location=London}}</ref> This threat forced the workers to evacuate for a short period of time on the morning of Tuesday 15 March 2011 when radiation detected at Fukushima rose to approximately 1000 mSv/h,<ref>{{Cite news |title=Radiation spike hinders work at Japan nuke plant |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/03/15/501364/main20043621.shtml |publisher=CBS News |date=15 March 2011 |accessdate=18 March 2011}}</ref> the highest level of radiation detected at any point of time during the accident at the plant.
The workers wore [[hazmat suit]]s and hazmat masks, carrying [[dosimeter]]s that alerted at 80 millisieverts. Each worker had to stop the operation once the dosimeter alerted.<ref name=Sponichi>{{Cite news|script-title=ja:復旧へ命がけ…「フクシマ５０」に援軍|trans-title=Threatening lives for recovery.... Reinforcements sent to "Fukushima 50"|url=http://www.sponichi.co.jp/society/news/2011/03/20/kiji/K20110320000460780.html|language=Japanese|work=[[Sports Nippon|Sponichi Annex]] |location=JP|date=20 March 2011}}</ref> According to TEPCO, seven TEPCO workers were exposed to radiation over the limit of 100 millisievert by the morning of 20 March.<ref name=Sankei110320>{{Cite news|script-title=ja:上限１００ミリシーベルト超被曝の東電作業員１人増え、計７人に|trans-title=one more TEPCO worker added, now seven workers exposed to radiation over 100 millisievert.|url=http://sankei.jp.msn.com/affairs/news/110320/dst11032011560034-n1.htm|language=Japanese|work=[[Sankei Shimbun]]|location=JP|date=20 March 2011|title=Archived copy|access-date=22 March 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110323212333/http://sankei.jp.msn.com/affairs/news/110320/dst11032011560034-n1.htm#|archive-date=23 March 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In context, [[Sievert#Symptom benchmarks|immediate symptoms become apparent if exposed to above 250 mSv]] per day. Symptoms include [[nausea]] and [[loss of appetite]] as well as damage to [[bone marrow]], [[lymph nodes]] and the [[spleen]]. Generally, these symptoms become [[Sievert#Symptom benchmarks|more severe and noticeable in the 1000 to 3000 mSv bracket]] with recovery probable, but not assured. New and more serious symptoms appear above 3000 mSv such as [[Desquamation|peeling of the skin]], [[hemorrhaging]] and [[sterility (physiology)|sterility]] with death if left untreated.
==Explosions==
The Fukushima 50 were present when hydrogen explosions occurred at the reactor buildings of units 1, 3, and 4. Five workers were injured in the unit 1 explosion at 15:36 on 12 March. Most of the injuries were not severe. Eleven workers were injured in the unit 3 explosion at 11:01 on 14 March. The explosion at unit 4 at about 6am on 15 March did not cause injuries. The explosions scattered radioactive concrete debris around the buildings, which made the working conditions on the site more difficult.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hasegawa|first=A.|last2=Ohira|first2=T.|last3=Maeda|first3=M.|last4=Yasumura|first4=S.|last5=Tanigawa|first5=K.|date=2016-04-01|title=Emergency Responses and Health Consequences after the Fukushima Accident; Evacuation and Relocation|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0936655516000054|journal=Clinical Oncology|language=en|volume=28|issue=4|pages=237–244|doi=10.1016/j.clon.2016.01.002|issn=0936-6555|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cas.go.jp/jp/seisaku/icanps/eng/120224Honbun02Eng.pdf|title=Interim report|last=|first=|date=26 December 2011|website=|publisher=Investigation Committee on the Accident at the Fukushima Nuclear Power Stations|pages=51-52|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
==Number of workers==
[[File:TFD-LP.jpg|thumb|right|Water tower vehicles from major fire departments were integral to the emergency cooling operations]]
Originally there were approximately 800 workers on 11 March 2011, the day the earthquake and tsunami struck. On 15 March, workers deemed non-essential were withdrawn by the [[Tokyo Electric Power Company]]. A total of around 750 workers left due to increased risk and consequently left around 50. It was on this day that the media started to call the remaining workers the "Fukushima 50".
However, on the morning of the 16 March the remaining workers had to be evacuated for a brief period of time due to a radiation spike which was detected which could be harmful to the workers' health. It was reported that when they returned to the plant, a further 130 or so workers joined their colleagues to total of around 180 to stabilize the reactors.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Winerman|first=Lea|title=The 'Fukushima 50': Nuclear Workers Stay Behind to Brave Plant's Woes|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/rundown/2011/03/nuclear-plant-workers-become-anonymous-faces-of-bravery.html|accessdate=16 March 2011|newspaper=PBS NewsHour}}</ref> The number of workers rose to 580 on the morning of the 18 March.<ref name=Asahi /> By 12 April, approximately 700 workers were working on-site.<ref name="asahi.com">http://www.asahi.com/english/TKY201104110137.html Heroes and realists found among the brave "Fukushima 700"</ref>
By 21 March 2011, Toshiba had sent a 100-strong team to two Fukushima plants as part of a task-force of 700 Toshiba workers organized at Toshiba's [[Isogo-ku, Yokohama|Isogo]] Engineering Centre to defuse the nuclear crisis, and Hitachi had dispatched 120 to Fukushima I and formed a 1000-strong task force.<ref name=Reuters110322> {{Cite news|title=Toshiba, Hitachi send engineers to stricken nuclear plant|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/22/us-toshiba-idUSTRE72L0U020110322|work=[[Reuters]]|date=22 March 2011|first=Isabel|last=Reynolds}}</ref><ref name=responce/>
Referring to the original 50 workers, nuclear researcher Dr. Eric Hall opined that they were likely to be older, and unlikely to have further children, so the long-term effects of exposure to high-levels of [[ionizing radiation]] would be less likely to appear before a [[Death by natural causes|natural death]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/fukushima-50-line-defense-japanese-nuclear-complex/story?id=13147746&page=2 |title=Japan's Fukushima 50: Heroes Who Volunteered to Stay Behind at Japan's Crippled Nuclear Plants |last1=KATRANDJIAN |first1=Olivia |last2=Cho |first2=Joohee |last3=Chang|first3=Juju|date=16 March 2011 |work= |publisher= ABC News|accessdate=19 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=KATRANDJIAN|first=OLIVIA|title=Japan's Fukushima 50: Heroes Who Volunteered to Stay Behind at Japan's Crippled Nuclear Plants|url=http://abcnews.go.com/m/story?id=13147746&sid=76&p=2|accessdate=17 March 2011|newspaper=ABC News|date=16 March 2011}}</ref> Some younger workers were injured<ref name=mainichiKandenko /> and young Osaka firefighters were operating at the site.<ref name=SankeiOsaka /> A group of 250 skilled senior citizens volunteered to work in the radioactive environment, citing reduced harm to them.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/asiapcf/05/31/japan.nuclear.suicide/index.html?hpt=hp_t2 |title=Japanese seniors volunteer for Fukushima 'suicide corps' |author= Lah, Kyung |date=1 June 2011 |work= |publisher=CNN |accessdate=1 June 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://af.reuters.com/article/energyOilNews/idAFL3E7H60ZD20110606 |title=Japanese retirees ready to risk Fukushima front line |last1=Krolicki |first1=Kevin |last2= |first2= |date=6 June 2011 |work= |publisher= Reuters Africa|accessdate=7 June 2011}}</ref>
Team leader Masao Yoshida died of [[esophageal cancer]] in 2013, but the cancer was likely to be unrelated to the event at Fukushima, as development typically takes 5–10 years.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/07/10/world/asia/japan-yoshida-death/index.html?iid=article_sidebar |title=Man who battled Japan's nuclear meltdown dies |last1=Wakatsuki |first1=Yuko |last2=Hunt |first2=Katie |date=10 July 2013 |website=CNN.com |publisher= |accessdate=28 July 2013}}</ref>

Some co-operative "company men" were only paid around 20,000 yen (US$236), and volunteered for the position for fear of losing their jobs.<ref name="asahi.com"/> While others volunteered because they felt they were "the only workers that [could] do the job" and a shared a sense of solidarity.<ref name="asahi.com"/> |- | [[Hazama Corporation]] || 7* || 15 March to 18 March || clear and repair roads at the scene ||<ref>https://blogs.wsj.com/japanrealtime/2011/04/06/fukushima-construction-team-in-50s-cleared-the-way/ Fukushima: Construction Team, in 50s, Cleared the Way</ref>|| |} <nowiki>*</nowiki>: task finished
==Injury== Over 20 workers were injured by 18 March.<ref name=Asahi /> Three workers were exposed to radiation and two were rushed to a hospital with up to 180 mSv, which is less than the maximum 250 mSv that the government allowed for workers at the plant.<ref name=Belfasttelegraph>{{cite news|title=Japan nuclear workers exposed to radioactive elements|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/world-news/japan-nuclear-workers-exposed-to-radioactive-elements-15125832.html|accessdate=25 March 2011|newspaper=Belfasttelegraph|date=25 March 2011}}</ref> Both workers, one in his twenties and one in his thirties, were from [[:ja:関電工|Kandenko]] and were regular workers at [[Fukushima II nuclear power plant]].<ref name=mainichiKandenko>{{cite news|script-title=ja:福島第１原発：作業員被ばく 搬送の２人は関電工社員|trans-title=Fukushima I Nuclear Plant: Workers exposed, two rushed to hospital were staff of Kandenko plant|url=http://mainichi.jp/select/jiken/news/20110325k0000e040087000c.html|accessdate=25 March 2011|newspaper=Mainichi Shimbun|date=25 March 2011|location=JP|language=Japanese|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121219045258/http://mainichi.jp/select/shakai/|archivedate=19 December 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Another worker was from a contract company of Kandenko.<ref name=Sankei110325>{{cite news|script-title=ja:被曝の関電工社員は２０代と３０代「こんな量を…」戸惑う担当者|trans-title=Exposed Kandenko workers 20s and 30s, "We haven't experienced this much radiator...", confused manager|url=http://sankei.jp.msn.com/affairs/news/110325/dst11032511180019-n1.htm|accessdate=25 March 2011|date=25 March 2011|location=JP|language=Japanese|title=Archived copy|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723054347/http://sankei.jp.msn.com/affairs/news/110325/dst11032511180019-n1.htm#|archive-date=23 July 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Cooperation== {| class="wikitable" |- !style="width:130px;"| Organization ! ! Source !style="width:400px;" | |- | [[U.S. Navy]] ||preparing 2 ships with 1,100 tons of water each ||<ref name=sankeiUsNavy>{{cite news|script-title=ja:米軍が冷却用の真水提供、福島第１原発へ|trans-title=US force providing fresh water for cooling, to Fukushima I N-plant|url=http://sankei.jp.msn.com/affairs/news/110325/dst11032522080109-n1.htm|accessdate=25 March 2011|newspaper=[[Sankei Shimbun]]|date=25 March 2011|location=JP|language=Japanese|title=Archived copy|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324145746/http://sankei.jp.msn.com/affairs/news/110325/dst11032522080109-n1.htm#|archive-date=24 March 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> || The U.S. government strongly recommended the Japanese government use fresh water because of accidents salt water could cause. The U.S. Navy supplied backup fresh water. |}
==Reaction of media and public== Media outlets lauded the remaining workers' bravery, and called them "heroes", and as a result they have become known in the media as the "Fukushima 50". ''[[France 24]]'' called them "Japan's faceless heroes",<ref>{{Cite web |title=Japan's faceless heroes |url=http://www.france24.com/en/20110316-fukushima-japan-nuclear-power-plant-reactors-fire-explosion-50-workers-survivors-death |publisher=France24 |date=16 March 2011}}</ref> British newspaper, ''[[The Guardian]]'' wrote: "Other nuclear power employees, as well as the wider population, can only look on in admiration".<ref>{{Cite news |title='Fukushima heroes' battle to tame nuclear plant as Japan watches |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/mar/16/fukushima-heroes-nuclear-japan-watches |work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=16 March 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011 |first=Justin |last=McCurry}}</ref> They have been compared to the [[Forty-seven Ronin]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Japan aktuell: Die 50 von Fukushima – die modernen 47 Ronin? |url=http://www.spreadnews.de/japan-aktuell-die-50-von-fukushima-die-modernen-47-ronin/119578/ |work=Spreadnews.de |location=DE |date=19 March 2011 |accessdate=19 March 2011}}</ref> In Hong Kong, a group of netizens at [[HKGolden]] Forum dedicated Cantonese and Japanese lyrics based on a [[Cantopop]] song, entitled "福島烈士─向福島50人致敬" (''Martyr of Fukushima - Tribute to the Fukushima Fifty''), to the workers.<ref>{{Cite web |title=港網民改歌向死士致敬 (''HK Netizens Recomposes a Song in Tribute to Martyrs'')|url=http://hk.apple.nextmedia.com/template/apple/art_main.php?iss_id=20110322&sec_id=4104&art_id=15097111|work=hk.apple.nextmedia.com/ |location=HK |date=22 March 2011 |accessdate=23 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=向福島50人致敬！ 港「高登音樂台」自唱自製MV (''Tribute to Fukushima 50! HKGolden Sings their Self-made MV'')|url=http://www.nownews.com/2011/03/21/334-2698508.htm#ixzz1HQRIaLHK|work=nownews.com |location=TW |date=21 March 2011 |accessdate=23 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=[高登音樂台] 福島烈士 (向福島50人致意)(''[HKGolden] Fukushima heroes (Tribute to Fukushima 50)'')|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l-IPT_vnOjs |date=23 March 2011 |accessdate=28 March 2011}}</ref>
According to Robert Hetkämper, a correspondent for the German television network [[ARD (broadcaster)|ARD]], the label "Fukushima 50" was invented by a foreign newspaper, and then was imported by the Japanese media. The "Fukushima 50" would include engineers as well as unskilled workers, and there would be grounds to suspect that many workers were not really aware of the dangers of their assignment.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=ARD|title=Die "Fukushima 50" sind eine Legende|trans-title=The "Fukushima 50" are a legend|language=German|location=GER|date=23 March 2011|url=https://www.tagesschau.de/ausland/japanberichterstattung100.html|accessdate=23 March 2011}}</ref>
==Awards== On 7 September 2011, the "Fukushima Heroes" were honored with the [[Prince of Asturias Awards|Prince of Asturias Award for Peace]], an award given by the Crown Prince of [[Spain]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.rtve.es/noticias/20110907/los-heroes-fukushima-premio-principe-asturias-concordia-2011/459906.shtml |title = Los "Héroes de Fukushima", Premio Príncipe de Asturias de la Concordia 2011 |accessdate = 7 September 2011 |author = RTVE |date = 7 September 2011 |publisher = RTVE.es}}</ref>
