revision.text:
{{About|the investigate committee formed by the Japanese government|the investigate committee or commission formed by the [[statutory law]]|National Diet of Japan Fukushima Nuclear Accident Independent Investigation Commission}}
The '''Investigation Committee on the Accident at the Fukushima Nuclear Power Stations of Tokyo Electric Power Company''' was formed June 7, 2011 by the Japanese government as an independent body to investigate the March [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster]].<ref>Ito, Masami, [http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110608a1.html "Official probe begins into nuclear disaster"], ''[[Japan Times]]'', 8 June 2011, p. 1.</ref> The Investigation Committee issued an interim report in December 2011, and issued its final report in July 2012.
==Investigation ==
===The Committee=== The Investigation Committee on the Accident at the Fukushima Nuclear Power Stations (ICANPS) was tasked with: ''"conducting an investigation to determine the causes of the accident that occurred at Fukushima Daiichi and Daini Nuclear Power Stations of Tokyo Electric Power Company, and those of the damages generated by the accident, and thereby making policy proposals designed to prevent the expansion of the damages and the recurrence of similar accidents in the future"''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Official website of the Investigation Committee on the Accident at the Fukushima Nuclear Power Stations of Tokyo Electric Power Company |url=http://icanps.go.jp/eng/ |accessdate=29 July 2012 |quote=This committee was established with the aim of conducting an investigation to determine the causes of the accident that occurred at Fukushima Daiichi and Daini Nuclear Power Stations of Tokyo Electric Power Company, and those of the damages generated by the accident, and thereby making policy proposals designed to prevent the expansion of the damages and the recurrence of similar accidents in the future. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60axydhPx?url=http://icanps.go.jp/eng/ |archivedate=31 July 2011 |df= }}</ref> The 10 member,<ref name="AlJaz20120723">{{cite web|title=Japan nuclear plants 'still not safe'|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/asia-pacific/2012/07/20127236623434937.html|publisher=Al Jazeera Online|accessdate=29 July 2012|date=23 July 2012}}</ref> government-appointed panel included scholars, journalists, lawyers and engineers,<ref name="NTI20120723" /> was supported by public prosecutors and government experts<ref name="WSJ20120723">{{cite news|title=Japan Panel Says Plant Operator Falls Short on Nuclear Safety|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10000872396390444025204577544732979462706 |accessdate=30 July 2012|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|date=23 July 2012|author=Mitsuru Obe and Eleanor Warnock}}</ref> interviewed 772 people,<ref name="BBW20120723" /> including plant workers, government officials and evacuees,<ref name="Yamaguchi20120723" /> for a total of nearly 1,479 hearing hours<ref name="BBW20120723" /> - and released its final 448-page<ref name="BBW20120723">{{cite news|title=Fukushima Investigators Say More Study Needed on What Went Wrong|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2012-07-23/fukushima-investigators-say-more-study-needed-on-what-went-wrong|accessdate=29 July 2012|newspaper=Bloomsberg Businessweek|date=23 July 2012|author=Tsuyoshi Inajima and Yuji Okada}}</ref> investigation report on July 23, 2012.<ref name="CNN20120723">{{cite web|last=Hancocks|first=Paula|title=New report criticizes TEPCO over Fukushima nuclear crisis|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/07/23/world/asia/japan-fukushima-report/index.html|publisher=CNN|accessdate=29 July 2012|date=23 July 2012}}</ref><ref name="Asahi20120723">{{cite news|title=UPDATE: Government panel blasts lack of 'safety culture' in nuclear accident |url=http://ajw.asahi.com/article/0311disaster/fukushima/AJ201207230081 |accessdate=29 July 2012 |newspaper=The [[Asahi Shimbun]] |date=23 July 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140413220232/http://ajw.asahi.com/article/0311disaster/fukushima/AJ201207230081 |archivedate=13 April 2014 |df= }}</ref> Its report was the fourth investigation into the crisis after the earlier release of a parliamentary study, a private report by journalists and academics as well as an investigation by TEPCO.<ref name="ANN20120723">{{cite web|last=Willacy|first=Mark|title=New report says Japan ignored nuclear safety risks|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-07-23/an-fukushima-report/4148874|publisher=Australia Network News|accessdate=29 July 2012|date=23 July 2012}}</ref>
===Interim investigation report=== For [http://icanps.go.jp/eng/interim-report.html the interim report issued on December 26, 2011], the committee interviewed 456 people over a total of 900 hours of hearings by Dec. 16, 2011. The interim report was "a scathing assessment of the response to the Fukushima disaster", in which the investigative panel "blamed the central government and the Tokyo Electric Power Co., saying both seemed incapable of making decisions to stem radiation leaks as the situation at the coastal plant worsened in the days and weeks after the disaster".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/money_co/2011/12/a-new-study-released-today-said-that-theregulatory-fallout-from-the-fukushima-power-plantdisaster-in-japan-last-marchwill-pro.html |title=Report: U.S. nuclear renaissance unlikely after Fukushima |author= |date=December 28, 2011 |work=LA Times }}</ref> It attaches blame to Japan's central government as well as Tokyo Electric Power Co., "depicting a scene of harried officials incapable of making decisions to stem radiation leaks as the situation at the coastal plant worsened in the days and weeks following the disaster".<ref name=yotaro2011/> The 507-page interim report, said Japan's response to the crisis at Fukushima Daiichi was flawed by "poor communication and delays in releasing data on dangerous radiation leaks at the facility", and poor planning also worsened the disaster response, noting that authorities had "grossly underestimated tsunami risks" that followed the magnitude 9.0 earthquake. The 15m (40-foot) high tsunami that struck the plant was twice as tall as the highest wave predicted by officials, and the erroneous assumption that the plant's cooling system continued to work after the tsunami struck worsened the disaster. "Plant workers had no clear instructions on how to respond to such a disaster, causing miscommunication, especially when the disaster destroyed backup generators. Ultimately, the series of failures led to the worst nuclear catastrophe since Chernobyl".<ref name=yotaro2011>{{cite web |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/world_now/2011/12/japans-march-11-earthquake-and-tsunami-fukushima-daiichi-nuclear-power-plant-meltdown.html |title=Report: Japan, utility at fault for response to nuclear disaster |author= |date=December 26, 2011 |work=LA Times }}</ref>
The report concluded “It's inexcusable that a nuclear accident couldn't be managed because a major event such as the tsunami exceeded expectations.”<ref name=BW01>[http://news.businessweek.com/article.asp?documentKey=1376-LWSRLN1A1I4H01-73QTPPK5C1TSH942F3ITTFH13N "Fukushima Probe Puts Regulator, Cellphones on List of Failures"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120109051325/http://news.businessweek.com/article.asp?documentKey=1376-LWSRLN1A1I4H01-73QTPPK5C1TSH942F3ITTFH13N |date=2012-01-09 }}, ''[[Bloomberg Businessweek]]'', December 27, 2011. Retrieved 2011-12-26.</ref> An account said "[t]he report, which is highly critical of [[Tokyo Electric Power Company|Tepco]] as well as the authorities contrasts with the conclusions of a separate exercise by Tepco, which laid blame for the crisis squarely on the natural disaster."<ref>Nakamoto, Michiyo, [http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/a5711ed0-2fc4-11e1-8ad0-00144feabdc0.html?ftcamp=rss#axzz1hf5MZbKn "Report scathing of response to Fukushima nuclear crisis"], ''[[Financial Times]]'', December 26, 2011. Retrieved 2011-12-26.</ref> [[Nuclear and Industrial Safety Agency|NISA]], Japan's nuclear regulatory agency, received "some of [the] strongest criticism" in the report.<ref name=BW01/>
===Final investigation report===
The panel said the government and TEPCO failed to prevent the disaster not because a large tsunami was unanticipated, but because they were reluctant to invest time, effort and money in protecting against a natural disaster considered unlikely.<ref name="Yamaguchi20120723" /> "The utility and regulatory bodies were overly confident that events beyond the scope of their assumptions would not occur . . . and were not aware that measures to avoid the worst situation were actually full of holes," the government panel said in its final report.<ref>{{cite news|last=Wallace|first=Rick|title=Fukushima crushed by 'myth', says panel|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/fukushima-crushed-by-myth-says-panel/story-e6frg6so-1226433149824|accessdate=30 July 2012|newspaper=[[The Australian]]|date=24 July 2012}}</ref> TEPCO had even weighed in on a report about earthquake risk and asked the government to play down the likelihood of a tsunami in the region, the report said.<ref name="Yamaguchi20120723">{{cite web|title=Fukushima Nuclear Disaster Report: Plant Operators Tokyo Electric And Government Still Stumbling|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/07/23/fukushima-dai-ichi-nuclear-plant-operators_n_1694476.html|work=The Associated Press|publisher=The Huffington Post|accessdate=29 July 2012|author=Mari Yamaguchi|date=23 July 2012}}</ref> The panel's report faulted an inadequate legal system for nuclear crisis management, a crisis-command disarray caused by the government and Tepco, and possible excess meddling on the part of the prime minister's office in the early stage of the crisis.<ref name="JapanTimes20120724" /> The panel concluded that a culture of complacency about nuclear safety and poor crisis management led to the nuclear disaster.<ref name="AlJaz20120723" />
The report stated that measures taken by TEPCO and the Japanese nuclear regulator to prepare the Fukushima nuclear plant for earthquakes and tsunamies were "insufficient" and their response to the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster was "inadequate."<ref name="CNN20120723" /> "Preparedness for a large-scale complex disaster was insufficient; and they were unprepared for the release of a large amount of radioactive materials into the environment caused by a containment failure," noted the report with respect to TEPCO and the Japanese [[Nuclear and Industrial Safety Agency]].<ref name="NTI20120723">{{cite web|title=Japan, TEPCO ignored atomic accident risks due to 'myth of nuclear safety': Report|url=http://www.newstrackindia.com/newsdetails/2012/07/23/330-Japan-TEPCO-ignored-atomic-accident-risks-due-to-myth-of-nuclear-safety-Report.html|work=[[Asian News International]] (ANI)|publisher=News Track India|accessdate=29 July 2012|date=23 July 2012}}</ref> It noted for example that Fukushima staff was poorly trained to deal with the crisis after the plant's reactors went into meltdown.<ref name="NTI20120723" /><ref name="JapanTimes20120724" /><ref name="MainichiShimbun20120723" /> TEPCO did not adequately train employees "to think independently and to act, and lacked flexible and proactive thinking required for crisis response", the report said.<ref name=BangkokPost20120723 /> Tepco was criticized by the panel for failing to give most workers dosimeters that would have kept track of their exposure to harmful radiation as they fought to contain meltdowns in the early days of the crisis. While Tepco had access to hundreds of dosimeters sent from other nuclear power plants across Japan, managers of the company failed to put them to use — a sign that the company paid little heed to worker safety, the report said.<ref name="NYT20120723">{{cite news|title=Inquiry Sees Chaos in Evacuations After Japan Tsunami|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/24/world/asia/inquiry-sees-chaos-in-evacuations-after-japan-tsunami.html?_r=3|accessdate=30 July 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=23 July 2012|author=Hiroko Tabuchi}}</ref> Because of poor communication among Fukushima officials, the police and Japanese Self-Defense Forces personnel, the evacuation of Futaba hospital and its nearby health care facility for the elderly, located just 5 km from the damaged plant, was delayed.<ref name="JapanTimes20120724" /><ref name="NYT20120723" /> Residents living around the Fukushima plant may also have been able to keep exposure to minimum if the government had effectively used a computer system to predict the spread of radioactive materials, even though data on the damaged reactors were not available.<ref name="MainichiShimbun20120723" /><ref name="NYT20120723" />
Besides a failure of disaster management and risk analysis, TEPCO lacks “sufficient enthusiasm to fully investigate the Fukushima disaster and learn lessons to prevent recurrence even more than one year after the accident,” the report said.<ref name="BBW20120723" /> The investigators of the panel said TEPCO has to address problems within its own culture that contributed to its failings in the crisis, including employees “not fully trained to think for themselves.”<ref name="WP20120723" /> “We still don’t perceive much enthusiasm in the accident investigation from” the company, the report said. “TEPCO must take our findings sincerely and resolve the problems to achieve a higher level of safety culture across the company.”<ref name="WP20120723">{{cite web|title=Operator of Japan’s crippled nuke plant still mishandling disaster response, investigators say|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/govt-appointed-panel-criticizes-tepco-for-dragging-feet-in-probe-into-japan-nuclear-disaster/2012/07/23/gJQAzulW3W_story.html|work=The Associated Press|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=29 July 2012|date=23 July 2012}}</ref> The ICANPS report also said interference by then Japan prime minister Naoto Kan at the time of the disaster created confusion in the response to the crisis.<ref name="CNN20120723" /> "It must be said that more harm was done (than good) as his involvement ... could have confused the scene, potentially missing opportunities to make important judgments and creating opportunities for misjudgments," the report said.<ref name=BangkokPost20120723>{{cite news|title=Japan, TEPCO 'ignored' nuke risk|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/asia/303862/japan-tepco-ignored-nuclear-accident-risks-report|accessdate=29 July 2012|newspaper=The Bangkok Post|date=23 July 2012}}</ref> Kan's office was criticized by the ICANPS panel for controlling information, delaying crucial announcements to the public and overly softening expressions about the severity of the accident, causing confusion, threats to health and public distrust in the government.<ref name="Yamaguchi20120723" />
Japanese officials ignored the risks of an atomic accident because they believed in the 'myth of nuclear safety'.,<ref name="NTI20120723" /> i.e. the notion that severe accidents don't happen at nuclear power plants in Japan.<ref name="ANN20120723" /> "The fundamental problem lies in the fact that utilities, including Tokyo Electric Power (TEPCO), and the government failed to see the danger as reality," the report said. It also said that they were under the 'notion that severe accidents do not happen at nuclear plants in our country'.<ref name="NTI20120723" /> "Because the government and the power utilities, including Tepco, were biased by the safety myth, thinking they would never ever face such a serious accident, they were unable to realize that such a crisis could occur in reality. This appears to be the fundamental problem," the panel said in its final report.<ref name="JapanTimes20120724">{{cite news|title=Government, Tepco again hit for nuke crisis|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/text/nn20120724a1.html|accessdate=29 July 2012|newspaper=[[The Japan Times]]|date=24 July 2012|author=Kazuaki Nagata}}</ref> Tepco thus failed to prepare adequate tsunami defenses or crisis management procedures to deal with a station blackout, the panel's report said.<ref name="JapanTimes20120724" /> "The Fukushima crisis occurred because people didn't take the impact of natural disasters so seriously," University of Tokyo engineering professor Yotaro Hatamura, who chaired the commission, told a news conference. "Even though there were new findings (about the risk of a tsunami), Tepco couldn't see it because people are blind to what they don't want to see."<ref name="Reuters2012072">{{cite web|title=UPDATE 2-Japan Fukushima probe urges new disaster prevention steps, mindset|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2012/07/23/japan-nuclear-idINL4E8IN4NN20120723|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=29 July 2012|author=Risa Maeda|date=23 July 2012}}</ref>
Nuclear regulators did not pay sufficient attention to improvements in nuclear safety standards as recommended by the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]] (IAEA) and the Japanese Nuclear Industrial and Safety Agency had been promoting nuclear energy without being open about the inherent risks.<ref name="AlJaz20120723" /> According to the report, the Nuclear and Industrial Safety Agency strongly opposed a plan in 2006 to enhance preparedness against a nuclear disaster, fearing such a move would raise concerns about the safety of nuclear power among residents living near atomic plants.<ref name="MainichiShimbun20120723" /> The failure of the central and local governments to consider the possibility of a nuclear accident caused by multiple factors such as earthquakes and tsunami also caused a delay in responding to the accident. According to the report there was an insufficient crisis management structure for ensuring the safety of local communities.<ref name="Asahi20120723" /> The Japanese government failed to give a detailed announcement about what was happening and how it might affect people living nearby, while the Nuclear and Industrial Safety Agency was reluctant to inform the media that reactor 1's fuel rods possibly melted, although it knew that was quite likely.<ref name="JapanTimes20120724" />
The panel suggested that post-Fukushima safety steps taken at nuclear power plants across the country have not been enough to cope with a complex catastrophe. "We understand that immediate safety measures are being further detailed and will materialise in the future. But we strongly urge the people concerned to make continued efforts to take really effective steps," said the panel, chaired by University of Tokyo engineering professor Yotaro Hatamura.<ref name="AlJaz20120723" /> "Both the government and companies should establish a new philosophy of disaster prevention that requires safety and disaster measures against any massive accident and disaster... regardless of event probability," the report said.<ref name="AlJaz20120723" />
The report criticized TEPCO's argument that the nuclear accident was due to a tsunami of an unimaginable, unpredictable scale.<ref name="MainichiShimbun20120723">{{cite news|title=TEPCO mishandled nuclear crisis, 'overly confident' of safety: gov't panel|url=http://mainichi.jp/english/english/newsselect/news/20120723p2g00m0dm081000c.html|accessdate=30 July 2012|newspaper=The [[Mainichi Shimbun]]|date=23 July 2012}}</ref> It stated, "The reason the accident was beyond assumptions was because no attempt was made to make assumptions due to a safety myth that had no basis in fact." The ICANPS panel said that there was no proof that the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami|earthquake]] was a key factor in the disaster, but added that a certain degree of impact could not be ruled out.<ref name="AlJaz20120723" /> Many scientists and activists have disputed the Japanese government and TEPCO's findings that the plant's cooling systems were knocked out by giant waves that slammed into the plant, suggesting it was the initial earthquake that damaged the reactors.<ref name=BangkokPost20120723 /> TEPCO's own investigation put the blame for the accident solely on the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami|tsunami]].<ref name="AlJaz20120723" /> The panel, however, called on TEPCO to review data that had been presented to it, saying that it believed that it contained errors.<ref name="AlJaz20120723" /> It also said TEPCO covered up unfavourable data in a computer analysis attempting to measure the extent of damage inside the reactors.<ref name="Yamaguchi20120723" />
Commission chairman Yotaro Hatamura said that due to time restrictions, his panel was unable to address the concerns of residents, and the international community, who questioned whether the damaged reactors and the pool of used nuclear fuel at Fukushima's No.4 reactor could withstand another earthquake. "I now understand what people are worried the most about is the vulnerability of the No.4 spent fuel pool. I wish we had started an investigation on it much earlier," Hatamura said.<ref name="Reuters2012072" />
Based on the lessons learned from the accident, the panel proposed the government and utilities take safety steps regardless of the probability of tsunami and other events that could have a potentially strong impact, and review disaster reduction measures when important new findings are revealed.<ref name="MainichiShimbun20120723" /> The final report included seven recommendations for preventing a recurrence of the Fukushima nuclear accident, such as safety measures and ways to prevent the spreading of damage.<ref name="Asahi20120723" /> The panel didn't recommend charges against any of those involved in the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster,<ref>{{cite web|title=Final report criticises weak Fukushima response|url=http://www.radioaustralia.net.au/international/2012-07-23/final-report-criticises-weak-fukushima-response/985054|work=ABC/Agence France Presse|publisher=Radio Australia|accessdate=29 July 2012|date=23 July 2012}}</ref> but the panel called on the government to take immediate action on certain issues, such as ensuring off-site nuclear accident management centres are protected against the kind of massive radiation leaks that rendered the one at Fukushima unusable.<ref name="AlJaz20120723" /> It recommended that all nuclear operators in Japan conduct a comprehensive risk analysis of their facilities<ref name="CNN20120723" /><ref>{{cite web|title=Fukushima probe delivers damning verdict|url=http://www.euronews.com/2012/07/23/fukushima-probe-delivers-damning-verdict/|work=Euronews|publisher=Euronews|accessdate=29 July 2012|date=23 July 2012}}</ref> and urged the Japanese government and TEPCO to conduct further investigations to fully disclose the cause of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster,<ref>{{cite web|title=Japan panel blames Fukushima plant operator, nuclear regulators|url=http://www.kuna.net.kw/ArticleDetails.aspx?id=2254224&language=en|work=Kuwait News Agengcy|publisher=Kuwait News Agengcy|accessdate=29 July 2012|date=23 July 2012}}</ref> because there are many unresolved issues, such as the process by which radioactive materials leaked out of the Fukushima No. 1 plant.<ref name="Asahi20120723" /> “The government shouldn’t close its accident investigation into Fukushima with the end of probes by our committee and the [[w:National Diet of Japan Fukushima Nuclear Accident Independent Investigation Commission|parliamentary commission]],” Hatamura’s panel reported. “When radiation levels fall, detailed on-site examination inside reactor buildings, including examination of quake effects, must be carried out.”<ref name="BBW20120723" />
===Fukushima Nuclear Accident Independent Investigation Commission===
On July 5, 2012, the [[National Diet of Japan Fukushima Nuclear Accident Independent Investigation Commission]] released an executive summary report<ref>{{cite web|title=The Fukushima Nuclear Accident |url=http://naiic.go.jp/wp-content/uploads/2012/07/NAIIC_report_lo_res.pdf |publisher=Fukushima Nuclear Accident Independent Investigation Commission |accessdate=7/5/2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120710075620/http://naiic.go.jp/wp-content/uploads/2012/07/NAIIC_report_lo_res.pdf |archivedate=2012-07-10 |df= }}</ref> of The Fukushima Nuclear Accident. The report "blames Japanese culture for the fundamental causes of the disaster."<ref name="Wakatsuki">{{cite web|last=Wakatsuki|first=Yoko|title=Japanese parliament report: Fukushima nuclear crisis was 'man-made'|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/07/05/world/asia/japan-fukushima-report/index.html?hpt=hp_c1|publisher=CNN|accessdate=7/5/2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=TABUCHI|first=HIROKO|title=Commission Calls Fukushima Nuclear Crisis a Man-Made Disaster|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/06/world/asia/fukushima-nuclear-crisis-a-man-made-disaster-report-says.html?_r=1&pagewanted=all|accessdate=July 5, 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=7/5/2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Hiyama|first=Hiroshi|title=Japan’s Fukushima nuclear disaster ‘man-made,’ probe decides|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/japans-fukushima-nuclear-disaster-man-made-probe-decides/article4391288/|accessdate=7/5/2012|newspaper=The Globe and Mail|date=7/5/2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Inajima|first=Tsuyoshi|title=Fukushima Disaster Was Man-Made, Investigation Finds|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-07-05/fukushima-nuclear-disaster-was-man-made-investigation-rules.html|accessdate=07/5/2012|newspaper=Bloomberg News|date=07/5/2012}}</ref>
==Membership== *Yotaro Hatamura, '''Chairperson'''; Professor Emeritus of the [[University of Tokyo]], Professor of Kogakuin University *Kazuo Oike, Director, International Institute for Advanced Studies, Former President of Kyoto University *Shizuko Kakinuma, Team Leader, Research Center for Radiation Protection, National Institute of Radiological Science *[[Yukio Takasu]], Project Professor, Institute for Advanced Global Studies, The University of Tokyo, Former Permanent Representative, Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary of Japan to the International Organizations in Vienna, and the United Nations in New York *Toshio Takano, Attorney-at-Law, Former Superintending Prosecutor of Nagoya High Public Prosecutors Office *Yasuro Tanaka, Professor of Meiji Law School, Former Chief Justice of the Sapporo High Court *[[Yoko Hayashi]], Attorney-at-Law *Michio Furukawa, Mayor of [[Kawamata, Fukushima|Kawamata Town]], Fukushima Prefecture *[[Kunio Yanagida (Critic)|Kunio Yanagida]], Writer, Critic *Hitoshi Yoshioka, Vice-President of Kyushu University<ref name=IC01/>
===Technical advisors=== *Seiji Abe, Professor, Kansai University *Masao Fuchigami, Advisor, Komatsu Ltd., Ph.D. in Engineering<ref name=IC01>[http://icanps.go.jp/eng/2011/07/03/ListoftheCommitteeMenber.pdf "Member] [plural] of the Investigation Committee ...", committee webpage. Retrieved 2011-12-27.</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox news event | image_name = Fukushima I by Digital Globe.jpg | image_size = 260px | caption = Satellite image on 16 March 2011 of the four damaged reactor buildings | date={{start date|2011|03|11|df=y}} | place = [[Futaba, Fukushima|Futaba-machi]] and [[Ōkuma, Fukushima|Okuma-machi]], [[Futaba District, Fukushima|Futaba-gun]], [[Fukushima Prefecture]], [[Japan]] | outcome = [[International Nuclear Event Scale|INES]] Level 7 (ratings by Japanese authorities as of 11 April){{cite web|title=Fukushima accident upgraded to severity level 7|url=http://spectrum.ieee.org/tech-talk/energy/nuclear/fukushima-accident-upgraded-to-severity-level-7/ |work=[[IEEE Spectrum]]|date=12 April 2011| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140311005901/http://spectrum.ieee.org/tech-talk/energy/nuclear/fukushima-accident-upgraded-to-severity-level-7/ | archivedate = 2014-03-11| deadurl=no}} |reported injuries =37 with physical injuries,
2 workers taken to hospital with [[Ionizing radiation|radiation burns]] {{cite news|url=http://msa.hanford.gov/hills/lesson.cfm?id=2468|title=Radiation-exposed workers to be treated at Chiba hospital|accessdate=17 April 2011|agency=Kyodo News |date=25 March 2011| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130217162707/http://msa.hanford.gov/hills/lesson.cfm?id=2468 | archivedate = 2013-02-17| deadurl=yes}} }} '''Investigations into the [[Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Disaster]] (or Accident)''' {{nihongo|Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Accident|福島第一原子力発電所事故|[[Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station|Fukushima Dai-ichi]] ( {{Audio|Fukushima daiichi.ogg|pronunciation|lang=ja|help=no}} ) genshiryoku hatsudensho jiko}} began on 11 March 2011 when a series of [[Nuclear and radiation accidents#Equipment failure|equipment failures]], [[nuclear meltdown|core melt and down]], and [[Nuclear and radiation accidents#Radiation accidents|releases of radioactive materials]] occurred at the [[Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station]] from the [[Great East Japan Earthquake|2011 off the Pacific coast of Tohoku Earthquake and tsunami]] on the same day.{{cite web |title=Explainer: What went wrong in Japan's nuclear reactors |url=http://spectrum.ieee.org/tech-talk/energy/nuclear/explainer-what-went-wrong-in-japans-nuclear-reactors |work=IEEE Spectrum |date=4 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zujk3oQL?url=http://spectrum.ieee.org/tech-talk/energy/nuclear/explainer-what-went-wrong-in-japans-nuclear-reactors |archivedate=4 July 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }} It is the largest nuclear disaster since the [[Chernobyl disaster]] of 1986.
{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/news/article.cfm?c_id=2&objectid=10716671 |title=Japan's unfolding disaster 'bigger than Chernobyl' |work=[[New Zealand Herald]] |date=2 April 2011 }}
[http://in.ibtimes.com/articles/132391/20110409/japan-nuclear-crisis-radiation.htm "Analysis: A month on, Japan nuclear crisis still scarring"] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/5y2agYEQZ?url=http://in.ibtimes.com/articles/132391/20110409/japan-nuclear-crisis-radiation.htm |date=18 April 2011 }} ''International Business Times'' (Australia). 9 April 2011, retrieved 12 April 2011; excerpt, According to [[James M. Acton|James Acton]], Associate of the Nuclear Policy Program at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, "Fukushima is not the worst nuclear accident ever but it is the most complicated and the most dramatic...This was a crisis that played out in real time on TV. Chernobyl did not." {{cite web |url=http://in.ibtimes.com/articles/132391/20110409/japan-nuclear-crisis-radiation.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-04-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5y2agYEQZ?url=http://in.ibtimes.com/articles/132391/20110409/japan-nuclear-crisis-radiation.htm |archivedate=18 April 2011 |df=dmy-all }} == Introduction == In Japan, the [[Great East Japan Earthquake|2011 off the Pacific coast of Tohoku Earthquake]] occurred at 14:46 on 11 March 2011.This name of the earthquake is chosen by [[Japan Meteorological Agency|Japan Meteorological Agency(JMA)]]. By a cabinet decision, the Japanese government has approved the use of expression "Great East Japan Earthquake" in reference to the disaster, including the [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster]], caused by this earthquake. [[#ICANPS(2011)|ICANPS(2011)]] p.19 At the [[Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station]] (Fukushima Daiichi NPS),The power station has six [[boiling water reactor]]s (BWRs) originally designed by [[General Electric]] (GE) and [[Toshiba]]. operated by the [[Tokyo Electric Power Company]] (TEPCO), the earthquake and tsunami caused the compound accident (hereinafter called Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Accident) consisting of '''Station BlackOut''' (SBO) incident, Unit [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster (Unit 1 Reactor)|1]], [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster (Unit 2 Reactor)|2]], [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster (Unit 3 Reactor)|3]] severe core damage accidents, Unit 1, 2, 4 hydrogen explosion accidents, radioactive releases The Japanese government estimates the total amount of radioactivity released into the atmosphere was approximately one-tenth as much as was released during the Chernobyl disaster. : {{cite web |url=http://bos.sagepub.com/content/67/5/27.full |title=The radiological and psychological consequences of the Fukushima Daiichi accident |author=Frank N. von Hippel |date=September/October 2011 vol. 67 no. 5 |work=Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists |pages=27–36 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/643mZ4JGx?url=http://bos.sagepub.com/content/67/5/27.full |archivedate=20 December 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }} In May 2012, TEPCO reported that at least 900 [[Petabecquerel|PBq]] had been released "into the atmosphere in March last year [2011] alone" although it has been said staff may have been told to lie, and give false readings to try and cover up true levels of radiation. : {{cite web|url=http://english.kyodonews.jp/news/2012/05/159960.html|title=TEPCO puts radiation release early in Fukushima crisis at 900 PBq|work=[[Kyodo News]]|date=24 May 2012|accessdate=24 May 2012| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120524191342/http://english.kyodonews.jp/news/2012/05/159960.html | archivedate = 2012-05-24| deadurl=yes}} and so on. The accident was initially assessed by Japanese officials as Level 4 on the [[International Nuclear Event Scale]] (INES). Later, the level was raised to 5 and eventually to 7, the maximum scale value. :Justin McCurry. [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/apr/12/japan-nuclear-alert-level-seven Japan raises nuclear alert level to seven]. The Guardian. 12 April 2011 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130311011101/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/apr/12/japan-nuclear-alert-level-seven |date=11 March 2013 }} :[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1375981/Now-radiation-Japan-bad-Chernobyl-crisis-level-raised-seven-second-time-history.html 'Now radiation in Japan is as bad as radiation level is raised to 7 for only the second time in history'] ''Daily Mail'' 12 April 2011. In response to the early events of this accident, Japanese government declared a nuclear emergency situation and established the '''Nuclear Emergency Response Headquarters''' (NERHQ), which instructed the Fukushima Prefectural Governor and relevant local governments to issue an evacuation order to citizens from the nearby Fukushima Daiichi NPS.[[#ICANPS(2011)|ICANPS(2011)]] p.303 Significant amounts of radioactive material have also been released into ground and ocean waters. Measurements taken by the Japanese government 30–50 km from the plant showed [[caesium-137]] levels high enough to cause concern, leading the government to ban the sale of food grown in the area.[https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/19/us-japan-nuclear-food-idUSTRE72I1X120110319 Japan mulls Fukushima food ban: IAEA], Reuters, 19 March 2011 {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/5xJGKu1SX?url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/19/us-japan-nuclear-food-idUSTRE72I1X120110319 |date=19 March 2011 }} A few of the plant's workers were severely injured or killed by the disaster conditions resulting from the earthquake. There were no immediate deaths due to direct radiation exposures, but at least six workers have exceeded lifetime legal limits for radiation and more than 300 have received significant radiation doses. Predicted future cancer deaths due to accumulated radiation exposures in the population living near Fukushima have ranged from none{{cite news|agency=NPR|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/transcript/transcript.php?storyId=148227596|date=2012-03-09|accessdate=2012-04-15|title=Trauma, Not Radiation, Is Key Concern In Japan| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140309033042/http://www.npr.org/templates/transcript/transcript.php?storyId=148227596 | archivedate = 2014-03-09| deadurl=no}} to 100 to a non-peer-reviewed "guesstimate"{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/ombudsman/2012/03/15/148703963/the-cost-of-fear-the-framing-of-a-fukushima-report|date=2012-03-15|accessdate=2012-04-15|title=The Cost of Fear: The Framing of a Fukushima Report| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140505174012/http://www.npr.org/blogs/ombudsman/2012/03/15/148703963/the-cost-of-fear-the-framing-of-a-fukushima-report | archivedate = 2014-05-05| deadurl=no}} of 1,000. On 16 December 2011, Japanese authorities declared the plant to be stable, although it would take decades to decontaminate the surrounding areas and to decommission the plant altogether.{{cite news|title=Japan PM says Fukushima nuclear site finally stabilised|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-16212057|work=BBC Online|accessdate=7 January 2012|date=16 December 2011| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140220102647/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-16212057 | archivedate = 2014-02-20| deadurl=no}} === A process overview of the accident === At the Fukushima Daiichi NPS, all the off-site power supply was lost due to the earthquake. Later, the subsequent arrival of the tsunami caused flooding of many cooling seawater pumps, emergency diesel generators (EDGs), and power panels which were housed in low-lying rooms.Immediately after the earthquake, the remaining Units 1-3 [[shutdown (nuclear reactor)|shutdown]] automatically, and emergency generators came online to control electronics and coolant systems.
By the way, Units 1-3 were operating at the time of the accident; Units 4, 5 and 6 were in planned shutdown. [[#IAEA(2015)|IAEA(2015)]] p.1 This resulted in the total loss of AC power at Unit1 through 5. As [[nuclear reactor coolant]] systems stopped for a long time from cutting power, the [[Decay heat#Power reactors in shutdown|reactors overheated]] due to the normal high radioactive [[decay heat]] producedsmaller amounts of this heat normally continue to be released for years, but are not enough to cause fuel melting. in the first few days after nuclear reactor shutdown.F. Tanabe, Journal of Nuclear Science and Technology, 2011, volume 48, issue 8, pages 1135 to 1139 As the water boiled away in the reactors and the water levels in the [[Spent nuclear fuel|fuel]] rod pools dropped, the reactor fuel rods began to overheat severely, and to melt down. In the hours and days that followed, Reactors 1, 2 and 3 experienced full [[Nuclear meltdown|meltdown]].{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/asiapcf/06/06/japan.nuclear.meltdown/index.html?iref=NS1 |title=3 nuclear reactors melted down after quake, Japan confirms |work=CNN|date= 7 June 2011|accessdate=13 July 2011| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140414115531/http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/asiapcf/06/06/japan.nuclear.meltdown/index.html?iref=NS1 | archivedate = 2014-04-14| deadurl=no}}{{cite web|url=http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/national/T110607005367.htm |title='Melt-through' at Fukushima? / Govt report to IAEA suggests situation worse than meltdown |work=Yomiuri |date=8 June 2011 |accessdate=8 June 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zSkWxIIC?url=http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/national/T110607005367.htm |archivedate=15 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} In the intense heat and pressure of the melting reactors, a reaction between the nuclear fuel metal cladding and the remaining water surrounding them produced explosive hydrogen gas. As workers struggled to cool and shut down the reactors, several [[Hydrogen safety|hydrogen-air]] chemical explosions occurred.[http://www.hyer.eu/news/regional-news/hydrogen-in-nuclear-accidents-what-is-the-role-of-the-gas-in-fukushima Hydrogen explosions Fukushima nuclear plant: what happened?] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202235552/http://www.hyer.eu/news/regional-news/hydrogen-in-nuclear-accidents-what-is-the-role-of-the-gas-in-fukushima |date=2 December 2013 }} ==Investigation Groups== ; National Diet of Japan Fukushima Nuclear Accident Independent Investigation Commission The [[National Diet of Japan Fukushima Nuclear Accident Independent Investigation Commission]] (NAIIC) was established by the [[National Diet|National Diet of Japan]] as the first independent investigation commission on 8 December 2011.A profile description in the [http://warp.da.ndl.go.jp/info:ndljp/pid/3856371/naiic.go.jp/en/ NAIIC] top page. On 5 July 2012, NAIIC released an executive summary report[[#NAIIC_summary(2012)|NAIIC_summary(2012)]] of The Fukushima Nuclear Accident. The panel is due to deliver its final report at the end of July. ; Investigation Committee on the Accident at the Fukushima Nuclear Power Stations of Tokyo Electric Power Company The [[Investigation Committee on the Accident at the Fukushima Nuclear Power Stations of Tokyo Electric Power Company]] (ICANPS) was established by the Cabinet decision on 24 May 2011.[[#ICANPS_summary(2011)|ICANPS_summary(2011)]] p.1 On 2 December 2011, ICANPS issued an interim report.{{cite news |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/money_co/2011/12/a-new-study-released-today-said-that-theregulatory-fallout-from-the-fukushima-power-plantdisaster-in-japan-last-marchwill-pro.html |title=Report: U.S. nuclear renaissance unlikely after Fukushima |date=28 December 2011 |work=LA Times | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140124025906/http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/money_co/2011/12/a-new-study-released-today-said-that-theregulatory-fallout-from-the-fukushima-power-plantdisaster-in-japan-last-marchwill-pro.html | archivedate = 2014-01-24| deadurl=no}} On 23 July 2012, the government appointed the committee submitted its final report to the Japanese government. ; TEPCO Internal Investigation On 20 June 2012, TEPCO released its final internal investigation report. In the report, TEPCO complained that top politicians, including the prime minister, interfered with recovery efforts during the initial stages of the disaster by making specific requests that were out of touch with what was actually taking place at the plant. TEPCO concluded that the direct cause of the accident was the tsunami which knocked out the reactors' cooling system. TEPCO also admitted that it was at fault in not being prepared for the situation, but said that its workers did the best they could "amid unprecedented circumstances."Nagata, Kazuaki, "[http://www.japantimes.co.jp/text/nn20120621a3.html Tepco lashes prime minister's office]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 21 June 2012, p. 1 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121101132556/http://www.japantimes.co.jp/text/nn20120621a3.html |date=1 November 2012 }} [[Timeline of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster#Friday.2C 12 October 2012|Tepco admitted for the first time on October 12, 2012]] that it had failed to take stronger measures to prevent disasters for fear of inviting lawsuits or protests against its nuclear plants. {{cite web|last=Sheldrick|first=Aaron|title=Fukushima operator must learn from mistakes, new adviser says|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2012/10/13/japan-nuclear-adviser-fukushima-idINDEE89C03220121013?feedType=RSS&feedName=worldNews|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=13 October 2012|date=12 October 2012| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140309030940/http://in.reuters.com/article/2012/10/13/japan-nuclear-adviser-fukushima-idINDEE89C03220121013?feedType=RSS&feedName=worldNews | archivedate = 2014-03-09| deadurl=no}} ; Others As part of the government inquiry, the [[House of Representatives of Japan]]'s special science committee directed TEPCO to submit to them its manuals and procedures for dealing with reactor accidents. TEPCO responded by submitting manuals with most of the text blotted out. In response, the [[Nuclear and Industrial Safety Agency]] ordered TEPCO to resubmit the manuals by 28 September 2011 without hiding any of the content. TEPCO replied that it would comply with the order.[[Jiji Press]], "Tepco must submit reactor accident manuals without deleted portions", ''Japan Times'', 28 September 2011, p. 2. On 24 October [[Nuclear and Industrial Safety Agency|NISA]] published a large portion of Tokyo Electric Power Company's procedural manuals for nuclear accidents. These were the manuals that the operator of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant earlier did send to the Lower House with most of the contents blacked out, saying that this information should be kept secret to protect its intellectual property rights, and that disclosure would offer information to possible terrorists. NISA ordered TEPCO to send the manuals without any redaction, as the law orders. 200 pages were released from the accident procedural manuals used for Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant. All their contents were published, only the names of individuals were left out. From these documents could be concluded: * TEPCO did not make sufficient preparations to cope with critical nuclear accidents. * After the batteries and power supply boards were inundated on 11 March, almost all electricity sources were lost * TEPCO did not envision such a power failure or any kind of prolonged power loss. * TEPCO thought that in a serious incident, venting pressure in the reactor containment vessels or carrying out other safety procedures would still be possible, because emergency power sources would still be available. The agency said, the decision to publish the manuals was taken, for transparency in the search what caused the nuclear accident in Fukushima and also to establish better safety measures for the future.NHK-world (24 October 2011) [http://www3.nhk.or.jp/daily/english/24_33.html Parts of TEPCO's accident manuals made public]. {{webarchive |url=https://www.webcitation.org/5zgtSnLOL?url=http://www3.nhk.or.jp/daily/english/24_33.html |date=24 June 2011 }} On 24 October 2011 the first meeting was held by a group of 6 nuclear energy specialists invited by [[Nuclear and Industrial Safety Agency|NISA]] to discuss the lessons to be learned from the accidents in Fukushima. Their first remarks were: * Japanese nuclear power plants should have multiple power sources * plants should be able to maintain electricity during an earthquake or other emergencies * TEPCO should examine why the equipment failed to work and should take appropriate actions to prevent such failures in the future On 28 February 2012, the Independent Investigation Commission on the Fukushima Nuclear Accident by the Rebuild Japan Initiative Foundation announced an investigation report. [http://rebuildjpn.org/en/project/fukushima/ The Independent Investigation Commission on the Fukushima Nuclear Accident] [[Oregon]]'s [[United States Senator]] [[Ron Wyden]] toured the plant and issued a statement that the situation was "worse than reported." He sent a letter to Japanese Ambassador Ichiro Fujisaki urging Japan to seek international help to relocate spent fuel rods stored in unsound structures and prevent leakage of dangerous nuclear material.Phred Dvorak, [https://blogs.wsj.com/japanrealtime/2012/04/17/fukushima-daiichis-achilles-heel-unit-4s-spent-fuel/ Fukushima Daiichi’s Achilles Heel: Unit 4′s Spent Fuel?], [[Wall Street Journal]], 17 April 2012. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140312175237/https://blogs.wsj.com/japanrealtime/2012/04/17/fukushima-daiichis-achilles-heel-unit-4s-spent-fuel/ |date=12 March 2014 }}[http://www.wyden.senate.gov/news/press-releases/after-tour-of-fukushima-nuclear-power-station-wyden-says-situation-worse-than-reported After Tour of Fukushima Nuclear Power Station, Wyden Says Situation Worse than Reported], from Office of [[United States Senator]] [[Ron Wyden]], 16 April 2012. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140404194624/http://www.wyden.senate.gov/news/press-releases/after-tour-of-fukushima-nuclear-power-station-wyden-says-situation-worse-than-reported |date=4 April 2014 }} ==See also== * [[List of civilian nuclear accidents]] * [[Lists of nuclear disasters and radioactive incidents]] * [[Timeline of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster]] * [[Comparison of Fukushima and Chernobyl nuclear accidents]] ; Investigation Committees * [[National Diet of Japan Fukushima Nuclear Accident Independent Investigation Commission]] * [[Investigation Committee on the Accident at the Fukushima Nuclear Power Stations of Tokyo Electric Power Company]] ==Notes and references== {{reflist|refs= {{cite web|url=http://www.iaea.org/newscenter/news/2011/fukushima150311.html |title=Fukushima nuclear accident update log, updates of 15 March 2011 |work=IAEA |date=15 March 2011 |accessdate=8 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xoqS3dVJ?url=http://www.iaea.org/newscenter/news/2011/fukushima150311.html |archivedate=9 April 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }} {{cite web|url=http://www.iaea.org/newscenter/news/tsunamiupdate01.html |title=IAEA Update on Japan Earthquake |quote=As reported earlier, a 400 millisieverts (mSv) per hour radiation dose observed at Fukushima Daiichi occurred between 1s 3 and 4. [[File:Fukushima I by Digital Globe.jpg|thumb|Three of the reactors at [[Fukushima I nuclear accidents|Fukushima I]] overheated, causing [[nuclear meltdown|meltdowns]] that eventually led to explosions, which released large amounts of [[radioactive]] material into the air.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/02/world/asia/02japan.html?_r=1&ref=world |title=Report Finds Japan Underestimated Tsunami Danger |author=Martin Fackler |date=June 1, 2011 |work=New York Times }}</ref>]]
The {{nihongo|'''Atomic Energy Commission of Japan'''|原子力委員会|Genshiryokuiinkai}} was established in 1956 and serves as the regulatory body for [[nuclear power in Japan]]. The [[Atomic Energy Basic Law]] contained a provision for its creation, and shortly after the law was enacted, the organization started activities, which are stated to be: assure that research and use of [[nuclear power]] is conducted safely and with peaceful intentions, and construct plans for the use and development of nuclear power. It is now structured with 5 different committee members as commission of inquiry to the [[Cabinet Office (Japan)|Cabinet Office]].
The AEC is located in [[Kasumigaseki]], [[Chiyoda, Tokyo]].

{{main article|Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster}} [[Image:Towns evacuated around Fukushima on April 11th, 2011.png|thumb|Japan towns, villages, and cities around the Daiichi nuclear plant. The 20km and 30km areas had evacuation and sheltering orders, respectively. Later, more evacuation orders were given beyond 20km in areas northwest of the site. This affected portions of the administrative districts highlighted in yellow.]] [[Image:Fukushima accidents overview map.svg|thumb|right|Fukushima I and II Nuclear Accidents Overview Map showing evacuation and other zone progression and selected radiation levels]]
The Japanese reaction occurred after the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster, following the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]]. A nuclear emergency was declared by the [[government of Japan]] on 11 March. Later Prime Minister [[Naoto Kan]] issued instructions that people within a {{convert|20|km|mi|abbr=on}} zone around the [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant]] must leave, and urged that those living between 20 km and 30 km from the site to stay indoors.<ref name=BBC15>{{cite news|author=Richard Black |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-12740843 |title=BBC News – Japan quake: Radiation rises at Fukushima nuclear plant |publisher=BBC News |date= 15 March 2011|accessdate=15 March 2011}}</ref><ref name=Rian15>{{cite web|url=http://en.rian.ru/world/20110315/163008635.html |title=Japan's PM urges people to clear 20-km zone around Fukushima NPP (Update-1) | World | RIA Novosti |publisher=En.rian.ru |date= |accessdate=15 March 2011}}</ref> The latter groups were also urged to evacuate on 25 March.<ref name=evac/>
Japanese authorities admitted that lax standards and poor oversight contributed to the nuclear disaster.<ref name=reuters2011>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/08/15/nuclear-iaea-safety-idUSLDE77E0F720110815 |title=U.N. atom body wants wider nuclear safety checks |author= |date=August 15, 2011|work=Reuters }}</ref> The government came under fire for their handling of the emergency, including the slow release of data on areas which were likely to be exposed to the radioactive plume from the reactor, as well as the severity of the disaster.<ref name=reuters2011/><ref name=nytaug>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/09/world/asia/09japan.html?_r=1 |title=Japan Held Nuclear Data, Leaving Evacuees in Peril |author=Norimitsu Onishi |date=August 8, 2011 |work=The New York Times }}</ref><ref name=bellaug>{{cite web|url=http://www.bellona.org/articles/articles_2011/rad_forcasts_ignored |title=Japan ignored its own radiation forecasts in days following disaster, imperiling thousands |author=Charles Digges |date=10 August 2011 |work=Bellona |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120318044157/http://www.bellona.org/articles/articles_2011/rad_forcasts_ignored |archivedate=18 March 2012 |df= }}</ref> The accident is the second biggest [[nuclear accident]] after the [[Chernobyl disaster]], but is more complicated as three reactors suffered at least partial meltdowns.<ref>[http://in.ibtimes.com/articles/132391/20110409/japan-nuclear-crisis-radiation.htm "Analysis: A month on, Japan nuclear crisis still scarring,"] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/5y2agYEQZ?url=http://in.ibtimes.com/articles/132391/20110409/japan-nuclear-crisis-radiation.htm |date=2011-04-18 }} ''International Business Times'' (Australia). 9 April 2011, retrieved 12 April 2011; excerpt, According to [[James M. Acton|James Acton]], Associate of the Nuclear Policy Program at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, "Fukushima is not the worst nuclear accident ever but it is the most complicated and the most dramatic ... This was a crisis that played out in real time on TV. Chernobyl did not."</ref>
Once a proponent of building more reactors, Prime Minister Naoto Kan took an increasingly [[anti-nuclear]] stance in the months following the Fukushima disaster. In May, he ordered the aging [[Hamaoka Nuclear Power Plant]] be closed over earthquake and tsunami fears, and said he would freeze plans to build new reactors. In July 2011, Mr. Kan said that "Japan should reduce and eventually eliminate its dependence on nuclear energy ... saying that the Fukushima accident had demonstrated the dangers of the technology".<ref name="Hiroko Tabuchi">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/14/world/asia/14japan.html?_r=1&hp |title=Japan Premier Wants Shift Away From Nuclear Power |author=Hiroko Tabuchi |date=July 13, 2011 |work=The New York Times }}</ref> In August 2011, the Japanese Government passed a bill to subsidize electricity from [[renewable energy]] sources.<ref name="Chisaki Watanabe">{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-08-26/japan-passes-renewable-energy-bill-one-precondition-of-kan-s-resignation.html |title=Japan Spurs Solar, Wind Energy With Subsidies, in Shift From Nuclear Power |author=Chisaki Watanabe |date=August 26, 2011 |work=Bloomberg }}</ref> An energy white paper, approved by the Japanese Cabinet in October 2011, says "public confidence in safety of nuclear power was greatly damaged" by the Fukushima disaster, and calls for a reduction in the nation's reliance on nuclear power.<ref name="Tsuyoshi Inajima and Yuji Okada">{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-10-28/nuclear-promotion-dropped-in-japan-energy-policy-after-fukushima.html |title=Nuclear Promotion Dropped in Japan Energy Policy After Fukushima |author=Tsuyoshi Inajima and Yuji Okada |date=Oct 28, 2011 |work=Bloomberg }}</ref>
==Assessment and requests for help== Prime Minister Kan visited the plant for a briefing on 12 March.<ref name=Kyodo12>{{Cite news|title=Kan inspects quake-hit nuclear plant in Fukushima|url=http://english.kyodonews.jp/news/2011/03/77002.html|accessdate=12 March 2011|publisher=[[Kyodo News]]|date=12 March 2011}}</ref> He had been quoted in the press calling for calm and minimizing exaggerated reports of danger.<ref name=Guardian15>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/mar/15/japan-nuclear-plant-third-explosion |title=Japanese nuclear plant hit by fire and third explosion |work=The Guardian |date=15 March 2011 |location=London |first1=Jonathan |last1=Watts |first2=Tania |last2=Branigan |first3=Matthew |last3=Taylor}}</ref> Kan met with Tokyo Electric Power Company (TEPCO) on 15 March and lamented the lack of information. According to press accounts, he asked, "What the hell is going on?"<ref>{{cite web|last=Halloran |first=Liz |url=https://www.npr.org/2011/03/16/134573800/nuclear-information-gap-spreads-doubt-fear |title=Nuclear Information Gap Spreads Doubt, Fear |publisher=NPR |date= |accessdate=18 March 2011}}</ref> Secretary of Government [[Yukio Edano]] stated around 18 March, "We could have moved a little quicker in assessing the situation."<ref>{{cite news|last=Rayner |first=Gordon |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/japan/8391581/Japan-still-racing-against-the-clock-to-prevent-nuclear-meltdown-at-Fukushima.html|title=Japan still racing against the clock| publisher=Telegraph |accessdate=19 March 2011 |location=London |date=18 March 2011}}</ref>
The Japanese government asked the [[United States]] to provide cooling equipment to the plant. As of 15 March, the U.S. had provided {{convert|3265|kg|lb}} of "special equipment", a fire truck,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://joongangdaily.joins.com/article/view.asp?aid=2933656|title=Frantic cooling efforts continue |publisher=joongangdaily|year=2011 |accessdate=19 March 2011}}</ref> to help monitor and assess the situation at the plant.<ref>Takahara, Kanako, and Kazuaki Nagata, "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110315z1.html Meltdown looks more imminent]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 16 March 2011, p. 1.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5jUu8h_YHQHfszn_iv_OEGsv_PsKQ?docId=6254052 |title=The Canadian Press: Obama defends use of nuclear energy despite calamity in Japan |publisher=AP (Canada) |year=2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011}}</ref>
The French nuclear accident response organization [[Groupe INTRA]] shipped some of its radiation-hardened [[mobile robot]] equipment to Japan to help with the nuclear accident.<ref name=WNN-2011-03-21>{{cite web|url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/RS-Progress_in_stabilising_Fukushima_Daiichi-2103114.html|title=Work on Fukushima Daiichi power connections|date=21 March 2011|publisher=World Nuclear News}}</ref> At least 130 tonnes of equipment has been shipped to Japan.<ref name=WNN-2011-03-21/>
Japan requested that [[Russia]] send the [[Landysh]], a floating water decontamination facility originally built with Japanese funding and intended for [[nuclear decommissioning|decommissioning]] [[nuclear submarines]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Japan Seeks Russian Help On Nuclear Crisis |first= |last= |url=http://www.rferl.org/content/japan_nuclear/3546499.html |newspaper=Radio Free Europe |date=4 April 2011 |accessdate=8 April 2011}}</ref>
Former chiefs of key nuclear safety commissions and government agencies have apologized for overlooking important nuclear safety concerns.<ref name="Michael Alison Chandler">{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/in-japan-new-attention-for-longtime-anti-nuclear-activist/2011/04/05/AFMTG3GD_story.html |title=In Japan, new attention for longtime anti-nuclear activist |author=Michael Alison Chandler |date=April 10, 2011 |work=Washington Post }}</ref>
The Japanese government has admitted it failed to keep records of key meetings during the Fukushima nuclear crisis. Such detailed notes are considered a key component of disaster management.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-16754891 |title=Japan did not keep records of nuclear disaster meetings |author= |date=27 January 2012 |work=BBC News }}</ref>
==Evacuations== [[File:JapanDogEvac2011.jpg|thumb|right|U.S. military dependent-family dog is unloaded off an evacuation flight from Japan]]
After the declaration of a nuclear emergency by the Government at 19:03 on 11 March, the Fukushima prefecture ordered the evacuation of an estimated 1,864 people within a distance of 20 km from the plant. This was extended to {{convert|30|km}} and 5,800 people at 21:23 by a directive to the local governor from the Prime Minister, together with instructions for residents within {{convert|10|km}} of the plant to stay indoors.<ref name=nisa313>{{cite web|url=http://www.nisa.meti.go.jp/english/files/en20110313-3.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-04-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6E0qt3Eii?url=http://www.nisa.meti.go.jp/english/files/en20110313-3.pdf |archivedate=2013-01-28 |df= }} Seismic Damage Information (19th press communicate released by [[Nuclear and Industrial Safety Agency|NISA]] on 08:30 13 March 2011).</ref><ref name="bwokada">{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-03-11/japan-orders-evacuation-from-near-nuclear-plant-after-quake.html |title=Japan Orders Evacuation From Near Nuclear Plant After Quake |author=Inajima, Tsuyoshi |author2=Okada, Yuji |work=Bloomberg BusinessWeek |date=11 March 2011 |accessdate=11 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120202204525/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-03-11/japan-orders-evacuation-from-near-nuclear-plant-after-quake.html |archivedate= 2 February 2012 |df= }}</ref> The evacuation was expanded to a {{convert|10|km}} radius at 5:44 on 12 March, and then to {{convert|20|km}} at 18:25, shortly before ordering use of [[seawater]] for emergency cooling.<ref name=nisa313/><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://ca.news.yahoo.com/blast-destroys-part-japan-nuclear-plant-20110312-024412-523.html |title=Blast destroys part of Japan nuclear plant |publisher=CBC.ca |date=12 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718134246/http://ca.news.yahoo.com/blast-destroys-part-japan-nuclear-plant-20110312-024412-523.html |archivedate=18 July 2011 |df= }}</ref>
''[[The Guardian]]'' reported at 17:35 JST on 12 March that NHK advised residents of the Fukushima area "to stay inside, close doors and windows and turn off air conditioning. They were also advised to cover their mouths with masks, towels or handkerchiefs" as well as not to drink tap water.<ref>{{cite news|last=Glendinning |first=Lee |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/blog/2011/mar/12/japan-tsunami-earthquake-live-coverage |title=Japan tsunami and earthquake – live coverage | World news | guardian.co.uk |work=Guardian |location=UK |date=12 March 2011|accessdate=12 March 2011}}</ref> Air traffic has been restricted in a {{convert|20|km|adj=on}} radius around the plant, according to a [[NOTAM]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ourairports.com/airports/RJSS/pilot-info.html |title=Pilot information for Sendai Airport |date=12 March 2011 |accessdate=12 March 2011}}</ref> The BBC has reported as of 22:49 JST (13:49 GMT) "A team from the National Institute of Radiological Sciences has been dispatched to Fukushima as a precaution, reports NHK. It was reportedly made up of doctors, nurses and other individuals with expertise in dealing with radiation exposure, and had been taken by helicopter to a base 5 km from the nuclear plant."<ref>{{Cite news|title=Radioactive emergency team dispatched |url=http://www3.nhk.or.jp/daily/english/12_40.html |accessdate=13 March 2011 |newspaper=[[NHK World]] |date=12 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110628184852/http://www3.nhk.or.jp/daily/english/12_40.html |archivedate=28 June 2011 |df= }}</ref>
Over 50,000 people were evacuated during 12 March.<ref>{{cite web|author=Joe Weisenthal |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/fukushima-nuclear-plant-2011-3 |title=Fukushima Nuclear Plant |publisher=Businessinsider.com |date=4 March 2011 |accessdate=12 March 2011}}</ref> The figure increased to 170,000–200,000 people on 13 March, after officials voiced the possibility of a meltdown.<ref name=autogenerated4>{{cite web|agency=The Associated Press|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5h27to-uk4j6utkt4KKWlUQJX6AHA?docId=6230208 |title=IAEA says 170,000 people evacuated from area near damaged Japan nuclear plant |publisher=The Canadian Press|date=12 March 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110325012712/https://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5h27to-uk4j6utkt4KKWlUQJX6AHA?docId=6230208|archivedate=25 March 2011|deadurl=y|accessdate=9 January 2018}}</ref><ref name="wp-partial">{{Cite news |title=Japanese nuclear plants' operator scrambles to avert meltdowns |first=Steven |last=Mufson |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/03/12/AR2011031205493.html |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=13 March 2011 |accessdate=13 March 2011}}</ref><ref>https://news.yahoo.com/iaea-170-000-evacuated-near-japan-nuclear-plant-20110312-133929-901.html</ref>
On the morning of 15 March, the evacuation area was again extended. Prime Minister Naoto Kan issued instructions that any remaining people within a {{convert|20|km|mi|abbr=on}} zone around the plant must leave, and urged that those living between 20 km and 30 km from the site should stay indoors.<ref name="BBC15"/><ref name="Rian15"/> A 30 km [[no-fly zone]] has been introduced around the plant.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}}
[[File:RCEvacFlight.JPG|thumb|left|Evacuation flight departs Misawa]]
On 16 March, the [[Embassy of the United States in Tokyo|U.S. Embassy]] advised Americans in Japan to leave areas within "approximately 50 miles" ({{convert|50|mi|km|disp=output only}}) from the plant. Gregory Jaczko, the chairman of the [[United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission]], said before the [[United States Congress]], believing the Japanese government was not telling the full story, "We would recommend an evacuation to a much larger radius than has currently been provided by Japan."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.newsobserver.com/2011/03/17/1059140/japan-races-to-get-power-to-reactors.html |title=U.S.: Reactor may spew radiation |last1=Sanger |first1=David E. |last2=Wald |first2=Matthew L. |last3=Tabuchi |first3=Hiroko |work=The New York Times |date=17 March 2011 |accessdate=17 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110318085209/http://www.newsobserver.com/2011/03/17/1059140/japan-races-to-get-power-to-reactors.html |archivedate=18 March 2011 |df= }}</ref> Spain advised to leave an area of 120 km, Germany advised to leave even the metropolitan area of Tokyo, and [[South Korea]] advised to leave farther than 80 km and plans to evacuate by all possible means.<ref name="inquirer1">[http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/inquirerheadlines/nation/view/20110318-326099/Foreigners-stream-out-of-Tokyo Foreigners stream out of Tokyo] Inquirer Headlines</ref><ref name="koreaherald1">[http://www.koreaherald.com/national/Detail.jsp?newsMLId=20110318000919 Seoul ready to send planes, ships to evacuate its citizens from Japan] Korea Herald</ref> Travel to Japan was very low, but additional flights were chartered to evacuate foreigners. Official evacuation of Japan was started by several nations.<ref name="comparecarhire1">[http://www.comparecarhire.co.uk/news/us-evacuates-nationals-from-japan-53825979.html US evacuates nationals from Japan] Travel News</ref> The US military expected to voluntarily evacuate over 7000 family dependents from Japan,<ref>{{cite web|last=Mass |first=Chief |url=http://www.navy.mil/search/display.asp?story_id=59220 |title=Military Families Arrive in Seattle from Japan |publisher=Navy.mil |date= |accessdate=2011-03-26}}</ref> and moved ships under repair away from Japanese ports.<ref>{{cite news|author=David Martin |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/03/21/eveningnews/main20045637.shtml |title=Pentagon weighs pullout from Japan hot zone – CBS Evening News |publisher=CBS News |date=2011-03-21 |accessdate=2011-03-26}}</ref>
Of 90 bedridden patients moved from a hospital in the town of Futaba-machi, a sample of three patients were tested and shown to have been exposed to radiation. The patients had been waiting outdoors for rescuers before being moved by helicopter at the time an explosion happened.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.news.com.au/world/missing-in-japanese-town/story-fn6sb9br-1226020512318 |title=10,000 missing in Japanese town | News.com.au |first= |last= |work=news.com.au |quote= |accessdate=15 March 2011 |date=13 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4041147,00.html |title=Japan: At least 3 exposed to radiation in nuclear station explosion – Israel News, Ynetnews |first= |last=|work=ynetnews.com |year=2011|quote=The three residents were among a group of some 90 patients hospitalized in the town of Futaba-machi, and were chosen at random by doctors for tests linked to the nuclear incident, the public broadcaster NHK reported. (AFP) |accessdate=15 March 2011}}</ref> On 25 March, residents in the 30 kilometer circle were urged to leave their houses as well.<ref name=evac>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fgw-japan-nuclear-plant-20110326,0,5763742.story|title=Japan steps up nuclear plant precautions; Kan apologizes|date=25 March 2011|work=L.A. Times|first=Julie|last=Makinen}}</ref>
On 30 March the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]] (IAEA) discovered 20 [[becquerel|MBq]]/m<sup>2</sup> of Iodine-131 samples taken from 18 to 26 March in [[Iitate, Fukushima]], 40 km northwest of the Fukushima I reactor. The IAEA recommended expanding the evacuation area, based on its criteria of 10 MBq/m<sup>2</sup>. Japanese Secretary [[Yukio Edano]] stated the government would wait to see if the high radiation continued.<ref>Takahara, Kanako, and Kazuaki Nagata, "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110401a1.html High radiation found outside no-go zone]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 1 April 2011, p. 1.</ref> On 31 March the IAEA announced a new value of 7 MBq/m<sup>2</sup>, in samples taken from 19 to 29 March in Iitate.<ref>http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110402x3.html</ref> The material decays at 8% to 9% each day.
On 11 April, with ongoing concerns about the stability of the reactors, Japan considered extending the evacuation zone around the Fukushima I.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/04/11/us-japan-idUSTRE72A0SS20110411?feedType=RSS&feedName=topNews |title=Japan set to extend nuclear evacuation zone |author=Shinichi Saoshiro and Chisa Fujioka |date=April 10, 2011 |work=Reuters }}</ref> Then, on 21 April 2011, the Japanese government declared a 20-km zone around Daiichi as a "no-go" zone, and threatened anyone who entered or remained in the zone with arrest or detention and fines. The order affected 80,000 residents.<ref>[[Associated Press]], "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110422a1.html No-go zone trespassers face fines, arrest]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 22 April 2011, p. 1.</ref><ref>http://www.cbsnews.com/news/a-rare-look-at-the-fukushima-daiichi-no-go-zone/</ref> Shortly thereafter, on 22 April, the Japanese government officially announced that the evacuation zone would be extended from the 20 km "circular" zone to an irregular zone extending northwest of the Fukushima site.<ref>[http://www3.nhk.or.jp/daily/english/22_20.html Evacuation area officially expanded] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110511120445/http://www3.nhk.or.jp/daily/english/22_20.html |date=2011-05-11 }}</ref> Then, on 16 May, the Japanese government began evacuating people from outside the official exclusion zones, including the village of Iitate, where high levels of radiation had been repeatedly measured.<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2011/05/16/3217488.htm?section=world Japan evacuates villages outside nuclear zone]</ref><ref>[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110513f1.html Fukushima village on way to becoming ghost town]</ref>
Evacuees from the radiation zone have reported that some evacuation shelters, including ones run by the city of [[Tsukuba, Ibaraki]], have refused to allow them entrance to their facilities, claiming that the evacuees could be carrying radioactive contamination with them. The shelters have required the evacuees to present certificates obtained by the government of Fukushima prefecture stating that the evacuees are "radiation free".<ref>[[Agence France-Presse]]/[[Jiji Press]], "Atomic evacuees getting cold shoulder at shelters", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 16 April 2011, p. 2.</ref><ref>[[Jiji Press]], "Tsukuba asked evacuees for radiation papers", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 20 April 2011, p. 2.</ref>
As of September 2011, more than 100,000 Fukushima Prefecture residents are still subject to a range of evacuation measures, forcing them to live outside their home cities and towns. Some locations near the crippled nuclear power plant are estimated to be contaminated with accumulated radiation doses of more than 500 millisieverts a year, diminishing residents' hopes of returning home anytime soon. Even areas away from the nuclear plant are still suffering from a sharp decline in tourism and sluggish financial conditions.<ref name="mdn.mainichi.jp">{{cite web|url=http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20110909p2a00m0na014000c.html |title=Over 100,000 Fukushima Prefecture residents can't return to hometowns |author= |date=September 9, 2011 |work=Mainichi Daily |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110910225829/http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20110909p2a00m0na014000c.html |archivedate=September 10, 2011 |df= }}</ref>
As of 23 February 2012, 62,674 Fukushima residents had evacuated from the prefecture.<ref>Aoki, Mizuho, "[http://www.japantimes.co.jp/text/nn20120307x1.html Tohoku fears nuke crisis evacuees gone for good]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 8 March 2012, p. 1.</ref>
In 2012, ex-prime minister [[Naoto Kan]] was interviewed about the Fukushima nuclear disaster, and has said that at one point Japan faced a situation where there was a chance that people might not be able to live in the capital zone including Tokyo and would have to evacuate. He says he is haunted by the specter of an even bigger nuclear crisis forcing tens of millions of people to flee Tokyo and threatening the nation's existence. "If things had reached that level, not only would the public have had to face hardships but Japan's very existence would have been in peril".<ref name=k12/> That convinced Kan to "declare the need for Japan to end its reliance on atomic power and promote renewable sources of energy such as solar that have long taken a back seat in the resource-poor country's energy mix".<ref name=k12>{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/02/17/us-japan-kan-idUSTRE81G08P20120217 |title=Nuclear crisis turns Japan ex-PM Kan into energy apostle |author=Linda Sieg and Yoko Kubota |date=Feb 17, 2012 |work=Reuters }}</ref> Government Officials revealed in interviews that they were grappling the possibility of a "demonic chain reaction": If Fukushima collapsed and released enough radiation, it was "possible that other nearby nuclear power plants would have to be abandoned and could also collapse, thereby necessitating the evacuation of one of the world’s largest cities".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://globalspin.blogs.time.com/2012/02/29/panel-government-told-people-to-keep-calm-while-mulling-tokyo-evacuation/#ixzz1ntRd4YIz |title=Fukushima Report: Japan Urged Calm While It Mulled Tokyo Evacuation |author=Krista Mahr |date=February 29, 2012 |work=TIME }}</ref>
===Evacuation drills=== In Japan, during each fiscal year, a prefecture that has nuclear power stations in its territory is legally bound to hold nuclear accident disaster drills, demonstrating how to evacuate the population out of the 10-kilometer evacuation zone according to the governmental anti-disaster guidelines. The Fukishima Daiichi accidents proved this 10-kilometer zone to be an underestimation of the evacuation zones that would actually be needed to protect the population of the prefecture from escaping radiation in a proper way. On 5 September 2011, three prefectures—Aomori, Fukushima and Ibaraki—were unable to hold the drills before March 2012. Six prefectures, including Hokkaido and Fukui, had not taken a decision to hold a drill and were awaiting new governmental guidelines on how far to evacuate. Four other prefectures, including Ehime and Saga, planned to hold drills by establishing temporary guidelines and by expanding evacuation zones on their own. The Nuclear Safety Commission aimed to review the evacuation zones and other policies by the end of October.<ref>''JAIF'' (5 September 2011) [http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1315192330P.pdf 70% of prefectures baffled on nuclear drill] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120419005409/http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1315192330P.pdf |date=2012-04-19 }}</ref>
===Revising the nuclear disaster response: widening evacuation zones=== On 20 October 2011, the Nuclear Safety Commission of Japan published its views on the evacuation zones around nuclear plants in case of accidents. Instead of the 10-kilometer evacuation-zone previously thought to be sufficient to protect inhabitants, a circle of 30 kilometer was proposed as Urgent Protective Action Planning Zones, or UPZ. This definition was in line with the emergency response requirements proposed by the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]]. This draft plan included the designation of areas within 5 kilometers of plants as precautionary action zones, where residents would immediately evacuate in the event of an accident. Residents within a radius of about 50 kilometers would be prepared to take immediately action to prevent internal exposure to their thyroid glands by taking iodine tablets. Further studies were planned with experts and municipalities. Implementation of this plan would mean a major review of all anti-nuclear disaster programs by local governments, and it would increase the number of municipalities involved up to around 130, about three times more than the present figure.<ref>NHK-world (20 October 2011 ) [http://www3.nhk.or.jp/daily/english/20_25.html Nuke committee drafts disaster-response revisions ] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111020184052/http://www3.nhk.or.jp/daily/english/20_25.html |date=2011-10-20 }}</ref><ref>JAIF (20 October 2011)[http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1319168910P.pdf Earthquake-report 241: Nuke committee drafts disaster-response revisions ] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130517084407/http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1319168910P.pdf |date=2013-05-17 }}</ref>
===Long-term effects=== Experts on the ground in Japan agree that mental health challenges are the most significant issue.<ref>Sugimoto, T., Umeda, M., Shinozaki, T., Naruse, T. and Miyamoto, Y. (2015), Sources of perceived social support associated with reduced psychological distress at 1 year after the Great East Japan Earthquake: Nationwide cross-sectional survey in 2012. Psychiatry Clin Neurosci, 69: 580–586. doi:10.1111/pcn.12235</ref> Stress, such as that caused by relocation and uncertainty and concern about unseen toxicants, often manifests in physical ailments, such as heart disease. So even if radiation risks are low, people are still concerned and worried.<ref>Sugimoto T, Shinozaki T, Naruse T, Miyamoto Y (2014) Who Was Concerned about Radiation, Food Safety, and Natural Disasters after the Great East Japan Earthquake and Fukushima Catastrophe? A Nationwide Cross-Sectional Survey in 2012.
