[[File:NIT Combined Flights Ground Measurements 30Mar 03Apr2011 results.jpg|thumb|Readings from aerial survey conducted by United States federal agencies after the Fukushima accident]] Three days after the earthquake, the [[U.S. Department of Energy]] in cooperation with the NNSA sent 33 people and 8.6 tons of equipment to Japan to assist efforts to monitor radiation, including consequence management response teams and a NNSA aerial system that took thousands of radiation readings over the next two weeks.{{cite news|title=DOE to Continue Radiation Monitoring and Other Assistance in Japan|url=http://nuclearstreet.com/nuclear_power_industry_news/b/nuclear_power_news/archive/2011/03/29/doe-to--continue-radiation-monitoring-and-other-assistance-in-japan032903.aspx|accessdate=11 April 2011|newspaper=Nuclear Street|date=29 March 2011}} ===Cleanup=== International experts have said that a workforce in the hundreds or even thousands would take years or decades to clean up the area. John Price, a former member of the Safety Policy Unit at the UK's National Nuclear Corporation, has said that it "might be 100 years before melting fuel rods can be safely removed from Japan's Fukushima nuclear plant".{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2011/04/01/3179487.htm |title=Crews 'facing 100-year battle' at Fukushima |author=David Mark, Mark Willacy |date=1 April 2011 |work=ABC News }} Edward Morse, a professor of nuclear engineering at the [[University of California, Berkeley]], has said:
...there would be at least six months of emergency stabilisation, about two years of temporary remediation and up to 30 years of full-scale clean-up. Furthermore, the high levels of ground contamination at the site are raising concerns about the viability of individuals to work at the site in coming decades.{{cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/environment/containing-a-calamity-creates-another-nuclear-nightmare-20110408-1d7qn.html |title=Containing a calamity creates another nuclear nightmare |author=Julie Makinen, Ralph Vartabedian |date=9 April 2011 |work=Sydney Morning Herald }}
===Other reactions=== The [[Hong Kong Government]] issued a ''black outbound travel alert'' for [[Fukushima prefecture]] on 12 March urging to avoid all travel. The alert came in addition to the ''red outbound travel alert'' for the rest of Japan.{{cite web|url=http://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/201103/12/P201103120213.htm|date=12 March 2011|title=Hong Kong issues Black Travel Alert for Japan (Fukushima Prefecture)|accessdate=18 March 2011}} On 19 March 2011, Indonesia began screening passengers and luggage on direct flights from Japan for radiation. No radiation has been detected.{{cite web|author= |url=http://news.asiaone.com/News/Latest%2BNews/Asia/Story/A1Story20110319-268964.html |title=Indonesia screens Japan travellers for radiation |publisher=News.asiaone.com |date=2011-03-19 |accessdate=2016-11-15}} On 16 March, Swedish citizens were advised to avoid staying within 80 km of the Fukushima nuclear power plants, and all travel to Japan was advised against. On 29 March the travel advice eased to only apply to non-necessary travel. The South Korea Korea Atomic Energy Research Institute operates 59 radiation monitoring centers across the nation of South Korea. After the Fukushima disaster begun, radiation monitoring activities increased across the country but radiation levels remained normal.{{cite news|title=S. Korea steps up radiation monitoring|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2011/04/08/S-Korea-steps-up-radiation-monitoring/UPI-67601302294190/|accessdate=11 April 2011|newspaper=United Press International|date=8 April 2011}} ==Protests and politics by country== ===Taiwan=== In March 2011, around 2,000 anti-nuclear protesters demonstrated in Taiwan for an immediate halt to the construction of the island's fourth nuclear power plant. The protesters were also opposed to plans to extend the lifespan of three existing nuclear plants.{{cite news |url=http://www.asiaone.com/News/Latest+News/Asia/Story/A1Story20110320-269104.html |title=Over 2,000 rally against nuclear plants in Taiwan |date=20 March 2011 |agency=AFP }} Amid Japan's ongoing nuclear crisis, nuclear energy is emerging as a contentious issue for [[Republic of China presidential election, 2012|next year's presidential election]] in Taiwan, as opposition leader [[Tsai Ing-wen]] declared her intention to abandon nuclear power by 2025 if elected. Taiwan is on the West Pacific Rim earthquake zone, like Japan.{{cite web |url=http://www.atimes.com/atimes/China/MC29Ad02.html |title=Cold comfort for anti-nuclear Taiwanese |author=Jou Ying-cheng |date=29 March 2011 |work=Asia Times }} George Hsu, a professor of applied economics at National Chung Hsing University in central Taiwan, said nuclear power plants in quake-prone areas need to be redesigned to make them more resistant, an investment that would reduce their original cost advantage.{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-04-12/taiwan-halts-plans-to-build-atomic-reactors-after-japan-crisis.html |title=Quake-Prone Taiwan Halts Nuclear Expansion as Japan Struggles at Fukushima |author=Yu-huay Sun |date=13 April 2011 |work=Bloomberg }} In May 2011, 5,000 people joined an anti-nuclear protest in [[Taipei City]], which was characterized by a carnival-like atmosphere, with protesters holding yellow banners and clutching sunflowers. This was part of a nationwide "No Nuke Action" protest, urging the government to stop construction of a Fourth Nuclear Plant and pursue a more [[sustainable energy]] policy.{{cite web |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/front/archives/2011/05/01/2003502115 |title=Anti-nuclear rally draws legions |author=Lee I-Chia |date=1 May 2011 |work=The Taipei Times }} On the eve of [[World Environment Day]] in June 2011, environmental groups demonstrated against Taiwan's nuclear power policy. The Taiwan Environmental Protection Union, together with 13 environmental groups and legislators, gathered in Taipei with banners that read: "I love Taiwan, not nuclear disasters". They protested against the nation's three operating nuclear power plants and the construction of a fourth plant. They also called for "all nuclear power plants to be thoroughly re-evaluated and shut down immediately if they fail to pass safety inspections". According to Wang To-far, economics professor at [[National Taipei University]], "if a level-seven nuclear crisis were to happen in Taiwan, it would destroy the nation".{{cite web |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2011/06/05/2003505021 |title=Conservationists protest against nuclear policies |author=Lee I-Chia |date=5 June 2011 |work=Tapai Times }} ===United States=== What had been growing acceptance of nuclear power in the United States was eroded sharply following the [[2011 Japanese nuclear accidents]], with public support for building nuclear power plants in the U.S. dropping slightly lower than it was immediately after the [[Three Mile Island accident]] in 1979, according to a CBS News poll. Only 43 percent of those polled after the Fukushima nuclear emergency said they would approve building new power plants in the United States.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/23/us/23poll.html?_r=1 |title=Nuclear Power Loses Support in New Poll |author=Michael Cooper |date=22 March 2011 |work=The New York Times }} Activists who were involved in the U.S. anti-nuclear movement's emergence (such as [[Graham Nash]] and [[Paul Gunter]]), suggest that Japan's nuclear crisis may rekindle an interest in the movement in the United States. The aim, they say, is "not just to block the Obama administration's push for new nuclear construction, but to convince Americans that existing plants pose dangers".{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/19/science/earth/19antinuke.html?_r=1 |title=Japan Crisis Could Rekindle U.S. Antinuclear Movement |author=Leslie Kaufman |date=18 March 2011 |work=New York Times }} In March 2011, 600 people gathered for a weekend protest outside the [[Vermont Yankee]] nuclear plant. The demonstration was held to show support for the thousands of Japanese people who are endangered by possible radiation from the [[Fukushima I nuclear accidents]].{{cite web |url=http://www.wcax.com/Global/story.asp?S=14288307 |title=Vermont Yankee: Countdown to closure |date=21 March 2011 |work=WCAX }} The New England region has a long history of [[anti-nuclear]] activism and 75 people held a State House rally on 6 April 2011, to "protest the region's aging nuclear plants and the increasing stockpile of radioactive spent fuel rods at them". The protest was held shortly before a State House hearing where legislators were scheduled to hear representatives of the region's three nuclear plants – Pilgrim in Plymouth, Vermont Yankee in Vernon, and Seabrook in New Hampshire—talk about the safety of their reactors in the light of the Japanese nuclear crisis. Vermont Yankee and Pilgrim have designs similar to the crippled Japanese nuclear plant.{{cite news |url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/breaking_news/2011/04/anti-nuclear_se.html |title=Anti-nuclear sentiment regains its voice at State House rally|author=Martin Finucane |date=6 April 2011 |work=Boston Globe }} The nuclear disaster in Japan is likely to have major effects on US energy policy, according to billionaire investor [[Warren Buffett]]. Buffet said that the "United States was poised to move ahead with nuclear plans here, but the events in Japan derailed that".{{cite web |url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/42178651/Japan_Disaster_To_Delay_US_Nuclear_Energy_Plans_Buffett |title=Japan Disaster To Delay US Nuclear Energy Plans: Buffett |author=Becky Quick |date=20 March 2011 |work=CNBC }} In April 2011, Rochelle Becker, executive director of the Alliance for Nuclear Responsibility said that the United States should review its nuclear accident liability limits, in the light of the economic impacts of the [[Fukushima I nuclear accidents|Fukushima I nuclear disaster]].{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/04/18/EDAV1J2TQ7.DTL |title=Who would pay if nuclear disaster happened here? |author=Rochelle Becker |date=18 April 2011 |work=San Francisco Chronicle }} In December 2011, as Japan completed "step 2" of its control roadmap at Fukushima, U.S. NRC chairman Jaczko visited the plant and said afterwards "that there was no longer enough energy in the reactors at the crippled Fukushima No. 1 Nuclear Power Plant to produce an offsite release of radiation, but pointed out that a large cleanup task remained".{{cite web |url=http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20111221p2a00m0na007000c.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-12-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111221193033/http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20111221p2a00m0na007000c.html |archivedate=21 December 2011 |df=dmy-all }} ===Other=== ;France In France around 1,000 people took part in a protest against nuclear power in Paris on 20 March,{{cite web|url=http://www.lepoint.fr/societe/pres-d-un-millier-de-manifestants-a-paris-demandent-la-sortie-du-nucleaire-20-03-2011-1308974_23.php |title=Près d'un millier de manifestants à Paris demandent la sortie du nucléaire - Le Point |publisher=Lepoint.fr |date=2011-03-20 |accessdate=2016-11-15}} and some 3,800 French and Germans demonstrated for the closure of the [[Fessenheim Nuclear Power Plant]] on 8 April; a larger demonstration is expected on 25 April.{{cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/planete/article/2011/04/10/nucleaire-3-800-manifestants-demandent-l-arret-de-la-centrale-de-fessenheim_1505660_3244.html |title=Des milliers de manifestants demandent l'arrêt de la centrale de Fessenheim |publisher=Lemonde.fr |date= |accessdate=2016-11-15}} [[Nuclear power in France#Public opinion|Opinion polls on the topic]] indicated that 55% of the population were in favour of nuclear power in the days following Fukushima, but 57% against by the end of March.{{cite web|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/energyOilNews/idAFLDE73C0ZI20110413 |title=Majority of French want to drop nuclear energy-poll | Energy & Oil | Reuters |publisher=Af.reuters.com |date=2011-04-13 |accessdate=2016-11-15}} ;Germany In March 2011, more than 200,000 people took part in anti-nuclear protests in four large German cities, on the eve of state elections. Organisers called it the biggest anti-nuclear demonstration the country has seen, with police estimating that 100,000 people turned out in Berlin alone. Hamburg, Munich and Cologne also saw big demonstrations.{{cite news |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/03/26/germany-nuclear-idUKLDE72P0FG20110326 |title=Anti-nuclear Germans protest on eve of state vote |date=26 March 2011 |work=Reuters |first=Stephen |last=Brown}} The ''New York Times'' reported that "most Germans have a deep-seated aversion to nuclear power, and the damage at the Fukushima Daiichi plant in Japan has galvanized opposition".{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/28/world/europe/28germany.html?_r=1 |title=Merkel Loses Key German State on Nuclear Fears |author=Judy Dempsey |date=27 March 2011 |work=New York Times }} After Japan's nuclear disaster, there was an [[Baden-Württemberg state election, 2011|all-time best state election result]] for the [[anti-nuclear]] Green Party in Germany in the [[Baden-Württemberg]] election on 27 March 2011.{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/28/germany-election-greens-idUSLDE72Q0KS20110328 |title=RPT-Germany's Greens come of age after Japan disaster |author=Erik Kirschbaum |date=28 March 2011 |work=Reuters }} However, the Greens' rise in popularity, which began October 2010 in the polls, has also been attributed to the unanimous opposition to [[Stuttgart 21]].{{cite news|title=CDU wary after Stuttgart rail project approval|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/1614de80-fcac-11df-bfdd-00144feab49a.html#axzz16zAkNhAv|work=Financial Times|date=29 November 2010|accessdate=2 December 2010}} The CDU-led government under Chancellor Angela Merkel made an aboutface in their nuclear energy policy. In 2010 the Government had just prolonged the retention period of nuclear power plants which were scheduled to be phased out in 2021 by the nuclear phase-out plan of 2000. In light of the Fukushima disaster, the Government changed its mind:
A physicist by training and a former environment minister, Merkel understood what Fukushima meant. Germany has 17 reactors, providing 23 percent of the electrical power in the country and making it the sixth largest nuclear electricity producer in the world. The eight oldest reactors were taken off the grid within days of 3/11 and will not return to operation. In record time, what once was the most pro-nuclear German government in decades prepared comprehensive legislation to phase out the remaining nine reactors by 2022 at the latest, starting in 2015. In June, parliament overwhelmingly passed the law (513 in favor, 79 against, 8 abstentions).{{cite web|url=http://www.thebulletin.org/web-edition/features/fukushima-crisis-can-japan-be-the-forefront-of-authentic-paradigm-shift |title=Fukushima crisis: Can Japan be at the forefront of an authentic paradigm shift? |author=Mycle Schneider |date=9 September 2011 |work=[[Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130106021131/http://www.thebulletin.org/web-edition/features/fukushima-crisis-can-japan-be-the-forefront-of-authentic-paradigm-shift |archivedate=6 January 2013 |df=dmy-all }}
;India In India, there has been rapid growth in energy use and there are plans to build the world's largest nuclear plant in Jaitapur, but anti-nuclear protests have intensified following the Fukushima crisis.{{cite web |url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nb20110528x1.html |title=G-8 differ in reactions to Fukushima |author=Alex Martin |date=28 May 2011 |work=The Japan Times }} On 18 April one man was shot and killed by police and eight were injured after protests against the planned [[Jaitapur Nuclear Power Project]] turned violent.{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gc1zxEqG5c895I8zEM2vePR9LoeQ?docId%3DCNG.03f9550f39158525b47a166b6f5d4741.421 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-11-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130419013521/http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gc1zxEqG5c895I8zEM2vePR9LoeQ?docId=CNG.03f9550f39158525b47a166b6f5d4741.421 |archivedate=19 April 2013 |df=dmy-all }} Although protests have been ongoing for some years, they have gained greater prominence and support since Fukushima.{{cite web|url=http://www.climatespectator.com.au/commentary/view-jaitapur?cookie_check=1&= |title=Nocookies | The Australian |publisher=Climatespectator.com.au |date= |accessdate=2016-11-15}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/politics-add-danger-to-jaitapur-nuclear-plant-protests-99937 |title=Politics add danger to Jaitapur nuclear plant protests |publisher=Ndtv.com |date=2011-04-19 |accessdate=2016-11-15}} ;Italy Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi announced in 2009 that Italy would go nuclear again after its four atomic power plants were shut down following a 1987 nationwide referendum. But in the wake of the Fukushima crisis, antinuclear rallies drawing thousands have erupted in Italy, and the Italian government has "decided on a one-year moratorium on its plans to revive nuclear power". A further [[Italian referendums, 2011|Italian nuclear power referendum]] was held on 13 June 2011 and the No vote won 94,05 %, leading to cancellation of future nuclear power plants planned during the previous years, and due to the Italian nuclear power referendum turn out being over 50%+1 of the Italian population creates a legally binding cancellation of future plants. ;Spain In March 2011, hundreds of people took part in protests held across Spain to demand the closure of the country's six nuclear power stations, after Japan's nuclear accidents. Demonstrators, many with signs that read "No nuclear power, neither here nor in Japan", gathered in small groups in more than 30 cities, including Madrid, Barcelona, Seville and Valencia.{{cite news |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5j-hX7fOLMkQOUJhgWSgQYsNztRtA?docId=CNG.af94279f2de063afb3fd0d2db3261792.1331 |title=Anti-nuclear demonstrations held across Spain |date=17 March 2011 |agency=AFP }} ;Sweden A 2011 poll suggests that scepticism over nuclear power is growing in Sweden following Japan's nuclear crisis. 36 percent of respondents want to phase-out nuclear power, up from 15 percent in a similar survey two years ago.{{cite web |url=http://www.businessweek.com/ap/financialnews/D9M4CAL00.htm |title=Poll shows anti-nuclear sentiment up in Sweden |date=22 March 2011 |work=Businessweek }} ;Switzerland Japan's Fukushima Dai-ichi nuclear disaster "has entirely changed the energy debate in Switzerland". In May 2011, some 20,000 people turned out for Switzerland's largest anti-nuclear power demonstration in 25 years. Demonstrators marched peacefully near the [[Beznau Nuclear Power Plant]], the oldest in Switzerland, which started operating 40 years ago.{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/ap/financialnews/D9NCL8100.htm |title=Biggest anti-nuclear Swiss protests in 25 years |date=22 May 2011 |work=Bloomberg Businessweek |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121026080657/http://www.businessweek.com/ap/financialnews/D9NCL8100.htm |archivedate=26 October 2012 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web |url=http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/swiss_news/Anti-nuclear_protests_attract_20,000.html?cid=30291990 |title=Anti-nuclear protests attract 20,000 |date=22 May 2011 |work=Swissinfo }} Days after the anti-nuclear rally, Cabinet decided to ban the building of new nuclear power reactors. The country's five existing reactors would be allowed to continue operating, but "would not be replaced at the end of their life span".{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/26/business/global/26nuclear.html?_r=1 |title=Switzerland Decides on Nuclear Phase-Out |author=James Kanter |date=25 May 2011 |work=New York Times }} ;TEPCO violates Human Rights On January 7, 2014 the largest pension fund in The Netherlands announced, that it had sold all its investments in [[TEPCO]], because the ABP found it unethical to invest in this company any longer. TEPCO was blamed for its conduct during and after the disaster. TEPCO had ignored the U.N. human rights, and had demonstrated that it had insufficient attention for public safety". There were insufficient measures to prevent environmental damage and it was impossible to move the company to different behavior. After all attempts of the ABP to change the attitude of the company had failed, all stock was sold in the first week of 2014.{{cite web|author=Heleen Haverkort |url=http://www.nu.nl/economie/3669190/pensioenfonds-abp-weert-tepco-wegens-schenden-mensenrechten.html |title=Pensioenfonds ABP weert Tepco wegens schenden mensenrechten | NU - Het laatste nieuws het eerst op |publisher=Nu.nl |date=2014-01-07 |accessdate=2016-11-15}} ==Re-evaluation of existing nuclear energy programs== ===Overview=== Following the [[Fukushima nuclear disaster]], Germany has permanently shut down eight of its reactors and pledged to close the rest by 2022.{{cite news |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/05/30/us-germany-nuclear-idUKTRE74Q2P120110530 |title=German government wants nuclear exit by 2022 at latest |author=Annika Breidthardt |date=30 May 2011 |work=Reuters }} The Italians have voted overwhelmingly to keep their country non-nuclear.{{cite web|url=http://referendum.interno.it/referendum/refe110612/RFT0003.htm |title=Italy Nuclear Referendum Results |date=13 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120325171121/http://referendum.interno.it/referendum/refe110612/RFT0003.htm |archivedate=25 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }} Switzerland and Spain have banned the construction of new reactors.{{cite web |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/2011/11/27/post-fukushima-nuclear-power-changes-latitudes.html |title= Nuclear Power Goes Rogue |author= [[Henry Sokolski]] |date= 28 Nov 2011 |work=Newsweek }} Japan's prime minister has called for a dramatic reduction in Japan's reliance on nuclear power.{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-10-28/nuclear-promotion-dropped-in-japan-energy-policy-after-fukushima.html |title=Nuclear Promotion Dropped in Japan Energy Policy After Fukushima |author=Tsuyoshi Inajima and Yuji Okada |date=28 Oct 2011 |work=Bloomberg }} Taiwan's president did the same. Mexico has sidelined construction of 10 reactors in favor of developing natural-gas-fired plants.{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-11-02/mexico-scraps-plans-to-build-as-many-as-10-nuclear-plants-focus-on-gas.html |title=Mexico Scraps Plans to Build 10 Nuclear Power Plants in Favor of Using Gas |author=Carlos Manuel Rodriguez |date=4 Nov 2011 |work=Bloomberg Businessweek }} Belgium is considering phasing out its nuclear plants, perhaps as early as 2015. China—nuclear power's largest prospective market—suspended approvals of new reactor construction while conducting a lengthy nuclear-safety review.{{cite news|author=the CNN Wire Staff |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/asiapcf/03/16/china.nuclear/?hpt=T2 |title=China freezes nuclear plant approvals |publisher=CNN |date= 16 March 2011|accessdate=16 March 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.channel4.com/news/will-chinas-nuclear-nerves-fuel-a-boom-in-green-energy |title=Will China's nuclear nerves fuel a boom in green energy? – Channel 4 News |publisher=Channel4.com |date=2011-03-17 |accessdate=2016-11-15}} Neighboring India, another potential nuclear boom market, has encountered effective local opposition, growing national wariness about foreign nuclear reactors, and a nuclear liability controversy that threatens to prevent new reactor imports. There have been mass protests against the French-backed 9900 MW [[Jaitapur Nuclear Power Project]] in Maharashtra and the 2000 MW [[Koodankulam Nuclear Power Plant]] in Tamil Nadu. The state government of West Bengal state has also refused permission to a proposed 6000 MW facility near the town of Haripur that intended to host six Russian reactors.{{cite web |url=http://www.asiasentinel.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=3889&Itemid=614 |title=India's Rising Nuclear Safety Concerns |author=Siddharth Srivastava |date=27 October 2011 |work=Asia Sentinel }} In the United States, new-reactor construction has also suffered—not because of public opposition but because of economics and tougher, yet-to-be-determined, safety regulations. In 2007, U.S. utilities applied to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to build 28 nuclear-power plants before 2020; now, if more than three come online before the end of the decade, it will be a major accomplishment. France is, per capita, the world's most nuclear-powered state. Frequently heralded as a nuclear commercial model for the world, today it's locked in a national debate over a partial nuclear phaseout. President Nicolas Sarkozy is still backing nuclear power, but his Socialist opponent, François Hollande, now well ahead in the polls, has proposed cutting nuclear power's electricity contribution by more than a third by 2025. ===Africa=== *{{flagicon|Niger}} Niger – In January 2012, President [[Mahamadou Issoufou]] said that Niger will continue with its plans to build a civilian nuclear power plant in cooperation with other West African countries in the [[ECOWAS]], rather than letting the Chernobyl and Fukushima disasters make Niger cancel its plans. He also stated that "In addition to renewable energy, nuclear energy is clean and low cost".{{cite news| url=https://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE80G00B20120117 | work=Reuters | title=Niger to pursue nuclear plans despite Fukushima: president | date=17 January 2012}}{{cite news| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-07-18/niger-plans-west-african-nuclear-power-plant-president-says.html | work=Bloomberg | title=Niger Plans West African Nuclear Power Plant, President Says}} ===Americas=== *{{flagicon|Canada}} Canada – On 16 March 2011, five days after the [[Fukushima I nuclear incident]] began, it was found that the [[Pickering Nuclear Generating Station]] in [[Pickering, Ontario]], situated east of [[Toronto]],{{Cite news|author=14 Mar 2011 4:09 pm ET |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/story/2011/03/14/ontario-nuclear-safety-japan.html |title=Japan quake triggers Ont. nuclear safety debate – Toronto – |publisher=CBC News |date=14 March 2011 |accessdate=18 March 2011}} was leaking demineralized water into [[Lake Ontario]].{{Cite news|url=http://toronto.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20110316/leak-pickering-nuclear-plant-110316?hub=TorontoNewHome |title=CTV Toronto – Leak at Pickering nuclear plant poses no threat: OPG |publisher=CTV News |date=23 November 2010 |accessdate=18 March 2011}} While the [[Canadian Nuclear Safety Commission]] declared that the leak, caused by a pump seal failure, did not pose any threat to human health, many Canadians questioned the safety of nuclear power plants in Canada. [[Gordon Edwards]], Canadian physicist and founder of the [[Canadian Coalition for Nuclear Responsibility]], claimed that the leak "shows the potential for more significant nuclear contamination of Lake Ontario [compared to that of Japan's disaster]". He added that the source of the Pickering plant's leak was the same as that of the incident at Fukushima I and that the leak must not be taken lightly.{{Cite news|url=http://toronto.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20110317/pickering-nuclear-leak-lake-ontario-110317/20110317/?hub=TorontoNewHome |title=CTV Toronto – Group questions nuclear safety after Pickering leak |publisher=CTV News |date=11 September 2001 |accessdate=18 March 2011}} The [[Gentilly Nuclear Generating Station]] near [[Bécancour, Quebec]], is the only Canadian nuclear power plant near a fault line. [[Quebec Premier]] [[Jean Charest]] issued statements that the Gentilly-2 reactor was safe, and the Canadian Nuclear Safety Commission declared it could withstand earthquakes.{{cite web |url= https://montrealgazette.com/opinion/reader-comments/Gentilly+reactor+sits+fault+line/4447202/story.html |publisher=The Gazette (Montreal) |date= 16 March 2011 |author=William Marsden |title= Gentilly 2 reactor sits on fault line |accessdate=17 March 2011 }} *{{Flagicon|Chile}} Chile – In Chile, Emol reported on 16 March there has been much controversy over the installation of nuclear power plants, following the Chilean Government report that it was ready to sign a cooperation agreement with the United States Government on Nuclear Energy. The opposition urged a meeting on the plans with the Minister of Mines and Energy, Laurence Golborne.{{cite web|url=http://www.emol.com/noticias/nacional/detalle/detallenoticias.asp?idnoticia=470405 |title=Concertación inicia fuerte ofensiva ante acuerdo nuclear del Gobierno con EE.UU |publisher=Emol.com |accessdate=18 March 2011|language=Spanish}} *{{flagicon|United States}} United States – U.S. President Obama and aides for former Senator Domenici publicly supported continued development of new U.S. nuclear power facilities.[https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/25/us/25lobby.html Lobbyists’ Long Effort to Revive Nuclear Industry Faces New Test] The influential ''The New York Times'' stated in an editorial on 14 March that "the unfolding Japanese tragedy also should prompt Americans to closely study our own plans for coping with natural disasters and with potential nuclear plant accidents to make sure they are, indeed, strong enough".{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/15/opinion/15tue1.html|accessdate=18 March 2011|date=14 March 2011|work=NY Times|title=Editorial}} A more definitive expression of the impact of the accidents in the United States was the decision by [[NRG Energy]], Inc. to abandon already started construction on two new nuclear power plants in Texas.{{cite web|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/business/energy/20110419-nrg-ends-project-to-build-new-nuclear-reactors.ece |title=NRG ends project to build new nuclear reactors | Energy |publisher=Dallas News |date=2011-04-19 |accessdate=2016-11-15}} Analysts attributed the abandonment of the project to the financial situation of the plant-partner TEPCO, the inability raise other construction financing, the current low cost of electricity in Texas, and expected additional permitting delays. *{{flagicon|Venezuela}} Venezuela – Venezuelan President [[Hugo Chavez]] announced a halt to freeze all nuclear power development projects for peaceful means, which included design of a nuclear power plant for which a contract had been made with Russia.{{Cite news|last=Rodriguez |first=Corina |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-16/chavez-halts-venezuela-nuclear-plans-after-japanese-crisis.html |title=Chavez Halts Venezuela Nuclear Plans After Japanese Crisis |publisher=Bloomberg |date=16 March 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011}} ===Asia & Pacific=== *{{flagicon|Australia}} Australia – The Prime Minister of Australia, [[Julia Gillard]], stated in Melbourne, "I don't see nuclear energy as part of our future. We are blessed with abundant sources of renewable energy, of clean energy, of solar, wind, tide, hot rocks. That's our future, not nuclear..."{{Cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/03/22/us-australia-uranium-idUKTRE72L14P20110322/ |title=Australia weighs nuclear push after Japan crisis |publisher=Reuters |date=22 March 2011|accessdate=28 March 2011}} per a Reuters report of 22 March 2011. Australia has no nuclear power stations. *{{flagicon|China}} China – ZSR reported on 14 March that During a News Conference of the Annual Meeting of National People's Congress of China, the Deputy Chief of Environmental Protection Authority of China, Mr Lijun Zhang had said: "We are concerned about the damage of the Nuclear Facility of Japan, concerned about the further development of this issue, we will learn from it, and will take it into account when we make strategic planning for the nuclear energy development in the future. However, our decision on development of more nuclear power plants and current arrangement on nuclear energy development will not be changed."{{cite web|url=http://www.zsr.cc/zsrFocus/PostdoctorFocus/201103/572385.html/ |script-title=zh:中国启动沿海核安全监测装置 防日本核泄漏 |publisher=zsr |accessdate=14 March 2011|language=Chinese}} On 16 March, China froze nuclear plant approvals.{{Cite news|author=the CNN Wire Staff |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/asiapcf/03/16/china.nuclear/?hpt=T2 |title=China freezes nuclear plant approvals |publisher=CNN |date= 16 March 2011|accessdate=16 March 2011}} On 28 March, the Chinese government revised nuclear power targets, which would likely result "in a reduction of about 10 gigawatts in nuclear generating capacity from the 90 gigawatts previously expected to be built by 2020."[http://www.siouxcityjournal.com/business/article_dace94fa-62f0-5ea7-81aa-24db276572a0.html Power group: China lowering nuclear target]{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} *{{flagicon|India}} India – The Prime Minister of India, [[Manmohan Singh]], ordered the [[Nuclear Power Corporation of India]] to review the safety systems and designs of all the nuclear power reactors on 15 March. The Government of India was reported on 15 March to also be looking to put in place additional environmental safeguards to ensure safety of newly proposed nuclear reactors.{{Cite news|author=PTI|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Govt-to-review-safety-at-nuclear-plants-Ramesh/articleshow/7708580.cms |title=Govt to review safety at nuclear plants: Ramesh|work=The Times of India |date= 15 March 2011|accessdate=15 March 2011}} Nuclear Power Corporation of India said on 14 March that the nuclear power stations in India survived the earthquake of [[2001 Bhuj earthquake]] and the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami]] but there was "no room for complacency".{{Cite news|author=Sujay Mehdudia |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article1537394.ece |title=News / National : Indian nuclear plants ‘safe’ but no room for complacency: NPCIL |work=The Hindu |date=14 March 2011 |accessdate=18 March 2011 |location=Chennai, India}} *{{Flagicon|Israel}} Israel – Prime Minister [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] stated on 17 March 2011, that Israel was now unlikely to pursue civil nuclear energy.{{cite web|url=http://piersmorgan.blogs.cnn.com/2011/03/17/israel-prime-minister-netanyahu-japan-situation-has-caused-me-to-reconsider-nuclear-power/ |title=Israel Prime Minister Netanyahu: Japan situation has "caused me to reconsider" nuclear power – Piers Morgan - CNN.com Blogs |publisher=Piersmorgan.blogs.cnn.com |date= |accessdate=2016-11-15}}[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2011-03/18/c_13784578 ]{{dead link|date=November 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4043982,00.html|title=Netanyahu: We'll reconsider nuclear power plans|publisher=Ynetnews|date=18 March 2011|accessdate=17 March 2011}} *{{flagicon|Democratic People's Republic of Korea}} North Korea – The [[Korean Central News Agency]] reported on 31 March that dissatisfaction with the Naoto Kan administration has risen concerning the accident response in Japan. Also, [[Rodong Sinmun]] reported, "The situation of the nuclear plant accident get worse and worse every day, and made the international society worry greatly".{{cite news |url=http://sankei.jp.msn.com/world/news/110331/kor11033122540005-n1.htm |script-title=ja:原発事故で「菅政権へ不満」「国際社会憂慮」と北朝鮮 |language=Japanese |quote=sankei msn |newspaper=[[sankei Shimbun]] |date=31 March 2011 |accessdate=31 March 2011}} *{{flagicon|Pakistan}} Pakistan– The Government of Pakistan ordered the [[Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission]] (PAEC) to check and review the power plants security, system, and designs of all the atomic power reactors in the country.{{cite web|author=APP |date=15 March 2011 |url=http://app.com.pk/en_/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=133832&Itemid=2 |title=Nuclear power plants in the country are functioning safely |publisher=Associated Press of Pakistan|accessdate=16 March 2011}} The [[Pakistan Nuclear Regulatory Authority]] (PNRA) issued safety guidelines in plants, and ordered to re-evaluate the designs of [[Karachi Nuclear Power Complex|KANUPP-II]] and the [[Chashma Nuclear Power Plant]] in Chashman city, Pakistan today reported on 16 March 2011.{{cite web|author=Shaiq Hussain |date=16 March 2011 |url=http://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/pakistan-news/National/16-Mar-2011/Karachi-Chashma-Nplants-safe-PAEC |title=Karachi, Chashma N-plants safe: PAEC|work=Pakistan Times|accessdate=16 March 2011}} The PAEC is continuously monitoring the flow of events in nuclear plants in Japan in the wake of the recent earthquake and tsunami there, [[Associated Press of Pakistan|APP]] concluded on 16 March 2011.{{cite web|author=The Financial Daily |date=16 March 2011|url=http://thefinancialdaily.com/news/top-stories/pak-n-plants-safe-says-paec-64016.aspx |title=Pakistan's nuclear power plants safe: PAEC|publisher=The Financial Daily|accessdate=16 March 2011}} According to the ''[[Jang News]]'', Pakistan offered Japan to provide technical assistance to control to their nuclear radiation. On 20 March 2011, Jang News reported that scientists from [[Pakistan Nuclear Regulatory Authority|PNRA]] and [[Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission|PAEC]] are ready to leave for Japan as soon as [[International Atomic Energy Agency|IAEA]] gives an approval.{{Cite news | last =Eqdas | first =Farouq | title =Japan accepted Pakistan's offer to control the nuclear radiation and recovery assistance | newspaper =[[Jang News]] | location =Islamabad | pages =3–4 | language =Urdu | publisher =Jang Group of Newspapers | date =20 March 2011 | url =http://jang.com.pk/jang/mar2011-daily/21-03-2011/main3.htm | accessdate =2011 }} Japanese officials have accepted the Pakistan's offer, however, due to IAEA laws, both countries needs an approval from IAEA for such cooperation. According to the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Pakistan)|Foreign Office]] of Pakistan, Pakistani scientists are ready to leave for Japan as soon as IAEA gives an approval for such technical assistance. *{{flagicon|Taiwan}} Taiwan has ordered the suspension of its plans to expand nuclear power until a full safety review is complete.{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-04-12/taiwan-halts-plans-to-build-atomic-reactors-after-japan-crisis.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-03-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130829113709/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-04-12/taiwan-halts-plans-to-build-atomic-reactors-after-japan-crisis.html |archivedate=29 August 2013 |df=dmy-all }} *{{flagicon|Turkey}} Turkey – Turkish Prime Minister [[Recep Tayyip Erdogan]] reaffirmed his commitment of building Turkey's first nuclear plant at [[Akkuyu Nuclear Power Plant|Akkuyu]], [[Mersin Province]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/erdogan_turkey_tatarstan/2340790.html |title=Turkey's Erdogan Pays Visit To Tatarstan |publisher=Rferl.org |accessdate=18 March 2011}} * {{flagicon|Kuwait}} In July 2011 Kuwait scrapped the plan to build four nuclear power plants by 2022. After the Fukushima disaster, opposition against the plans started to emerge. Sabah al-Ahmad al-Jaber al-Sabah, emir of Kuwait, issued an order to dissolve the national nuclear energy committee. Besides the opposition, Kuwait is a small country, and it would be difficult to find a safe place for the nuclear waste the reactors would produce. Besides the cooperation with Japan, Kuwait did sign agreements on atomic energy with the United States, France and Russia.{{cite web |url=http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20120222p2g00m0dm102000c.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-02-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120222194507/http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20120222p2g00m0dm102000c.html |archivedate=22 February 2012 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/text/nn20120223a7.html |title=Kuwait scraps nuclear power in light of 3/11 |publisher=The Japan Times |date=2012-02-23 |accessdate=2016-11-15}} ===Europe=== *{{flagicon|European Union}} European Union – In an interview on [[ORF2]], Austrian Environment Minister [[Faymann cabinet|Nikolaus Berlakovich]] said that he would enter a request at the environmental meeting in Brussels on 14 March 2011 for a review of reactor safety. He emphasized both coolant and containment and compared these measures to reviews of the financial system after the banking crisis of 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.allheadlinenews.com/briefs/articles/90039901?UN%20atomic%20watchdog%20mulling%20increased%20nuclear%20safety%20scrutiny%20after%20Japan%26%23146%3Bs%20Fukushima%20disaster#ixzz1GeXRTLaO |title=UN atomic watchdog mulling increased nuclear safety scrutiny after Japan's Fukushima disaster|publisher=AHN |date=14 March 2011 |accessdate=15 March 2011}} :[[Connie Hedegaard]], the [[European Commissioner for Climate Action]] stated on 17 March that generating energy from [[wind turbines at sea]] would be cheaper than building new atomic power plants.{{Cite news|author=Fiona Harvey and Terry Macalister |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2011/mar/17/wind-cheaper-nuclear-eu-climate |title=Wind power cheaper than nuclear, says EU climate chief | Environment |work=The Guardian |location=UK |date= 17 March 2011|accessdate=18 March 2011}} :On 23 March a European Union-wide stress test was announced after an emergency meeting of the [[European Council of Ministers]] on Energy. All 143 nuclear power plants in the Union were planned to be subject to an assessment and it was also hoped plants of neighbouring countries were taken into account. The evaluation would include "[[vulnerability]] to seismic events, their exposure to flooding, as well as man-made disasters (such as power cuts and terrorism), with special attention being paid to [[Nuclear safety systems|cooling and back-up systems]]."{{cite news|title=Ministers authorise nuclear 'stress tests' |url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/RS_Ministers_authorise_nuclear_stress_tests_2303111.html|work=World Nuclear News|date=23 March 2011|accessdate=25 March 2011}} *{{flagicon|France}} France – In a letter dated 23 March, Prime Minister [[Francois Fillon]] asked the [[Autorité de sûreté nucléaire|Nuclear Safety Authority]] to carry out an 'open and transparent' audit each of its nuclear installations, looking at the risks of flood, earthquake, loss of power and cooling, and accident management processes, in order to identify any improvements that should be made in the light of lessons learned from Fukushima. The initial conclusions are expected by the end of 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.asn.fr/index.php/S-informer/Actualites/2011/Le-Premier-Ministre-demande-a-l-ASN-d-auditer-les-installations-nucleaires |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-03-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614031347/http://www.asn.fr/index.php/S-informer/Actualites/2011/Le-Premier-Ministre-demande-a-l-ASN-d-auditer-les-installations-nucleaires |archivedate=14 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }} France conducted a more limited review following [[1999 Blayais Nuclear Power Plant flood|flooding at its Blayais Nuclear Power Plant]] in 1999. President [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] has stressed the need for dialogue but said that France had chosen nuclear power for reasons of [[energy security]] and to counter [[greenhouse gas]] emissions.{{cite web|url=http://www.lcp.fr/actualites/politique/13753-nucleaire-sarkozy-defend-ses-choix-plaide-pour-le-dialogue-entre-politiques-et-chercheurs |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-04-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723202033/http://www.lcp.fr/actualites/politique/13753-nucleaire-sarkozy-defend-ses-choix-plaide-pour-le-dialogue-entre-politiques-et-chercheurs |archivedate=23 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }} However pressure to permanently close the [[Fessenheim Nuclear Power Plant]], the oldest in France, is growing within France and in neighbouring Switzerland and Germany.{{cite web|author=Par latribune.fr |url=http://www.latribune.fr/entreprises-finance/industrie/energie-environnement/20110329trib000611588/une-motion-adoptee-en-franche-comte-pour-fermer-fessenheim.html |title=Une motion adoptée en Franche-Comté pour fermer Fessenheim |publisher=Latribune.fr |date=2011-05-20 |accessdate=2016-11-15}}{{cite web|url=http://www.lematin.ch/actu/suisse/grand-conseil-bale-ville-exige-arret-fessenheim-400877 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-02-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150218023258/http://www.lematin.ch/actu/suisse/grand-conseil-bale-ville-exige-arret-fessenheim-400877/ |archivedate=18 February 2015 |df=dmy-all }}[https://archive.is/20120903124205/http://www.leparisien.fr/strasbourg-67000/nucleaire-les-verts-europeens-veulent-faire-de-fessenheim-un-site-pilote-06-04-2011-1396291.php ] *{{flagicon|Germany}} Germany – During the chancellorship of [[Gerhard Schröder]], the [[Social Democratic Party of Germany|social democratic]]-[[Alliance '90/The Greens|green]] government had decreed Germany's [[Nuclear power in Germany#Phase-out|final retreat from using nuclear power]] by 2022, but the phase-out plan was delayed in late 2010, when during the chancellorship of [[Angela Merkel]] the [[Christian Democratic Union of Germany|conservative]]-[[Free Democratic Party (Germany)|liberal]] government decreed a 12-year delay of the schedule.{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/germany/0,1518,750836,00.html |title=Germany Reconsiders Reactor Lifespan Extensions |work=DER SPIEGEL |accessdate=14 March 2011}} This delay provoked protests, including a [[human chain]] of 50,000 from [[Stuttgart]] to the nearby nuclear plant in Neckarwestheim. This protest had long been scheduled for 12 March, which now happened to be the day of the explosion of reactor block 1.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2011/mar/12/nuclear-safety-worries-spread-europe |title=Nuclear safety worries spread to Europe |publisher=Guardian UK |date=12 March 2011|accessdate=14 March 2011 |location=London |first=Tracy |last=McVeigh}} [[Anti-nuclear]] demonstrations on 12 March attracted 100 000 across Germany.{{Cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/newsbook/2011/03/german_energy_policy?page=1|title=Nuclear power? No thanks (again) |work=The Economist |date=15 March 2011|accessdate=17 March 2011}} On 14 March 2011, in response to the renewed concern about the use of nuclear energy the Fukushima incident raised in the German public and in light of upcoming elections in three [[States of Germany|German states]], Merkel declared a 3-months moratorium on the reactor lifespan extension passed in 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/0,1518,750872,00.html |title=AKW Neckarwestheim muss vom Netz |work=DER SPIEGEL |accessdate=14 March 2011}} On 15 March, the German government announced that it would temporarily shut down 7 of its 17 reactors, i.e. all reactors that went online before 1981.{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/n.php?n=germany-to-shut-down-seven-reactors-temporarily-2011-03-15 |title=ECONOMY - Germany to shut down seven reactors temporarily |publisher=Hurriyetdailynews.com |date=2011-03-15 |accessdate=2016-11-15}} Former proponents of nuclear energy such as [[Angela Merkel]], [[Guido Westerwelle]], [[Stefan Mappus]] have changed their positions,{{cite web|url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,,14909851,00.html |title=Nuclear backlash forces Merkel to rethink energy policy | Germany | Deutsche Welle | 14.03.2011 |publisher=Dw-world.de |accessdate=18 March 2011}} yet 71% of the population believe that to be a tactical manoeuvre related to upcoming [[States of Germany|state]] elections.{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/0,1518,752631,00.html|title=Umfrage: Wähler strafen Union für Atomkurs ab|work=DER SPIEGEL |date=23 March 2011|accessdate=26 March 2011}} In the largest [[Anti-nuclear movement in Germany|anti-nuclear demonstration]] ever held in Germany, some 250,000 people protested on 26 March under the slogan "heed Fukushima – shut off all nuclear plants."{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/0,1518,753371,00.html|title=Rekord-Demos in Deutschland. Atomstreit trifft Koalition mit voller Wucht|work=DER SPIEGEL |date=26 March 2011|accessdate=26 March 2011}} *{{flagicon|Italy}} Italy – A moratorium on the construction of nuclear power plants was approved on 24 March by the Council of Ministers of Italy for a period of 1 year.{{cite web|url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/NP-Italy_announces_nuclear_moratorium-2403117.html|title=Italy announces nuclear moratorium|date=24 March 2011|accessdate=23 May 2011|publisher=[[World Nuclear News]]}} A further Italian nuclear power referendum was held on 13 June 2011 and the No vote won, leading to cancellation of future nuclear power plants planned during the previous years, and due to the Italian nuclear power referendum turn out being over 50%+1 of the Italian population creates a legally binding cancellation of future plants. *{{flagicon|NLD}} Netherlands – [[Maxime Verhagen]], Minister of Energy, Agriculture and Innovation, wrote in a letter to the [[House of Representatives of the Netherlands|House of Representatives]] that the experience of Japan would be taken into account in the definition of the requirements for a new nuclear power plant to be built in 2015.{{cite web|language=Dutch|url=http://www.trouw.nl/tr/nl/4324/Nieuws/article/detail/1860025/2011/03/14/Verhagen-Japanse-ervaring-met-kerncentrale-telt-ook-voor-Nederland.dhtml|date=14 March 2011|title=Verhagen: Japanse ervaring met kerncentrale telt ook voor Nederland|publisher=[[Trouw]]}} Prime minister [[Mark Rutte]] indicated on 18 March there were no plans to change operations at [[Borssele nuclear power plant]] and called the German moratorium 'curious' ({{lang-nl|merkwaardig}}).{{cite web|date=18 March 2011|url=http://www.nu.nl/politiek/2471861/besluit-merkel-centrales-merkwaardig.html|publisher=[[nu.nl]]|title='Besluit Merkel centrales merkwaardig'}} *{{flagicon|Slovakia}} Slovakia – The Slovak republic said in the week after the accidents it would continue with the construction of two new [[VVER 440]]/V-213 reactors (PWR) at the [[Mochovce Nuclear Power Plant]]. All blocks at the Mochovce plant, existing and under construction, shall be updated and modernised to withstand higher earthquakes than the current limit.{{cite web|url=http://www.sme.sk/c/5807375/slovensko-sa-jadra-nevzda.html |title=Slovensko sa jadra nevzdá |publisher=SME |accessdate=15 March 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sme.sk/c/5811089/mochovce-maju-byt-odolnejsie-proti-zemetraseniu.html |title=Mochovce majú byť odolnejšie proti zemetraseniu |publisher=SME |accessdate=17 March 2011}} *{{flagicon|Russia}} Russia – On 15 March, Prime Minister Vladimir Putin ordered officials to check Russian nuclear facilities and to review the country's ambitious plans to develop atomic energy amid Japan's nuclear crisis.{{Cite news|author=Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/15/japan-quake-russia-putin-idUSWEA860820110315 |title=Reuters: Putin orders review of Russian nuclear plans |publisher=Reuters |date= 15 March 2011|accessdate=15 March 2011}} *{{flagicon|Spain}} Spain – Spanish Prime Minister [[Jose Luis Rodriguez Zapatero]] ordered on 16 March a review of his country's nuclear power plants.{{Cite news|author=From Al Goodman, CNN |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/europe/03/16/spain.nuclear.power/index.html?eref=edition |title=Spain orders review of nuclear power plants |publisher=CNN |date= 16 March 2011|accessdate=18 March 2011}} *{{flagicon|Switzerland}} Switzerland – Swiss Federal Councillor [[Doris Leuthard]] announced on 14 March a freeze in the authorisation procedures for three new nuclear power plants, and ordered a safety review of the country's plants.{{cite web |author=Swiss Federal Council |url=http://www.uvek.admin.ch/dokumentation/00474/00492/index.html?lang=fr&msg-id=38236 |title=Energy Policy: The Federal Council orders a revision of decision processes after Fukushima (in French) |publisher=Swiss Federal Council |accessdate=25 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723090646/http://www.uvek.admin.ch/dokumentation/00474/00492/index.html?lang=fr&msg-id=38236 |archivedate=23 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }} *{{flagicon|United Kingdom}} United Kingdom – On 12 March, British Energy Minister [[Chris Huhne]] wrote to Dr Mike Weightman, head of the [[Health and Safety Executive#Nuclear Directorate|HSE's Nuclear Directorate]], asking for a report 'on the implications of the situation and the lessons to be learned for the UK nuclear industry.[http://www.decc.gov.uk/media/viewfile.ashx?filetype=4&filepath=What%20we%20do/UK%20energy%20supply/Energy%20mix/Nuclear/1437-letter-from-the-secretary-of-state-for-energy-and-.pdf ]{{dead link|date=November 2016}} The report is to be delivered within 6 months, with an interim report by mid-May, 'prepared in close cooperation with the International nuclear community and other nuclear safety regulators'. On 15 March, Huhne expressed regret that some European politicians were 'rushing to judgement' before assessments had been carried out, and said that it was too early to determine whether the willingness of the private sector to invest in new nuclear plants would be affected.{{cite web|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201011/cmselect/cmenergy/uc742-vii/uc74201.htm |title=Uncorrected Evidence - Electricity Market Reform |publisher=Publications.parliament.uk |date= |accessdate=2016-11-15}}{{cite web|last=Armitstead |first=Louise |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/energy/8384145/Chris-Huhne-Japan-is-a-risk-to-UK-nuclear-plans.html |title=Chris Huhne: Japan is a risk to UK nuclear plans |publisher=Telegraph |date=2011-03-16 |accessdate=2016-11-15}} Dr Weightman visited Japan in May with an [[IAEA]] team.{{cite journal|last1=Grimes|first1=Robin|title=The UK Response to Fukushima and Anglo-Japanese Relations|journal=Science & Diplomacy|date=2014-06-16|volume=3|issue=2|url=http://www.sciencediplomacy.org/perspective/2014/uk-response-fukushima-and-anglo-japanese-relations}} ==Renewable energy== [[Nancy Folbre]], an economics professor, has said that the biggest positive result of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster could be renewed public support for the [[Renewable energy commercialization|commercialization of renewable energy technologies]].{{cite news |url=https://economix.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/03/28/renewing-support-for-renewables/ |title=Renewing Support for Renewables |author=Nancy Folbre |date=28 March 2011 |work=New York Times }} In 2011, London-based bank HSBC said: "With Three Mile Island and Fukushima as a backdrop, the US public may find it difficult to support major nuclear new build and we expect that no new plant extensions will be granted either. Thus we expect the clean energy standard under discussion in US legislative chambers will see a far greater emphasis on gas and [[renewable energy|renewables]] plus [[Efficient energy use|efficiency]]".HSBC (2011). Climate investment update: Japan's nuclear crisis and the case for clean energy. ''HSBC Global Research'', 18 March. In 2011, [[Deutsche Bank]] analysts concluded that "the global impact of the Fukushima accident is a fundamental shift in public perception with regard to how a nation prioritizes and values its populations health, safety, security, and natural environment when determining its current and future energy pathways". As a consequence, "[[renewable energy]] will be a clear long-term winner in most energy systems, a conclusion supported by many voter surveys conducted over the past few weeks. At the same time, we consider natural gas to be, at the very least, an important transition fuel, especially in those regions where it is considered secure".Deutsche Bank Group (2011). The 2011 inflection point for energymarkets: Health, safety, security and the environment. ''DB Climate Change Advisors'', 2 May. In September 2011, [[Mycle Schneider]] said that the Fukushima disaster can be understood as a unique chance "to get it right" on [[energy policy]]. "Germany – with its nuclear phase-out decision based on a highly successful renewable energy program – and Japan – having suffered a painful shock but possessing unique technical capacities and societal discipline – can be at the forefront of an authentic paradigm shift toward a truly sustainable, low-carbon and nuclear-free energy policy". ==See also== *[[Anti-nuclear movement]] *[[Anti-nuclear protests]] *[[Humanitarian response to the 2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]] *[[Japanese reaction to Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster]] *[[Nuclear energy policy]] *[[Nuclear power debate]] *[[Nuclear renaissance]] *[[Radiation effects from the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster]] *[[Timeline of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} *''Some text on this page is being used through a Creative Commons Licence.'' {{2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami}} {{Nuclear power in Japan}} [[Category:Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster]] [[Category:International responses to natural disasters|Fukushima]] [[de:Nuklearkatastrophe von Fukushima#Auswirkungen auf Wirtschaft und Gesellschaft]]

{{advert|date=January 2019}} {{COI|date=January 2019}} {{infobox brand | logo = File:Dupont Tyvek logo.svg | name = Tyvek | image = | type = [[Flashspun fabric|Flashspun]] [[Nonwoven fabric|nonwoven]] [[High-density polyethylene|HDPE]] [[fiber]] | currentowner = [[DuPont]] | origin = United States | introduced = {{start date and age|1967|4}} | discontinued = | related = [[:ja:ユポ・コーポレーション|YUPO]] synthetic [[Oji Paper Company|paper]] | markets = [[Construction]], [[Packaging]] and [[label|labeling]] | previousowners = | trademarkregistrations = | ambassador = | tagline = What do you need to protect?™ | website = [http://www.dupont.com/products-and-services/fabrics-fibers-nonwovens/protective-fabrics/brands/tyvek.html dupont.com/Tyvek] }} [[File:Tyvek house wrap.jpg|thumb|Tyvek house wrap]] '''Tyvek''' ({{IPAc-en|t|ai|ˈ|v|ɛ|k}}) is a [[brand]] of [[flashspun]] [[high-density polyethylene]] [[fiber]]s, a [[Chemical synthesis|synthetic]] material; the name is a [[registered trademark]] of the [[DuPont]] company, well known for their production of chemicals and textiles. Tyvek is often used as [[housewrap]], a synthetic material used to protect buildings during construction. The material is difficult to tear but can easily be cut with [[scissor]]s or a knife. [[Water vapor]] can pass through Tyvek, but liquid water cannot. All of these properties make Tyvek useful in a variety of applications.
==History== Tyvek is a [[Nonwoven fabric|nonwoven]] product consisting of spun bond [[olefin fiber]]. It was first discovered in 1955 by a researcher for the DuPont [[textile]] company, named Jim White. While working in an experimental lab, Jim noticed a type of white fluff coming out of a pipe in a DuPont experimental lab.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dupont.com/products-and-services/fabrics-fibers-nonwovens/protective-fabrics/brands/tyvek.html|title=Tyvek® brand - For Greater Good™|author=admin|publisher=|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071207232132/http://www2.dupont.com/Tyvek/en_US/products/about_pgs/history.html|archivedate=2007-12-07}}</ref> That fluff was a product known as [[polyethylene]], which DuPont requested a patent for within a year of the discovery. After technologies improved during the next few years, in 1959 DuPont discovered that when the fluff was spun at high speeds it produced a durable fabric that was able to be cut with a blade. While the product Tyvek was used since 1959, DuPont did not trademark the actual brand until 1965, making it available for commercial purposes in April 1967.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dupont.com/products-and-services/fabrics-fibers-nonwovens/protective-fabrics/brands/tyvek/tyvek-media-center.html|title=DuPont™ Tyvek® Marks 40 Years of Energy Efficiency and Protection|publisher=[[DuPont]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080209122333/http://www2.dupont.com/Tyvek/en_US/news_events/article20070619.html|archivedate=2008-02-09}}</ref> As of 1970, Tyvek had reached the mainstream construction industry on both a national and global scale, and is often used for the construction of houses due to its unique ability to keep out liquid, while allowing vapor through.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www2.dupont.com/Building_Innovations/en_CN/knowledgeCenter/kc_tyvekhistory.html|title=History of Weather Barrier|website=www2.dupont.com|access-date=2018-11-28}}</ref> In 1972, DuPont released Tyvek packaging for sterile instruments that were to be used by surgeons and doctors in the medical field.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dupont.com/content/dam/dupont/products-and-services/packaging-materials-and-solutions/medical-and-pharmaceutical-packaging-materials/documents/MPP_Introduction_to_DuPont_Tyvek.pdf|website=www.dupont.com|access-date=2018-12-11}}</ref>
=== 21st century === In 2017, [[DuPont]] and [[Focus DIY]] entered an current agreement to sell Tyvek along with [[DuPont]]’s other products at [[Focus DIY]] stores. In 2017, the DuPont company merged with another chemical company, [[Dow Chemical Company|Dow Chemicals]] to form [[DowDuPont]]. The net worth of this newly merged company is over $150 billion as of 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.delawareonline.com/story/money/business/2018/08/02/dowdupont-dupont-earnings-delaware-breen/888844002/|title=DowDuPont announces earnings, but few new details about spin-off companies|work=delawareonline|access-date=2018-11-28|language=en}}</ref> While the DuPont company still makes Tyvek, it also produces products such as [[Kevlar]] and cellophane, among numerous other chemical products. Tyvek is currently manufactured at the Spruance plant in [[Richmond, Virginia]], and in [[Sandweiler]]-[[Contern]], [[Luxembourg]]. In 2018, DowDuPont announced that they would spend $400 million to increase the amount of Tyvek that could be produced in the Sandweiler-Contern factory.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nonwovens-industry.com/contents/view_breaking-news/2018-06-05/dupont-announces-400-million-tyvek-expansion/|title=DuPont Announces $400 Million Tyvek Expansion|website=Nonwovens Industry Magazine - News, Markets & Analysis for the Nonwovens Industry|access-date=2018-12-11}}</ref>
== Scientific characteristics and properties == [[File:TyvekExpressMailEnvelope.jpg|thumb|Tyvek USPS Express Mail envelope]]
=== Adhesion and bonding === DuPont recommends [[starch]], [[dextrin]], [[casein]], and [[Animal glue|animal-based]] [[adhesive]]s over most [[Adhesive#Synthetic|synthetic-based adhesives]], emphasizing the effectiveness of water-based and quick-drying glues as the best for bonding Tyvek both to itself and to a variety of substrates. DuPont also claims that the following [[adhesive]]s are highly effective:
* Water-based synthetic lattices * Ethylene/[[vinyl acetate]] * Acrylic pressure-sensitive tape * Solvent-based single-component [[polyurethane]] * [[Hot glue]]
[[Heat sealing]] can be used to melt Tyvek and cause it to bond to itself, but this form of bonding tends to create puckers in the otherwise flat material. [[Dielectric]] bonding can be effective in some circumstances, as is [[ultrasonic welding]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dupont.com/products-and-services/packaging-materials-solutions/industrial-packaging/articles/seaming-and-sealing.html|title=Seaming and Sealing with DuPont™ Tyvek®|last=|first=|authorlink=|year=2012|website=|publisher=DuPont|doi=|accessdate=11 November 2013}}</ref>
===Recycling=== Though Tyvek superficially resembles paper (for example, it can be written and printed on), it is plastic, and it cannot be [[Recycling|recycled]] with paper. Some Tyvek products are marked with the #2 resin-code for [[HDPE]], and can be collected with plastic bottles as part of some municipal curbside recycling programs. DuPont runs a program in the United States where disposable clothing, coveralls, lab coats, medical packaging and other non-hazardous Tyvek disposable [[garment]]s can be recycled, as well as providing a mail-in recycling program for envelopes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dupont.com/products-and-services/packaging-materials-solutions/industrial-packaging/articles/recycling-information.html|title=Recycling - DuPont Tyvek® for Industrial Packaging - DuPont USA|author=admin|publisher=}}</ref>
Recently, plastic bag recycling has become more prevalent. According to the [[American Chemistry Council]], these plastic film drop-off locations accept Tyvek.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.plasticfilmrecycling.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/Recycling-Reach-Study-2012.pdf|title=Plastic Film and Bag Recycling Collection: National Reach Study|publisher=Moore Recycling Associates Inc.}}</ref>
=== Properties of Tyvek === According to DuPont's Web site, the fibers are 0.5–10 [[Micrometre|µm]] (compared to 75 µm for a human hair). The nondirectional fibers (plexifilaments) are first spun and then bonded together by heat and pressure, without binders.<ref>[http://www.dupont.com/content/dam/dupont/products-and-services/fabrics-fibers-and-nonwovens/industrial-fabrics/documents/DPT_Tyvek_Product_Handbook.pdf Product Handbook for DuPont Tyvek]</ref>
Tyvek is also:
* Light weight * Class 1 [[flammability]] rating * Chemical resistant * Dimensional stabilized * [[Opacity (optics)|Opaque]] * Neutral [[pH]] * Tear resistant
==Uses==
=== Construction/engineering ===
* Large sheets of Tyvek are frequently used as "[[housewrap]]," to provide an air barrier between the outer cladding of a structure and the frame, insulation, etc., allowing water vapor to pass yet restricting air infiltration.<ref>DuPont: [http://www.dupont.com/products-and-services/construction-materials/tyvek-building-envelopes.html Tyvek Weatherization Systems] [https://web.archive.org/web/20090228064001/http://www2.dupont.com/Tyvek_Weatherization/en_US/index.html archive] [http://www.dupont.com/content/dam/assets/products-and-services/construction-materials/assets/Architectural%20Binder/Residential%20Products%20Brochure%20K10844.pdf Pdf]</ref> * Tyvek is used in [[archery]] to construct waterproof target faces, replacing paper.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/American-Whitetail-Archery-Target-Multicolor/dp/B0000AV8XN|title=Amazon.com : American Whitetail H-36 Flat Archery Target Face, Square, Tyvek Fiber Paper, 36" Size, Multicolor : Industrial & Scientific|website=www.amazon.com|access-date=2018-11-28}}</ref> * Tyvek was used to cover and protect the [[Reaction Control System]] (RCS) thruster ports from water and debris while the shuttle stack was exposed on the launchpad during the latter years of the [[Space Shuttle]] program.<ref>https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/20120014272.pdf</ref> The Tyvek covers were dislodged shortly after ignition and before the shuttle cleared the tower, posing no strike risk as the shuttle was travelling below 100 MPH.<ref>{{Cite AV media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zhuGwQq7qZk&t=35s|title=Dashcam on a Space Shuttle - FRONT WINDOW launch|date=2 March 2011|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref> * [[Tom Sachs (artist)|Tom Sachs]] used Tyvek for the outer shell of the spacesuits used in his Space Program series of artworks.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/jonathonkeats/2016/10/07/tom-sachs-ybca/|title=Artist Tom Sachs' DIY Space Program Is Outmaneuvering Elon Musk And NASA With Plywood And Tyvek|first=Jonathon|last=Keats|website=Forbes}}</ref>[[File:Newone_-_FedEx_Tyvek_envelope.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Newone_-_FedEx_Tyvek_envelope.jpg|thumb|Tyvek envelopes]]
=== Government use ===
* Tyvek is used by the [[United States Postal Service]] for some of its [[United States Postal Service#Priority Mail|Priority Mail]] and [[United States Postal Service#Express Mail|Express Mail]] [[envelope]]s * [[FedEx]] also uses it for some of its document envelopes. * New Zealand used it for its [[driver's license]]s from 1986 to 1999.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://nzta.govt.nz/resources/factsheets/54/|title=Upgrading driver licences from paper to photo (Factsheet 54) - NZ Transport Agency|website=nzta.govt.nz}}</ref> * [[Costa Rica]] (solely their 1000 colones bank note),<ref>[https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http://au.geocities.com/kai_oceania/costarica252.htm&date=2009-10-25+02:53:49 Costa Rica Tyvek Envelopes]</ref> the [[Isle of Man]],<ref>[https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http://au.geocities.com/kai_oceania/isleofman38.htm&date=2009-10-25+02:54:06 Isle of Man Bradvek Banknotes]</ref> and [[Haiti]]<ref>[https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http://au.geocities.com/kai_oceania/haiti.htm&date=2009-10-25+02:54:03 Haitian Tyvek Banknotes] 1980 and 1982 issues</ref> have made [[Polymer banknote|banknotes]] from it. These banknotes are no longer in circulation and have become collectors' items.
=== Fashion/personal use ===
* Race bibs, or race numbers are often produced on Tyvek paper, so they are less likely to rip during competition.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}} * Tyvek is often used in garment and other textile labeling due to high durability and washability.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fabriclabels.com/printed-tyvek-labels.php|title=Printed Tyvek Labels - Fast Turnaround - Hi-Tech Printing & Labeling - Fabriclabels.com|website=www.fabriclabels.com}}</ref> * Tyvek [[wristband]]s are used at festivals, conventions, and events where admission and security are concerns,<ref>uk.orakel.com</ref> as well as hospitals, resorts, nightclubs, schools, and reunions. * More recently fashion retailer and manufacturer [[American Apparel]] has included white Tyvek [[shorts]] as part of its range.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://store.americanapparel.net/rsaj401.html?cid=175|title=Tyvek Short - Shop American Apparel|publisher=|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716155811/http://store.americanapparel.net/rsaj401.html?cid=175|archivedate=16 July 2011}}</ref> * In 1976, fashion house [[Fiorucci]] made an entire collection out of Tyvek.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.doranix.com/what-is-tyvek/|title=What is Tyvek? Everything You Need to Know - Doranix|date=2017-06-20|work=Doranix|access-date=2018-11-28|language=en-US}}</ref> * Rock band [[Devo]] is known for wearing large, two-piece Tyvek suits with black elastic belts and 3-D glasses. In 1979, Devo appeared with Tyvek leisure suits and shirts made specifically for the band, with the band's own designs and images.{{Citation needed|date=August 2010}} In 2005 Dynomighty Design introduced stitchless Tyvek wallets which can be customized with whatever imagery the customer chooses.<ref name="Bespoke Tyvek wallets2">{{Cite web|url=https://mightywallet.shop/|title=MIGHTY WALLET - THE ORIGINAL TYVEK® WALLET SINCE 2005|website=dynomighty|access-date=2017-12-17}}</ref> * The [[ultralight backpacking]] community has begun to use Tyvek for the construction of extremely light yet durable backpacks.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://backpackinglight.com/forums/topic/18758/|title=Tyvek Backpack|last=McNall|first=Ralph|work=Forum Post}}</ref> In 2012, The Open Company released a foldable city map made of one of the stiffer variants of Tyvek.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://boingboing.net/2012/01/31/clever-folding-tyvek-san-franc.html|title=Clever-folding tyvek San Francisco map, with out-of-the-way landmarks|last=Doctorow|first=Cory|work=Blog Post|publisher=Boing Boing|accessdate=5 September 2012}}</ref> * British company [http://www.bo-borsa.com Bo-borsa] has produced a range of Tyvek tote bags, handbags, backpacks and light luggage * Increasingly, reused Tyvek material is being used by home crafters. Protective sleeves for [[Compact Disc]]s and [[DVD]]s, tote bags,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dupont.com.au/products-and-services/packaging-materials-solutions/Tyvek-envelopes/products/Disc-packaging-sleeves.html|title=DuPont™ Tyvek® for Disc Packaging Sleeves|accessdate=2018-07-31}}</ref> and [[origami]] wallets <ref>{{YouTube|oQGJbP92NRI|How to make a Tyvek Wallet}}</ref><ref>[https://www.amazon.com/DuPont-Sleeves-Window-Automated-Packaging/dp/B000WXGWLQ CD DVD DuPont White Tyvek Sleeves with 4" Clear Window and Flap (Automated Packaging Grade) 100 Pack] [[Amazon (company)|Amazon]]</ref> also use Tyvek-containing materials. * Tyvek is also used as a durable fabric in shoes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.theutlab.com/web/lightwing/|title=Archived copy|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130628030506/http://en.theutlab.com/web/lightwing/|archivedate=2013-06-28|deadurl=yes|accessdate=2013-06-17|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/31/business/Shoes-made-with-Tyvek.html|title=No Canvas, No Leather: A Reboot for the Sneaker|date=31 August 2014|work=The New York Times}}</ref>
[[File:Tyvek_Suits_(cropped).jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Tyvek_Suits_(cropped).jpg|thumb|Tyvek coveralls]]
=== Medical ===
* Tyvek [[Jumpsuit|coveralls]] are one-piece garments, usually white, commonly worn by mechanics, oil industry workers, painters, insulation installers, and laboratory and [[cleanroom]] workers wear disposable, one-time use [[Boilersuit|coverall]] is needed. They are also used for some light [[Dangerous goods|HAZMAT]] applications, such as [[asbestos]] and [[radiation]] work, but do not provide the protection of a full [[hazmat suit]]. Tychem is a sub-brand of Tyvek rated for a higher level of liquid [[Safety|protection]], especially from chemicals. DuPont makes Tyvek clothing in different styles from [[White coat|laboratory coats]] and aprons to complete head-to-toe coveralls with hoods and booties. The latter was notably used by the [[Japan Ground Self-Defense Force]] as emergency limited [[CBRN defense|CBRN]] gear during the [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster|Fukushima nuclear incident]].<ref>[http://jsw.newpacificinstitute.org/?p=7353 Boosting SDF’s Nuclear Accident Response Capabilities]. ''Japan Security Watch''. July 13th 2011. Accessed 11th October 2014.</ref> * Tyvek is also extensively used for packaging in laboratory and medical equipment as the material withstands conditions used to sterilize equipment.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=1982|title=New Products and Services|journal=Infection Control|volume=3|issue=4|pages=342–348|jstor=30146417|doi=10.1017/S0195941700056459|url=https://docs.lib.purdue.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1898&context=atg}}</ref> * [[NSW Police]], Australia uses Tyvek overalls to keep the integrity of alleged criminals' bodies at a crime scene, until they have had a chance to do body swabs.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dupont.co.za/products-and-services/personal-protective-equipment/chemical-protective-garments-accessories/case-studies/soco.html|title=Crime scene protection with DuPontTM Tyvek® {{!}} DuPont South Africa|last=workflow-process-service|website=www.dupont.co.za|language=en|access-date=2018-11-28}}</ref>
