revision.comment: Robot makes first contact with fuel debris
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} [[File:Fukushima I Nuclear Powerplant site close-up (wotext).PNG|thumb|Fukushima Daiichi I nuclear powerplant site close-up.]] [[File:Fukushima I nuclear accidents diagram.svg|thumb|Schematic representation of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear accidents.]] [[File:Fukushima I by Digital Globe.jpg|thumb|Following the 2011 Japanese [[Fukushima nuclear disaster]], authorities shut down the nation's 54 nuclear power plants. As of 2013, the Fukushima site remains [[Radiation effects from Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster|highly radioactive]], with some 160,000 evacuees still living in temporary housing, and some land will be unfarmable for centuries. The [[Fukushima disaster cleanup|difficult cleanup job]] will take 40 or more years, and cost many tens of billions of dollars, with total economic costs estimated at $250–$500 billion.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/mar/12/fukushima-nuclear-accident-lessons-for-us |title=Two years on, America hasn't learned lessons of Fukushima nuclear disaster |author=Richard Schiffman |date=12 March 2013 |work=The Guardian |location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/02/world/asia/02japan.html?_r=1&ref=world |title=Report Finds Japan Underestimated Tsunami Danger |author=Martin Fackler |date=June 1, 2011 |work=New York Times }}</ref><ref> {{cite web|url=http://www.smartplanet.com/blog/bulletin/the-staggering-costs-to-clean-up-fukushima/ |title=The Staggering Costs to Clean Up Fukushima|publisher=smartplanet.com|author=Tyler Falk|date=12 November 2013|accessdate=21 January 2014}}</ref>]]
'''Fukushima Dai-ichi''' (''dai-ichi'' means "#1"), is a multi-[[Nuclear reactor technology|reactor]] [[Nuclear power plant|nuclear power site]] in the [[Fukushima Prefecture]] of Japan. The [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster]] occurred after a [[Moment magnitude scale|9.0 magnitude]] [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami|Tōhoku earthquake and subsequent tsunami]] on 11 March 2011, only 14 days before the reactor was to be shut down. This offshore earthquake, near the island of [[Honshu Island|Honshu]],<ref> {{cite web |url=https://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/eqinthenews/2011/usc0001xgp/ |title=Magnitude 9.0 – near the East coast of Honshu, Japan |publisher=Earthquake.usgs.gov |accessdate=17 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5x7WfsrXn?url=http://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/eqinthenews/2011/usc0001xgp/ |archivedate=12 March 2011 |df=dmy-all }} </ref> produced a large [[tsunami]] in Japan, and a [[Tsunami warning system|tsunami warning]] for over 20 countries within and around the [[Pacific Rim]].
The earthquake triggered a [[scram]] shut down of the three active reactors at the [[Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant|Fukushima I Nuclear Power Plant]] (Fukushima Dai-Ichi). The ensuing tsunami crippled the site, stopped the Fukushima I backup [[diesel generator]]s, and caused a station [[power outage|blackout]]. The subsequent [[Loss-of-coolant accident|lack of cooling]] led to explosions and [[nuclear meltdown|meltdowns]] at the Fukushima I facility, with problems at three of the six reactors and in one of the six [[Spent nuclear fuel|spent-fuel pool]]s.
Times are given in [[Japan Standard Time]] (JST), unless noted, which is [[UTC+09:00|UTC plus nine hours]]. {{TOC limit|}}
==March 2011==
===Monday, 7 March=== [[Tokyo Electric Power Company]] (TEPCO) submits a report to Japan's nuclear safety agency which predicts the possibility of a tsunami up to 10.2 metres high at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant in the event of an earthquake similar to the [[1896 Sanriku earthquake|magnitude 7.2 earthquake with accompanying tsunami]] that devastated the area in 1896. TEPCO actually made this prediction in 2008 but delayed in submitting the report because they ''"did not feel the need to take prompt action on the estimates"''.<ref name="JAIF_Report_224">{{cite web|url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1317702304P.pdf|title=Earthquake report No. 224|publisher=JAIF|date=4 October 2011|accessdate=4 October 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111028152753/http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1317702304P.pdf|archivedate=28 October 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Friday, 11 March=== {{wikinews|8.9 magnitude earthquake hits Japan, causes tsunami}} * 14:46: A [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami|9.1 magnitude earthquake]] strikes off the coast of [[Honshu Island]] at a depth of about {{convert|24|km|mi}}. The [[Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant|Fukushima I]] power plant's nuclear reactors 1, 2, and 3 are automatically shut down by the tremor. Nuclear reactors 4, 5, and 6 were undergoing routine maintenance and were not operating (reactor 4 was defueled in November 2010). The tremor has the additional effect of causing the power plant to be cut off from the Japanese electricity grid; however, backup diesel generators kick in to continue cooling. * 14:52: Reactor 1's emergency cooling system, which is capable of running without external power, turns on automatically.<ref name="JAIF91">{{cite web |url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1306229916P.pdf |title=Earthquake Report No. 91 |publisher=JAIF |date=25 May 2011 |accessdate=23 June 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120103112327/http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1306229916P.pdf |archivedate=3 January 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * 15:03: Reactor 1's emergency cooling system is manually shut down to avoid reactor damage (temperature was not critical at this point).<ref name="JAIF91" /> * 15:27: The first tsunami strikes the plant.<ref>{{cite web | title=TEPCO details tsunami damage | url=http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/national/T110410003477.htm | archive-url=http://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20110410215841/http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/national/T110410003477.htm | dead-url=yes | archive-date=10 April 2011 | publisher=The Yomiuri Shimbun | accessdate=24 April 2011 }}</ref> * 15:30: The emergency condenser designed to cool the steam inside the pressure vessel of the No. 1 reactor fails.<ref name='m15'>[http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20110516p2a00m0na028000c.html The Mainichi Daily News] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520220937/http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20110516p2a00m0na028000c.html |date=20 May 2011 }} TEPCO admits nuclear meltdown occurred at Fukushima reactor 16 hours after quake</ref> * 15:46 (approximate): A {{convert|14|m|adj=on}} tsunami, unleashed by the earthquake, overtops the [[seawall]] designed to protect the plant from a [[tsunami]] of {{convert|5.7|m}}, inundating the Fukushima facility and disabling the backup diesel generators – all but one of which were housed underground – and washing away their fuel tanks.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/japan/8392730/Japan-nuclear-crisis-tsunami-study-showed-Fukushima-plant-was-at-risk.html |publisher=The Telegraph |title=Japan nuclear crisis: tsunami study showed Fukushima plant was at risk |date=19 March 2011 |accessdate=5 May 2011 |location=London |first=Richard |last=Gray}}</ref> With the loss of all electrical power supply, the low-pressure core spray, the residual heat removal and low-pressure coolant injection system main pumps, and the automatic depressurization systems all failed (most of the emergency core cooling system). Only the steam-powered pump systems (isolation condenser in reactor 1, high-pressure coolant injection and reactor core isolation cooling system in reactors 2 and 3) remained available. A subsequent investigation by NHK would later reveal that the isolation condenser units had not been tested or operated in over 40 years. Later, as the temperature rose, a system started that used steam-powered pumps{{Failed verification|date=May 2011}} and battery-powered valves.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/RS_Fukushima_faced_14-metre_tsunami_2303113.html |title=Fukushima faced 14-metre tsunami |date=23 March 2011|publisher=World Nuclear News |accessdate=24 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-13017282 |title=Fukushima: What happened – and what needs to be done |date=10 April 2011|publisher=BBC |accessdate=22 April 2011}}</ref>
According to a report in the ''New York Times'', "... at the start of the crisis Friday, immediately after the shattering earthquake, Fukushima plant officials focused their attention on a damaged storage pool for spent nuclear fuel at the No. 2 reactor at Daiichi, said a nuclear executive who requested anonymity ... The damage prompted the plant’s management to divert much of the attention and pumping capacity to that pool, the executive added. The shutdown of the other reactors then proceeded badly, and problems began to cascade."<ref>{{Cite news | title=In stricken fuel-cooling pools, a danger for the longer term | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/15/world/asia/15fuel.html?ref=asia |work=New York Times | accessdate=14 March 2011 | first1=William J. | last1=Broad | first2=Hiroko | last2=Tabuchi | date=14 March 2011}}</ref> * 16:00: The [[Nuclear and Industrial Safety Agency]] of Japan (NISA) initiates an emergency headquarters {{Clarify|date=August 2016|reason=Is headquarters the correct word to use?}} in an attempt to gather information on the 55 nuclear reactors in Japan.<ref name="FNAref2">{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-12722719 | title=Timeline: Japan power plant crisis | accessdate=15 March 2011 | date=13 March 2011 |work=BBC News}}</ref> There is no report that radiation was detected outside power-plant borders.<ref name="JAIF_earthquake_2">{{cite web|title=Earthquake report 2|url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/aij/member/2011/2011-03-11earthquake2.pdf|publisher=JAIF|date=11 March 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722121333/http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/aij/member/2011/2011-03-11earthquake2.pdf|archivedate=22 July 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> * 18:00: The falling water level in reactor 1 reaches the top of the fuel, and the core temperature starts climbing.<ref name="TEPCOCore">{{cite web |url=http://www.tepco.co.jp/en/press/corp-com/release/betu11_e/images/110515e10.pdf |publisher=TEPCO |title=Reactor core status of Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power station Unit 1 |date=15 May 2011 |accessdate=20 May 2011}}</ref> * 18:18: Reactor 1's emergency cooling system is once again back on.<ref name="JAIF91" /> * 19:03: Prime Minister [[Naoto Kan]] declares a nuclear emergency status<ref>{{cite web | title=Declaration of nuclear emergency | url=http://www.kantei.go.jp/foreign/topics/2011/20110311Nuclear_Emergency.pdf | publisher=Cabinet Secretariat, Cabinet Public Relations Office | accessdate=14 March 2011}}</ref> announced by [[Yukio Edano]], Chief Cabinet officer in Japan. [[Government of Japan|Japanese government]] officials try to comfort the people of Japan by telling them that the proper procedures are being undertaken. They also announce that no [[radioactive]] leaks have been detected.<ref name="FNAref2" /> * 19:30: The fuel in reactor 1 becomes fully exposed above the water surface, and fuel damage in the central core begins soon after.<ref name="TEPCOCore" /> * 21:00: An evacuation order is issued by the government to persons within a radius of {{convert|3|km|mi}} from the [[Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant|Fukushima I]] station. Those within a radius of {{convert|10|km|mi}} are told that they can remain in their homes, and carry on with regular activities, until told otherwise.<ref name="FNAref2" /> TEPCO announces that the pressure inside reactor unit 1 of Fukushima I is more than twice normal levels.<ref name="FNAref2" />
===Saturday, 12 March=== [[File:Fukushima accidents overview map.svg|thumb|right|Overview map showing evacuation and other zone progression and selected radiation levels.]] * 02:44: Emergency battery power for the high pressure core-flooder system (HPCFS) for reactor 3 runs out. * 04:15: Fuel rods in reactor 3 are exposed. * 05:30: Despite the high risk of hydrogen (produced from the water in the containment vessel) igniting after combining with oxygen from water or in the atmosphere, and in order to release some of the pressure inside the reactor at Fukushima I unit 1, the decision is taken to vent some of the steam (which contained a small amount of radioactive material) into the air. * 05:50: Fresh water injection into reactor 1 is started.<ref name="TEPCOCore" /> * 06:50: Although unknown at the time, the core of reactor 1 has now completely melted and falls to the bottom of the reactor pressure vessel.<ref name="TEPCOCore" /> * 10:09: TEPCO confirms that a small amount of vapor has been released into the air to release pressure in reactor unit 1 at Fukushima I.<ref name="BBC_timeline">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-12722719| title=Timeline: Japan power plant crisis|publisher=BBC News |accessdate=15 March 2011|date=13 March 2011}}</ref> * 10:58: Pressure still remains too high inside reactor unit 2 at Fukushima I. In order to alleviate some of this pressure, a consensus is reached to once more vent radioactive vapor into the air.<ref name="BBC_timeline" /> * 14:50: Fresh water injection into reactor 1 is halted.<ref name="TEPCOCore" /> * 15:30: Evacuation of residents within 3 km of Fukushima II and within 10 km of Fukushima I are underway.<ref name="IAEA-Tsunami-update-01">{{cite web|url=http://www.iaea.org/newscenter/news/tsunamiupdate01.html|title=IAEA update on Japan earthquake|publisher=IAEA|date=March 2011}}</ref> * 15:36: There is a massive explosion in the outer structure of unit 1. The concrete building surrounding the steel reactor vessel collapses as a result of the explosion; however no damage is believed to have been sustained to the reactor itself. Four workers are injured. {{Citation needed|date=October 2013}} * 19:00: Seawater injection into reactor 1 is started. TEPCO orders Daiichi to cease seawater injection at 19:25, but Daiichi plant boss [[Masao Yoshida (nuclear engineer)|Masao Yoshida]] orders workers to continue with the seawater injection.<ref name="TEPCOCore" /><ref>[[Kyodo News]], "[http://www.japantimes.co.jp/text/nn20111130x2.html Disregard Tepco order, boss told plant workers]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 30 November 2011, p. 1.</ref> * 21:40: The evacuation zone around Fukushima I is extended to 20 km, while the evacuation zone around Fukushima II is extended to 10 km.<ref name="IAEA-Tsunami-update-01" />
To release pressure within reactor unit 1 at Fukushima I, steam is released out of the unit into the air. This steam contains water vapor, hydrogen, oxygen and some radioactive material.
TEPCO engineers decided to directly inject seawater inside the pressure vessel of the reactors by means of the mobile trucks of the firemen. The pressure relief was also necessary to allow the firemen to inject seawater into the reactors vessels.
===Sunday, 13 March=== * 02:42: The high pressure coolant injection system for reactor 3 stops and, shortly thereafter, the water level within the reactor starts falling.<ref name="TEPCOCore2and3">{{cite web |url=http://www.tepco.co.jp/en/press/corp-com/release/betu11_e/images/110524e14.pdf |title=Status of cores at Units 2 and 3 in Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power station |publisher=TEPCO |date=23 May 2011 |accessdate=6 June 2011}}</ref> * 05:10: Fukushima I Unit 1 is declared as an INES Level-4 "accident with local consequences" event.<ref name="IAEA-Tsunami-update-01" /> * 07:00 (approximate): The water level in reactor 3 reaches the top of the fuel.<ref name="TEPCOCore2and3" /><!-- approximate value from graph --> * 09:00: Core damage starts occurring in reactor 3.<ref name="TEPCOCore2and3" /> A partial meltdown was reported to be possible at unit 3.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2011/03/13/partial-meltdown-possible-japan-nuclear-plant-death-toll-estimates-soar/ |title=Partial meltdown possible at Japan nuclear plant as death toll estimates rise to 10,000 |publisher=Fox News |date=7 April 2010 |accessdate=29 March 2011}}</ref> At 13:00 JST reactors 1 and 3 are vented to release overpressure and then re-filled with water and [[boric acid]] for cooling, and to inhibit further nuclear reactions.<ref name=TEPCO13-3:1>{{cite web|url=http://www.tepco.co.jp/en/press/corp-com/release/11031308-e.html|title=Press release 8|date=13 March 2011|publisher=TEPCO|accessdate=13 March 2011}}</ref> Unit 2 was possibly suffering a lower than normal water level, but was thought to be stable; although pressure inside the containment vessel was high.<ref name=TEPCO13-3:1/> The [[Japan Atomic Energy Agency]] announced that it was rating the situation at unit 1 as level 4 (an accident with local consequences) on the [[International Nuclear and Radiological Event Scale]].<ref name="IAEAtsunami1"/><ref name=autogenerated3>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/12/us-japan-quake-rating-idUSTRE72B2FR20110312|title=Japan rates quake less serious than Three Mile Island, Chernobyl|last=Maeda|first=Risa|date=12 March 2011|agency=Reuters |accessdate=12 March 2011}}</ref>
===Monday, 14 March=== {{wikinews|Japan suffers second reactor explosion, cooling issue at third reactor}} * 11:01: The unit 3 reactor building explodes, injuring six workers.<ref>{{Cite news|author=Justin McCurry|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/mar/14/japan-nuclear-explosion-second-reactor-fukushima|title=Explosion at Japanese nuclear plant|work=The Guardian |location=London|date=14 March 2011}}</ref> According to TEPCO there was no release of radioactive material beyond that already being vented, but blast damage affected the water supply to unit 2.<ref>{{Cite press release|title=White smoke around the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station unit 3 (2nd release)|publisher=[[Tokyo Electric Power Company]]|date=14 March 2011|url=http://www.tepco.co.jp/en/press/corp-com/release/11031402-e.html}}</ref> * 13:15: The reactor core isolation cooling system for reactor 2 stops and, shortly afterwards, the water level within the reactor starts falling.<ref name="TEPCOCore2and3" /> * 15:00: A major part of the fuel in reactor 3 drops to the bottom of the reactor pressure vessel.<ref name="TEPCOCore2and3" /> * 18:00 (approximate): The water level in reactor 2 reaches the top of the fuel.<ref name="TEPCOCore2and3" /><!-- approximate value from graph --> * 20:00: Core damage starts occurring in reactor 2.<ref name="TEPCOCore2and3" />
The president of the French nuclear safety authority, [[Autorité de sûreté nucléaire]] (ASN), said that the accident should be rated as a 5 (an accident with wider consequences) or even a 6 (a serious accident) on INES.<ref>[http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/03/14/japan-quake-nuclear-france-idUKLDE72D21I20110314 ] ''Reuters UK'' 15 March 2011</ref>
===Tuesday, 15 March=== {{wikinews|Third explosion at Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant}} * approx. 06:00 According to TEPCO, an explosion damaged the 4th floor area above the reactor and spent-fuel pool of the Unit 4 reactor.<ref name="TEPCO press release regarding Unit 4 explosion"> {{cite press release |url=http://www.tepco.co.jp/en/press/corp-com/release/11031504-e.html |title=Damage to the Unit 4 Nuclear Reactor Building at Fukushima Dai-ichi Nuclear Power Station |publisher=[[Tokyo Electric Power Company]] |date=15 March 2011 |accessdate=26 February 2013 }}</ref> * 11:00: A second explosion of reactor 3 (according to The World Meteorological Organization [http://www.wmo.int/pages/prog/www/DPFSERA/Meetings/CG-NERA_Vienna2011/documents/Doc-5-4-China.doc report]) * 20:00: A majority of the fuel in reactor 2 drops to the bottom of the reactor pressure vessel.<ref name="TEPCOCore2and3" /> Damage to the temporary cooling systems on unit 2 from the explosion in unit 3, plus problems with its venting system, meant that water could not be added to the extent that unit 2 was in the most severe condition of the three reactors.<ref name="unit2damaged">{{Cite news|author=Hiroko Tabuchi, Keith Bradsher, Matt Wald |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/15/world/asia/15nuclear.html|title=Japan faces prospect of nuclear catastrophe as workers leave plant|work=The New York Times |date=14 March 2011}}</ref> An explosion in the "pressure suppression room" causes some damage to unit 2’s containment system.<ref name="unit2damaged"/><ref>[http://english.kyodonews.jp/news/2011/03/78008.html Radiation shoots up at Fukushima nuke plant after blast heard] ''[[Kyodo News]]'' 15 March 2010</ref> A fire breaks out at unit 4. Radiation levels at the plant rise significantly but subsequently fall.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Container damaged, radiation leak feared at Fukushima No.2 reactor|agency=Kyodo News|date=15 March 2011|url=http://english.kyodonews.jp/news/2011/03/78063.html}}</ref> Radiation [[equivalent dose]] rates of 400 [[sievert|millisieverts]] per hour (400 mSv/h) are observed at one location in the vicinity of unit 3.<ref name="IAEAtsunami1">{{cite web|url=http://www.iaea.org/newscenter/news/tsunamiupdate01.html|title=IAEA update on Japan earthquake|quote=As reported earlier, a 400 millisieverts (mSv) per hour radiation dose observed at Fukushima Daiichi occurred between Units 3 and 4. This is a high dose-level value, but it is a local value at a single location and at a certain point in time. The IAEA continues to confirm the evolution and value of this dose rate. It should be noted that because of this detected value, non-indispensable staff was evacuated from the plant, in line with the Emergency Response Plan, and that the population around the plant is already evacuated.|accessdate=16 March 2011}}</ref><ref name="400_mSv">{{cite news |url=http://www.jiji.com/jc/c?g=soc_30&k=2011031500479 |script-title=ja:放射線、福島原発で４００ミリシーベルト＝「人体に影響及ぼす可能性」－官房長官 |language=Japanese |newspaper=[[jiji press]] |date=15 March 2011 |accessdate=15 March 2011 }}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref name="400_mSv_CNN">{{Cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/asiapcf/03/14/japan.nuclear.reactors/index.html?hpt=T1 |title=Radiation levels spike at Japanese nuclear plant |publisher=CNN |date=15 March 2011 |accessdate=15 March 2011}}</ref>
===Wednesday, 16 March=== {{wikinews|Fukushima reactor suffers multiple fires, radiation leak confirmed}} At approximately 14:30 [[TEPCO]] announces its belief that the fuel rod storage pool of unit 4 – which is located outside the containment area<ref name="autogenerated12">{{Cite news|last=Black|first=Richard|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-12762608 |title=Japanese emperor 'deeply worried' BBC News |publisher=BBC News|date=16 March 2011|accessdate=23 March 2011}}</ref> — may have begun boiling, raising the possibility that exposed rods could [[criticality accident|reach criticality]]. By midday NHK TV is reporting white smoke rising from the Fukushima I plant, which officials suggest is likely coming from reactor 3. Shortly afterwards all but a small group<ref>{{Cite news|last=Mackey|first=Robert|url=http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/03/15/latest-updates-on-japans-nuclear-crisis-and-earthquake-aftermath-2/?src=twt&twt=thelede#core-group-of-workers-remain-at-plant|title=Latest updates on Japan's nuclear crisis and earthquake aftermath |location=Japan |work=The New York Times|date=15 March 2011|accessdate=18 March 2011}}</ref> of remaining workers at the plant are placed on standby because of the radiation rising to a dangerous level of up to 1 Sv/h.<ref name=cbs1>{{Cite news|author=CBS/AP|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/03/15/501364/main20043621.shtml|title=Radiation spike hinders work at Japan nuke plant|publisher=CBS News|date= 15 March 2011|accessdate=18 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aolnews.com/2011/03/15/japan-nuclear-reactor-storage-pool-may-be-boiling/|title=Japan suspends work at stricken nuclear plant|publisher=aolnews.com|accessdate=26 June 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110611163226/http://www.aolnews.com/2011/03/15/japan-nuclear-reactor-storage-pool-may-be-boiling/|archivedate=11 June 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> TEPCO temporarily suspended operations at the facility.<ref>{{Cite news|author=Richard Black|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-12755739 |title=Fukushima workers withdraw after radiation spikes |publisher=BBC News|date= 16 March 2011|accessdate=18 March 2011}}</ref> A TEPCO press release states that workers had been withdrawn at 06:00 JST because of abnormal noises coming from one of the reactor pressure suppression chambers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tepco.co.jp/en/press/corp-com/release/11031604-e.html |title=Press release: Transfer of Fukushima Dai-ichi power station workers |publisher=TEPCO |accessdate=18 March 2011}}</ref> Late in the evening [[Reuters]] reports that water is being poured into reactors 5 and 6.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/16/japan-nuclear-plant-water-idUSTFD00670220110316 |title=Fukushima operator: pouring water into No. 5, 6 reactors |agency=Reuters |date= 16 March 2011|accessdate=18 March 2011}}</ref>{{Dubious|date=September 2011}}
===Thursday, 17 March=== During the morning Self-Defense Force helicopters drop water four times on the spent-fuel pools of units 3 and 4.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/feature/20110316-866921/news/20110317-OYT1T00422.htm |title=北沢防衛相「自衛隊ヘリの水投下、４回実施」 |work=Yomiuri Shimbun |location=Japan |accessdate=23 March 2011}}</ref> They measure radiation field of 3.75 Sv/h above Unit 3.<ref>http://pbadupws.nrc.gov/docs/ML1205/ML12052A109.pdf</ref> In the afternoon it is reported that the unit 4 spent-fuel pool was filled with water and none of the fuel rods were exposed.<ref>{{Cite news |script-title=ja:４号機プール内に大量の水、自衛隊ヘリ確認 |language=Japanese |work=Yomiuri Shimbun |date=17 March 2011 |url=http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/science/news/20110317-OYT1T00480.htm}}</ref> Construction work is started to supply a working external electrical power source to all six units of Fukushima I.<ref>{{Cite news |script-title=ja:冷却装置回復へ、原発に送電線引き込み工事開始 |language=Japanese |work=Yomiuri Shimbun |date=16 March 2011 |url=http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/feature/20110316-866921/news/20110317-OYT1T00487.htm}}</ref> Starting at 7 pm, police and fire water trucks attempt to spray water into the unit 3 reactor with high pressure hoses.<ref>Takahara, Kanako, and Alex Martin, "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110318a1.html Copters, trucks try to cool fuel rod pool]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 18 March 2011, p. 1.</ref> Japanese authorities inform the [[IAEA]] that engineers are laying an external grid power line cable to unit 2.<ref name=IAEAtsunami1/> After watching the helicopter effort on TV Kazunori Hasegawa, president of Chuo Construction, calls the government and offers the use of his two truck-mounted concrete boom pumps to spray water directly into the reactors. TEPCO did not respond for three days, and then stated it would wait for the arrival of similar pumps obtained elsewhere.<ref>Higgins, Andrew, "[https://www.washingtonpost.com/todays_paper/A%20Section/2011-04-20/A/6/18.0.2348772357_epaper.html Early disorder intensified Japan’s crisis]", ''[[Washington Post]]'', 19 April 2011. Retrieved 21 April 2011.</ref>
===Friday, 18 March=== {{wikinews|IAEA Clarifies: Fukushima nuclear cable has not been completed}} Tokyo Fire Department dispatches thirty fire engines with 139 fire-fighters and a trained rescue team at approximately 03:00 JST, including a fire truck with a 22-metre water tower.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www3.nhk.or.jp/nhkworld/ |title=NHK WORLD English |publisher=.nhk.or.jp |accessdate=18 March 2011}}</ref> For the second consecutive day, high radiation levels are detected in an area {{convert|30|km|mi}} northwest of the damaged Fukushima I nuclear plant at 150 μSv/h.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www3.nhk.or.jp/daily/english/18_25.html |title=NHK WORLD English |publisher=nhk.co.jp |accessdate=18 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xJ1uphia?url=http://www3.nhk.or.jp/daily/english/18_25.html |archivedate=19 March 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Japanese authorities upgrade INES ratings for cooling loss and core damage at unit 1 to level 5, and issue the same rating for units 2 and 3.<ref name="IAEAtsunami1"/> The loss of fuel pool cooling water at unit 4 is classified as a level 3.<ref name="IAEAtsunami1"/> In a 24-hour period ending at 11 am local time, radiation levels near the plant decline from 351.4 to 265 μSv/h, but it is unclear if the water spraying efforts were the cause of the decrease.<ref>Takahara, Kanako, and Kazuaki Nagata, "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110319a1.html Workers battle against time]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 19 March 2011, p. 1.</ref>
===Saturday, 19 March=== A second group of 100 Tokyo and 53 Osaka firefighters replaces the previous team. They use a vehicle that projects water from a height of 22 meters to cool spent nuclear fuel in the storage pool inside the reactor of unit 3.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www3.nhk.or.jp/daily/english/19_11.html|title=More Tokyo firefighters join the battle|date=19 March 2011|publisher=NHK|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110414184011/http://www3.nhk.or.jp/daily/english/19_11.html|archivedate=14 April 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>[http://www.iza.ne.jp/news/newsarticle/event/disaster/497757/ 放水支援で大阪市消防局部隊]{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}, Sankei newspaper 19 March 2011</ref> Water is sprayed into the reactor for a total of 7 hours during the day. TEPCO reports that the water was effective in lowering the temperature around the spent fuel rods to below 100 °C.<ref>''[[NHK]]'' (Evening news broadcast), 19 March 2011, 19:00.</ref>{{Verify source|date=March 2011}}
===Sunday, 20 March=== External power is reconnected to unit 2, but work continues to make the equipment operational. Repaired diesel generators at unit 6 provide power to restart the cooling on units 5 and 6, both of which are returned to [[cold shutdown]] and their fuel cooling ponds returned to normal operating temperatures.<ref name=WNN20>{{cite web|url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/RS_Stabilisation_at_Fukushima_Daiichi_2003111.html |title=Stabilisation at Fukushima Daiichi, update 2|publisher=World Nuclear News|date=20 March 2011}}</ref><ref name=report15>{{cite web|publisher=JAIF|url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1300579753P.pdf|title=Earthquake Report 15 (Chief Cabinet Secretary's Press briefing on March 20)|date=20 March 2011}}</ref> TEPCO announces that the pressure in reactor 3's containment vessel is rising, and that it might be necessary to vent air containing radioactive particles to relieve pressure, as reported by Japanese broadcaster NHK at 1:06.<ref name=WNN20/> The operation is later aborted as TEPCO deems it unnecessary.<ref name=WNN20/> While joining in a generally positive assessment of progress toward overall control, Japanese chief cabinet secretary Edano confirms, for the first time, that the heavily damaged and contaminated complex will be closed once the crisis is over.<ref name=NYT20>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/21/world/asia/21japan.html?_r=1 |title=Japan makes progress at nuclear reactors, but contamination spreads|work=The New York Times |date=20 March 2011|first1=Hiroko|last1=Tabuchi|first2=Norimitsu|last2=Onishi}}</ref>
===Monday, 21 March=== Ongoing repair work is interrupted by a recurrence of grey smoke from the south-east side of unit 3 (the general area of the spent-fuel pool) seen at 15:55 and dying down by 17:55. Employees are evacuated from unit 3, but no changes in radiation measurements or reactor status are seen. No work was going on at the time (such as restoring power) which might have accounted for the fire. White smoke, probably steam, is also seen coming from unit 2 at 18:22 JST, accompanied by a temporary rise in radiation levels. A new power line is laid to unit 4 and unit 5 is transferred to its own external power from a transmission line instead of sharing the unit 6 diesel generators.<ref name=NISA40>{{cite web |url=http://www.nisa.meti.go.jp/english/files/en20110322-1-1.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-04-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110501090831/http://www.nisa.meti.go.jp/english/files/en20110322-1-1.pdf |archivedate=1 May 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name=Kyodo80015>{{cite web|url=http://english.kyodonews.jp/news/2011/03/80015.html |title=Work to restore power delayed as smoke seen at Fukushima reactors, Kyodo News |publisher=English.kyodonews.jp |accessdate=23 March 2011}}</ref>
Officials learn that the crisis will not end with power recovery as the cooling pumps are damaged beyond repair and must be replaced. An emergency order was placed for new pumps for unit 2 which had suffered less damage than units 1 and 3.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://seetell.jp/2011/03/more-trouble-at-fukushima/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120718153121/http://seetell.jp/2011/03/more-trouble-at-fukushima/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=18 July 2012 |title=More trouble at Fukushima |publisher=Seetell.jp |accessdate=24 April 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.freedomsphoenix.com/News/086173-2011-03-21-fukushima-reactor-2-cooling-fails-pump-must-be-replaced.htm |title=Fukushima reactor 2 cooling fails: Pump must be replaced |publisher=Freedomsphoenix.com |accessdate=24 April 2011}}</ref>
===Tuesday, 22 March=== Smoke is still rising from units 2 and 3, but is less visible, and is theorized to be steam following operations to spray water onto the buildings. Repair work resumes, after having been halted because of concerns over the smoke; it is felt safe because no significant changes in radiation levels have occurred. Work continues to restore electricity, and a supply cable is connected to unit 4. Injection of seawater into units 1–3 continues.<ref name=NISA42>{{cite web |url=http://www.nisa.meti.go.jp/english/files/en20110322-3-1.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-04-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110322195213/http://www.nisa.meti.go.jp/english/files/en20110322-3-1.pdf |archivedate=22 March 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> External power cables are reported to be connected to all six units and lighting is back on again in the control room of unit 3.<ref>Hogg, Chris [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-12814871 Stop-start work at Japan reactors] BBC News Asia-Pacific, 22 March 2011, 15:44 GMT. Retrieved 22 March 2011</ref><ref>Marin, Alex, "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110323a1.html All reactors linked to outside power]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 23 March 2011, p. 1.</ref>
===Wednesday, 23 March=== Smoke again starts belching from reactor 3 in the late afternoon, this time black and grey smoke, causing another evacuation of workers from around the area. Aerial video <!--footage--> from the plant shows what appears to be a small fire at the base of the smoke plumes in the heavily damaged reactor building. Feed water systems in unit 1 are restored allowing an increase in the rate water that can be added to the reactor.<ref name=TEPCO23-3:23>{{cite web|url=http://www.tepco.co.jp/en/press/corp-com/release/11032303-e.html |title=Press release: Plant status of Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power station (as of 11:00 pm Mar 22nd) |publisher=TEPCO |accessdate=26 March 2011}}</ref> The Japanese Chief Cabinet Secretary also advises that high levels of radioactivity have been found in Tokyo's drinking water and that it should not be used to reconstitute baby formula as it is around twice the legal limit for children.<ref>Coren, Anna "[http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/asiapcf/03/23/japan.nuclear.crisis/index.html?iref=obinsite Bottled water scarce after Japan's tap water shown unsafe for infants]", CNN, 24 March 2011. Retrieved 24 March 2011.</ref>
===Thursday, 24 March=== Seawater injection to units 1, 2 and 3 continues,<ref name=TEPCO24>{{cite web|url=http://www.tepco.co.jp/en/press/corp-com/release/11032412-e.html|title=Press release|date=24 March 2011|work=TEPCO}}</ref> and radiation levels near the plant decline to 200 μSv/h,<ref name=TEPCO24_a>{{cite web|url=http://www.tepco.co.jp/en/nu/monitoring/11032413a.pdf|title=Press release|work=TEPCO|date=24 March 2011}}</ref> while lighting is restored to the unit 1 control room.<ref>{{cite web|author=Martin, Alex|url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110325a2.html|title=No. 3 cooling pump test-run readied|work=The Japan Times |location=Japan|date=25 March 2011|page=1}}</ref> Three workers are exposed to high levels of radiation which cause two of them to require hospital treatment, after radioactive water seeps through their protective clothes.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/03/24/501364/main20046609.shtml|title=3 Japan nuclear workers exposed to radiation|work=CBS News|date=24 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/science/la-sci-japan-workers-exposed-20110324,0,5425809.story|title=2 Japanese nuclear workers hospitalized for radiation exposure|work=LA Times|date=24 March 2011|first=Thomas H.|last=Maugh II}}</ref> The workers are exposed to an estimated equivalent dose of 2–6 Sv to the skin below their ankles.<ref name="kyodo81122"/><ref>{{Cite news |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/26/world/asia/26japan.html |title=Japan raises possibility of breach in reactor vessel |work=The New York Times |quote=The injured workers’ dosimeters suggested exposure to 170 millisieverts of radiation. But the institute said that the actual amount of radiation the workers are thought to have been exposed to in the water is 2 to 6 sievert. Even 2 sievert is eight times the 250 millisievert annual exposure limit set for workers at Daiichi. |accessdate=25 March 2011 |first1=Hiroko |last1=Tabuchi |first2=Keith |last2=Bradsher |first3=David |last3=Jolly |date=25 March 2011}}</ref> They were not wearing protective boots, as their employing firm's safety manuals "did not assume a scenario in which its employees would carry out work standing in water at a nuclear power plant".<ref name="kyodo81122">{{cite news |url=http://english.kyodonews.jp/news/2011/03/81122.html |title=2 of 3 radiation-exposed workers suffer internal exposure |agency=Kyodo News |location=Japan |accessdate=25 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5ykpp0m9m?url=http://english.kyodonews.jp/news/2011/03/81122.html |archivedate=17 May 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The activity concentration of the water is about 3.9 [[becquerel|GBq]]/L. Infra-red surveys of the reactor buildings, obtained by helicopter, show that the temperatures of units 1, 2, 3 and 4 continue to decrease, ranging from 11–17 °C, and the fuel pool at unit 3 is recorded at 30 °C.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www3.nhk.or.jp/daily/english/24_53.html|title=Surface temps of reactors continue to fall|work=NHK|date=24 March 2011|quote=Reactor temperatures as of 24 March 2011: No 1- 13, No 2- 13, No 3- 11, and No 4- 17 degrees|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110511114926/http://www3.nhk.or.jp/daily/english/24_53.html|archivedate=11 May 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Friday, 25 March=== [[Nuclear and Industrial Safety Agency|NISA]] announces a possible breach in the containment vessel of the unit 3 reactor, though radioactive water in the basement might alternatively have come from the fuel storage pool.<ref name=Bloomberg25>{{Cite news |title=Reactor core may be breached at damaged Fukushima plant |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/print/2011-03-22/nuclear-plant-s-fuel-rods-damaged-leaking-into-sea-tokyo-electric-says.html |publisher=Bloomberg |accessdate=25 March 2011 |author=Go Onomitsu and Takashi Hirokawa |date=25 March 2011}}</ref><ref name=Kyodo25>{{Cite news |title=High radiation leak suggests damage to No. 3 reactor vessel |url=http://english.kyodonews.jp/news/2011/03/80947.html |publisher=Kyodo|accessdate=25 March 2011}}</ref> Highly radioactive water is also found in the turbine buildings of units 1 and 2.<ref name="Kyodo possible 1&2 breach">{{Cite news|title=Japan reactor core may be leaking radioactive material, official says|url=http://english.kyodonews.jp/news/2011/03/81116.html|accessdate=25 March 2011|agency=Kyodo News Network|date=25 March 2011|location=Tokyo}}</ref> The US Navy sends a barge with {{convert|1890|m3|gal}} of fresh water, expected to arrive after two days.<ref name=USNavy25>{{cite web|url=http://www.navy.mil/search/display.asp?story_id=59318|title=US Navy to provide 500,000 gallons of fresh water to Fukushima power plant|date=25 March 2011|work=NAVY.mil}}</ref> Japan announces transportation will be provided in a voluntary evacuation zone of {{convert|30|km|mi}}. Tap water is reported to be safe for infants in Tokyo and [[Chiba, Chiba|Chiba]] by Japanese authorities, but still exceeds limits in [[Hitachi]] and [[Tokaimura]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/asiapcf/03/25/japan.nuclear.disaster/index.html|title=Japan encourages voluntary evacuations near stricken nuclear plant|publisher=CNN|date=25 March 2011}}</ref> Iodine-131 in the ocean near the plant measures 50,000 [[becquerel|Bq]]/L, 1,250 times normal levels.<ref name=CSmonitor>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/2011/0326/Radioactive-seawater-in-Japan-raises-new-fears-of-reactor-crack |title=Radioactive seawater in Japan raises new fears of reactor crack |publisher=CSMonitor.com |accessdate=27 March 2011}}</ref>
===Saturday, 26 March=== Fresh water becomes available again for use instead of seawater to top up reactor water levels.<ref name=11032602-e>{{cite web|url=http://www.tepco.co.jp/en/press/corp-com/release/11032602-e.html |title=Press Release (Mar 26, 2011) Plant status of Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power station (as of 10:30 am 26 Mar) (TEPCO press release) |publisher=Tepco.co.jp |accessdate=26 March 2011}}</ref> The fresh water is provided by two [[United States Navy]] barges holding a total of 2,280 metric tons of fresh water which were towed by the [[Japan Maritime Self-Defense Force]] from the [[United States Fleet Activities Yokosuka]] Naval Base to Fukushima.<ref>[http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/national/T110326003023.htm "Water-laden U.S. barge heading for Fukushima,"] ''Yomiuri Shimbun'' (Japan). 27 March 2011.</ref> Radiation levels near the plant decline to a still relatively high 170 μSv/h.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tepco.co.jp/en/nu/monitoring/11032606a.pdf |title=Monitoring data by a monitoring car at Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power station, measurement date: 03/26/2011 (TEPCO) |format=PDF |accessdate=26 March 2011}}</ref>
===Sunday, 27 March=== Levels of "over 1000" and 750 mSv/h are reported from water within unit 2 (but outside the containment structure) and 3 respectively. A statement that this level in unit 2 is "ten million times the normal level" were later retracted and attributed to incorrectly high levels of [[iodine-134]] (which is later reported to be below the limit by TEPCO).<ref name=WNN27>{{cite web|url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/RS_Contaminated_pools_to_the_drained_2703111.html|title=Contaminated pools to be drained |date=27 March 2011|work=World Nuclear News}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/la-fgw-japan-radiation-20110327,0,7935538.story|title=Officials retract reports of extremely high radiation at Fukushima plant|date=27 March 2011|work=Los Angeles Times|first1=Julie|last1=Makinen|first2=Kenji|last2=Hall}}</ref><ref name=TEPCO28>{{cite web|url=http://www.tepco.co.jp/en/press/corp-com/release/betu11_e/images/110327e15.pdf|title=Results of contamination check of water in the basement at the turbine building of Unit 2 of Fukushima Daiichi power station|date=29 March 2011|work=TEPCO}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Officials: Big spike at Japan nuke plant an error |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20110327/ap_on_bi_ge/as_japan_earthquake |agency=AP, Yahoo! News |accessdate=27 March 2011 |author=Yuri Kageyama and Mari Yamaguchi |date=27 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110405074653/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20110327/ap_on_bi_ge/as_japan_earthquake |archivedate=5 April 2011 }}</ref> Japan's Nuclear and Industrial Safety Agency indicate that "The level of radiation is greater than 1,000 millisieverts. It is certain that it comes from atomic fission ... But we are not sure how it came from the reactor."<ref>{{cite web|last=Nagata|first=Kazuaki|title=Radioactive pools block reactor repairs: 1 sievert readings in Unit No. 2 signal fission under way|url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110327x1.html|work=The Japan Times |accessdate=27 March 2011}}</ref> The high radiation levels cause delays for technicians working to restore the water cooling systems for the troubled reactors.<ref>Nagata, Kazuaki, "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110328a1.html Wild radiation spike in Unit No. 2 proves false]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 28 March 2011. Retrieved 28 March 2011.</ref> USAF technicians at Yokota AB complete the fabrication of compatibility valves to allow the connection of deployed pump systems to the existing infrastructure at Fukushima.<ref>{{cite web|author=Staff Sgt. J.G. Buzanowski|url=http://www.af.mil/news/story_print.asp?id=123248837|title=Yokota AB airmen play vital role in cooling Fukushima power plant|publisher=Af.mil|accessdate=29 March 2011|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120716134322/http://www.af.mil/news/story_print.asp?id=123248837|archivedate=16 July 2012|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> An aerial video recorded by a Ground Self-Defense Force helicopter reveals, according to NHK, the clearest and most detailed view of the damaged plant to date. Significant observations include:<ref>{{Cite news|title=Latest Fukushima plant video released|url=http://www3.nhk.or.jp/daily/english/27_26.html|accessdate=27 March 2011|newspaper=NHK (Japan Broadcasting Company)|date=27 March 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xWI2G8Me?url=http://www3.nhk.or.jp/daily/english/27_26.html|archivedate=28 March 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> :* White vapour, possibly steam, emanating from the buildings of reactors 2, 3, and 4. :* The roof of the reactor 2 building has been badly damaged but is still intact.
===Monday, 28 March=== The Japanese Nuclear Safety Commission states that it "assumed" melted fuel rods in unit 2 have released radioactive substances into the coolant water, which subsequently leaked out through an unknown route to the unit 2 turbine building basement. To reduce the amount of leaking water, TEPCO reduced the amount of water pumped into the unit 2 reactor, from 16 tons per hour to 7 tons per hour, which could lead to higher reactor temperatures. The highly radioactive water halts work on restoring the cooling pumps and other powered systems to reactors 1–4.<ref>Nagata, Kazuaki, and Kanako Takahara, "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110329a1.html Radioactive water keeps workers out]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 29 March 2011, p. 1.</ref> TEPCO confirms finding low levels of [[plutonium]] in five samples during 21 and 22 March.<ref>{{cite news|author=the CNN Wire Staff|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/asiapcf/03/28/japan.nuclear.plutonium/?hpt=T2|title=TEPCO says plutonium found on quake-damaged plant grounds|publisher=CNN|accessdate=7 April 2011|date=28 March 2011}}</ref> Enriched levels of [[Plutonium-238]], relative to [[Plutonium-239]] and [[Plutonium-240]], at two of the sites in the plant (solid waste area and field) indicate that contamination has occurred at those sites due to the "recent incident". Nonetheless, the overall levels of plutonium for all samples are about the same as background Pu levels resulting from atmospheric nuclear bomb testing in the past.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tepco.co.jp/en/press/corp-com/release/11032812-e.html|title=Press Release (Mar 28, 2011) Detection of radioactive material in the soil in Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station|publisher=Tepco.co.jp|date=28 March 2011|accessdate=7 April 2011}}</ref> However, these weapons did not use fuel that has decayed significantly. Such nuclear accidents as this one are a potent source of biologically accumulating isotopes of transuranic elements such as [[curium]] and [[americium]] which are incorporated into bones, complexed into the Ca/PO4 hydroxide.{{Citation needed|date=April 2012}}
===Tuesday, 29 March=== TEPCO continues to spray water into reactors 1–3 and discovers that radioactive runoff water is beginning to fill utility trenches outside the three reactor buildings. The highly radioactive water in and around the reactor buildings continues to limit progress of the technicians in restoring the cooling and other automated systems to the reactors.<ref>Matsutani, Minoru, "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110330a1.html Plutonium traces point to core leak]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 30 March 2011, p. 1.</ref>
===Wednesday, 30 March=== At a news conference TEPCO Chairman Tsunehisa Katsumata announces that it is unclear how the problems at the plant will be resolved. An immediate difficulty is the removal of large quantities of radioactive water in the basement buildings, but also salt build up inside the reactors, from using seawater for cooling, will need to be removed. Building concrete walls to enclose the reactors in a shield is being considered, as had been done at Chernobyl.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www3.nhk.or.jp/daily/english/30_39.html |title=TEPCO chief shows no road map to end nuke accident |publisher=NHK WORLD English |date=30 March 2011 |accessdate=7 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110402103547/http://www3.nhk.or.jp/daily/english/30_39.html |archivedate=2 April 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) finds radioactive iodine in milk in the United States.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fgw-japan-radiation-milk-20110331,0,7944812.story |title=Traces of radioactive iodine found in Washington state milk |accessdate=9 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110404021750/http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fgw-japan-radiation-milk-20110331%2C0%2C7944812.story |archivedate=4 April 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Thursday, 31 March=== Workers pump radioactive water from a utility trench near reactor 1 into a storage tank near reactor 4.<ref name="japantimes1">Takahara, Kanako, and Kazuaki Nagata, "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110401a1.html High radiation found outside no-go zone]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 1 April 2011, p. 1.</ref> Water in the condensers for reactors 2 and 3 is shifted to outside storage tanks so that the condensers can remove more contaminated water from inside the reactors.<ref>''[[Asahi Shimbun]]'', "TEPCO testing new ways to stop radioactive pollution from Fukushima", 1 April 2011.</ref> The world's largest concrete pumping truck is shipped from the United States to Fukushima.<ref name="augusta1">{{cite web|last=Pavey |first=Rob |url=http://chronicle.augusta.com/latest-news/2011-03-31/srs-concrete-pump-heading-japan-nuclear-site |title=SRS pump will head to Japan |publisher=Chronicle.augusta.com |accessdate=7 April 2011}}</ref> The truck has been slightly modified to be able to pump cooling water initially, then will later possibly to be used to pump concrete for any eventual permanent containment structure.<ref name="augusta1"/><ref name="world-nuclear-news2">{{cite web|url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/RS_Concrete_pumps_to_Fukushima_0104111.html |title=Concrete pumps to Fukushima |publisher=World-nuclear-news.org |date=1 April 2011 |accessdate=7 April 2011}}</ref> A 62-metre-tall pumping truck, donated by Chinese manufacturer [[SANY Group Company Ltd.|SANY]] is also used.<ref>{{cite web |author=寄給朋友 |url=http://hk.news.yahoo.com/article/110320/3/ncmx.html |script-title=zh:雅虎香港新聞 : 中國62米泵車助日射水 2011年3月21日 |publisher=Hk.news.yahoo.com |language=Chinese |accessdate=7 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110323204637/http://hk.news.yahoo.com/article/110320/3/ncmx.html |archivedate=23 March 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==April 2011==
===Friday, 1 April === TEPCO says that groundwater near unit 1 contains radioiodine at levels 10,000 times normal, but NISA later disputes the numbers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110401x1.html |title=Iodine 131 found in groundwater |work=The Japan Times |date=1 April 2011 |accessdate=7 April 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news| url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/asiapcf/04/02/japan.nuclear.status/ |publisher=CNN | title=Status report: Reactor-by-reactor at the Fukushima Daiichi plant | date=2 April 2011}}</ref> The Japanese government is reported to be considering injecting nitrogen into the reactor vessels.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.kyodonews.jp/news/2011/04/82625.html |title=Gov't eyes injecting nitrogen into reactor vessels to prevent blasts |publisher=English.kyodonews.jp |accessdate=7 April 2011}}</ref><ref name="kyodonews1">{{cite web|url=http://english.kyodonews.jp/news/2011/04/82827.html |title=Absorbent used to soak up radioactive water, 2 found dead at nuke plant |publisher=English.kyodonews.jp |accessdate=7 April 2011}}</ref> Two more concrete pumping trucks, used initially to pump cooling water, are shipped to Japan from the [[Putzmeister]] factory in Germany.<ref name="world-nuclear-news2"/>
===Saturday, 2 April === TEPCO observes for the first time that contaminated water from the unit 2 is flowing into the sea.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/03/world/asia/03japan.html|work=The New York Times|first1=Ken|last1=Belson|first2=Hiroko|last2=Tabuchi|title=Japan struggles to plug leak as radioactive water seeps into the sea|date=2 April 2011}}</ref> Workers discover a crack about 20 cm (8 inches) wide in the maintenance pit, which lies between the reactor 2 and the sea, and holds cables used to power seawater pumps. Workers were preparing to pour concrete into the crack to stop the water, which was emitting radiation at 1 Sv/h.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-12945525 |title=Radioactive water from Japan nuclear plant leaks in sea |publisher=BBC News |date=2 April 2011 |accessdate=7 April 2011}}</ref><ref name="IAEA020411">{{cite web|url=http://www.iaea.org/press/?p=1908|title=IAEA briefing on Fukushima nuclear accident (2 April 2011, 12:00 UTC)|accessdate=3 April 2011}}</ref>
===Sunday, 3 April=== The attempt to plug the leak near unit 2 fails when the concrete fails to set. TEPCO then reattempts to plug up the trench that leads to the damaged storage pit with a combination of [[superabsorbent polymer]], sawdust and shredded newspaper, which also fails.<ref>Takahara, Kanako, "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110404a1.html Two missing Tepco workers found dead]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 4 April 2011, p. 1.</ref> Radioactive water continues to leak into the sea. Radiation levels around the plant are estimated at 1 Sv/h and continue to decrease.<ref>''[[NHK]]'', "Radiation levels gradually decreasing", 3 April 2011.</ref><ref>''[[NHK]]'', "Radiation levels drop or remain flat", 4 April 2011.</ref>
TEPCO confirms the first deaths at the Fukushima facility, two workers who had been missing since 11 March and appear to have died in the basement of reactor 4 from bleeding due to multiple injuries inflicted by the tsunami.<ref name="kyodonews1"/><ref name="latimes1">{{cite news|last=Makinen |first=Julie |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-japan-quake-20110403,0,2146668.story |title= Two workers' bodies recovered at Fukushima nuclear plant |work=Los Angeles Times |date=3 April 2011 |accessdate=5 July 2011}}</ref>
Japanese government officials say the Daiichi plant may continue to release dangerous radiation into the air for several months.<ref name="washingtonpost1">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/japan-dumps-contaminated-water-into-pacific-leaks-to-go-on-for-months/2011/04/04/AFf1pLbC_story.html |title=Japanese utility dumps radioactive water into Pacific to ease storage woes |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=24 April 2011 |date=5 April 2011 |first=Joel |last=Greenberg}}</ref>
===Monday, 4 April=== TEPCO begins dumping water from storage tanks tainted with low levels of radioactivity into the Pacific Ocean on Monday night. Officials say this is needed to make room in a central waste facility to store water with a higher radioactive level. This more highly radioactive water is preventing workers from making progress on restoring the cooling and other systems to reactors 1–4.<ref>Takahara, Kanako, "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110405a1.html Tepco dumps toxic water into sea]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 5 April 2011, p. 1.</ref><ref>''[[NHK]]'', "Discharge of radioactive water into sea continues", 5 April 2011.</ref> Samples of seawater near the plant reveal radioactive [[caesium]] at 1.1 million times the legal limit.<ref name="latimes2">Hall, Kenji and Makinen, Julie, "[http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-japan-nuclear-20110406,0,2697428.story]", "[[Los Angeles Times]]", 5 April 2011.</ref>
The company says it could release up to 11,500 tons of radioactive water into the sea. A spokeswoman for Japan’s Nuclear and Industrial Safety Agency says the less-contaminated water must be disposed of so that workers can secure a place to store more highly contaminated water on the site.<ref name="washingtonpost1"/>
Engineers consider plans to inject inert [[nitrogen]] gas into the containment buildings of units 1, 2 and 3 to expel atmospheric [[oxygen]] and to dilute accumulated [[hydrogen]], which combine explosively.<ref>[http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-japan-reactor-damage-20110403,0,1606193.story Japanese nuclear plant continues its radioactive spill into ocean], ''Los Angeles Times''.</ref>
===Tuesday, 5 April=== It is determined that the leak into the cable storage pit from unit 2 was likely due to a faulty joint where the pit meets a duct. The pit leads to a gravel layer beneath, resulting in highly radioactive water pouring directly into the sea.<ref name=iaea1960>{{cite web|url=http://www.iaea.org/press/?p=1960 |title=IAEA Update on Fukushima Nuclear Accident (6 April 2011, 8:15 UTC) : IAEA Alert Log: Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Accident |publisher=Iaea.org |accessdate=24 April 2011}}</ref><ref name="lot">[http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-japan-nuclear-20110406,0,2697428.story Japan nuclear plant operator reports some success on leak], ''Los Angeles Times''.</ref>
Levels of radioactive [[iodine-131]] in seawater near the facility are found to be 7.5 million times the legal limit.<ref name="latimes2"/> TEPCO drills a hole into the pit near reactor 2, from which highly radioactive water is leaking, and injects [[water glass]] ([[sodium silicate]]) into the pit to prevent further leaking.<ref name="autogenerated14">''[[NHK]]'', "Radioactive water leak at Fukushima plant stops", 6 April 2011.</ref>
===Wednesday, 6 April=== TEPCO announces that an injection of {{convert|6000|L|gal}} of polymer coagulant into the pit mitigated the leaking;<ref>[http://www.tepco.co.jp/en/press/corp-com/release/11040603-e.html "Out flow of fluid containing radioactive materials to the ocean from areas near intake channel of Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station Unit 2,"] TEPCO Press Release. 6 April 2011. Retrieved 8 April 2011.</ref> however, the IAEA and others credit additional factors.<ref>[http://www.iaea.org/press/?p=1960 "IAEA Update (6 April 2011, 8:15 UTC),"] retrieved 8 April 2011; [http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/RS-Fukushima_leak_plugged_nitrogen_considered-0604117.html "Fukushima leak plugged; nitrogen approved,"] ''World Nuclear News'' (UK). 6 April 2011. Retrieved 8 April 2011.</ref> Sodium silicate ("water glass") and additives are injected into the ground in order to stop the leakage of radioactive water.<ref>Daily Mail Reporter. [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1373901/Fukushima-nuclear-power-plant-Liquid-glass-used-plug-leak.html#ixzz1IlSiOwOk "Liquid glass successfully plugs radioactive leak at crippled Fukushima nuclear plant"], ''Daily Mail'' (UK). 6 April 2011. Retrieved 8 April 2011.</ref> The residual heat carried by the water used for cooling the damaged reactors accelerates the setting of the injected mixture.
Despite protests from the South Korean government, Russian scientists, and Japanese fishermen, Japan authorizes the release of {{convert|11500|tonne}} of less radioactive water into the ocean to make room to store the more highly contaminated water.<ref name="lot"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110406x6.html |title=Japan defends radical decision to dump toxic water in Pacific |work=The Japan Times |date=6 April 2011 |accessdate=24 April 2011}}</ref>
Iodine-131 levels reach 7.5 million times the legal limit in a seawater sample taken near the facility.<ref name="lot"/>
TEPCO announces that the leak of highly radioactive water from the utility pit near reactor 2 has stopped.<ref name="autogenerated14"/> According to U.S. Representative Ed Markey, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission says that the core of unit 2 has become so hot that part of it has melted through the reactor pressure vessel;<ref>Rampton, Roberta and Rascoe, Ayesha."[http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/04/06/us-japan-markey-idUKTRE7353Y820110406]" "[[Reuters]]", "Japan No 2 core melted through reactor vessel: Rep. Markey", 6 April 2011.</ref> however, a NRC spokesperson says, "That's not clear to us, nor is it clear to us that the reactor has penetrated the vessel."<ref>{{cite web|last=Rampton |first=Roberta |url=http://ca.news.yahoo.com/japan-no-2-core-melted-reactor-vessel-rep-20110406-074109-708.html |title=NRC says not clear that Japan reactor has melted vessel – Yahoo! News |publisher=Ca.news.yahoo.com |accessdate=7 April 2011}}</ref> TEPCO begins injection of nitrogen into unit 1 to lower the possibility of hydrogen explosions.<ref name="Yamaguchi">{{cite news | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/04/06/japan-nuclear-crisis-prevent-hydrogen-explosions_n_845908.html | title=Japan nuclear crisis: Workers focus on preventing more hydrogen explosions | work=Huffington Post | location=USA from AP | date=6 April 2011 | accessdate=6 April 2011 | author=Yamaguchi Mari | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110407100510/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/04/06/japan-nuclear-crisis-prevent-hydrogen-explosions_n_845908.html | archivedate=7 April 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Thursday, 7 April=== Nitrogen injection into the pressure containment vessel of unit 1 commences at 01:31.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tepco.co.jp/en/press/corp-com/release/11040709-e.html |title=Plant Status of Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station (as of 7:00 pm, April 7)|publisher=TEPCO |accessdate=7 April 2011}}</ref>
Workers are evacuated following a magnitude 7.1 aftershock off the north-eastern coast of Japan, 118 kilometers from the plant. TEPCO reports communications and power were not affected and no additional damage was observed as a result.<ref>{{cite news|author=the CNN Wire Staff |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/asiapcf/04/07/japan.quake/index.html?hpt=T2 |title=Fresh aftershock in Japan rouses fear, kills 2 |publisher=CNN |accessdate=24 April 2011 |date=8 April 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/recenteqsww/Quakes/usc0002ksa.php |title=Magnitude 7.1 – Near the East coast of Honshu, Japan |publisher=Earthquake.usgs.gov |accessdate=24 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110414005120/http://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/recenteqsww/Quakes/usc0002ksa.php |archivedate=14 April 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> A tsunami warning is also issued, but is lifted after 90 minutes. Most of the workers at the nuclear plant were evacuated.{{Citation needed|date=April 2011}}
Official measures at Fukushima I reactor unit 1, however, show a rise in temperature following the aftershock and a spiking amount of radiation in the Dry Well, which exceeds the instrument maximum of 100 Sv/h.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://atmc.jp/plant/rad/?n=1 |title=Unit 1 nuclear power plant Fukushima Radiation |publisher=TEPCO |accessdate=8 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110408070037/http://atmc.jp/plant/rad/?n=1 |archivedate=8 April 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Gauge B, in the meantime, records a steady increase in pressure for the previous ten days in the same reactor.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://atmc.jp/plant/vessel/?n=1 |title=Unit 1 nuclear power plant Fukushima Pressure |publisher=TEPCO |accessdate=8 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110410002940/http://atmc.jp/plant/vessel/?n=1 |archivedate=10 April 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Reporting the rise to 100 Sv/h from the earlier 30 Sv/h, TEPCO declares that the "validity of the measurement is questioned" both for radiation levels and pressure.
===Friday, 8 April=== Before the crisis evaluation was elevated by Japanese authorities to level 7, the highest level, experts already recognized that Fukushima is the most complicated nuclear accident.<ref>DiSavino, Scott. [https://www.reuters.com/article/us-nuclear-japan-month-idUSTRE7377I120110408 "Analysis: A month on, Japan nuclear crisis still scarring,"] Reuters (UK). 8 April 2011. Retrieved 26 March 2017.</ref>

|url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1302175357P.pdf |publisher=JAIF |accessdate=7 April 2011 |date=7 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110513003413/http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1302175357P.pdf |archivedate=13 May 2011 |df=dmy-all }} </ref><ref name=jaif20110408T2000JST> {{Cite web |title=Status of nuclear power plants in Fukushima as of 20:00 JST on 8 April |url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1302260293P.pdf |publisher=JAIF |accessdate=8 April 2011 |date=8 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110513003506/http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1302260293P.pdf |archivedate=13 May 2011 |df=dmy-all }} </ref> |}
===Saturday, 9 April=== Japan still struggles to keep water on the reactors to cool them and prevent further meltdown. Russian [[Antonov An-124]] cargo planes fly out of Atlanta and Los Angeles, each carrying a huge concrete boom pump. The two 95-ton boom pumps, which TEPCO purchased for $2million each, can be operated from two miles away by remote control. Each boom pump can direct focused streams of water into the damaged reactors.<ref name="Longbottom">Longbottom, Wil. [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1375120/Massive-cargo-plane-transports-2m-remote-controlled-concrete-pump-stricken-Japanese-nuclear-plant.html "Massive cargo plane transports £2m remote-controlled concrete pump to stricken Japanese nuclear plant,"] ''Daily Mail'' (UK). 9 April 2011. Retrieved 11 April 2011; [http://www.thestreet.com/story/11077371/1/worlds-largest-concrete-boom-pumps-en-route-to-japan-to-help-cool-nuclear-reactors.html "World's largest concrete boom pumps en route to Japan to help cool nuclear reactors"], ''The Street'' (US). 9 April 2011. Retrieved 11 April 2011.</ref>
TEPCO does not plan to take a Chernobyl approach to resolving the nuclear power plant crisis by entombing the radioactive material in concrete.<ref>[http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20110408p2a00m0na005000c.html "TEPCO won't take Chernobyl approach to resolving nuclear power plant crisis,"] ''Mainichi Shimbun'' (Japan). 8 April 2011. Retrieved 11 April 2011.</ref> If this decision were to change, the boom pumps could be retrofitted to deliver concrete for that purpose.<ref name="Longbottom"/>
Prior to the elevation to level 7 by the Japanese authorities [[James M. Acton|James Acton]], Associate of the Nuclear Policy Program at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, was of the opinion that "Fukushima is not the worst nuclear accident ever but it is the most complicated and the most dramatic, {{sic|This}} was a crisis that played out in real time on TV. Chernobyl did not."<ref>[https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20110414005117/http://in.ibtimes.com/articles/132391/20110409/japan-nuclear-crisis-radiation.htm "Analysis: A month on, Japan nuclear crisis still scarring,"] ''International Business Times'' (Australia). 9 April 2011. Retrieved 12 April 2011.</ref>
A survey of radiation in seawater outside unit 2 shows radioactive isotope concentrations ([[iodine-131]], [[caesium-134]] and [[caesium-137]]) falling for the third consecutive day since the leak was plugged. However, the levels are still high at several thousand times legal levels. Other nuclides are being investigated, but Japanese regulator NISA has flagged up problems with TEPCO's sampling methodology.<ref name="neimagazine1">{{cite web |url=http://www.neimagazine.com/story.asp?sectionCode=72&storyCode=2059373 |title=Nuclear Engineering International |publisher=Neimagazine.com |date=12 April 2011 |accessdate=24 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120319191628/http://www.neimagazine.com/story.asp?sectionCode=72&storyCode=2059373 |archivedate=19 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Monday, 11 April=== Coolant injection into reactors 1 and 3 is interrupted for 50 minutes due to a loss of power after a strong earthquake.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.kyodonews.jp/news/2011/04/84640.html |title=Restoration work at Fukushima plant suffers setback in Monday quake |agency=Kyodo News |accessdate=11 April 2011}}</ref>
Workers plan to pump water into turbine condensers, but need to pump water out of them first. Work to transfer water from the unit 2 and unit 1 condensers to a central storage tank was completed on 9 and 10 April. Workers have also knocked holes through the turbine hall buildings of units 2 and 4 to accommodate hoses for the water transfer. At unit 3, work continues to make space for water in the turbine condenser by pumping existing water into other tanks. Japanese news wire NHK reports that workers are laying hoses to transfer water to an LLW waste processing facility, which continues to be inspected. TEPCO says that it cannot start work switching on emergency systems on site until the turbine hall is dry. NHK also reported that radioactive water filling a tunnel near unit 2 has risen 12 cm since a leak in a trench was stopped on Wednesday 6 April.<ref name="neimagazine1"/>
===Tuesday, 12 April=== Japan officially raises Fukushima to INES Level 7, the same as [[Chernobyl disaster|Chernobyl]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www3.nhk.or.jp/daily/english/12_19.html|title=Nuclear accident level raised to maximum|publisher=NHK World|date=12 April 2011|accessdate=12 April 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110314044445/http://www3.nhk.or.jp/daily/english/12_19.html|archivedate=14 March 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Fukushima Accident Upgraded to Severity Level 7|url=http://spectrum.ieee.org/tech-talk/energy/nuclear/fukushima-accident-upgraded-to-severity-level-7/|publisher=[[IEEE Spectrum]]|date=12 April 2011}}</ref> This new rating considers the accidents as a single event and uses estimated total release to the atmosphere as a justification.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=IAEA|url=http://www.iaea.org/newscenter/news/tsunamiupdate01.html|title=Fukushima Nuclear Accident Update Log|date=12 April 2011|accessdate=13 April 2011}}</ref>
Following the hydrogen explosion in the reactor 1 building on 12 March and releases from the reactor 3 building, the equivalent of 190,000 terabecquerels of radioactive iodine had been released from the reactor buildings by 15 March, according to calculations by the Nuclear Safety Commission of Japan. A terabecquerel is equivalent to 1 trillion becquerels. The high level meant that by 15 March the Fukushima plant accident had already reached the worst level 7 on the International Nuclear and Radiological Event Scale, matching the assessment given to the 1986 Chernobyl nuclear disaster.<ref>{{cite news|title=High radiation levels detected at Fukushima grounds a month after explosions|date=26 April 2011|url=http://www.asahi.com/english/TKY201104250130.html}}</ref> Since that time the Fukushima reactors have continued to emit radiation; including atmospheric, water, and gamma ray releases.
At Chernobyl, approximately 10 times the amount of radiation was released into the atmosphere as was released from Fukushima I through 12 April 2011.<ref>{{cite news|author=Tran, Mark|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/apr/12/japan-fukushima-chernobyl-crisis-comparison|title=Nuclear crises: How do Fukushima and Chernobyl compare?|work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=12 April 2011|accessdate=13 April 2011}}</ref> The total amount of radioactive material still stored at Fukushima is about 8 times that stored at Chernobyl, and leakage at Fukushima continues.
After cooling efforts at spent-fuel pool 4 were halted, due to an erroneous warning about the pool filling up,<ref>{{cite web|title=Japan Plant Emits More Radiation After Cooling Lapse |url=http://www.globalsecuritynewswire.org/gsn/nw_20110414_5466.php |publisher=NTI |accessdate=17 April 2011}}</ref> the temperature of the pool rises to 90 °C and the dose rate 6 meters above the pool spikes at 84 mSv/h.<ref>{{cite web|title=Radiation surges above 4's fuel pool |url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110413x1.html |work=The Japan Times |accessdate=17 April 2011}}</ref>
===Friday, 15 April=== Nuclear fuel is reported to have melted and fallen to the lower containment sections of reactors 1, 2 and 3. The melted material is not expected to breach a container (which might cause a massive radiation release). Instead, the melted fuel is thought to have dispersed fairly uniformly across the lower portions of the containers of the three reactors, which would make the resumption of the fission process, to the extent of a [[criticality accident|recriticality]] accident, 'most unlikely';<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globalsecuritynewswire.org/gsn/nw_20110415_5020.php |title= Japan plant fuel melted partway through reactors: Report |publisher=Globalsecuritynewswire.org |date=15 April 2011 |accessdate=24 April 2011}}</ref> however, it is only during future dismantling of the three damaged reactors that it would be possible to verify this hypothesis and to know what really occurred inside the reactor cores.
===Saturday, 16 April=== Plans are announced for a large-scale study on the environmental and health effects of radioactive contamination from the nuclear plant. Academics and researchers from across Japan will work with the Fukushima Prefectural Government starting in May.<ref name="JTO">{{cite web | url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110416a4.html | title=Scholars eye extensive study on nuclear crisis | publisher=Tokyo Times (Japan) | date=16 April 2011 | accessdate=16 April 2011}}</ref>
===Monday, 18 April=== The Associated Press reports that two [[PackBot]] ground robots from [[iRobot]] have entered unit 1 and unit 3 of the crippled Fukushima nuclear power plant and performed temperature, pressure, and radioactivity measurements. The remote-controlled robots entered the two reactors over the preceding weekend. The devices opened closed doors and explored the insides of the reactor buildings, coming back with radioactivity readings of up to 49 mSv/h inside unit 1 and up to 57 mSv/h inside unit 3. TEPCO officials say that the radiation data from the robots do not change their plans for shutting down the plant by the end of this year. Though more robots will be used, a TEPCO official, Takeshi Makigami, says that robots are limited in what they can do, and eventually "people must enter the buildings".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://spectrum.ieee.org/automaton/robotics/industrial-robots/robots-enter-fukushima-reactors-detect-high-radiation |title=Robots enter Fukushima reactors, detect high radiation – IEEE Spectrum |publisher=Spectrum.ieee.org |accessdate=24 April 2011}}</ref> Robots also entered unit 2, but the probe was hindered by fogging of the robot's camera lens from the high humidity, over 90%, inside the building.<ref name="jaif.or.jp-1">{{cite web |url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1305711249P.pdf |title=Earthquake Report No. 85 |publisher=JAIF |date=18 May 2011 |accessdate=18 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111011180610/http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1305711249P.pdf |archivedate=11 October 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Test spraying of an "[[anti-scattering agent]]" on the ground to prevent further spread of radioactive materials from the site is carried out over an area of about 1200 m<sup>2</sup>.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nisa.meti.go.jp/english/files/en20110418-2-1.pdf |title=Seismic damage information (the 100th Release) (as of 15:00 April 18th, 2011) |publisher=TEPCO |accessdate=18 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110428013646/http://www.nisa.meti.go.jp/english/files/en20110418-2-1.pdf |archivedate=28 April 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Tuesday, 19 April=== TEPCO begins transferring excess radioactive cooling water from the reactor 2's basement and maintenance tunnels to a waste processing facility.<ref>Bradsher, Keith and Hiroko Tabuchi. [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/20/world/asia/20japan.html?scp=1&sq=removal%20of%20radioactive%20water%20begins&st=cse "Water pumping begins at Japan nuclear reactor"] ''New York Times'' (US). 20 April 2011, retrieved 2011; "Transfer of highly contaminated water begins", NHK (Japan). 19 April 2011.</ref>  Operations to pump radioactive water in the basements of buildings of units 1, 2, 3 and their associated tunnels start with unit 2.<ref name="jaif.or.jp">{{cite news|url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1304303809P.pdf|newspaper=JAIF|date=2 May 2011}}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}</ref>
===Friday, 22 April=== Japanese Prime Minister Naoto Kan states additional towns might be asked to evacuate, which largely involves agricultural lands.<ref>{{cite news|last=Williams|first=Martyn|title=Japan expands evacuation zone around nuclear plant|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/asia/east-pacific/Japan-Expands-Evacuation-Zone-Around-Fukushima-Daiichi-Plant-120445924.html|accessdate=22 April 2011|newspaper=VOANews.com|date=22 April 2011}}</ref>  The government also plans to build 30,000 temporary homes by the end of May, and an additional 70,000 will follow.
The president of the Tokyo Electric Power Company (TEPCO), Masataka Shimizu, formally apologizes at the prefectural government office in Fukushima to the Fukushima Governor Yuhei Sato for the nuclear crisis following the 11 March 2011 earthquake and tsunamis.<ref>{{cite news|title=TEPCO president apologizes to Fukushima governor for nuke crisis|url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90851/7359141.html|accessdate=22 April 2011|newspaper=People's Daily Online (Xinhua)|date=<!-- 15:34 --> 22 April 2011}}</ref> In response, the Governor requests better working conditions for the workers.
