===Tuesday, 26 April=== To prevent the proliferation of dust, TEPCO initiates spraying a synthetic resin to contain contaminated dust.<ref name="jaif.or.jp"/>
===Wednesday, 27 April=== Junichi Matsumoto, a general manager at Tokyo Electric Power Co., reports that radiation readings taken by two [[iRobot]] [[PackBot]] robots inside the reactor 1 building are as high as 1120 mSv/h, the highest level disclosed to date.<ref>{{cite news|title=Radiation readings in Fukushima reactor rise to highest since crisis began|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-04-27/tokyo-water-radiation-falls-to-zero-for-first-time-since-crisis.html|accessdate=27 April 2011|publisher=Bloomberg|date=<!-- 09:14:54 --> 27 April 2011|first1=Tsuyoshi|last1=Inajima|first2=Michio|last2=Nakayama}}</ref>
==May 2011==
===Monday, 2 May=== T. Matsui of the University of Tokyo Institute of Physics releases a scientific paper analysing the ratio of iodine-131 to caesium-137 taken from water samples, which concludes that a recriticality may have occurred at least 10–15 days after the attempted shutdown.<ref>{{cite journal|arxiv=1105.0242 |title=Deciphering the measured ratios of Iodine-131 to Cesium-137 at the Fukushima reactors |date=2 May 2011|author1=Matsui|doi=10.1143/PTP.126.1167|volume=126|issue=6 |journal=Progress of Theoretical Physics|pages=1167–1176|bibcode=2011PThPh.126.1167M }}</ref>
===Thursday, 5 May=== Workers enter the reactor 1 building. This is the first time since the start of the crisis that a reactor building in the plant is visited by a human being. The workers will connect a ventilation system that should absorb radiation inside the building for the next 4–5 days, allowing them to start installation of the cooling system replacement. Because of protective gear, the workers are only exposed to a small amount of radiation (about 2 mSv).<ref>Tomoka A Hosaka (2011)[http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2069695,00.html Workers Enter Fukushima Reactor Building]. ''TIME''.</ref> TEPCO expects to bring the plant into a cold shutdown within six to nine months. IAEA releases a briefing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slideshare.net/iaea/technical-briefing-11-0505|title=Summary of reactor unit status – 5 May 2011|author=International Atomic Energy Agency|publisher=|accessdate=18 February 2015}}</ref>
===Tuesday, 10 May=== In a press release,<ref>{{cite web|date=10 May 2011|title=TEPCO Press Release (May 10, 2011): Results of nuclide analyses of (radioactive materials in the) water in spent-fuel pool of unit 3 at Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power station|url=http://www.tepco.co.jp/en/press/corp-com/release/11051009-e.html}}</ref> [[TEPCO]] reports that levels of [[caesium-134]], [[caesium-136]], [[caesium-137]], and [[iodine-131]] (half-life of ~ 8 days), had spiked since last sampled on 2 March 2011, when these four [[nuclides]] were below detection limits. TEPCO's report<ref>TEPCO Press Release (10 May 2011): Results of nuclide analyses of radioactive materials in the water in the spent-fuel pool of unit 3 at Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station: http://www.tepco.co.jp/en/press/corp-com/release/betu11_e/images/110510e12.pdf</ref> gives the newly measured concentration ([[Bq]]/cm<sup>3</sup>) of each [[nuclide]] as of sampling date, 8 May.
===Thursday, 12 May=== TEPCO engineers confirm that a meltdown occurred, with molten fuel having fallen to the bottom of the reactor's containment vessel.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/japan/8509502/Nuclear-meltdown-at-Fukushima-plant.html |title=Nuclear meltdown at Fukushima plant |date=12 May 2011|author=Julian Ryall |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=London}}</ref> The utility says fuel rods of the No. 1 reactor are fully exposed with the water level 1 meter (3.3 feet) below the base of the fuel assembly. The government and TEPCO are described as "''consistently appeared to be underestimating the severity of the situation.''" According to a Japanese press report, there are holes in the base of the pressure vessel, and most of the fuel has likely melted. The nuclear fuel has possibly leaked into the containment vessel, which was damaged by an explosion during the crisis.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-05-12/japan-suffers-setback-at-fukushima-after-no-1-reactor-s-fuel-rods-exposed.html |title=Japan Reactor-Core Damage Worse Than Thought |date=12 May 2011|author=Joe Carroll and Michio Nakayama |publisher=Bloomberg }}</ref> However, the [[Nuclear Energy Institute]], a nuclear lobbying firm, states that the situation "''is in no way alarming. It was anticipated that there was fuel damage in reactors 1, 2 and 3. This is confirmation.''"<ref name="CNN Wire Staff">{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/asiapcf/05/12/japan.nuclear.reactors/?hpt=T2|newspaper=CNN|date=12 May 2011|title=Low reactor water level may have caused fuel rods to melt}}</ref> <!-- I'll try to update this entry to reflect Radio Australia instead of CNN. -->
===Saturday, 14 May=== A third TEPCO (contractor) employee dies, after falling ill at 06:50, being brought to the plant's medical room unconscious.  The likely cause of death is a heart attack.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2011/05/14/Fukushima-death-not-from-radiation-TEPCO/UPI-11591305376358/|title=Fukushima death not from radiation: TEPCO|newspaper=UPI}}</ref>  TEPCO says he was exposed to 0.17 millisieverts of radiation on Saturday. <ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43031447/ns/world_news-asiapacific/|newspaper=Reuters|title=Third worker dies at Japan's troubled nuclear plant}}</ref>
===Sunday, 15 May=== A robot sent to the first floor of unit 1 records a radiation level of 2,000 mSv/h. At this level, workers would only be allowed to stay in the area for 8 minutes. In addition, the reactor's containment vessel is leaking large amounts of water into the basement. A TEPCO worker is able to peer into the basement and determines that the 11 m deep basement is approximately half full of water.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/15/japan-nuclear-idUSL4E7GF00T20110515 |publisher=Reuters |title=Japan readies new tactics for Fukushima after setback |date=15 May 2011 |accessdate=22 May 2011}}</ref>
TEPCO releases a report on the core status of reactor 1, revealing that fuel elements had become exposed above the water just 4 hours after the earthquake and [[SCRAM]], and had fully melted after 16 hours.<ref name="TEPCOCore" />
===Wednesday, 18 May=== Four workers in protective suits and [[SCBA]] enter unit 2 for the first time since the 15 March explosion, to check on radiation levels and other conditions inside the building. The workers receive a dose of between 3 and 4 mSv each.<ref name="jaif.or.jp"/>
===Friday, 20 May=== [[TEPCO]] president Masataka Shimizu resigns after reporting the largest financial losses in the company's history.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/japan/8526489/Tepco-president-resigns-over-Japan-nuclear-crisis.html|title=Tepco president resigns over Japan nuclear crisis |publisher=Telegraph |date=20 May 2011 |accessdate=29 June 2011 |location=London}}</ref>
===Sunday, 22 May=== [[TEPCO]] reports that reactor 3 leaked at least 250 tons of radioactive water into the Pacific Ocean over a period of 41 hours beginning on 10 May 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2011/05/22/Japan-reports-more-radiation-leakage/UPI-28701306071295|title=Japan reports more radiation leakage |publisher=UPI.com |date=22 May 2011 |accessdate=22 May 2011}}</ref>
===Tuesday, 24 May=== On the eve of the arrival in Tokyo of a delegation from the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]], [[TEPCO]] admits that the cores of reactor 2 and reactor 3 also melted down in the days immediately following the earthquake in mid-March 2011.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/may/24/japan-nuclear-plant-more-meltdowns|title=Japan nuclear plant confirms meltdown of two more reactors; Fukushima Daiichi operator accused of delaying announcement of meltdowns in reactors 2 and 3 as IAEA inspectors arrive|work=The Guardian|date=24 May 2011 |accessdate=24 May 2011|location=London|first=Justin|last=McCurry}}</ref> 16 hours after the earthquake and [[SCRAM]],<ref name="TEPCOCore" /> the fuel rods of reactor 1 had "mostly melted and fallen into a lump at the bottom of the pressure vessel – a state that TEPCO officials have described as a 'meltdown'".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2073745,00.html|title=Fuel Rods at Japan Nuke Plant Mostly Melted |agency=AP |author=Shino Yuasa |work=Time|date=24 May 2011 |accessdate=24 May 2011}}</ref> A TEPCO spokesman Yoshimi Hitosugi stated last night, "The situation inside two and three is almost the same." TEPCO further stated that the fuel in reactor three took about 60 hours to melt and that the reactor melted down 100 hours after the magnitude nine quake struck.<ref>{{cite news|last=McNeill|first=David|title=Fukushima plant suffered triple meltdown|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/world/2011/0525/1224297712520.html|accessdate=25 May 2011|newspaper=Irish Times|date=25 May 2011}}</ref>
===Wednesday, 25 May=== [[TEPCO]] informs the Nuclear and Industrial Safety Agency and the government of Fukushima Prefecture of the results of soil tests for [[plutonium]] ({{SimpleNuclide2|plutonium|238}}, {{SimpleNuclide2|plutonium|239}} and {{SimpleNuclide2|plutonium|240}}) carried out around the Fukushima Daiichi plant. While the levels were comparable to the fallout in Japan from [[nuclear weapons testing|atmospheric nuclear testing]], TEPCO deemed that the plutonium had originated from the accidents.<ref name="Pu25May">{{cite web |url=http://www.tepco.co.jp/en/press/corp-com/release/11052508-e.html |title=Detection of radioactive materials in the soil in Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station (12th release) |publisher=TEPCO |date=25 May 2011 |accessdate=28 May 2011}}</ref>
===Saturday, 28 May=== TEPCO informs the Nuclear and Industrial Safety Agency and the government of Fukushima Prefecture of the results of soil tests for [[uranium]] ({{SimpleNuclide2|Uranium|234}}, {{SimpleNuclide2|Uranium|235}} and {{SimpleNuclide2|Uranium|238}}) carried out around the Fukushima Daiichi plant. The uranium found was considered to be natural, as its isotope ratios were consistent with the [[natural abundance]].<ref name="U28May">{{cite web |url=http://www.tepco.co.jp/en/press/corp-com/release/11052812-e.html |title=Detection of radioactive materials in the soil in Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station (13th release) |publisher=TEPCO |date=28 May 2011 |accessdate=28 May 2011}}</ref>
At 21:14 a cooling pump at reactor five stops. At 08:12 the next day, work began on a spare pump, and cooling was restored at 12:49.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tepco.co.jp/en/press/corp-com/release/11052908-e.html |title=Status of TEPCO's Facilities and its services after the Tohoku-Chihou-Taiheiyou-Oki Earthquake(as of 4:00 pm, May 29) |publisher=TEPCO |date=29 May 2011 |accessdate=29 May 2011}}</ref> The reactor temperature had risen to 92.2 °C. The cause of the outage is suspected to be motor failure.<ref name="JAIF96">{{cite web |url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1306659230P.pdf |title=Earthquake News No. 96 |publisher=JAIF |date=29 May 2011 |accessdate=29 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111011175026/http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1306659230P.pdf |archivedate=11 October 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Sunday, 29 May=== It is reported that 22 out of 23 radiation monitoring systems around the Fukushima plants were disabled by the earthquake and tsunami. Some were directly damaged, but most were disabled due to communication and power lines being cut. Even monitors equipped with backup satellite links failed, probably due to antenna damage. In [[Miyagi prefecture]], 4 out of 7 were disabled by the tsunami, with the remaining three stopping after three hours. In [[Ibaraki Prefecture|Ibaraki]], some 40 monitors stopped working for three hours until power could be restored.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kyodo|title=Power outages, downed communication lines knocked out most radiation monitoring systems in disaster areas|url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110529a4.html|accessdate=29 May 2011|newspaper=The Japan Times |date=29 May 2011}}</ref>
The first of the typhoons of the season is due to strike the area, while Japan states radiation levels at the seabed are several hundreds of times above normal levels off the coast of Fukushima. "The Science Ministry announced late on Friday highly radioactive materials were detected in a 300-km north-south stretch from [[Kesennuma]] in Miyagi Prefecture to [[Choshi]] in [[Chiba Prefecture]], the Kyodo news agency reported."<ref>{{cite news|title=Japan detects radiation|url=http://main.omanobserver.om/node/52783|accessdate=29 May 2011|newspaper=Oman Daily Observer|date=29 May 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110601020921/http://main.omanobserver.om/node/52783|archivedate=1 June 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
TEPCO reports that cooling has been restored for spent-fuel pools 1 to 4.<ref name="JAIF96" />
===Tuesday, 31 May=== An oil spill near reactors 5 and 6 is detected at 8:00 am, as well as an explosion heard at 2:30 pm near reactor 4.<ref>{{cite news|title=Japanese nuclear plant hit by explosion and oil spill|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/may/31/japan-nuclear-plant-explosion|accessdate=31 May 2011<!-- 15.38 BST-->|newspaper=Guardian News and Media Limited 2011|date=31 May 2011<!-- 15.38 BST-->|location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Press Release (Jun 01,2011), Status of TEPCO's Facilities and its services after the Tohoku-Chihou-Taiheiyou-Oki Earthquake(as of 9:00 am, June 1)|url=http://www.tepco.co.jp/en/press/corp-com/release/11060103-e.html|publisher=Tokyo Electric Power Company|date=1 June 2011|accessdate=4 June 2011}}</ref> TEPCO reports that the explosion was the bursting of an oxygen cylinder damaged by unmanned machinery during debris removal.<ref name="JAIF99">{{cite web |url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1306919449P.pdf |title=Earthquake Report No. 99 |publisher=JAIF |date=1 June 2011 |accessdate=1 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69MifzzuY?url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1306919449P.pdf |archivedate=23 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
TEPCO states that there was a temporary oil leak into the sea near the plant, from an oil pipe that may have been damaged in the March disaster. It is stated as being an extremely small leak, possibly caused by recent rainy weather from Typhoon Songda. TEPCO says that the leak has stopped and oil fences have been installed to prevent the liquid from spreading into the Pacific Ocean.<ref>{{cite web|title=TEPCO starts system to cool spent-fuel pool at Fukushima plant|url=http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20110601p2g00m0dm010000c.html|date=1 June 2011|publisher=THE MAINICHI DAILY NEWS|accessdate=3 June 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110603065018/http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20110601p2g00m0dm010000c.html|archivedate=3 June 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Storm suspends work at Japan Fukushima nuclear plant|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-13595323|work=BBC News Asia-Pacific|date=30 May 2011|accessdate=4 June 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=TEPCO starts system to cool spent-fuel pool at nuclear plant|url=http://www.japantoday.com/category/national/view/oil-leaking-into-sea-near-fukushima-nuclear-plant|work=Japan Today|date=1 June 2011|accessdate=4 June 2011}}</ref>
==June 2011==
===Friday, 3 June === The first case is confirmed where radiation levels in humans have exceeded limits since the accident at the plant.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1307179693P.pdf |title=Earthquake Report No. 102 |publisher=JAIF |date=4 June 2011 |accessdate=4 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69MigzqTW?url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1307179693P.pdf |archivedate=23 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> One worker in his thirties received 678 mSv, while another one in his forties received 643 mSv.<ref name="jaif.or.jp 110711">{{cite web|url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1307783131P.pdf|title=Earthquake Report No. 109|publisher=JAIF|date=11 June 2011|accessdate=11 June 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111116092304/http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1307783131P.pdf|archivedate=16 November 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Before the accident the limit for emergency situations was 100 mSv, but it was raised by the government to 250 mSv just after the accident. The two TEPCO workers were on duty in the central control rooms of reactors Nos. 3 and 4 and told the health and labor ministry that they didn't remember whether they wore protective masks or not when a hydrogen explosion occurred at reactor No. 1 on 12 March.<ref name="jaif.or.jp 110711"/>
===Saturday, 4 June=== Air radiation readings of up to 4000 millisieverts per hour are recorded in the reactor 1 building.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110604x1.html |title=No. 1 plant's air radiation highest measured so far |work=The Japan Times |date=4 June 2011 |accessdate=7 June 2011}}</ref>
===Monday, 6 June=== Japan's [[Nuclear and Industrial Safety Agency]] ([[Nuclear and Industrial Safety Agency|NISA]]) gives new estimates of the times at which the reactor pressure vessels were damaged and possibly dropped fuel into the containment vessels: 5 hours after the initial earthquake for reactor 1 (20:00 March 11); 80 hours for reactor 2 (22:50 March 14); and 79 hours for reactor 3 (22:10 March 14).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/national/T110607005367.htm |title='Melt-through' at Fukushima? / Govt report to IAEA suggests situation worse than meltdown |work=Yomiuri Shimbun |date=8 June 2011 |accessdate=8 June 2011}}</ref> In addition, NISA more than doubles its original estimate of radiation that escaped into the atmosphere in the first six days, from 370,000 terabecquerels to 770,000 terabecquerels.<ref>Japan says fuel may have melted through 3 reactors http://www.ctvbc.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20110607/japan-says-it-was-unprepared-for-nuclear-disaster-110607/20110607/?hub=BritishColumbiaHome</ref>
===Wednesday, 8 June=== The ministry of education says that [[strontium]] {{SimpleNuclide2|Strontium|89}} and {{SimpleNuclide2|Strontium|90}} have been detected in soil samples collected from late March to early May and 22–62 km away from the Fukushima Daiichi plant. The highest values are reported in Namie town at 1,500 Bq/kg of strontium {{SimpleNuclide2|Strontium|89}}, and 250 Bq/kg of [[strontium]] {{SimpleNuclide2|Strontium|90}}.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/science/news/20110609-OYT1T00095.htm?from=main3 |title=Strontium detected in soil more than 20 km away from Fukushima Daiichi plant |work=Yomiuri Shimbun |date=8 June 2011 |accessdate=8 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111126004555/http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/science/news/20110609-OYT1T00095.htm?from=main3 |archivedate=26 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The Japanese government's report on the Fukushima disaster to [[IAEA]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Report of Japanese government to the IAEA ministerial conference on nuclear safety – The accident at TEPCO's Fukushima nuclear power stations|url=http://www.kantei.go.jp/foreign/kan/topics/201106/iaea_houkokusho_e.html}}</ref> is described in an article in the Yomiuri newspaper. The government report states that nuclear fuel has possibly melted through the base of the pressure vessels in the first three reactors. With data from the government report, the newspaper compares the March timelines provided by [[TEPCO]] and by [[Nuclear and Industrial Safety Agency|NISA]], which had performed further analysis; there were differences in the theoretical timing of events of up to 29 hours in the days following the tsunami.<ref>'Melt-through' at Fukushima? / Govt. suggests situation worse than meltdown http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/national/T110607005367.htm</ref>
===Thursday, 9 June=== A spokesman for [[TEPCO]] says the company is revising its earlier road-map for bringing the plant under control, including the time expected to achieve cold shutdown.<ref>Nuclear fuel has melted through base of Fukushima plant|https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/8565020/Nuclear-fuel-has-melted-through-base-of-Fukushima-plant.html</ref>
===Tuesday, 14 June=== From 00:44 to 02:35 there is a massive steam and smoke release from unit 3, recorded by the TEPCO live cam.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.twitmunin.com/v/280278/2011-06-14-00-00-01-00-福島原発ライブカメラ-live-fukushima-nuclear-plant-cam/ |title=2011.06.14 00:00–01:00 / 福島原発ライブカメラ (Live Fukushima Nuclear Plant Cam) |publisher=Tepco [http://www.tepco.co.jp/nu/f1-np/camera/] |date=14 June 2011 |accessdate=2 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719152136/http://www.twitmunin.com/v/280278/2011-06-14-00-00-01-00-%E7%A6%8F%E5%B3%B6%E5%8E%9F%E7%99%BA%E3%83%A9%E3%82%A4%E3%83%96%E3%82%AB%E3%83%A1%E3%83%A9-live-fukushima-nuclear-plant-cam/ |archivedate=19 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fg8yGBhoLxU |title=2011.06.14 01:00–02:00 / 福島原発ライブカメラ (Live Fukushima Nuclear Plant Cam) |publisher=Tepco [http://www.tepco.co.jp/nu/f1-np/camera/] |date=14 June 2011 |accessdate=2 July 2011}}</ref> No explanation has been given yet by TEPCO officials.
===Wednesday, 15 June=== TEPCO begins a trial run of a radioactive water treatment system in an effort to break away from the vicious cycle of injecting water into reactors to cool them and ending up with more contaminated water.<ref>[http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20110616p2a00m0na015000c.html TEPCO starts up water treatment system, but massive radioactive waste feared] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110619001951/http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20110616p2a00m0na015000c.html |date=19 June 2011 }}</ref> While contaminated water is treated, the system is expected to produce about 2,000 cubic meters of radioactive sludge by the end of 2011.
===Saturday, 18 June=== The radioactive water treatment system is forced to shut down because a filter exceeds its radioactivity limit. The separation unit, which removes caesium from the water, had been expected to last about a month before its cartridge required replacing—at a radiation level of 4 millisieverts per hour. The radiation levels near the filter cartridge replacement valves reach 4.7 millisieverts per hour after just 5 hours of operation, reportedly due to oil and sludge in the water which contained more radioactivity than expected.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nuclearstreet.com/nuclear_power_industry_news/b/nuclear_power_news/archive/2011/06/20/after-five-hours_2c00_-accumulated-radiation-forces-tepco-to-stop-water-treatment-062002.aspx |title=After five hours, accumulated radiation forces TEPCO to stop water treatment| publisher=Nuclear Street |date=20 June 2011| accessdate=23 June 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110620n1.html |title=TEPCO plays down decontamination failure|work=The Japan Times |date=20 June 2011 |accessdate=20 June 2011}}</ref>
===Sunday, 19 June=== Radiation in some areas of Tsukidate, 50 km NW of the Fukushima 1 plant, exceeds the legal limit. The government plans to help households in designated areas to evacuate, raising concern among residents. Although the Tsukidate elementary school has not detected radiation levels in excess of the legal limit, about 80 parents and teachers thoroughly wash windows and verandas with high-pressure water jets and brushes and the school suspends activities on the playground in response to concern by parents.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1308474763P.pdf|title=Earthquake Report No. 117|publisher=JAIF|date=19 June 2011|accessdate=19 June 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120403225727/http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1308474763P.pdf|archivedate=3 April 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Tuesday, 21 June=== A radiation reading of 430 millisieverts per hour is recorded in a mezzanine between the first floor and basement of reactor 2. This is the highest level measured up to this point in the reactor 2 building, and marks the first time that workers have entered the basement of this building since the beginning of the crisis.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/national/T110622005235.htm|title=TEPCO cuts back on water due to expected rains|publisher=Yomiuri|date=23 June 2011|accessdate=23 June 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110622222235/http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/national/T110622005235.htm|archivedate=22 June 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Monday, 27 June=== Although the radioactive water treatment system has not yet started full-scale operation, a total of 1,850 tons of radioactive water has been processed during test runs of the system. Today this decontaminated water is used to cool the reactors for the first time. TEPCO states that it will continue injecting 16 tons of water per hour for cooling the 3 reactors, and that 13 tons of this will be made up from the decontaminated water.<ref name="JAIF125">{{cite web |url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1309166580P.pdf |title=Earthquake Report No. 125 |publisher=JAIF |date=27 June 2011 |accessdate=27 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111011174801/http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1309166580P.pdf |archivedate=11 October 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The recycling system operates for only 90 minutes before it is halted due to a burst connection which leaks about one ton of water.<ref name="JAIF126">{{cite web |url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1309252163P.pdf |title=Earthquake Report No. 126 |publisher=JAIF |date=28 June 2011 |accessdate=28 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111001130315/http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1309252163P.pdf |archivedate=1 October 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Wednesday, 29 June=== [[TEPCO]] reports that [[tellurium]]-129m is found at 720 [[becquerels]] per litre of seawater collected on 4 June, detected near the water intake for the reactor 1; about 2.4 times safe levels. Though [[tellurium]]-129m has a short half-life of about 34 days, [[TEPCO]] denied that its detection indicated the possibility of a new leak of radioactive water into the sea.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asahi.com/english/TKY201106300191.html|title=TEPCO denies new leak at Fukushima plant|work=Asahi Shimbun|date=1 July 2011}}</ref>
===Thursday, 30 June=== The Itabashi Ward Office announces that a concentration of [[caesium-134]] at 2,700 becquerels per kilogram – in excess of the government's provisional limit – was detected in tea processed from leaves picked on 9 May in Tokyo.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20110701p2a00m0na005000c.html|title=Radioactive cesium detected in tea leaves grown in Tokyo|publisher=The Mainichi Daily News|date=1 July 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110703222952/http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20110701p2a00m0na005000c.html|archivedate=3 July 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==July 2011==
===Sunday, 3 July=== The water decontamination and water recycling systems are now both functional. 100% recycled water is now used for reactor cooling, and no additional volume of contaminated water is being generated.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1309663611P.pdf|title=Earthquake report No. 131|publisher=JAIF|date=3 July 2011|accessdate=4 July 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111116092835/http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1309663611P.pdf|archivedate=16 November 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Monday, 4 July=== Radioactive [[caesium-137]] is found in Tokyo's tap water for the first time since April.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/g/a/2011/07/03/bloomberg1376-LNS8HU1A1I4H01-0LGDTMA62NN12V3Q1MNPDH59JP.DTL |archive-url=https://archive.is/20110704235117/http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/g/a/2011/07/03/bloomberg1376-LNS8HU1A1I4H01-0LGDTMA62NN12V3Q1MNPDH59JP.DTL |dead-url=yes |archive-date=4 July 2011 |title=Cesium is found in Tokyo tap water for first time since April |publisher=Bloomberg |date=3 July 2011 }}</ref> Radioactive caesium from Fukushima was expected to enter the Japanese seafood supply, and was projected to reach the [[West Coast of the United States|US West Coast]] in 5 years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20110627p2a00m0na009000c.html|title=Radioactive cesium from Fukushima expected to reach US West coast in 5 years|publisher=Mainichi Daily News|date=27 June 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110630084302/http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20110627p2a00m0na009000c.html|archivedate=30 June 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
=== Wednesday, 13 July === The [[Japanese Nuclear Safety Commission]] publishes a report dated 11 June 1993, ([[Heisei period|Heisei]] 5) whose title [[literal translation|literally translates]] to ''The event of entire alternating current station blackout on the nuclear power plant (原子力発電所における全交流電源喪失事象について)'' conducted by a working group. This reports the results of an evaluation of the regulations to prevent and handle an occurrence of the full loss of [[alternating current]] (Station Blackout or SBO) in nuclear power plants in Japan and other countries. It concludes that further discussion is needed on methods to avoid or recover from such accidents. It also reports that the probability of an SBO in Japan is lower than in other countries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nsc.go.jp/info/20110713_dis.pdf|script-title=ja:原子力発電所における全交流電源喪失事象について|date=dated 1993-06-11|publisher=[[Japanese Nuclear Safety Commission]]|language=Japanese|trans-title=The event of entire Alternating Current station blackout on the nuclear power plant|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110817172438/http://www.nsc.go.jp/info/20110713_dis.pdf|archivedate=17 August 2011|accessdate=2011-07-18|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>1. {{cite news|script-title=ja:18年前、全電源喪失検討 安全委 幻の報告書|url=http://www.tokyo-np.co.jp/s/article/2011071390070408.html|newspaper=[[Tokyo Shimbun]]|date=14 July 2011 ver.11 Page 2|accessdate=2011-07-18|language=Japanese|trans-title=18 years ago, SBO was discussed by Japanese Nuclear Safety Commission, but it is a phantom report.|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716005936/http://www.tokyo-np.co.jp/s/article/2011071390070408.html|archivedate=16 July 2011|df=dmy-all}} <br/>2. {{cite news|script-title=ja:東日本大震災：福島第１原発事故「全電源喪失は考慮不要」93年、安全委が国追認|url=http://mainichi.jp/select/weathernews/news/20110714ddm001040054000c.html|newspaper=[[Mainichi Shimbun]]|date=14 July 2011 ver.14新Page 1|accessdate=2011-07-18|language=Japanese|trans-title=Aftermath of the 2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami; Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster, "reported in 1993, No need to consider SBO", Japanese Nuclear Safety Commission had followed to acknowledge governments regulation.|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715020854/http://mainichi.jp/select/weathernews/news/20110714ddm001040054000c.html|archivedate=15 July 2011|df=dmy-all}} <br />3. {{cite news|script-title=ja:18年前に電源喪失対策検討「重大性低い」安全委結論|url=http://www.asahi.com/national/update/0713/TKY201107130644.html|newspaper=[[Asahi Shimbun]]|date=14 July 2011 Ver. 13 Page 1|accessdate=2011-07-18|language=Japanese|trans-title=Japanese Nuclear Safety Commission concluded "Low seriousness" on discussed SBO 18 years ago.}} <br />4. {{cite news|script-title=ja:原発の電源喪失、安全委93年に検討…公表せず|url=http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/science/news/20110716-OYT1T00168.htm|newspaper=[[Yomiuri Shimbun]]|date=15 July 2011|accessdate=2011-07-18|language=Japanese|trans-title=SBO in nuclear power plant, Japanese Nuclear Safety Commission discussed in 1993, ..... but no disclosure.}}</ref>
===Thursday, 14 July=== The number of people actively working at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant is about 3,000. [[Nuclear and Industrial Safety Agency|NISA]] orders [[TEPCO]] to boost the number of safety managers to support this large number of workers.<ref name="JAIF_Report_142">{{cite web|url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1310614161P.pdf|title=Earthquake report No. 142|publisher=JAIF|date=14 July 2011|accessdate=14 July 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130521072158/http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1310614161P.pdf|archivedate=21 May 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The water decontamination systems continue to be plagued by leaks and filter problems. Over the last week they had been operating at an average of 73% capacity, below the target of 90% which is required to meet the current timetable.<ref name="JAIF_Report_142"/><ref name="JAIF_Report_143">{{cite web|url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1310712950P.pdf|title=Earthquake report No. 143|publisher=JAIF|date=15 July 2011|accessdate=15 July 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111001130409/http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1310712950P.pdf|archivedate=1 October 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Saturday, 16 July=== In a joint assessment the Japanese government and TEPCO say they have completed the first step of a 3-month plan outlined in mid-April for a complete cold shutdown. Reactors 1, 2 and 3 have been cooled down to a stable level and nitrogen has been injected into their containment vessels to prevent hydrogen explosions; however, the assessment admits that contaminated water has leaked out of storage tanks, and that water level settings at its water purification facilities were incorrect.<ref name="JAIF_Report_144">{{cite web|url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1310787776P.pdf|title=Earthquake report No. 144|publisher=JAIF|date=16 July 2011|accessdate=16 July 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110818030458/http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1310787776P.pdf|archivedate=18 August 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==August 2011==
===Monday, 1 August=== A radiation level of 10 sieverts per hour is read at a ventilation shaft between reactors 1 and 2. The area is subsequently sealed.<ref name="Japan utility seals area with high radiation level">{{cite news|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/news/article/Japan-utility-seals-area-with-high-radiation-level-1693617.php |archive-url=https://archive.is/20110803004939/http://www.seattlepi.com/news/article/Japan-utility-seals-area-with-high-radiation-level-1693617.php |dead-url=yes |archive-date=3 August 2011 |title=Japan utility seals area with high radiation level |publisher=seattlepi.com |accessdate=23 August 2011 }}</ref> The reading of 10 Sv is the maximum for many Geiger counters, including those used for these readings. One official states that it is entirely possible that the radiation readings were higher since the counter was reading its maximum. Radiation has been impeding attempts to replace cooling systems.<ref name="Tepco Reports Second Deadly Radiation Reading at Fukushima Plant">{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-08-02/tepco-reports-second-deadly-radiation-reading-at-fukushima-plant.html|title=Tepco Reports Second Deadly Radiation Reading at Fukushima Plant|publisher=Bloomberg|date=3 August 2011 |accessdate=3 August 2011|first1=Tsuyoshi|last1=Inajima|first2=Kari|last2=Lundgren}}</ref> These are the highest readings logged indoors since the initial March 2011 explosions.<ref name="Tepco Detects Hotspots At Fukushima Site, No Delay Expected For Recovery Plan">{{cite news|url=https://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20110802-710970.html |title=Tepco Detects Hotspots At Fukushima Site, No Delay Expected For Recovery Plan |work=Wall Street Journal |date=2 August 2011 |accessdate=3 August 2011 }}{{dead link|date=September 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
===Tuesday, 2 August=== On Tuesday, 2 August, a radiation level of 5 sieverts per hour is detected on the second floor of the turbine building in reactor 1.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tepco.co.jp/en/nu/fukushima-np/images/handouts_110803_01-e.pdf|title=Place where high radiation dose was detected on the 2nd floor of Turbine Building, Unit1, at Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station|publisher=TEPCO|accessdate=23 August 2011}}</ref> The radioactivity rates detected on 2 and 1 August are considered lethal for even brief human exposures,<ref name="Tepco Reports Second Deadly Radiation Reading at Fukushima Plant"/> an exposure of 0.1 Sv being the normal accepted workplace exposure over 5 years<ref>{{cite web|title=World nuclear Association|url=http://www.world-nuclear.org/info/inf05.html|work=Nuclear Radiation and Health Effects|accessdate=2011-08-22}}</ref> and 8 Sv or 8 [[Gray (unit)|Gray]] (8Gy){{Elucidate|reason=Absorbed dose (Gray) or dose equivalent (Sv)?|date=October 2015}} being a 100% lethal dose.<ref>{{cite web|title=Radiation Contamination and Exposure|url=http://www.merckmanuals.com/professional/sec22/ch337/ch337a.html|work=The Merck Manual|publisher=Merck|accessdate=2011-08-22}}</ref>
===Wednesday, 10 August === Installation of the new, closed circulation cooling system is finished for all four damaged reactors (1–4), reactor 1 being the last.<ref name="jaif_170">[https://www.webcitation.org/60vpoDAu2?url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1313037997P.pdf ''Earthquake Report – JAIF, No. 170''] (englisch, pdf). JAIF / NHK, 8. August 2011, archived from [http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1313037997P.pdf Original], fetched 14. August 2011.</ref> Previously, cooling was achieved with water injection by giant pump trucks.
The water decontamination system is not working as well as expected, operating at roughly 66% of expected performance and suffering from numerous malfunctions.<ref name="jaif_170"/> The system is necessary to decontaminate the large amount of radioactive water that remains on the site.
==September 2011==
===Thursday, 8 September=== The Japan Atomic Energy Agency calculates that a total of 15,000 terabecquerels of radiation has been released into the sea from the crippled Fukushima Daiichi power plant.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www3.nhk.or.jp/daily/english/08_25.html|title=Radioactive release into sea estimated triple|publisher=NHK|date=8 September 2011|accessdate=20 September 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110924023107/http://www3.nhk.or.jp/daily/english/08_25.html|archivedate=24 September 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Friday, 16 September=== Research indicates that the meltdown of reactor number 2 could have been avoided if water was injected to cool the reactor 4 hours earlier. Water injection was started at 8 pm on 14 March after the cooling system failed at 1 pm that day. The meltdown could have been avoided if injection had started by 4 pm.<ref name="JAIF_Report_206">{{cite web|url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1316157224P.pdf|title=Earthquake report No. 206|publisher=JAIF|date=16 September 2011|accessdate=16 September 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120419005538/http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1316157224P.pdf|archivedate=19 April 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Wednesday, 21 September=== Typhoon Roke brings strong winds and up to 42 cm of rain to some areas of NE Japan. At the same time a magnitude 5.3 earthquake strikes just south of Fukushima. No significant problems are reported at the Fukushima Daiichi plant.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/story/2011/09/21/japan-typhoon-roke.html |title=Typhoon-ravaged Japan also hit by earthquake |publisher=CBC |date=21 September 2011 |accessdate=22 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110921200920/http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/story/2011/09/21/japan-typhoon-roke.html |archivedate=21 September 2011 }}</ref>
===Thursday, 29 September=== The measured core temperature falls below 100 degrees Celsius for all 3 damaged reactors with reactor number 2 finally achieving this status; reactors 1 and 3 had been below 100 degrees since August.<ref name="JAIF_Report_219">{{cite web|url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1317264047P.pdf|title=Earthquake report No. 219|publisher=JAIF|date=29 September 2011|accessdate=29 September 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111028153744/http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1317264047P.pdf|archivedate=28 October 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Hydrogen is found at concentrations of 61 to 63 percent in pipes connected to the reactor 1 containment vessel. Plans are made to check for hydrogen in the pipes of all reactors and flush if necessary to prevent the possibility of another explosion.<ref name="JAIF_Report_219"/>
==October 2011==
===Saturday, 8 October === The Economist reports that high levels of radioactive particles, including [[plutonium]] have been found in an extended irregular zone<ref>http://media.economist.com/sites/default/files/imagecache/290-width/images/print-edition/20111008_ASM935.gif map</ref> that extends well outside the 30 km evacuation radius around the Fukushima Dai-ichi nuclear power plant.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/node/21531522|title=Radiation in Japan, Hot spots and blind spots, The mounting human costs of Japan’s nuclear disaster|date=8 October 2011 | work=The Economist}}</ref>
===Monday, 31 October === A French study<ref>{{cite web|title=Synthèse actualisée des connaissances relatives à l’impact sur le milieu marin des rejets radioactifs du site nucléaire accidenté de Fukushima Dai-ichi|url=http://www.irsn.fr/FR/Actualites_presse/Actualites/Documents/IRSN-NI-Impact_accident_Fukushima_sur_milieu_marin_26102011.pdf}}</ref> by the Institute for Radiological Protection and Nuclear Safety revealed that the Fukushima nuclear disaster caused the biggest discharge of radioactive material into the ocean in history. The radioactive caesium that flowed into the sea from the Fukushima Dai-Ichi nuclear plant was 20 times the amount estimated by its owner, Tokyo Electric Power Co.<ref name="Beth Thomas">{{cite news|author=Beth Thomas|title=Fukushima Plant Released Record Amount of Radiation Into Ocean|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-10-31/fukushima-plant-released-record-amount-of-radiation-into-ocean.html | work=Bloomberg|date=31 October 2011}}</ref> Atmospheric releases were cited as amounting to 35,800 terabecquerels of caesium-137 by the Atmospheric Chemistry and Physics journal—an estimate about 42 percent of that released into the atmosphere in the [[Chernobyl disaster|Chernobyl explosion]] in 1986. [[Caesium-137]] has a [[half-life]] of 30 years.<ref name="Beth Thomas"/>
== November 2011 ==
=== Tuesday, 1 November === TEPCO reports the completion of a cover for the reactor unit 1, which is 54 metres high, 47 metres wide and 42 metres deep. The cover has a built-in ventilation system that is supposed to filter radioactive material.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldnuclear.org/_news_database/rss_detail_features.cfm?objID=C22E6204-BCD4-4A49-8F70DCFF118F34B8|title=Tepco Completes Installation Of Cover at Fukushima-Daiichi Unit 1|date=1 November 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XHcKm8i_psA|title=Unit1 of Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station Construction work of cover panels around}}</ref>
=== Wednesday, 2 November === Boric acid is injected into reactor number 2 after the discovery of xenon in its containment vessel. The presence of xenon may be an indication that a self-sustained fission reaction has been occurring.<ref name="JAIF_Report_253">{{cite web|url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1320208900P.pdf|title=Earthquake report No. 253|publisher=JAIF|date=2 November 2011|accessdate=2 November 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130521071937/http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1320208900P.pdf|archivedate=21 May 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
=== Friday, 4 November === TEPCO retracts Wednesday's statement about a possible self-sustained fission reaction, and now claims that the xenon was a result of the normal decay of radioisotopes in the fuel.<ref name="JAIF_Report_255">{{cite web|url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1320374709P.pdf|title=Earthquake report No. 255|publisher=JAIF|date=4 November 2011|accessdate=4 November 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120103124954/http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1320374709P.pdf|archivedate=3 January 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
=== Thursday, 17 November === The Japanese government bans shipments of rice from a farm near the Fukushima Dai-ichi nuclear plant. 630 becquerels of caesium per kilogram was found in the rice, over the 500 becquerels of caesium per kilogram allowed for human consumption. (From hundreds of spots tested around Fukushima, none had previously exceeded the limit.)<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia-pacific/japan-bans-rice-grown-near-crippled-nuclear-plant-after-detecting-excessive-radiation/2011/11/17/gIQAR31BUN_story.html Japan bans rice grown near crippled nuke plant]</ref>
=== Tuesday, 29 November === TEPCO now claims that there was no explosion at reactor number 2 on 15 March as previously reported, and that instead the explosion occurred at reactor number 4. However, TEPCO has no explanation for the observed rise in radioactive emissions from reactor 2 at this time.<ref name="JAIF_Report_276">{{cite web|url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1322541949P.pdf|title=Earthquake report No. 276|publisher=JAIF|date=29 November 2011|accessdate=29 November 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130516154734/http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1322541949P.pdf|archivedate=16 May 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
=== Wednesday, 30 November ===
TEPCO reports that a new computer simulation of the meltdown shows nuclear fuel rod material melting through the pressure vessel and deep inside the concrete of the primary containment vessel, within a foot of breaching it fully in Reactor No. 1. In the pessimistic scenario, all of the fuel of Reactor No. 1 has escaped the pressure vessel, as well as a majority of the fuel for Reactor No. 2 and 3.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/text/nn20111201a1.html|title=Containment vessels held: simulation test|publisher=The Japan Times Online|accessdate=5 December 2011|date=1 December 2011}}</ref>
== December 2011 ==
=== Saturday, 3 December === Forty-five tons of highly radioactive water leaked from the apparatus being used to decontaminate the water at the plant. Plant workers attempted to contain the leak, but it was unknown if any of the water escaped into the water table or the ocean.<ref>Matsutani, Minoru, "[http://www.japantimes.co.jp/text/nn20111205x1.html Fukushima plant springs new water leak]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 6 December 2011, p. 1.</ref>
=== Thursday, 15 December === A long-range timetable is announced for the decommissioning of the Fukushima Daiichi reactors.<ref name="JAIF_Report_291">{{cite web|url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1323921629P.pdf|title=Earthquake report No. 291|publisher=JAIF|date=15 December 2011|accessdate=15 December 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120103104541/http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1323921629P.pdf|archivedate=3 January 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The plan is to repair the damaged containment vessels and determine the condition of the melted fuel by the end of 2021, then begin the retrieval of this fuel in 2022. The full duration of the schedule is 40 years, with the decommissioning work to be completed by 2052.
=== Friday, 16 December === In a joint statement by TEPCO and the Japan government it is announced that the reactors have achieved a state of cold shutdown. Temperatures in the containment vessels were 38.9 degrees Celsius for reactor one, 67.5 degrees for reactor two, and 57.4 degrees for reactor 3.<ref>{{cite news|last=Nagata|first=Kazuaki|title=Officials: Cold shutdown has been achieved|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/text/nn20111216x1.html|accessdate=16 December 2011|newspaper=Japan Times|date=16 December 2011}}</ref> This announcement failed to lay to rest substantial concerns arising from TEPCO's inability to directly measure temperatures at the bottoms of the containment vessels, and the fact that the site is too radioactive for visual confirmation of the fuel rods' status.<ref>{{cite news | title=Skeptics cast doubt on Fukushima status, even as Japan declares nuclear reactors 'stable' | first = Arthur | last = Bright | date = 16 December 2011 | accessdate = 17 December 2011 | url = http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Global-News/2011/1216/Skeptics-cast-doubt-on-Fukushima-status-even-as-Japan-declares-nuclear-reactors-stable}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Japan’s Prime Minister Declares Fukushima Plant Stable | author = Hiroko Tabuchi | date = 16 December 2011 | accessdate = 17 December 2011 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2011/12/17/world/asia/japans-prime-minister-declares-fukushima-plant-stable.html?ref=opinion | work=The New York Times}}</ref>
=== Sunday, 18 December === 230 tons of highly radioactive water is discovered in a tunnel below a building that stores contaminated water, raising questions about TEPCO's inspection and management capabilities.<ref name="JAIF_Report_295">{{cite web|url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1324275503P.pdf|title=Earthquake report No. 295|publisher=JAIF|date=19 December 2011|accessdate=20 December 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130521074911/http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1324275503P.pdf|archivedate=21 May 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> TEPCO admits that this radioactive water may be mixing with the ground water, yet claims that the tunnel is not connected to the sea.<ref name="JAIF_Report_295"/>
=== Tuesday, 20 December === [[Nuclear Regulatory Commission|US Nuclear Regulatory Commission]] Chairman [[Gregory Jaczko]], visiting Japan, confirmed that the Daiichi reactors were stable. Said Jaczko, "The temperatures have decreased significantly, the amount of heat that's being produced from the reactor fuel itself is very, very low now. So it simply doesn't have the kind of energy, if you will, that's needed to have any kind of off-site releases of radiation. I feel very comfortable with the (government's cold shutdown) decision."<ref>[[Kyodo News]], "Fukushima 'stable': U.S. nuke chief", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 22 December 2011, p. 2.</ref>
=== Monday, 26 December === An interim report was issued by the investigative panel headed by Yotaro Hatamura. In the report, the panel concluded that poor internal communication by the Japanese government and faulty knowledge and actions by TEPCO employees contributed to the disaster. The Japanese cabinet was not informed of the government's System for Prediction of Environmental Emergency Dose Information, which could have told them of the wind direction's effect on the spread of radiation, which would have allowed them to make better decisions on which areas to evacuate around Fukushima Daiichi. TEPCO workers mistakenly believed that the isolation condenser for reactor No. 1 was still working, when it was not, delaying efforts to try other methods to cool the reactor. TEPCO workers turned off an emergency cooling system on reactor No. 3 for seven hours to try to switch to another system that was not working, allowing the reactor to overheat more quickly.<ref>Nagata, Kazuaki, "[http://www.japantimes.co.jp/text/nn20111226x1.html Report blasts government's crisis response]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 27 December 2011, p. 1.</ref>
== 2012 ==
=== 19 January === An attempt is made to view the state of the melted fuel in reactor 2 using a fibre-optic endoscope, however clear images of the water level and fuel location could not be obtained, probably due to the harsh environment inside the containment vessel.<ref name="JAIF_Report_323"/><ref>{{cite news|title=New video of Fukushima nuclear reactor interior|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-16649030|publisher=BBC|accessdate=20 January 2012|date=20 January 2012}}</ref>
After radioactive water was discovered in a tunnel under reactor 2 on 18 December, the government directed TEPCO to survey the plant's underground facilities and check for more accumulation of radioactive water. TEPCO finds an additional 500 tons of water containing 16,200 Bq/cm<sup>3</sup> of radioactive caesium in a pit near reactor 2, and 600 tons of 860 Bq/cm<sup>3</sup> water near reactor 3.<ref name="JAIF_Report_323">{{cite web|url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1327033033P.pdf|title=Earthquake report No. 323|publisher=JAIF|date=20 January 2012|accessdate=20 January 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130516160456/http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1327033033P.pdf|archivedate=16 May 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
=== 22 February === TEPCO begins pouring a 60-centimetre-thick layer of concrete over 70,000 square metres of the ocean seabed near the Fukushima Daiichi power plant in an effort to contain contaminated sediments.<ref name="JAIF_Report_354">{{cite web|url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1329889047P.pdf|title=Earthquake report No. 354|publisher=JAIF|date=22 February 2012|accessdate=22 February 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130521073935/http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1329889047P.pdf|archivedate=21 May 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
=== 27 March === TEPCO measures atmospheric radiation at several points inside the containment vessel of reactor 2 for the first time, and reports values of 31.1 and 72.9 Sv/h. The utility states that radiation is too high for robots, endoscopes, and other devices to work properly.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/text/nn20120329a1.html|work=The Japan Times |title=Reactor 2 radiation too high for access|author=Minoru Matsutani|date=29 March 2012|accessdate=1 April 2012}}</ref>
=== 5 April === For the second time in 10 days highly radioactive wastewater is accidentally discharged into the sea. About 12 tons of wastewater leaks from a disconnected joint, a large portion of which flows into the sea through a drainage ditch.<ref name="JAIF_Report_394">{{cite web|url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1333614003P.pdf|title=Earthquake report No. 394|publisher=JAIF|date=5 April 2012|accessdate=5 April 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130521082833/http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1333614003P.pdf|archivedate=21 May 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
=== 5 May === Japan's last remaining active nuclear reactor goes offline. Since the Fukushima Daiichi incident, nuclear reactors have not been allowed to restart after being shut down for maintenance or safety checks. One by one the number of active nuclear reactors has steadily decreased until the last of Japan's 54 nuclear reactors is finally taken offline.<ref>{{cite web|title=Japan switches off final nuclear reactor|url=http://www.japantoday.com/category/national/view/japan-switches-off-final-nuclear-reactor|publisher=Japan Today|date=6 May 2012|accessdate=7 May 2012}}</ref>
=== 22 May === Japanese scientists report that the water depth inside reactor No. 1 is only 40 cm; much lower than expected, and low enough to expose some fuel. From this observation, it is concluded that a 2 cm hole may exist in a pipe that is 40 cm from the bottom of the vessel.<ref name="JAIF_Report_427">{{cite web|url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1337763233P.pdf|title=Earthquake report No. 427|publisher=JAIF|date=23 May 2012|accessdate=24 May 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130521093530/http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1337763233P.pdf|archivedate=21 May 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
=== 24 May === TEPCO releases new estimate of 900,000 terabecquerels for the total amount of radioactive material released from this facility into the environment.<ref name="JAIF_Report_429">{{cite web|url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1337929736P.pdf|title=Earthquake report No. 429|publisher=JAIF|date=25 May 2012|accessdate=25 May 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121110061324/http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1337929736P.pdf|archivedate=10 November 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
=== 5 July === Japan once again has a working nuclear reactor as the number 3 reactor at the Ohi nuclear plant begins generating power.<ref name="JAIF_Report_459">{{cite web|url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1341488612P.pdf|title=Earthquake report No. 459|publisher=JAIF|date=5 July 2012|accessdate=5 July 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130521084314/http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1341488612P.pdf|archivedate=21 May 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> This is the first reactor to be restarted since the tsunami, and marks the end of two months without nuclear power for Japan.
=== 12 October === TEPCO admits for the first time that it had failed to take stronger measures to prevent disasters for fear of inviting lawsuits or protests against its nuclear plants.<ref name="NYT20121012">{{cite news|last=Fackler|first=Martin|title=Japan Power Company Admits Failings on Plant Precautions|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/10/13/world/asia/tepco-admits-failure-in-acknowledging-risks-at-nuclear-plant.html?_r=0|accessdate=13 October 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=12 October 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Sheldrick|first=Aaron|title=Fukushima operator must learn from mistakes, new adviser says|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2012/10/13/japan-nuclear-adviser-fukushima-idINDEE89C03220121013?feedType=RSS&feedName=worldNews|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=13 October 2012|date=12 October 2012}}</ref> TEPCO's internal reform task force, led by company President Naomi Hirose, said in a report TEPCO had feared efforts to better protect nuclear facilities from severe accidents such as tsunamis would trigger anti-nuclear sentiment, interfere with operations or increase litigation risks. TEPCO could have mitigated the impact of the accident if it had diversified power and cooling systems by paying closer attention to international standards and recommendations, the report said. TEPCO also should have trained employees with practical crisis management skills rather than conduct obligatory drills as a formality, it said.<ref name="Yamaguchi20121012">{{cite news|last=Yamaguchi|first=Mari|title=Japan utility agrees nuclear crisis was avoidable|url=http://www.boston.com/news/world/asia/2012/10/12/japan-utility-admits-nuke-crisis-avoidable-says-feared-consequences-new-safety-measures/NK3yENYHgVPQZ76POvbBLL/story.html|work=Associated Press|publisher=Boston.com|accessdate=13 October 2012|date=12 October 2012}}</ref> In the internal report TEPCO said that before the accident it had been afraid to consider the risk of such a large tsunami as the one in March 2011 which hit Fukushima, fearing admissions of risk could result in public pressure to shut plants down. "There were concerns that if new countermeasures against severe accidents were installed, concern would spread in host communities that the current plants had safety problems," the report said.<ref name="NYT20121012" /> TEPCO said in the report that "severe accident measures" were taken in 2002, which included "containment venting and power supply cross-ties between units," but additional measures were never put in place.<ref name="CNN20121012">{{cite news|title=Japanese nuclear plant operator admits playing down risk|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/10/12/world/asia/japan-tepco-report/index.html?hpt=ias_c2|work=CNN Wire Staff|publisher=CNN|accessdate=13 October 2012|date=12 October 2012}}</ref> TEPCO added that taking such measures could also add to "public anxiety and add momentum to anti-nuclear movements."<ref name="CNN20121012" />
== 2013 == [[File:IAEA Experts at Fukushima (02813336).jpg|thumb|IAEA Experts at Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant Unit 4, 2013]]
=== 18 March ===
Public trust in TEPCO takes another hit<ref>{{cite web|title=Govt. tells TEPCO to add multiple power sources|url=http://www3.nhk.or.jp/daily/english/20130322_01.html|publisher=NHK World|accessdate=21 March 2013|date=21 March 2013}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> as cooling systems for several spent-fuel pools go down for more than 29 hours<ref>{{cite news|title=Fukushima Plant Hit by Power Outage|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887323415304578370091965472544|work=Mitsuru Obe|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=21 March 2013|date=19 March 2013}}</ref> after a power interruption that may have been caused by a rat in a switchboard.<ref>{{cite news|title=Fukushima: Rat linked to outage at Japan nuclear plant|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-21867705|publisher=BBC|accessdate=21 March 2013|date=20 March 2013}}</ref>
=== 9 July === Levels of caesium in groundwater from monitoring wells around the reactors jumps by 90 times compared with the levels 3 days earlier. The contamination is now measured at 9,000 becquerels of caesium-134 and 18,000 becquerels of caesium-137 per litre of water.<ref name="nhk20130709_12">{{cite web|title=Cesium levels soar in Fukushima plant groundwater|url=http://www3.nhk.or.jp/nhkworld/english/news/20130709_12.html|publisher=NHK World|accessdate=10 July 2013|date=9 July 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130710233436/http://www3.nhk.or.jp/nhkworld/english/news/20130709_12.html|archivedate=10 July 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> As well, tritium levels in seawater from the port next to the plant have been increasing since May, and a water sample taken on 3 July showed 2,300 becquerels per litre, the highest measurement since the start of the nuclear crisis in March 2011.<ref name="nhk20130709_12"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Level of radioactive tritium rising in harbor at Fukushima plant|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2013/06/25/national/level-of-radioactive-tritium-rising-in-harbor-at-fukushima-plant|publisher=Japan Times|accessdate=10 July 2013|date=25 June 2013}}</ref>
=== 10 July === Japanese government admits Fukushima Daiichi may have been leaking radioactive water into ground water and into the ocean since 2011.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/11/world/asia/japanese-nuclear-plant-may-have-been-leaking-for-two-years.html | work=The New York Times | first=Hiroko | last=Tabuchi | title=Japanese Nuclear Plant May Have Been Leaking for Two Years | date=10 July 2013}}</ref>
=== 22 July === TEPCO admits that since the 2011 reactor breaches, radioactive water has continued to leak from the plant into groundwater, making the groundwater radioactive, with implications for drinking water and for the Pacific.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/07/22/japan-nuclear-fukushima-idUSL4N0FS2DC20130722 |title=Japan's Fukushima operator acknowledges contaminated water flowing into sea |author=Takenaka, Kiyoshi |publisher=Reuters |date=2013-07-22|accessdate=2013-07-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/23/world/asia/japan-nuclear-plant-admits-leaks.html | work=The New York Times | first=Martin | last=Fackler | title=Japan: Nuclear Plant Admits Leaks | date=22 July 2013}}</ref>
=== 19 August === It is discovered that 300 tonnes of highly contaminated water (80 MBq/L<ref>{{cite web |url=http://rt.com/news/japan-fukushima-level-three-762/|title=‘Serious’: Japan hikes Fukushima radiation danger level|publisher=rt.com |date=2013-08-21|accessdate=2013-08-22}}</ref>) had leaked from a storage tank and seeped into the ground.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/aug/20/fukushima-leak-nuclear-pacific|title=Fukushima operator reveals leak of 300 tonnes of highly contaminated water|publisher=theguardian.com |date=2013-08-20|accessdate=2013-08-22}}</ref>
=== 21 August === Japan's Nuclear Regulation Authority raises the severity of the contaminated water leaks at Fukushima to INES level 3 "serious incident".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-23776345|title=Japan nuclear agency upgrades Fukushima alert level|publisher=BBC |date=2013-08-21|accessdate=2013-08-22}}</ref>
=== 26 August ===
The Japanese government takes charge in dealing with the contaminated water situation. Trade minister Toshimitsu Motegi says "We’ve allowed Tokyo Electric to deal with the contaminated water situation on its own and they’ve essentially turned it into a game of Whack-a-Mole".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-08-26/tepco-s-whack-a-mole-means-government-takes-over-in-fukushima.html|title=Tepco ‘Whack-a-Mole’ Means Government Takeover in Fukushima|publisher=Bloomberg |date=2013-08-26|accessdate=2013-08-27|first1=Yuji|last1=Okada|first2=Takashi|last2=Hirokawa|first3=Jacob|last3=Adelman}}</ref>
=== 15 September ===
Japan is once again nuclear free as its only working reactor goes offline for refuelling and maintenance.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/japan-goes-nuclear-free-indefinitely-1.1855153|title=Japan goes nuclear-free indefinitely|work=Associated Press|publisher=CBC |date=2013-09-15|accessdate=2013-10-28|first1=Shizuo |last1=Kambayashi}}</ref>
=== 18 November === Workers begin removing fuel rods from a storage pond at the Unit 4 reactor building. About 1,500 rods, some of them damaged, must be removed in a risky and dangerous operation set to take a year. Removed rods will then be moved into a more secure storage.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-24958048|title=BBC News – Japan's Fukushima nuclear plant begins fuel rod removal|work=BBC News|accessdate=18 February 2015}}</ref>
== 2014 ==
=== 9 January ===
Nuclear scientists in Japan are planning a [[controlled nuclear meltdown]] in the hope of learning how to prevent disasters like the one at Fukushima. Using a scaled down version of a nuclear reactor, [[Tomoyuki Sugiyama]], a senior scientist at the [[Japan Atomic Energy Agency]], told [[MSN Sankei]] that scientists "want to help improve the accuracy of the Fukushima accident analysis" using the data from their experiment. "We want to study exactly how [[Nuclear meltdown|meltdown]]s happen and apply what we will learn to help improve ways to deal with severe accidents in the future," another spokesman for the government-backed engineering agency told [[Agence France Presse]]. The experiment will test a small [[fuel rod]] in a very rapid [[Nuclear fission|fission]] process. The project will begin sometime later this year, the spokesman said.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://worldnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2014/01/09/22239864-japan-plans-nuclear-reactor-meltdown-to-help-prevent-another-fukushima-disaster?lite&ocid=msnhp&pos=1|title=Japan plans nuclear reactor meltdown to help prevent another Fukushima disaster|author=World News|date=18 February 2015|work=NBC News|accessdate=18 February 2015}}</ref>
=== 6 February ===
The reanalysis of a groundwater sample taken from a well in July 2013 updates its measurement from 900,000 Bq/L total beta radioactivity to a record-high 5 MBq/L of strontium-90 only (corresponding to about 10 MBq/L total beta radioactivity), after a problem with the measuring devices was found in October.<ref name="Strontium 90 record in Feb 2014">{{cite web|title=Record-high strontium-90 in past Fukushima plant groundwater sample|url=http://english.kyodonews.jp/news/2014/02/270051.html|publisher=Kyodo News|accessdate=7 February 2014}}</ref>
=== 13 February ===
It is revealed that TEPCO had concealed for months the increase in measured groundwater radioactivity.<ref>http://voiceofrussia.com/news/2014_02_13/Deadly-cesium-levels-spike-in-groundwater-under-Fukushima-8345/</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/02/13/us-japan-nuclear-fukushima-strontium-idUSBREA1C09720140213|title=Tepco took months to release record strontium readings at Fukushima|work=Reuters|accessdate=18 February 2015|date=13 February 2014}}</ref>
=== 20 February=== Earlier this week a routine inspection discovers an overflowing tank which had leaked about 12,000 litres of highly contaminated water onto the ground. The spill was caused by a valve that was left open by mistake. Radiation readings of the ground nearby measure 230 MBq/L, including strontium-90. TEPCO claims it is unlikely that the water had spilled into the sea.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/new-radioactive-leak-found-japans-fukushima-nuclear-plant-n34356|title=New Radioactive Leak Found at Japan's Fukushima Nuclear Plant|publisher=nbcnews.com|author=Arata Yamamoto and Henry Austin|date=2014-02-20|accessdate=2014-02-21}}</ref>
=== 21 May=== TEPCO begins operation to bypass groundwater flow around the reactor by pumping upstream groundwater to storage tanks, then discharging directly to the sea after measuring the contamination levels.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tepco.co.jp/en/press/corp-com/release/2014/1236566_5892.html|title=BYPASS OF CLEAN GROUNDWATER TO OCEAN STARTS|publisher=TEPCO|date=2014-05-21|accessdate=2014-05-22}}</ref>
=== 3 June=== TEPCO begins to construct facilities to establish an ''ice wall'' within the ground around the reactors to prevent contaminated water to mix with groundwater flowing under the area.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tepco.co.jp/en/press/corp-com/release/2014/1237060_5892.html|title=CONSTRUCTION OF WATER-BLOCKING ICE WALL STARTS AT FUKUSHIMA|publisher=TEPCO|date=2014-06-03|accessdate=2014-06-28}}</ref>
=== 7 July=== TEPCO has switched off the cooling system at reactor 5 due to a 3mm leak near a flow valve. Approximately 1,300 litre of water has spilled. They have approximately 9 days to repair it before water temperature reaches 65 degrees Celsius<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tepco.co.jp/cc/press/2014/1238800_5851.html|title=Fukushima has 9 days to prevent unsafe overheating|publisher=TEPCO|date=2014-07-07|accessdate=2014-07-07}}</ref>
=== 17 July=== TEPCO launches another campaign to contain the spread of contaminated sediments in the sea near the power plant, this time coating 180,000 square meters of sea floor with cement.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1406532531P.pdf|title=TEPCO Begins Coating Bottom of Sea in Port near Fukushima Daiichi to Prevent Spread of Contaminated Materials|publisher=JAIF|date=2014-07-28|accessdate=2014-07-29}}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}</ref>
=== 20 December=== TEPCO reports that all spent fuel rods have now been safely removed from the storage pool at reactor 4.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/21/world/asia/fuel-rods-are-removed-from-japans-damaged-fukushima-reactor.html|title=Fuel Rods Are Removed From Damaged Fukushima Reactor Building|accessdate=2015-10-12}}</ref>
== 2015 ==
=== 10 January=== TEPCO begins operation of a new reverse-osmosis system to remove strontium from contaminated water. The new system was built to treat 500 to 900 cubic metres of water per day, and reduce the strontium levels in the water by a factor of 100 to 1000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1421648206P.pdf|title=TEPCO Starts Removing Strontium from Contaminated Water at Fukushima Daiichi NPS|publisher=JAIF|date=2015-01-19|accessdate=2015-01-20}}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}</ref>
=== 10 April === A robot designed to withstand intense heat and radiation is sent into Reactor 1 to locate the melted fuel. It covers 14 of 18 locations before it stops functioning and has to be abandoned.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2015/apr/13/fukushima-robot-stalls-reactor-abandoned|title=Fukushima robot stranded after stalling inside reactor|last=McCurry|first=Justin|date=2015-04-13|website=the Guardian|access-date=2016-06-02}}</ref>
=== 5 September=== The evacuation order is lifted for Naraha Town in Fukushima Prefecture.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/en/lifting-of-evacuation-order-for-naraha-town-marks-step-forward-toward-reconstruction-of-fukushima/|title=Lifting of Evacuation Order for Naraha Town Marks Step Forward toward Reconstruction of Fukushima|publisher=JAIF|date=2015-09-09|accessdate=2015-09-11}}</ref>
=== 10 September=== The Sendai-1 nuclear reactor resumes commercial operation for the first time since the earthquake in May 2011. This ends almost 2 years with no Japan nuclear power plants in commercial operation since Ohi-1 was halted on 15 September 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/en/kyushu-electric-power-starts-up-sendai-1/|title=Kyushu Electric Power Starts Up Sendai-1, Ending 23-month Hiatus in Japanese NPP Operation|publisher=JAIF|date=2015-08-11|accessdate=2015-08-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/en/sendai-1-npp-returns-to-commercial-operation-first-to-do-so-under-japans-new-nuclear-regulatory-standards/|title=Sendai-1 NPP Returns to Commercial Operation: First to Do So under Japan’s New Nuclear Regulatory Standards|publisher=JAIF|date=2015-09-11|accessdate=2015-09-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2013-09-16/shutdown-of-japan-s-last-nuclear-reactor-raises-power-concerns|title=Shutdown of Japan’s Last Nuclear Reactor Raises Power Concerns|date=2013-09-15|accessdate=2015-09-11}}</ref>
=== 26 October=== After a 3-1/2 year construction project, TEPCO completes a 780 m seaside shielding wall to reduce the amount of contaminated water leaking into the sea.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/en/tepco-completes-seaside-shielding-wall-at-fukushima-daiichi-greatly-reducing-risk-of-contaminated-water-leakage/|title=TEPCO Completes Seaside Shielding Wall at Fukushima Daiichi, Greatly Reducing Risk of Contaminated Water Leakage|publisher=JAIF|date=2015-10-29|accessdate=2015-10-29}}</ref>
== 2016 ==
=== 16 February=== TEPCO estimates that 749,000 cubic metres of contaminated debris from Fukushima Daiichi will be produced by the year 2027, and releases a plan for incineration and storage of this waste.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/en/tepco-total-debris-from-fukushima-daiichi-to-reach-749000-cubic-meters-by-2027/|title=TEPCO: Total Debris from Fukushima Daiichi to Reach 749,000 Cubic Meters by 2027|publisher=JAIF|date=2016-02-16|accessdate=2016-02-16}}</ref>
== 2017 ==
=== 03 February=== TEPCO said the radiation level in the containment vessel of reactor 2 at the crippled Fukushima No. 1 power plant was 530 sieverts per hour, the highest recorded level since the triple core meltdown in March 2011. This is however the first measurement of the radiation level within the reactor area and as such is likely lower than in the initial period after the meltdown. TEPCO also announced that there is a 2-meter hole under the pressure vessel in the reactor’s primary containment vessel.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2017/02/03/national/tepco-finds-gaping-hole-grate-containment-vessel-potential-fuel-debris-fukushima-no-1-power-plant/|title=Highest radiation reading since 3/11 detected at Fukushima No. 1 reactor|publisher= The Japan Times|date=2017-02-03|accessdate=2017-02-03}}</ref>
=== 20 June=== A recent investigation by TEPCO using temperature measurements has determined the probable location of the cores for reactors 1–3. They believe that most of the core debris has breached the pressure vessel and lays at the bottom of the containment vessel for reactors 1 and 3, although some debris seems to be lodged in the control rod drive mechanism for reactor 1. However, they believe that most debris may remain at the bottom of the pressure vessel for reactor 2.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/en/new-data-obtained-on-debris-locations-based-on-temperature-changes-using-reduced-injections-of-water/|title=New Data Obtained on Debris Locations Based on Temperature Changes Using Reduced Injections of Water|publisher= JAIF|date=2017-06-20|accessdate=2017-06-21}}</ref>
=== 19–21 July === A remote operated robot takes the first pictures of the melted core of reactor 3.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jaif.or.jp/en/fuel-debris-at-fukushima-daiichi-unit-3-apparently-located-under-pressure-vessel-and-at-bottom-of-pcv/|title=Fuel Debris at Fukushima Daiichi Unit 3 Apparently Located under Pressure Vessel and at Bottom of PCV|publisher=JAIF|date=2017-07-25|accessdate=2017-07-27}}</ref> Some melted material hangs from the control-rod insertion mechanism under the pressure vessel, and there are piles of rocky objects at the bottom of the PCV that are thought to be melted core.
=== 26 September ===
A revised decommissioning roadmap has the removal of fuel rods from reactor 3 storage pool starting in 2018, but the removal of fuel rods from the reactor 1 and 2 storage pools will be delayed until 2023.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.asahi.com/ajw/articles/AJ201709260025.html|title=3-year delay in removal of fuel rods from Fukushima plant|publisher=The Asahi Shimbun|author=Chikako Kawahara|date=2017-09-26|accessdate=2018-05-09}}</ref> Removal of melted fuel debris from one of the reactors is expected to begin by 2021.
== 2019 ==
=== 15 February===
A robot with two "fingers" makes first contact with the fuel debris in the primary containment vessel (PCV) of reactor 2.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.jaif.or.jp/en/tepco-makes-contact-with-debris-at-fukushima-daiichi-2/|title=TEPCO Makes Contact with Debris at Fukushima Daiichi-2|publisher=JAIF|author=Noriyuki Ishii|date=2019-02-15|accessdate=2019-02-22}}</ref> The robot was able to move loose debris at 7 of the 10 locations probed, providing hope that it may be possible to remove these deposits from the PCV.
