{{Infobox film | name = Surviving the Tsunami - My Atomic Aunt | image = | alt = My Atomic Aunt, Beyond the Wave (Germany) | caption = | film name = Meine Tante aus Fukushima | director = Kyoko Miyake (三宅響子（みやけ きょうこ）) | producer = Gregor Streiber | screenplay = Kyoko Miyake and Friedemann Hottenbacher | story = | based on = | starring = | narrator = Kyoko Miyake | music = L. Jack Ketch and [[Shigeru Umebayashi]] | cinematography = Natsuumi Kozo and Shai Levy | editing = | studio = | distributor = [[Women Make Movies]] (United States), Inselfilm Productions (Germany), [[NHK]] (Japan) | released = March 8, 2013 | runtime = 52/73 minutes | country = Germany, Japan | language = English, Japanese (with subtitles) | budget = | gross = }}
'''''Surviving the Tsunami - My Atomic Aunt''''' is a 2013 [[documentary film]] written, directed, and co-produced by Kyoko Miyake remembers the [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster|Fukushima]] nuclear disaster that occurred on March 11, 2011 by focusing on how the disaster has affected her home town of [[Namie, Fukushima]], Japan. The film develops into a personal reflection on how the Fukushima disaster has affected not only the world, but Miyake herself and the family she once knew.
==Director==
After obtaining her degree in English History from the [[University of Tokyo]], Kyoko Miyake moved to England to study English Witchcraft at [[Oxford University]] as a Swire Centenary Scholar.<ref name="Film Director Always Looking… ">Umehara, Toshiya. "KYOKO MIYAKE: Film Director Always Looking for the Truth." The Asahi Shimbun. The Asahi Shimbun Company, 21 Mar. 2014. Web. <http://ajw.asahi.com/article/globe/people/AJ201403210010></ref><ref name="BritDoc">"My Atomic Aunt." BritDoc. The BRITDOC Foundation, 1 Apr. 2013. Web. <http://britdoc.org/real_films/puma_awards_directory/my-atomic-aunt></ref> While on sabbatical from her doctoral program at Oxford, Miyake began to create historically themed independent documentary films. Her inspiration for her first international feature-length documentary, Surviving the Tsunami, came from her familial connection to the Japanese city of Namie, which had to be completely evacuated after the meltdown of the Fukushima Number One nuclear plant, and her anger at the way the disaster was being portrayed by the larger, mainstream media outlets.<ref name="Film Director Always Looking…" /> Kyoko has directed award winning documentaries including Hackney Lullabies, which have been screened in Berlin, Germany, London, England and Sydney, Australia. Kyoko Miyake currently resides in England.<ref name=BritDoc />
==Synopsis== ''Surviving the Tsunami'' brings together social, environmental, and personal perspectives of the national catastrophe of the Fukushima nuclear meltdown. In the documentary, Kyoko Miyake travels back to her hometown in Namie, Fukushima, to revisit her old life and assess the trauma still lingering from the disaster.<ref name="First Hand Films ">"Surviving the Tsunami - My Atomic Aunt." First Hand Films, 1 Jan. 2013. Web. <http://www.firsthandfilms.com/index.php?film=1000354#film-1000354>.</ref> She revisits Namie, her mother's hometown and meets the people who depended on the success of the nuclear plant for their livelihood. The film also follows Bunsei Watanabe and Kyoko Miyake's Aunt Kuniko, two people who hope for the rejuvenation of Namie, despite the disaster that has occurred.<ref name="Film Director Always Looking…" /> Despite having lost family, friends, and jobs due to the meltdown and subsequent fear of the contamination zone, these two individuals are determined to rebuild their towns and neighborhoods and bring back the sense of community they once had. The film follows the residents of Namie, with emphasis on the experiences of Aunt Kuniko, as they come to terms with the reality of living in or near the "radiation zone" left in the wake the plant's nuclear meltdown.<ref name="First Hand Films" /> Surviving the Tsunami offers a different perspective on Japanese culture, national identity, human adaption, and global nuclear energy and proliferation.<ref>Women Make Movies. Surviving the Tsunami - Atomic Aunt Film Page. http://www.wmm.com/filmcatalog/pages/c865.shtml</ref>
==Production== The documentary was originally titled ''Beyond the Wave,'' yet the completed documentary was released as ''My Atomic Aunt.'' The film aired on seven television networks around the world in 2013, including the [[BBC]], and [[NHK]], Japan's National public broadcasting organization.<ref name="Film Director Always Looking…" />
Jon Lynes, of ''Time Out London'', describes ''Surviving the Tsunami'', as "Haunting and moving ... as hard-hitting as it is simply presented... a timely reminder that the impact of the Fukushima disaster is still being felt....".<ref>Lynes, Jon. "Storyville: ''Surviving the Tsunami – My Atomic Aunt''." ''Time Out London''. 11 Mar. 2013. Web. <http://www.timeout.com/london/tv-and-radio-guide/storyville-surviving-the-tsunami-my-atomic-aunt?>.</ref>
==Awards, festivals, and screenings==
* Hamburg Film Festival * [[Dok Leipzig]] * EDS International Documentary Festival * [[Sundance Institute]] Documentary Grant Winner, Spring 2012 * NaturVision, German Conservation and Sustainability Film Prize, July 2014 * Winner, PUMA Creative Catalyst Award, Channel4 [[BRITDOC Foundation]] * Winner, TIFFCOM Best Pitch Award, at Tokyo International Film Festival * Winner, Best Pitch Award, Tokyo TV Forum 2011 * Winner, Best Japan Pitch, Asian Side of the Doc * Gold Plaque Award, [[Chicago International Film Festival]], Television Awards, April 2014 * Official Selection, Hamburg Film Festival (Germany), September 2013 * Official Selection, [[Dok Leipzig]] (Germany), October 2013 * Official Selection, [[EBS International Documentary Festival]] (South Korea), October 2013 Official Selection, DocPoint (Finland), 2014 * Official Selection, Paris Human Rights Film Festival, 2014

{{Infobox film | name = 3.11: Surviving Japan | image = | caption = Theatrical movie poster | director = Christopher Noland | producer = [[Simon Hilton]] | writer = Christopher Noland | screenplay = | story = | narrator = Christopher Noland | starring = {{Plainlist| *Kouichi Oyama *Chris Noland *[[Helen Caldicott]](archive) *Yumie Keller *Hisako Miura *Yuka Nihei *Kimiaki Toda *Katsunobu Sakurai }} | music = [[Yoko Ono]], Joel F. Wilson, Dimiter Yordanov | cinematography = Christopher Noland | editing = {{Plainlist| *Andrea Hale *MB X. McClain }} | studio = 3.11 Productions, Inc | distributor = 3.11 Productions, inc (USA and Worldwide), Stand, Inc and Eleven Arts JP (Japan, Taiwan) | released = | runtime = 90 minutes | country = Japan, USA | language = English/Japanese | budget = | gross = }} '''''3.11: Surviving Japan''''' is a [[documentary film]] about the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]] and the [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster]] in [[Japan]] written and directed by volunteer and resident Christopher Noland. == Synopsis == The film spans from March 11, 2001 to September 19, 2011, starting with Noland's own experience in the [[Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]], [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster]] followed by volunteer activities in [[Ōfunato, Iwate|Ofunato]]{{cite web | title = Imagine Peace | url=http://imaginepeace.com/archives/15129 | accessdate = 20 March 2012 }} After meeting with volunteers and residents of the affected region that stated huge oversights in the disaster management, Noland continued to volunteer while going on an investigative journey through the [[Tōhoku region]]. He set out to [[Minamisōma, Fukushima]] near the crippled [[Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant]] to speak to the Mayor who had appeared on YouTube{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=70ZHQ--cK40 |title=SOS from Mayor of Minami Soma City, next to the crippled Fukushima nuclear power plant, Japan |publisher=YouTube |date= |accessdate=2012-08-01}} with a distress call that the [[Japanese Government]] had neglected the town during the [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster]]. He then returned north to the [[Miyagi Prefecture]] to interview officials about the crisis management of the tsunami victims.{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0a-_nDTcgU0 |title=Scene from "Surviving Japan " Sendai City Disaster prevention office |publisher=YouTube |date=2011-11-03 |accessdate=2012-08-01}} While on the same food delivery mission that May, he met a woman in [[Ishinomaki, Miyagi|Ishinomaki]] that had been denied food and shelter stating she felt "thrown away as a Japanese citizen{{cite web | title = Official Trailer | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p3h-HACUOeI | accessdate = 20 March 2012 }} which led him to further investigate and document the events.{{cite web | title = IMDB Official Page | url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2262171/ | accessdate = 20 March 2012 }} Noland went back to [[Tokyo]], where he interviewed [[Tokyo Electric Power Company|Tokyo electric power company]] in an effort to gain a better understanding of the impact of the disaster.{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3z2UJagSL6c |title=Clip From "Surviving Japan" TEPCO Interview |publisher=YouTube |date=2012-03-19 |accessdate=2012-08-01}} Unsatisfied with the little amount of information, he went on to interview more residents who shared the same frustration.{{cite episode | title = CBC Connect | url = http://www.cbc.ca/video/#/Shows/1221254309/ID=2208497621 | network = [[CBC Television]] | airdate = 2012-03-09}}

In June Noland returned to the [[Tōhoku region]] to volunteer and see how the people, communities, officials and cities were coping with the rebuilding efforts and [[Radiation]].{{Citation | last = King | first = Anna | title = Washington man directs new Japan disaster documentary | url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=148331783 | accessdate = 20 March 2012 }} He spent the entire summer visiting the largely hit communities of [[Miyako, Iwate|Miyako]], [[Kamaishi, Iwate|Kamaishi]], back to [[Ōfunato, Iwate|Ōfunato]], [[Rikuzentakata, Iwate|Rikuzentakata]], [[Kesennuma, Miyagi|Kesennuma]], [[Minamisanriku, Miyagi|Minami Sanriku]] and [[Ishinomaki, Miyagi|Ishinomaki]].

which led him to further investigate and document the events.{{Citation | last = Hunter | first = Brock | title = Film maker finds unique way to explain the Japan disaster. | url=http://www.news1130.com/news/local/article/339672--film-maker-finds-unique-way-to-explain-the-japan-disaster | accessdate = 20 March 2012 }} By August Noland saw another distress call from [[Minamisōma, Fukushima|Minamisōma]] again on YouTube, this time from a city councilman.{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KSvfro1Hwco |title=SOS Again from Minamisoma, Fukushima (en) |publisher=YouTube |date=2011-07-18 |accessdate=2012-08-01}} Noland contacted the councilman through the volunteer network and arranged a meeting after checking on citizens affected by high levels of [[Radiation]] in [[Fukushima, Fukushima|Fukushima city]] and [[Kōriyama, Fukushima|Kōriyama]]. It was Noland's conclusion that despite everything, the most important thing was the children's safety in the [[Radioactive contamination]] and further awareness of the [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster]] that he felt the media had ignored. Making appearances in the film are [[Helen Caldicott]], founder of [[Physicians for Social Responsibility|PSR]]; [[Cham Dallas|professor Cham Dallas]] a disaster management specialist; Kimiaki Toda, Mayor of [[Ōfunato, Iwate|Ofunato]]; [[Tokyo Electric Power Company]], owner and operator of [[Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant]]; Katsunobu Sakurai, Mayor of [[Minamisōma, Fukushima|Minamisōma]] and Kouichi Oyama, City Councilman of [[Minamisōma, Fukushima|Minamisōma]]. == Production == ''[[imdbtitle:2262171|3.11: Surviving Japan]]'' was conceived, directed, filmed and narrated by Christopher Noland. Executive producer was [[Simon Hilton]]; producers were [https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0452963/#producer Q'orianka Kilcher], Dave Parrish and Christopher Noland; Cinematographer was Christopher Noland; editing was done by Christopher Noland, MB X. McClain and Andrea Hale; sound editor and mixer [https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1383608/?ref_=ttfc_fc_cr22 Scott Delaney]; Soundtrack contribution of "Kurushi" by [[Yoko Ono]]. The documentary was made in exactly one year. Noland began the project as a one-man crew until September when he was joined by MB X. McClain to edit over 100 hours of footage down to 180 minutes until Noland moved back to the United States in late November to finish post-production with editor Andrea Hale. Noland credits the moral support of [[Yoko Ono]], [[Simon Hilton]], and [http://www.imaginepeace.com Imaginepeace.com] for their undying support during his one-man production. ''[[imdbtitle:2262171|3.11: Surviving Japan]]'' had its first pre-screening at [[Simon Fraser University]] on March 10, 2012 for the one-year anniversary of the disaster.{{Citation | last = Johnson | first = Gail | title = Vancouver Fukushima forum weighs nuclear risk with our health | url=https://www.straight.com/article-620421/vancouver/forum-weighs-nuclear-risk-our-health | accessdate = 20 March 2012 }} The film was Officially released on March 11th, 2013 and Premiered at [[Https://www.laemmle.com/theaters/23|Laemmle Noho 7 Theatre]] [[North Hollywood, Los Angeles|North Hollywood, CA]] {{Cite web|url=https://www.tugg.com/events/3-11-surviving-japan-keic|title=https://www.tugg.com/events/3-11-surviving-japan-keic|website=www.tugg.com|access-date=2018-09-08}}with Coverage by [[NHK World-Japan|NHK World]] and [[AMC Theatres]] in [[San Diego]]{{Cite web|url=https://www.tugg.com/events/3-11-surviving-japan-tshx|title=https://www.tugg.com/events/3-11-surviving-japan-tshx|website=www.tugg.com|access-date=2018-09-08}}, [[San Francisco]]{{Cite web|url=https://www.tugg.com/events/3-11-surviving-japan-sttr|title=https://www.tugg.com/events/3-11-surviving-japan-sttr|website=www.tugg.com|access-date=2018-09-08}} and [[New York City]]{{Cite web|url=https://www.tugg.com/events/3-11-surviving-japan|title=https://www.tugg.com/events/3-11-surviving-japan|website=www.tugg.com|access-date=2018-09-08}}. The film Premiered in [[Osaka|Osaka, Japan]] at Cinema 7 in 2014. ==Media response== ''[[imdbtitle:2262171|3.11 Surviving Japan]]'' was immediately picked up by [[Yoko Ono]]'s Imagine Peace Website{{Cite web|url=http://imaginepeace.com/archives/15129|title=On the anniversary of 3/11: SURVIVING JAPAN – UPDATE from Director Chris Noland – IMAGINE PEACE|website=imaginepeace.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-08}}, won the [[IndieWire|Indiewire]] project of the week{{Cite news|url=https://www.indiewire.com/2012/01/congrats-to-surviving-japan-iws-project-of-the-week-49681/|title=Congrats to ‘Surviving Japan,’ IW’s Project of the Week!|last=Renninger|first=Bryce J.|date=2012-01-19|work=IndieWire|access-date=2018-09-08|language=en-US}}, and Noland won the [[YouTube|Youtube]] Nextup Contest in 2011 using clips from the film. [[CBC Radio]]'s ''[[The Current (radio show)|The Current]]''{{cite episode | series = The Current | title = Mothers of Fukushima against Nuclear power | url = http://www.cbc.ca/thecurrent/episode/2012/03/07/mothers-of-fukushima-against-nuclear-power/ | network = [[CBC Radio]] | airdate = 2012-03-07}}{{cite episode | series = The Current | title = The winter that wasn't: Bird migration | url = http://www.cbc.ca/thecurrent/episode/2012/03/07/the-winter-that-wasnt-bird-migration/ | network = [[CBC Radio]] | airdate = 2012-03-07}} [[CBC Television]] interviewed Yumie Keller, an evacuee from [[Minamisōma, Fukushima|Minamisōma]] who appeared in the film. The film received a deluge of press from Vancouver, Canada{{cite web|last=Woo |first=Andrea |url=https://vancouversun.com/news/Nuclear+plant+crisis+from+over+activist/6286875/story.html |title=Nuclear plant crisis far from over: activist |publisher=Vancouversun.com |date=2012-03-12 |accessdate=2012-08-01}}{{cite web|url=http://vancouver.keizai.biz/headline/1449/ |title=バンクーバーで福島原発事故を振り返るカンファレンス－日本からもビデオ講演 - バンクーバー経済新聞 |publisher=Vancouver.keizai.biz |date= |accessdate=2012-08-01}} and Noland's birthplace in [[Washington (state)|Washington State]].{{cite web|last=King |first=Anna |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=148331783 |title=Washington Man Directs New Japan Disaster Documentary |publisher=NPR |date=2012-03-09 |accessdate=2012-08-01}}{{cite news| url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2017741115_quakeevents14m.html | work=The Seattle Times | first=Carol M. | last=Ostrom | title=Nobel winner Caldicott here for Japan nuclear crisis anniversary | date=13 March 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.kplu.org/post/washington-man-directs-new-japan-disaster-documentary |title=Washington Man Directs New Japan Disaster Documentary | KPLU News for Seattle and the Northwest |publisher=Kplu.org |date= |accessdate=2012-08-01}} Noland was interviewed on television by [[NBC]] [[KING-TV|King5]] [[Seattle]], [[NHK World Premium|NHK World News]], and [[RT (TV network)|RT News]]. [[NHK]] did a [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=buFvzvHoNxY feature segment] {{Citation|last=311 Productions, Inc.|title=NHK News on 3 11 Surviving Japan NHK ニュース サバイバル・ジャパン～3 11の真実～|date=2016-04-06|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=buFvzvHoNxY|access-date=2018-09-08}}which appeared on the Japanese 11'oclock News on the 2nd Anniversary of the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami|Tohoku Earthquake and Tsunami]]. The Premiere was in the [[LA Weekly|LAWeekly]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.laweekly.com/movies/311-surviving-japan-2708776|title=3.11: Surviving Japan|work=L.A. Weekly|access-date=2018-09-08}} and was promoted by [[Yoko Ono]], [[Q'orianka Kilcher]] and [[Jared Leto]] for the Los Angeles Premiere. For more articles and updated information please check the films website [http://survivingjapanmovie.com 3.11: Surviving Japan] The Film is available in the [[United States]] on [https://www.amazon.com/s/ref=nb_sb_noss_2?url=search-alias%3Daps&field-keywords=surviving+japan Amazon] and in [[Japan]] at [https://movie-tsutaya.tsite.jp/netdvd/dvd/goodsDetail.do?titleID=2237191777 Tsutaya,] [https://www.amazon.co.jp/サバイバル・ジャパン~3-11の真実~-DVD-クリストファー・ノーランド/dp/B00H993FO8 Amazon.Co.Jp], [https://www.yodobashi.com/product/100000009002026085/ Yodobashi Camera] and [https://tower.jp/item/3363057/サバイバル・ジャパン~3-11の真実~ Tower Records Japan] The Film is also available in The [https://www.yidff.jp Yamagata Film Festival] [http://www.yidff311docs.jp/?post_type=yidff0311&p=78&lng=eng Documentary film archive] as an educational and historical documentary. == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == *{{official|http://survivingjapanmovie.com/}} *{{imdbtitle|2262171}} [[Category:Documentary films about Japan]] [[Category:Documentary films about tsunamis]] [[Category:Documentary films about nuclear technology]] [[Category:Films about the 2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]] [[Category:Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster]] [[Category:2012 films]] [[Category:2010s documentary films]]

{{distinguish|text=the [[Fukushima Daini Nuclear Power Plant]]}} {{See also|Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster}} {{pp-move-indef}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox power station | name = Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant | name_official = | image = Fukushima-1.JPG | image_size = | image_caption = The Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant in 2002 | image_alt = | location_map = Japan Fukushima Prefecture | location_map_size = | location_map_caption = | coordinates = {{coord|37|25|23|N|141|01|59|E|type:landmark_region:JP-07_dim:1000|display=inline, title}} | country = Japan | location = [[Ōkuma, Fukushima]] | status = bd | construction_began = {{Start date|1967|07|25}} | commissioned = {{Start date|1971|03|26}} | decommissioned = | cost = | owner = | operator = [[Tokyo Electric Power Company]] | ps_units_uc = | ps_units_planned = | ps_units_decommissioned = 1 × 460 [[Megawatt|MWe]] (Unit 1 damaged)
4 × 784 [[Megawatt|MWe]] (Units 2, 3, and 4 damaged; Unit 5 slightly damaged)
1 × 1100 [[Megawatt|MWe]] (unit 6 slightly damaged) | np_reactor_type = BWR | np_reactor_supplier = [[General Electric]]
[[Toshiba]]
[[Hitachi]] | ps_units_manu_model = | ps_electrical_capacity = | ps_electrical_cap_fac = | ps_annual_generation = | website = http://www.tepco.co.jp/en/nu/press/f1-np/index-e.html | extra = }} The {{nihongo|'''Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant'''|福島第一原子力発電所|Fukushima [[Daiichi]] Genshiryoku Hatsudensho}} is a disabled [[nuclear power plant]] located on a {{convert|3.5|km2|acre|adj=on}} site{{Cite web|url=http://www.tepco.co.jp/nu/f1-np/pavilion/course1-j.html |title=Tepco site (Japanese). One Week Plant Grounds Course. 福島第一原子力発電所 {{!}} PR施設：構内見学コース |last= |first= |date=2011-04-07 |website= |publisher= |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110407093419/http://www.tepco.co.jp/nu/f1-np/pavilion/course1-j.html |archive-date=April 7, 2011 |access-date=2016-10-27 |quote=３５０万平方メートルの広い敷地に = 3.5 km² |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }} in the towns of [[Ōkuma, Fukushima|Ōkuma]] and [[Futaba, Fukushima|Futaba]] in the [[Fukushima Prefecture]], Japan. The plant [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster|suffered major damage]] from the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami|magnitude 9.0 earthquake and tsunami]] that hit Japan on March 11, 2011. The chain of events caused radiation leaks and permanently damaged several reactors, making them impossible to restart. By political decision, the remaining reactors were not restarted. First commissioned in 1971, the plant consists of six [[boiling water reactor]]s. These [[light water reactor]]s{{cite web |url=http://www2.jnes.go.jp/atom-db/en/general/atomic/ke02a13/info_f.html |title=Tokyo Electric Power Co. Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station |publisher=jnes.go.jp |accessdate=March 17, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110314081817/http://www2.jnes.go.jp/atom-db/en/general/atomic/ke02a13/info_f.html |archivedate=March 14, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} drove electrical generators with a combined power of 4.7 GWe, making Fukushima Daiichi one of the 15 largest [[List of nuclear power stations|nuclear power stations in the world]]. Fukushima was the first nuclear plant to be designed, constructed and run in conjunction with [[General Electric]] and [[Tokyo Electric Power Company]] (TEPCO).{{cite web|url=http://www.asahi.com/english/TKY201104060126.html|title=The Asahi Shimbun|publisher=|accessdate=February 7, 2017}}{{dl|date=November 2017}} The March 2011 disaster disabled the reactor cooling systems, leading to releases of radioactivity and triggering a 30 km evacuation zone surrounding the plant; the releases continue to this day. On April 20, 2011, the Japanese authorities declared the 20 km evacuation zone a no-go area which may only be entered under government supervision. In April 2012, Units 1-4 were decommissioned. Units 2-4 were decommissioned on April 19, while Unit 1 was the last of these four units to be decommissioned on April 20 at midnight.{{Citation needed|date=January 2013}} In December 2013 TEPCO decided none of the undamaged units will reopen. The sister nuclear plant [[Fukushima II Nuclear Power Plant|Fukushima Daini]] ([[dai-ichi#Related phrases|"number two"]]), {{convert|12|km|abbr=on}} to the south, is also run by TEPCO. It also suffered serious damages during the tsunami, especially at the seawater intakes of all four units, but could be shut down and brought to a safe state through [[Fukushima Daini Nuclear Power Plant#2011 earthquake and tsunami |extraordinary actions]] by the plant crew.{{cite book |title=The Fukushima Daiichi Accident |date=2015-08-31 |publisher=IAEA - International Atomic Energy Agency |location=Wienna |isbn=978-92-0-107015-9 |pages=131-132 |url=https://www-pub.iaea.org/MTCD/Publications/PDF/AdditionalVolumes/P1710/Pub1710-TV1-Web.pdf |accessdate=2018-10-12}} ==Power plant information== [[File:Reaktor.svg|thumb|left|Cross-section sketch of a typical BWR Mark I containment, as used in Units 1 to 5. The reactor core (1) consists of fuel rods and control rods (39) which are moved in and out by the device (31). Around the pressure vessel (8), there is an outer containment (19) which is closed by a concrete plug (2). When fuel rods are moved in or out, the crane (26) will move this plug to the pool for facilities (3). Steam from the dry well (11) can move to the wet well (24) through jet nozzles (14) to condense there (18). In the spent fuel pool (5), the used fuel rods (27) are stored.]] The reactors for Units 1, 2, and 6 were supplied by [[General Electric]], those for Units 3 and 5 by [[Toshiba]], and Unit 4 by [[Hitachi]]. All six reactors were designed by General Electric. {{Cite news |url=http://openchannel.msnbc.msn.com/_news/2011/03/13/6256121-general-electric-designed-reactors-in-fukushima-have-23-sisters-in-us |first=Bill |last=Dedman |publisher=MSNBC |date=March 13, 2011 |title=General Electric-designed reactors in Fukushima have 23 sisters in U.S |accessdate=March 14, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120320141531/http://openchannel.msnbc.msn.com/_news/2011/03/13/6256121-general-electric-designed-reactors-in-fukushima-have-23-sisters-in-us |archivedate=March 20, 2012 |df=mdy }}Asami, Eiichi ([[Kyodo News]]), "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110914f2.html American's Fukushima legacy lives on]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', September 14, 2011, p. 3. Architectural design for General Electric's units was done by [[Electric Bond and Share Company|Ebasco]]. All construction was done by [[Kajima]].{{cite web|url=http://nuctrans.org/Nuc_Trans/locations/daiichi/daiichi.htm |title=Nuclear Reactor Maps: Fukushima-Daiichi |publisher=Council for Security Cooperation in the Asia Pacific |accessdate=March 14, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130115221836/http://nuctrans.org/Nuc_Trans/locations/daiichi/daiichi.htm |archivedate=January 15, 2013 |df=mdy }} Since September 2010, Unit 3 has been fueled by a small fraction (6%){{Cite news| url = https://www.npr.org/2011/03/16/134600825/plutonium-in-fuel-rods-cause-for-concern| work=National Public Radio| date=March 16, 2011| title= Plutonium In Fuel Rods: Cause For Concern?| accessdate=March 20, 2011}} of [[plutonium]] containing [[MOX fuel|mixed-oxide (MOX) fuel]], rather than the [[low enriched uranium]] (LEU) used in the other reactors.{{Cite news| url = http://nuclearstreet.com/nuclear_power_industry_news/b/nuclear_power_news/archive/2010/09/17/fukushima-to-restart-using-mox-fuel-for-first-time-091704.aspx| work=Nuclear Street| date=September 17, 2010| title= Fukushima to Restart Using MOX Fuel for First Time| accessdate=March 12, 2011}}{{Cite news| url = http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/newsarticle.aspx?id=28211| work=World Nuclear News| date=August 10, 2010| title= Third Japanese reactor to load MOX| accessdate=March 12, 2011}} Units 1–5 were built with [[Boiling water reactor safety systems#Varieties of BWR containments|Mark I type]] (light bulb torus) [[Containment building|containment structures]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nirs.org/reactorwatch/accidents/Fukushimafactsheet.pdf |title=Fact Sheet on Fukushima Nuclear Power Plant |date=March 13, 2011 |publisher=Nuclear Information and Resource Service |accessdate=March 13, 2011}} The Mark I containment structure was slightly increased in volume by Japanese engineers.Lahey, R.T. and Moody, F.J., "The Thermal-Hydraulics of a Boiling Water Reactor", second edition, 1993. Unit 6 has a Mark II type (over/under) containment structure.{{Cite journal|url=https://www.nrc.gov/reading-rm/doc-collections/nuregs/contract/cr6906/cr6906.pdf |title=Containment Integrity Research at Sandia National Laboratories – An Overview |date=July 2006 |author=[[Sandia National Laboratories]] |publisher=U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission |id=NUREG/CR-6906, SAND2006-2274P |accessdate=March 13, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721061706/http://www.nrc.gov/reading-rm/doc-collections/nuregs/contract/cr6906/cr6906.pdf |archivedate=July 21, 2011 |df=mdy }} Unit 1 is a 460 MW [[boiling water reactor]] ([[Boiling water reactor#First series of production|BWR-3]]) constructed in July 1967. It commenced commercial electrical production on March 26, 1971, and was initially scheduled for shutdown in early 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.icjt.org/npp/podrobnosti.php?drzava=14&lokacija=818 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120801185152/http://www.icjt.org/npp/podrobnosti.php?drzava=14&lokacija=818 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=August 1, 2012 |title=Fukushima Daiichi Information Screen |publisher=Icjt.org |accessdate=March 15, 2011 }} In February 2011, Japanese regulators granted an extension of ten years for the continued operation of the reactor.{{Cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/feeds/ap/2011/03/12/general-as-japan-quake-power-plant_8352691.html|title= Japan quake causes emergencies at 5 nuke reactors|first1 = Mari | last1 = Yamaguchi |first2 = Jeff | last2 = Donn|work=Forbes | date=March 12, 2011 | accessdate=March 12, 2011}} It was damaged during the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]].{{cite web|url=http://www.icjt.org/plants/uni/a/uni194a.html |title= Nuke database system: fukushima daiichi-1 | publisher=ICJT Nuclear Training Centre|accessdate=March 12, 2011}} Unit 1 was designed for a [[peak ground acceleration]] of 0.18 [[g-force|g]] (1.74 m/s2) and a [[response spectrum]] based on the [[1952 Kern County earthquake]], but rated for 0.498 g.{{Cite book| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=qEuWntnoZzYC&pg=PA123 | publisher=[[United States Department of Commerce]], [[National Institute of Standards and Technology|National Bureau of Standards]]| first = A. Gerald | last = Brady| editor = Ellingwood, Bruce| year= 1980| page = 123| title= An Investigation of the Miyagi-ken-oki, Japan, earthquake of June 12, 1978 | volume = 592| series = NBS special publication}}[http://isterre.fr/IMG/pdf/acceleration_data_tentative_estimate_.pdf ]{{dead link|date=December 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} The design basis for Units 3 and 6 were 0.45 g (4.41 m/s2) and 0.46 g (4.48 m/s2) respectively.{{cite web | url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/RS_Fukushima_faced_14-metre_tsunami_2303113.html| title=Fukushima faced 14-metre tsunami| date=March 24, 2011| work=[[World Nuclear News]]| accessdate=March 24, 2011}} All units were inspected after the [[1978 Miyagi earthquake]] when the [[ground acceleration]] was 0.125 g (1.22 m/s2) for 30 seconds, but no damage to the critical parts of the reactor was discovered. The design basis for tsunamis was 5.7 meters.{{cite news |url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/RS_Stabilisation_at_Fukushima_Daiichi_2003111.html | title=Stabilisation at Fukushima Daiichi, update 2| work =World Nuclear News | date= March 20, 2011 | accessdate =March 20, 2011}} The reactor's emergency diesel generators and DC batteries, crucial components in helping keep the reactors cool in the event of a power loss, were located in the basements of the reactor turbine buildings. The reactor design plans provided by General Electric specified placing the generators and batteries in that location, but mid-level engineers working on the construction of the plant were concerned that this made the backup power systems vulnerable to flooding. TEPCO elected to strictly follow General Electric's design in the construction of the reactors.Yoshida, Reiji, "[http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2011/07/14/national/ge-plan-followed-with-inflexibility GE plan followed with inflexibility]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', July 14, 2011, p. 1. {{clear left}} ===Site layout=== [[File:Fukushima I NPP 1975 medium crop rotated labeled.jpg|thumb|Aerial view of the plant area in 1975, showing separation between Units 5 & 6, and the majority of the complex
・Unit 6: direction of [[Sōma, Fukushima|Sōma]]
・Unit 4: direction of [[Iwaki, Fukushima|Iwaki]]]] The plant is on a bluff which was originally 35 meters above sea level. During construction, however, TEPCO lowered the height of the bluff by 25 meters. One reason for lowering the bluff was to allow the base of the reactors to be constructed on solid bedrock in order to mitigate the threat posed by earthquakes. Another reason was the lowered height would keep the running costs of the seawater pumps low. TEPCO's analysis of the tsunami risk when planning the site's construction determined that the lower elevation was safe because the sea wall would provide adequate protection for the maximum tsunami assumed by the design basis. However, the lower site elevation did increase the vulnerability for a tsunami larger than anticipated in design.{{cite web | title=Fukushima plant site originally was a hill safe from tsunami | url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110712x2.html |work=The Japan Times | accessdate=September 29, 2011}} The Fukushima Daiichi site is divided into two reactor groups, the leftmost group - when viewing from the ocean - contains units 4, 3, 2 and 1 going from left to right. The rightmost group - when viewing from the ocean - contains the newer units 5 and 6, respectively, the positions from left to right. A set of seawalls protrude into the ocean, with the water intake in the middle and water discharge outlets on either side. File:Fukushima I NPP 1975.jpg|Aerial view of the Fukushima I plant area in 1975, showing sea walls and completed reactors File:Fukushima I NPP 1975 reactors 1 to 4 crop.jpg|Closeup of Units 4, 3, 2 and 1 File:Fukushima I Nuclear Powerplant site close-up (wotext).PNG|Major buildings File:Fukushima I nuclear accidents diagram.svg|Illustration of post-accident state of 1–4 reactors, all but 2 display obvious damage to secondary containment ===Reactor data=== Units 7 and 8 were planned to start construction in April 2012 and 2013 and to come into operation in October 2016 and 2017 respectively. The project was formally canceled by TEPCO in April 2011 after local authorities questioned the fact that they were still included in the supply plan for 2011, released in March 2011, after the accidents. The company stated that the plan had been drafted before the earthquake.Asahi. [http://www.asahi.com/business/update/0405/TKY201104050566.html Tepco Withdrawal of Plans for New Construction at Fukushima Daiichi]. (Mark II) | 1067 MW | October 26, 1973 | March 9, 1979 | October 24, 1979 | December 17, 2013 | General Electric | Ebasco | Kajima |- | 7 (planned) | [[Advanced Boiling Water Reactor|ABWR]] | 1380 MW | Canceled 04/2011 | Planned 10/2016 | | | | | |- | 8 (planned) | ABWR | 1380 MW | Canceled 04/2011 | Planned 10/2017 | | | | | |} ===Electrical connections=== The Fukushima Daiichi plant is connected to the power grid by four lines, the 500 kV Futaba Line (双葉線), the two 275 kV Ōkuma Lines (大熊線) and the 66 kV Yonomori Line (夜の森線) to the Shin-Fukushima (New Fukushima) substation. The Shin-Fukushima substation also connects to the Fukushima Daini plant by the Tomioka Line (富岡線). Its major connection to the north is the Iwaki Line (いわき幹線), which is owned by [[Tohoku Electric Power]]. It has two connections to the south-west that connect it to the Shin-Iwaki substation (新いわき). ===Operating history=== [[File:HD.15.055 (11839699333).jpg|thumb|Plant still under construction circa 1971]] The plant reactors came online one at a time beginning in 1970 and the last in 1979. From the end of 2002 through 2005, the reactors were among those shut down for a time for safety checks due to the [[Tokyo Electric Power Company#Scandal|TEPCO data falsification scandal]].{{Cite news |title=Heavy fallout from Japan nuclear scandal |url=http://archives.cnn.com/2002/BUSINESS/asia/09/02/japan.tepco/index.html |accessdate=March 15, 2011 |publisher=CNN |date=September 2, 2002 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110315065851/http://archives.cnn.com/2002/BUSINESS/asia/09/02/japan.tepco/index.html |archivedate=March 15, 2011 |df=mdy }}{{Cite book | publisher=[[Bloomsbury Publishing]]| first = Stephanie | last = Cooke| year= 2009| page = 388| title= [[In Mortal Hands: A Cautionary History of the Nuclear Age]]| isbn = 978-1-59691-617-3}} On February 28, 2011, TEPCO submitted a report to the Japanese [[Nuclear and Industrial Safety Agency]] admitting that the company had previously submitted fake inspection and repair reports. The report revealed that TEPCO failed to inspect more than 30 technical components of the six reactors, including power boards for the reactor's temperature control valves, as well as components of cooling systems such as water pump motors and emergency power diesel generators.{{Cite news|title=Operator of Fukushima nuke plant admitted to faking repair records |url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/special-reports/operator-of-fukushima-nuke-plant-admitted-to-faking-repair-records/story-fn858jk3-1226024977934 |accessdate=March 20, 2011|work=Herald Sun |location=Australia|date=March 20, 2011}} In 2008, the IAEA warned Japan that the Fukushima plant was built using outdated safety guidelines, and could be a "serious problem" during a large earthquake.http://www.indianexpress.com/news/iaea-warned-japan-over-nuclear-quake-risk-wikileaks/763709/ IAEA warned Japan over nuclear quake risk: WikiLeaks The warning led to the building of an emergency response center in 2010, used during the response to the 2011 nuclear accident.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/japan/8408863/Japan-tsunami-Fukushima-Fifty-the-first-interview.html|title=Japan tsunami: Fukushima Fifty, the first interview|publisher=|accessdate=February 7, 2017}} On April 5, 2011, TEPCO vice president Takashi Fujimoto announced that the company was canceling plans to build Reactors No. 7 and 8.''[[Mainichi Shimbun]]'', "TEPCO to drop plan to add two reactors at Fukushima nuclear plant", April 5, 2011.Higgins, Andrew, ''[[Washington Post]]'', "March 26: More reactors sought for plant?", ''[[Japan Times]]'', April 7, 2011, p. 2. On May 20 TEPCO's board of directors' officially voted to decommission Units 1 through 4 of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant and to cancel plans to build units 7 and 8. It refused however to make a decision regarding units 5 and 6 of the station or units 1 to 4 of the Fukushima Daini nuclear power station until a detailed investigation is made. In December 2013 TEPCO decided to decommission the undamaged units 5 and 6; they may be used to test remote clean-up methods before use on the damaged reactors.{{cite news |url=http://www.neimagazine.com/news/newstepco-will-decommission-fukushima-daiichi-56-4149387 |title=TEPCO will decommission Fukushima Daiichi 5&6 |publisher=Nuclear Engineering International |date=19 December 2013 |accessdate=21 December 2013}} {{hidden begin |toggle=left |title=Electricity generation for the Fukushima I NPP by Unit in GW·h{{cite web|title=Japan: Nuclear Power Reactors|url=http://www.iaea.org/cgi-bin/db.page.pl/pris.powrea.htm?country=JP|work=Power Reactor Information System – PRIS|publisher=IAEA|accessdate=March 14, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110528122321/http://www.iaea.org/cgi-bin/db.page.pl/pris.powrea.htm?country=JP|archivedate=May 28, 2011|df=mdy-all}}}} [[File:Electricity generation Fukushima I.png|thumb|upright=2.0|Electricity generation for the Fukushima I]] {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align: center;" |- ! 4903.293 || 4037.601 || 5462.108 || 5720.079 || 7130.99 |- | 2010 || 2089.015 || || || 6040.782 || || |} {{hidden end}} ==Warnings and design critique== In 1990, the U.S. [[Nuclear Regulatory Commission]] (NRC) ranked the failure of the emergency electricity generators and subsequent failure of the cooling systems of plants in seismically very active regions one of the most likely risks. The Japanese [[Nuclear and Industrial Safety Agency]] (NISA) cited this report in 2004. According to Jun Tateno, a former NISA scientist, TEPCO did not react to these warnings and did not respond with any measures.[https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-16/japan-s-reactor-risk-foretold-20-years-ago-in-u-s-nuclear-agency-s-report.html Makiko Kitamura, Maki Shiraki (Bloomberg, 16. März 2011): ''Japan's Reactor Risk Foretold 20 Years Ago in U.S. Agency Report''] Filmmaker [[Adam Curtis]] mentioned the risks of the type of [[boiling water reactor]]s cooling systems such as those in Fukushima I,{{cite web |author=Adam Curtis |title=A Is For Atom |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/adamcurtis/2011/03/a_is_for_atom.html | work=British Broadcasting Corporation | date=16 March 2011 |accessdate=19 May 2013}} and claimed the risks were known since 1971{{cite web|url=http://www.heise.de/tp/r4/artikel/34/34395/1.html |title=Notkühlprobleme von Fukushima-Reaktoren seit 1971 bekannt |author=Ralf Streck |publisher=Heise Zeitschriften Verlag |work=[[Telepolis]] |date=March 22, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xcyTaLqC?url=http://www.heise.de/tp/r4/artikel/34/34395/1.html |archivedate=April 1, 2011 |accessdate=April 1, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }} in a series of documentaries in the BBC in 1992 and advised that [[Pressurized water reactor|PWR type]] reactors should have been used. [[Tokyo Electric Power Company|TEPCO]], that operated the station, had been warned their seawall was insufficient to withstand a powerful tsunami, but the seawall height was not increased in response. While other stations run by the [[Tohoku Electric Power]] company had much more robust seawalls (such as the [[Onagawa Nuclear Power Plant]]) down the coast closer to the epicenter of the earthquake, the Fukushima Plant did not. ==Incidents and accidents== ===Prior to March 2011=== ====1978==== Fuel rods fell in reactor No. 3, causing a nuclear reaction.{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704396504576204461929992144?mod=WSJ_topics_obama|date=March 16, 2011|title=Plant's Design, Safety Record Are Under Scrutiny|author=NORIHIKO SHIROUZU and REBECCA SMITH|work=The Wall Street Journal}} It took about seven and a half hours to place the rods back into proper positions.Ikuko Kao, [http://uk.reuters.com/article/2007/03/22/japan-tepco-nuclear-idUKT16854920070322 Japan's TEPCO admits 1978 nuclear criticality], Reuters, March 22, 2007 ====February 25, 2009==== A manual shutdown was initiated during the middle of a start-up operation. The cause was a high pressure alarm that was caused by the shutting of a turbine bypass valve. The reactor was at 12% of full power when the alarm occurred at 4:03 am (local time) due to a pressure increase to 1,030 psi (7,100 kPa), exceeding the regulatory limit of 1,002 psi (6,910 kPa). The reactor was reduced to 0% power, which exceeded the 5% threshold that requires event reporting, and pressure dropped back under the regulatory limit at 4:25 am. Later, at 8:49 am the control blades were completely inserted, constituting a manual reactor shutdown. An inspection then confirmed that one of the 8 bypass valves had closed and that the valve had a bad driving fluid connection. The reactor had been starting up following its 25th regular inspection, which had begun on October 18, 2008.Tepco official release (Japanese).[http://www.tepco.co.jp/cc/press/09022501-j.html Manual shutdown during reactor startup operations in Fukushima I-1]. February 2, 2009. ====March 26, 2009==== Unit 3 had problems with over-insertion of control blades during outage. Repair work was being done on equipment that regulates the driving pressure for the control blades, and when a valve was opened at 2:23 pm a control blade drift alarm went off. On later inspection, it was found that several of the rods had been unintentionally inserted.Tepco official release (Japanese). [http://www.tepco.co.jp/cc/press/09032602-j.html Over-insertion of control rods in Fukushima I-3]. ====November 2, 2010==== Unit 5 had an automatic [[SCRAM]] while an operator was conducting an adjustment to the [[control blade]] insertion pattern. The [[SCRAM]] was caused by a reactor low water level alarm. The turbine tripped along with the reactor and there was no radiation injury to workers.Tepco official release (Japanese). [http://www.tepco.co.jp/cc/press/10110201-j.html Fukushima I-5 Automatic SCRAM Information]. ===Nuclear disaster of March 2011=== {{Main article|Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster}} {{See also|Timeline of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster}} [[File:Fukushima I by Digital Globe crop.jpg|thumb|Three of the reactors at Fukushima Daiichi overheated, causing [[Nuclear meltdown|meltdowns]] that eventually led to explosions, which released large amounts of [[radioactive]] material into the air.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/02/world/asia/02japan.html?_r=1&ref=world |title=Report Finds Japan Underestimated Tsunami Danger |author=Martin Fackler |date=June 1, 2011 |work=New York Times }}]] On March 11, 2011, an [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami|earthquake categorized as 9.0 MW]] on the [[moment magnitude scale]] occurred at 14:46 [[Japan Standard Time]] (JST) off the northeast coast of Japan, one of the most powerful earthquakes in history. Units 4, 5 and 6 had been "shut down" prior to the earthquake for planned maintenance.{{Cite news|last=Black |first=Richard |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-12745186 |title=Reactor breach worsens prospects |publisher=BBC News |date= March 15, 2011|accessdate=March 17, 2011}}{{cite web | url = http://www.noypi.ph/index.php/nation/3295-government-scientists-on-japan-nuke-meltdown-no-need-to-worry.html | title = Government Scientists on Japan Nuke Meltdown "No need to worry" | accessdate =March 14, 2011 | publisher=Noypi.ph | author=Biela Liwag}} The remaining reactors were shut down/[[SCRAM]]ed automatically after the earthquake, and the remaining decay heat of the fuel was being cooled with power from emergency generators. The subsequent destructive [[tsunami]] with waves of up to 14 meters that over-topped the station, which had seawalls, disabled emergency generators required to cool the reactors and [[Spent fuel pool]]s in Units 1-5. Over the following three weeks there was evidence of partial [[nuclear meltdown]]s in units 1, 2 and 3: visible explosions, suspected to be caused by hydrogen gas, in units 1 and 3; a suspected explosion in unit 2, that may have damaged the primary containment vessel; and a possible uncovering of the [[Spent fuel pool]]s in Units 1, 3 and 4.{{cite web|url=http://www.nisa.meti.go.jp/english/files/en20110327-2-2.pdf|title=Conditions of Fukushima Dai-ichi Nuclear Power Station Unit 2 as of 14:00 March 27, 2011|publisher=|accessdate=February 7, 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110523050242/http://www.nisa.meti.go.jp/english/files/en20110327-2-2.pdf|archivedate=May 23, 2011|df=mdy-all}} Units 5 & 6 were reported on March 19, by the station-wide ''alert log updates'' of the [[IAEA]], to have gradually rising spent fuel pool temperatures as they had likewise lost offsite power, but onsite power provided by Unit 6's two diesel generators that had not been flooded, were configured to do double-duty and cool both Unit 5 and 6's spent fuel pools "and cores".{{cite web|url=http://www.iaea.org/press/?p=1463|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607091828/http://www.iaea.org/press/?p=1463|dead-url=yes|archive-date=June 7, 2011|title=Japanese Earthquake Update (19 March 2011, 4:30 UTC) : IAEA Alert Log: Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Accident|date=June 7, 2011|publisher=|accessdate=February 7, 2017}} As a precautionary measure, vents in the roofs of these two units were also made to prevent the possibility of hydrogen gas pressurization and then ignition. Radiation releases from Units 1-4 caused large evacuations, concern about food and water supplies, and treatment of nuclear workers.[http://www.businessweek.com/ap/financialnews/D9M59PR00.htm Anxiety in Tokyo over radiation in tap water]{{cite web|url = http://english.kyodonews.jp/news/2011/03/78123.html | title= Radiation leak feared at nuke plant, people urged to stay indoors|publisher=[[Kyodo News Agency]]|date=March 15, 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110316145026/http://english.kyodonews.jp/news/2011/03/78123.html|archivedate=March 16, 2011}}{{cite news|publisher=[[World Nuclear News]]|date=March 24, 2011|title=Exposures and progress at Fukushima Daiichi|url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/RS_Exposures_and_progress_at_Fukushima_Daiichi_240311.html}} Radiation releases also contaminated the 2011 harvest. The events at units 1, 2 and 3 have been rated at Level 5 each on the [[International Nuclear Event Scale]], and those at unit 4 as Level 3 (Serious Incident) events, with the overall plant rating at Level 7 (major release of radioactive material with widespread health and environmental effects requiring implementation of planned and extended countermeasures).{{cite web|url=http://www.iaea.org/newscenter/news/2011/fukushimafull.html|title=Japan Earthquake Update|date=March 19, 2011|work=[[IAEA]]}} ===After March 2011=== [[File:IAEA Experts at Fukushima (02813336).jpg|thumb|IAEA Experts at Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant Unit 4, 2013]] ====April 3, 2011==== 2 bodies were discovered in the basement turbine room, most likely because the workers ran there during the tsunami. ====April 9, 2013==== Radioactive water leaked from the storage units, minimally contaminating the [[soil]] and [[water]] nearby. The leak was controlled and stored in a contained area. The stored water continues to require maintenance, until its ultimate purification.RussiaToday. [http://www.dw.de/radioactive-water-leaks-from-fukushima-nuclear-plant/a-16725927]. ====July 9, 2013==== [[TEPCO]] officials reported that radioactive [[caesium]] was 90 times higher than it was 3 days prior (July 6), and that it may spread into the [[Pacific Ocean]]. TEPCO reported that the caesium-134 levels in the well water were measured at 9 kilobecquerel per liter, 150 times the legal level, while [[Caesium-137]] was measured at 18 kilobecquerel per liter, 200 times the permitted level.{{Cite news|last=Black |first=Richard |url=http://rt.com/news/radiation-levels-soar-fukushima-839/|title=Radioactive cesium level soars 90-fold at Fukushima in just 3 days}} ====August 7, 2013==== Japanese officials said highly radioactive water was leaking from Fukushima Daiichi into the Pacific Ocean at a rate of 300 tons (about 272 metric tons) per day. Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe ordered government officials to step in.{{Cite news|last=Saito |first=Mari and Antoni Slodkowski |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/08/08/us-japan-fukushima-pm-idUSBRE97601K20130808 |title=Japan says Fukushima leak worse than thought, government joins clean-up |publisher=Reuters|date=August 8, 2013|accessdate=August 8, 2013}} ====April 12, 2016==== Melted reactors were being cooled down with 300 tonnes of water each day. {{ cite web| title=Japan prepares to release thousands of tonnes of water containing radioactive tritium from the beleaguered Fukushima plant amid fears for impact on Pacific Ocean;from google (tritium in water taste) page 2 result 10| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3536451/Japan-prepares-release-thousands-tonnes-water-containing-radioactive-tritium-Fukushima-nuclear-power-plant-destroyed-huge-tsunami-2011.html }} ====November 21, 2016==== In November 2016, a 6.9 magnitude earthquake struck off the northeast coast of Japan, causing a 1m tsunami to hit the Fukishima plant. A cooling system for spent nuclear fuel was temporarily stopped.{{citation needed|date=August 2017}} ==Dismantling of reactors== The reactors will take 30-40 years to be decommissioned.{{Cite web|url=https://www7.tepco.co.jp/responsibility/decommissioning/index-e.html|title=Fukushima Daiichi Decommissioning Project {{!}} TEPCO|website=www7.tepco.co.jp|access-date=2018-12-22}} On August 1, 2013, the Japanese Industry Minister [[Toshimitsu Motegi]] approved the creation of a structure to develop the technologies and processes necessary to dismantle the four reactors damaged in the Fukushima accident.[http://www.actu-environnement.com/ae/news/fukushima-structure-technologies-demantelement-reacteurs-fukushima-combustible-fondu-19219.php4 Fukushima : une structure dédiée aux technologies de démantèlement des réacteurs], "Actu environnement", August 2, 2013 ==See also== {{Portal|Japan|Nuclear technology|Energy}} {{Commons category|Fukushima I Nuclear Power Plant}} * [[GE Three]] * [[List of boiling water reactors]] * [[List of earthquakes in Japan]] * [[Nuclear power in Japan]] ;2011 earthquake and tsunami accident * [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster]] * [[International reactions to the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster]] * [[Japanese reaction to Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster]] * [[Radiation effects from the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster]] {{clear}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{sister project links|wikt=no|q=no|b=no|s=no|v=no|species=no}} * [http://www.tepco.co.jp/nu/f1-np/index-j.html Official site Tokyo Electric Company 東京電力・福島第一原子力発電所] {{ja icon}} * [https://www.panoramio.com/photo/46503912 Archived photo]. {{refimprove|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox organization |name = Safecast |logo = Safecast.org logo boxed version.svg |founded_date = {{start date and age|2011}} |founder = Sean Bonner, Joi Ito and Pieter Franken |location = Dogenzaka ([[Shibuya]], Japan) |origins = |key_people = Sean Bonner, Joi Ito, Pieter Franken |area_served = |focus = open citizen science |method = volunteer based data collecting, open hardware development, online data network |revenue = |endowment = |num_volunteers = About 900 (End of 2016)<ref>[[deutschlandfunk.de]], ''[[Forschung aktuell]]'', 29. Dezember 2016, [[Dagmar Röhrlich]]: [http://www.deutschlandfunk.de/citizen-science-netzwerk-safecast-von-der-hausfrau-bis-zum.676.de.html?dram%3Aarticle_id=375121 ''Von der Hausfrau bis zum Strahlenexperten''] (30. Dezember 2016)</ref> |owner = |Non-profit_slogan = |homepage = [http://www.safecast.org/ safecast.org] |dissolved = |footnotes = }} '''Safecast''' is an international, volunteer-centered organization devoted to open [[citizen science]] for the environment. Safecast was established by Sean Bonner, Pieter Franken, and [[Joi Ito]] shortly after the [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster]] in Japan, following the [[Tōhoku earthquake]] on 11 March 2011 and manages a global [[open data]] network for [[ionizing radiation]] monitoring.
The Safecast team, with help of International Medcom, Tokyo [[Hackerspace]] and other volunteers, has designed various [https://github.com/Safecast/General/wiki/Safecast-Devices devices] for radiation mapping. These include the bGeigie and bGeigie Nano for mobile applications (carborne and walking measurements) as well as fixed stations called Pointcast.
All data are collected via the [http://api.safecast.org/ Safecast API] and are presented on the publicly available interactive [http://safecast.org/tilemap/ Safecast Tile Map].
Safecast later expanded to offer [[air quality]] sensors which also report open [[Crowdsourcing|crowdsourced]] maps.
==bGeigie Nano== Safecast bGeigie Nano is a portable radiation detector equipped with a [[Geiger-Mueller tube]] type detector, built-in GPS and logging to microSD card.
<gallery widths="200" heights="150"> File:Safecast bGeigie Nano - closed.jpg|bGeigie Nano with closed case File:Safecast bGeigie Nano opened.jpg|Safecast bGeigie Nano opened </gallery>
[[Image:Safecast Tile Map screenshot.jpeg|250px|right|thumb|Screenshot of Safecast Tile Map website with data visualization]]
The bGeigie Nano is available as a kit, so the user needs to learn how to solder in order to build it from the supplied parts. The kit can be purchased from the [https://kithub.cc/safecast/ Kithub product page]. The device was developed in collaboration with International Medcom Inc. and shares some parts with their [https://medcom.com/product/imi-inspector-alert-surface-contamination-meter/ Inspector Alert™] detector. According to the [https://github.com/Safecast/bGeigie-transitional Safecast Github page] ''"bGeigie Nano is a lighter version of the bGeigie Mini using an Arduino Fio, a GpsBee, an OpenLog and an Inspector Alert geiger counter. The aim is to make everything fit in a Pelican Micro Case 1040"''. The final version of the bGeigie is placed inside the smaller Pelican Micro Case 1010. It features the [http://www.lndinc.com/products/17/ LND 7317] pancake [[Geiger-Mueller tube]] type detector, a GPS receiver and is expandable with a Bluetooth module. The mode switch offers choice between geotagged radiation logging (data saved to microSD card) and measuring without GPS - showing also Bq/m2 (Cs137) values. Inside the case the unit is calibrated for gamma radiation. The main unit taken out of its case will additionally do α- and β-detection for careful use as a surface contamination spot meter.
According to the KitHub page <ref>https://kithub.cc/safecast-researchers/ - KitHub - Agencies Using Safecast Devices</ref> Safecast devices are also used by the following institutions: * [[International Atomic Energy Agency]] ([[IAEA]]) * Institute for Radiological Protection and Nuclear Safety / [[Institut de radioprotection et de sûreté nucléaire]] ([[IRSN]]), France * [[Natural Resources Defense Council]] (NRDC), United States * Czech National Radiation Protection Institute / [http://www.suro.cz/en Státní ústav radiační ochrany] (SÚRO), [[Czech Republic]]
Slovenian [[NGO]] [http://irnas.eu/ IRNAS] - Institute for development of advanced applied systems Rače / Inštitut za razvoj naprednih aplikativnih sistemov Rače performs monitoring in Slovenia <ref>http://irnas.eu/other%20projects/2015/06/07/safecast-slovenia - Radiation monitoring of Slovenia with Safecast</ref> with their one bGeigie
